Corporal Spinelli was able to contact the property manager and through consent of

Sergeant Harrison (#2799), Corporal Spinelli, Deputy Carey, and Deputy Koble (#4270)
were inside the residence in the bedroom. For
statement, see Deputy Koble's attached report.
Deputies entered the residence to detain Sunny. Sunny was inside the residence in the bedroom with
clung to his right hip. Deputies gave Sunny commands to surrender. Sunny refused to comply with
commands and began to resist deputies all while
was by his side, unnecessarily placing
into potential danger. A use of force ensued, and deputies were able to successfully detain Sunny. (Refer
to Corporal Spinelli and Deputy Carey's use of force report for further details). Deputy Carey sustained a
minor abrasion and swelling to his right hand, along with a complaint of pain.
Sunny sustained injuries to his face and right arm during the use of force. Medics were called to the
location to assess Sunny's injuries. While waiting for medics, I performed a search of Sunny's person
incident to arrest. Inside Sunny's left front pocket, I located a small baggy of a white powdery substance
and a separate small baggy containing a brown tar-like substance. I collected both baggies as evidence.
Sunny had no weapons or any other paraphernalia on his person.
AMR #254 arrived on scene and transported Sunny to Sharp Memorial Hospital. Corporal McCarthy
(#0301) rode in the ambulance with Sunny and remained with him at the hospital. At the hospital, it was
determined Sunny sustained a fractured right arm during the use of force. The Division of Inspectional
Services (DIS) was notified and responded to the incident.
Corporal Mejia, Corporal Spinelli, Deputy Carey, Deputy Koble, and I returned to apartment #15 to
search for further contraband and firearms. A search of the residence yielded negative results. Deputies
consent to search the vehicle. Deputy Koble performed a search of the vehicle which yielded negative
I contacted Judge Alejandro Morales who granted the EPO which is set to expire on 04/06/2024 and lists
as protected persons and Sunny as the restrained person. I provided
with a copy of the EPO, explaining to her what it entails and the process on how to extend it if needed. I
with a domestic violence resource guide with the assigned case number.
I went to Sharp Memorial Hospital and met with Sunny. I read Sunny the Miranda Admonishment
verbatim utilizing my department issued Deputy's notebook. Sunny understood his rights and was willing
to provide a statement. Sunny provided the following summarized statement. For the full statement, refer
to my body worn camera footage.

After Deputy Carey was able to take down Estrada onto the bed, I grabbed his head and pinned it against the bed. I grabbed
his left wrist and also pinned it against the bed while we attempted to position Estrada onto his back to be safely handcuffed.
Estrada started pulling his arms away and continued to try to reach into his pockets. Fearing Estrada may have a firearm or
other deadly weapon, I continued to pull Estrada's arms away from his body. Due to the small space where we were pinned in
between the bed and the wall, and Estrada's refusal to comply, it was difficult to position Estrada onto his stomach to be
handcuffed. I feared that if Estrada was not handcuffed, he could injure myself or others. I delivered two closed fist strikes to
Estrada's face to try to gain compliance. Estrada began to yell in pain, and we were able to safely detain him in handcuffs
after approximately a minute. My initial force was not effective, causing additional force to be used. My strikes to Estrada's
face caused swelling to his facial area. Estrada was transported to Sharp Memorial for treatment, where it was later
determined he sustained a broken arm during the use of force. No Deputies were injured due to my use of force. Had I not
used force, Estrada could have continued to resist Deputy Carey and caused serious bodily injury to myself or others.

On 3/30/2024, at approximately 1150 hours, | responded to a radio call for a domestic violence incident at 8914 Troy Street
| arrived at the above listed address as deputies had already established a perimeter around the residence and had been
attempting to call Estrada out of the residence. Estrada refused to comply with instruction and would not communicate with
deputies or come out of the residence.
Deputies obtained a key from the property manager to access the apartment where Estrada was believed to be hiding.
Deputies made announcements into the apartment for Estrada to come out with his hands in the air holding nothing in his
hands. After making several announcements into the residence and receiving no reply deputies entered the residence. After
entering the residence deputies discovered the apartment was unoccupied and Estrada had left the scene with his (QE
J) Deputies located a loaded AR-15 rifle magazine on the kitchen floor of the apartment. Based on this finding |
believed Estrada had access to firearms and had possibly left the residence with a firearm.
After speaking with the victim, (QE) deputies learned Estrada will often leave QJQ@) in the care of (ED
Oy (b)(6)(A) Deputies arrived (QE) and contacted @@G) Wie
informed deputies Estrada was hiding in the bedroom of the residence.
Based on Estrada's previous criminal history, his felonious domestic assault on (EJ. and having found to be in
possession of a loaded magazine, | believed Estrada posed a significant threat to the safety of myself and my partners on
scene . | also believed Estrada may be in possession of a firearm and would use the weapon against deputies inflicting great
bodily injury or death. | drew my department issued Glock 17 9mm and pointed it at the door of the bedroom. | began
knocking on the door and called out Estrada's name. | intended to announce myself as a deputy sheriff and begin giving

NetRMS_CASDOR rtf v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: April 3, 2024 - 1:44 PM
verbal commands however when I knocked on the door it unintentionally swung open. When the door opened, I saw Estrada
standing in the bedroom with both hands-on
shoulder as he stood behind him.
I pointed my Glock 17 9mm at Estrada and began giving verbal commands for him to put his hands in the air. Estrada refused
to comply and ignored my commands. I feared Estrada may attempt to use
as a barrier to prevent deputies from
at risk for great bodily injury. Additionally, I was unsure if Estrada was in possession of any
weapons. I believed the safest option to gain control over the situation was to immediately intervene and physically detain
Estrada in handcuffs while my partners maintained lethal coverage.
I holstered my department issued Glock 19 9mm and approached Estrada. I grasped Estrada by both his left and right wrists
and began placing his arms in a position to be handcuffed. Estrada began pulling away from my grasp to escape detention. I
instructed Estrada to ""stop moving, stop reaching"" and he refused to comply. Estrada was given numerous commands to stop
resisting and he replied, ""nah this is bullshit"". I feared if I did not immediately detain Estrada the situation would violently
escalate. I grasped Estrada by the right arm and pulled him down onto the bed. Estrada continued to resist and pull away from
my grasp as I made numerous attempts to pull his arms behind his back. Estrada continued to push my hands away from him
to prevent me from gaining control. Estrada began curling his body in a fetal position while placing his hands under his torso
I feared Estrada was reaching for a weapon to inflict serious injury and prevent me from detaining him in handcuffs. I delivered
three closed fist strikes impacting Estrada in the face as he continued to resist deputies.  I pulled Estrada's right arm behind
his back and Deputy Spinelli pulled Estrada's left arm behind his back (See Deputy Spinelli's Officer's Report). As I was
pulling Estrada to the ground, Deputy Spinelli and I fell from the bed and onto the floor. The action of falling from the bed to
the floor while Estrada's arm was behind his back caused my entire body weight to collide with Estrada as he hit the ground
which compressed his arm. Estrada began shouting that his arm was hurt but continued to resist by kicking his legs and
flailing his body. I delivered two closed fist strikes impacting Estrada in the face.
Estrada stopped resisting and I rolled him onto his stomach in a prone position. I straddled Estrada's torso in a mounted
position. I pulled Estrada's right and left arm behind his back and secured him in handcuffs. Deputy Spinelli and I assisted
Estrada to a standing position and escorted him out of the residence.
San Miguel Fire Department Paramedics arrived on scene and transported Estrada to Sharp Memorial Hospital for further
treatment. Hospital staff determined Estrada sustained a fracture on his right arm as a result of the of force. I sustained pain,
swelling and an abrasion on my right hand as a result of the use of force.
The force I used was effective and necessary to detain Estrada as he displayed escalating assaultive behavior and continued
to resist deputies. Had I not used force Estrada would have continued to resist possibly injuring a deputy on scene and
Body worn camera was used during this investigation. This concludes my involvement in the investigation.

On 02/24/2024, Incarcerated Person (IP) Maradiaga, Jose (BN 24707521) assaulted and resisted a
lawful order given to him by Deputy Valenzuela #0641 while inside the elevator of the San Diego Central
Jail (SDCJ). Deputies had to use force to bring him under control. IP Maradiaga was medically assessed
by Nurse (GG x. Deputy Valenzuela was sent to Concentra Urgent Care for soreness to the
face region, soreness to the right pinky finger, and abrasion on both knees and his upper left shoulder
area sustained during the use of force. CCTV footage, photos, and Body Worn Camera (BWC) footage
are available. Deputy Valenzuela does desire prosecution for 69 PC (A) Obstruct/ Resist Executive
Officer with Serious Injury and 243 PC (C)(2) Battery On a Peace Or Police Officer.

use of force involving a deputy and an IP inside the elevator on the 2nd Floor. | immediately ran to the

NetRMS_CASDCRrtf v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: March 5, 2024 - 3:13 PM
Maradiaga, Jose (BN 24707521) is currently in custody for
Upon arrival to the 2nd Floor elevator well, I observed Deputy Valenzuela, Deputy Ordonez #2545,
Deputy McAnany #4060, and Corporal Uson #3452 physically struggling with an incarcerated person
later identified as Maradiaga, Jose (BN24707521) on the floor of Elevator 3.  It appeared each deputy
was trying to gain control of Maradiaga as he physically thrashing his body around causing the deputies
to use controlling force. I was later informed that Deputy Valenzuela had to utilize closed fist strikes to
gain compliance as well as in self defense. For more information, please reference Deputy Valenzuela,
Deputy Ordonez, Corporal Uson, and Deputy McAnany's Officer Reports.
As I arrived and assessed where I could assist, Corporal Wanzer also arrived on scene and instructed
the deputies involved to remove Maradiaga from the elevator.  In response, I grabbed Maradiaga's right
arm with both of my hands and, with a pulling motion, pulled Maradiaga out of the elevator with the
assistance of the other involved deputies.
Once out of Elevator #3 and in the incarcerated person well on his stomach, Maradiaga continued to
resist by thrashing about and tensing his body. While maintaining grip on Maradiaga's right arm, Corporal
Wanzer took control of Maradiaga's right arm, allowing me to apply downward pressure on Maradiaga's
upper back region to suppress his efforts of thrashing about. Corporal Wanzer then guided Maradiaga's
right hand towards me, allowing me to place both of his hands in handcuffs because Maradiaga's left
hand was now also behind his back. With Maradiaga now in handcuffs, another deputy was able to
secure Maradiaga in leg chains. Had I not used force, we would not have been able to place Maradiaga
Once Maradiaga was placed into handcuffs and leg chains, deputies lifted him onto the gurney, and was
secured to the gurney via the affixed gurney straps.  Maradiaga was then escorted to the 2nd Floor Strip
Search room and medically evaluated by Nurse
Maradiaga's injuries and cleared him to be housed.  Deputy Getnet #4549 took photos of all visible
Sgt. Applebaum #3075 took photos of Deputy Valenzuela's visible injuries before Deputy Valenzuela
went to the hospital for treatment. Deputy Crist #3604 from Classification arrived on scene shortly after
and interviewed Maradiaga and determined he would be housed on the 5th Floor with a classification
code of level 5. Deputy Crist also informed me that Maradiaga would now be dressed in Dayglow Green
Clothing to indicate his assaultive status.
Once Maradiaga was done being medically and mentally assessed, he was removed from the gurney.
Due to the previous use of force and assaultive behavior, Maradiaga remained in leg chains and
handcuffs as I utilized sheers to remove his clothing.  Maradiaga was placed into Dayglow Green Jail
Clothing as an indication of his assaultive behavior.  Maradiaga was then secured back onto the gurney
Once on the 5th Floor, Maradiaga was removed from the gurney and placed on the floor of 5D
Corporal Wanzer, Deputy McAnany, Deputy Ordonez, Deputy Delgado, and I entered the cell with
Maradiaga to safely remove his restraints. As I removed the handcuffs from Maradiaga's left wrist,
Corporal Wanzer attempted to guide Maradiaga's left hand under his stomach and ordered him not to
move. Deputy Delgado then entered the cell to articulate the orders in Spanish to help Maradiaga
understand the orders better. However, despite the instructions given to Maradiaga, he disobeyed the
order and attempted to free his hand from under his stomach. To suppress Maradiaga's efforts of
resistance, I applied downward pressure with both hands to Maradiaga's upper back region. My force
was effective as Corporal Wanzer was able to secure Maradiaga's left hand under his stomach.
Maradiaga's handcuffs and leg chains were removed, and all parties safely exited the cell without further
incident. Had I not pushed Maradiaga's upper back, we would not have been able to exit the cell safely.
In total, Maradiaga was on the gurney for approximately 30 minutes.  Sgt. Cardoza #3223 was the
designated safety officer for the duration of the gurney escort.
On 02/25/2024, I went to the 5th Floor and had Deputy Delgado #0186 translate and read Maradiaga's
Miranda Rights verbatim from a deputy-issued notebook.  Maradiaga responded yes to question number
one and yes to question number two.  Deputy Delgado asked Maradiaga what happened in the elevator,
and he essentially said the following.
When asked what happened, Maradiaga essentially said he was arguing with the Deputy and that he
was attacked and didn't do anything wrong.  Deputy Delgado asked him if he had anything relevant to the
situation he wanted to tell me, but Maradiaga said no. Based on Maradiaga having no other statements
to add, I ended my conversation with Maradiaga.
On 2/25/2024, I was informed that Deputy Valenzuela sustained abrasions to both knees, redness to his
face, swelling on his right pinky finger, and a scratch to his left shoulder region. I also called the 3rd Floor
Clinics area. I was informed by Nurse Practitioner
that Maradiaga sustained a deviated nasal
septum and bruising to his left eye and went to the hospital for treatment. Maradiaga returned from the
hospital and was placed back in 5D
. Based on the above information, Maradiaga will be charged with
PC 69 (A) Obstruct/ Resist Executive Officer With Serious Injury and PC 243 (C)(2) Battery On a Peace
Relevant body-worn camera footage, CCTV footage, and photos will be uploaded and attached to this
case. I transferred the CCTV and photos onto a CD and secured it in a manila envelope. The evidence
CD was then secured into SDCJ Evidence Locker #33.

there to ask him questions about the incident that occurred the day before. Maradiaga told me he remembered the incident. |
asked him to tell me what happened. He began saying things about being taken to a room. | asked him if he remembered the
incident that occurred in the elevator. Maradiaga told me he remembered being taken to another location. | asked him if he
did not want to be taken to another location. Maradiaga told me he did not know where he was being taken and asked where
he was going. | asked Maradiaga if that was the reason why he resisted while being escorted in the elevator. Maradiaga told
me that was not the reason, and he did nothing.
| asked Maradiaga if he could tell why he was taken to the floor while in the elevator. He said he disrespected the deputy
escorting him because he did not explain things right to him. | asked Maradiaga to tell me if he hit the deputy and if he was hit

because he was hit. Maradiaga told me he did not do anything. He told me his shirt was cut off, and then he was taken

deputies could not control it. | was concerned that he might strike or grab other deputies with the hand as they attempted to

small of his back so that he could be handcuffed. My initial force was ineffective, and he continued to struggle with his hands
Cpl. Wanzer #3363 suggested that Maradiaga be moved from the confines of the elevator towards the 2nd Floor elevator well
so that additional deputies could assist in controlling him. He was pulled out of the elevator by other deputies. | let go of his
right wrist when Cpl. Wanzer took control of the wrist. Maradiaga was prone on the elevator well floor at this time.
| noticed that other deputies were controlling Maradiaga's hands/wrists, but he was not handcuffed because he was resisting.

On 2/24/2024, at about 1545 hours, | was assigned to the Final / Book and Release Deputy position at the San Diego Central
Jail (SDCJ) when | heard on the facility radio of a use of force occurring in elevator #3 on the 2nd Floor.
| approached the elevator and saw Deputies Valenzuela #0641 and Ordonez #2545 on the elevator floor, attempting to gain
control of a person later identified as Jose Maradiaga BN24707521. | entered the elevator and tried to gain control of
Maradiaga's upper right torso and head. Deputy Valenzuela moved to where | was attempting to gain access to control
Maradiaga, so | assessed and saw that Maradiaga's legs were not secured and moved to that area.
| moved around Deputy Valenzuela and attempted to gain control of Maradiaga's right leg. As | reached for his right leg, he
pulled his legs up towards his torso. Deputy Getnet #4549 arrived and assisted in controlling Maradiaga. | reached up and
pulled Maradiaga's right foot with my right hand. This force was effective as it prevented Maradiaga from kicking. He would
have kicked one of us if | had not pulled his leg.
Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By
$H3452 - USON, DAVID 142 | SDCJ - San Diego Central Jail $H3223 - CARDOZA, CESAR

I heard Corporal Wanzer #3363 direct us to move Maradiaga from the elevator to the 2nd Floor elevator staging area so that
additional deputies could assist in controlling him.  I told Deputy Getnet to grab Maradiaga's right leg to assist in moving him
out of the elevator. I released Maradiaga's right foot as he was moved out of the elevator.

On 2/24/2024, at approximately 1545 hours, | was assigned to the Final Release Deputy position at the San Diego Central Jail
(SDCJ) when releasing Incarcerated Persons (IP) on the release list.
While releasing IPs on the 2nd Floor, | heard over the radio that there was a use of force on elevator three on the 2nd Floor. |
responded toward elevator three and observed IP Maradiaga, Jose BN24707521, inside the elevator and on the floor, actively
resisting deputies by tensing his hands and legs and attempting to strike them. Additionally, he was refusing to give them his
hands for handcuffing. The deputies were Deputy Weldon #4534, Deputy Ordonez #2545, Deputy McAnany #4060, and
Corporal Uson #3452. As | entered the elevator, | observed that IP Maradiaga’s legs were kicking toward deputies, trying to
| controlled his legs by initially grabbing them with both hands, then helped move IP Maradiaga outside the elevator by picking
him up from his legs with the other deputies and putting him outside the elevator. Once outside the elevator, | used both
hands to cross his legs and apply downward pressure. | did this to prevent him from being able to kick at us and control his
legs. If | had not used downward pressure, he would have had the ability to cause injury to one of us. | applied downward
pressure for approximately 60 seconds. | was then handed leg restraints by Deputy Delgado #0186.
Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By
SH4549 - GETNET, NAHOM 142 | SDCJ - San Diego Central Jail $H3223 - CARDOZA, CESAR
NetRMS_CASDOR rtf v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: March 5, 2024 - 3:15 PM
Maradiaga was handcuffed, and I applied the leg restraints on him and continued controlling his legs until we lifted him and
placed him on a gurney. The safety officer was Sergeant Cardoza #3223. IP Maradiaga was transported from the IP elevator
well on the 2nd Floor to the search room via gurney.
In the Search room, Maradiaga was medically evaluated for his minor abrasions to the left eye by Nurse
IP Maradiaga was then removed from the gurney. I helped by supporting his legs with my hands and we
placed him prone on the floor. We changed his clothing into jail-issued green clothing. I assisted by removing his pants and
placing jail-issued green pants on him. I then assisted in placing Maradiaga back onto the gurney by supporting his legs with
my hands. We escorted him to the 5th Floor via gurney.  We arrived to cell
in Module D. Deputies removed him from the
gurney, and I moved the gurney out of the way.
I had no further contact with IP Maradiaga.

On 02/24/2024 at approximately 1545 hours, | was assigned to the Central Command Center (CCC) at the San Diego Central
Jail (SDCJ). | was assisting the 2nd Floor deputies with normal operations.
| heard over my facility radio that a ""use of force"" was in progress inside elevator #3 on the 2nd Floor.
| arrived at the 2nd Floor elevator well and witnessed multiple deputies attempting to gain control of an incarcerated person,
later identified as Maradiaga, Jose (24707521). Maradiaga was actively fighting by kicking his legs and swinging his fists. |
instructed the deputies to remove Maradiaga from the elevator into the elevator well to gain control of him better.
| noticed Maradiaga's right hand was not under control and was swinging his fist around. | gained control of Maradiaga's right
arm with both hands and placed his right arm in a shoulder pin technique. This force was effective in stopping Maradiaga from
thrashing his body around. | then placed Maradiaga's right arm behind his back with my hands. Other deputies secured
Maradiaga's wrists in handcuffs. Maradiaga relaxed his body and stopped thrashing around. Had | not pinned Maradiaga's
shoulder and placed his arm behind him, we would not have been able to secure him in restraints.
Maradiaga was assisted onto a medical gurney and escorted to the 2nd Floor Strip Room. Maradiaga was medically
evaluated and cleared to continue the booking process. Maradiaga was (Tare)
who cleared Maradiaga to also continue the booking process. Maradiaga's clothes were cut off and
removed with no incident. Maradiaga was given jail-issued ""day-glo"" green clothing.
Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By
SH3363 - WANZER, ANDRE 142 | SDCJ - San Diego Central Jail $H3223 - CARDOZA, CESAR
NetRMS_CASDOR rtf v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: March 5, 2024 - 3:15 PM
Maradiaga was escorted to the 5th Floor Module D Cell
via a medical gurney. Maradiaga was assisted off the medical
gurney and placed in the prone position inside the cell. Maradiaga was given multiple commands to place his hands under his
stomach when the handcuffs were removed. Once the handcuffs were removed, Maradiaga attempted to stand up. I placed
my left hand on the left side of Maradiaga's head and applied downward pressure. This force effectively prevented Maradiaga
from standing up and possibly assaulting one of us. Had I not controlled his head, Maradiaga could have stood back up.
I commanded Maradiaga to remain on the floor until the cell door was secured. All deputies exited the cell with no incident.
I had no further contact with Maradiaga.

On 02/24/2024, at approximately 1545 hours, | was assigned to the 2nd Floor CNIT Deputy position at the San Diego Central
Jail (SDCJ) when | was awaiting the elevator to arrive on the 2nd Floor.
Deputy Valenzuela #0641 was escorting IP Maradiaga, Jose BN 24707521 to the 2nd Floor to continue the booking process
via the elevator. As the elevator arrived on the 2nd Floor, | observed Deputy Valenzuela in a physical altercation with IP
Maradiaga. | saw Maradiaga actively punching Deputy Valenzuela and | immediately responded, striking Maradiaga
approximately 12 times with my left closed fist to his face. | continued to strike Maradiaga because he was actively resisting
us and punching at Deputy Valenzuela. | attempted to gain control of his left arm. | used both hands to bring Maradiaga's arm
towards his back. | gave Maradiaga verbal commands, instructing him to give me his hands. This force was not successful,
and additional force was needed. To gain control of Maradiaga, deputies on scene pulled him out of the elevator and into the
In the elevator well, | placed Maradiaga's left arm onto his back with my hands. Maradiaga actively resisted me by flexing his
arm. | applied a wrist flex on his left wrist with my hands for approximately six seconds and applied downward pressure on
Maradiaga's left arm to keep it under control until handcuffs could be applied. Maradiaga flexed his left arm, and | delivered
two strikes with my left knee to Maradiaga's left side of his body. Handcuffs were subsequently applied to Maradiaga. | used
force to control Maradiaga's arms and secure him in handcuffs. Had | not used force, Maradiaga could have caused great

bodily injury to my partners or me trying to control him.  I assisted Maradiaga onto a medical gurney by lifting his left shoulder.
Once he was secured onto the gurney, we escorted him to the 2nd Floor Strip Search Room, where he received a medical
and a Detentions Safety Program evaluation. Maradiaga was cleared for housing.
We escorted Maradiaga to the 5th Floor D Module for housing. Maradiaga was to be placed into cell
escorted to the cell via gurney. I assisted Maradiaga off the gurney and onto the cell floor by supporting the feet and ankles
with my hands. Maradiaga was placed in a prone position. As I attempted to remove the leg chains, Maradiaga began
thrashing his legs around. I applied downward pressure on Maradiaga's feet with both of my hands. I applied pressure for
approximately 10 seconds. Maradiaga stopped resisting, and the leg chain was removed. Once the leg chains were removed,
Maradiaga thrashed his legs. I continued applying downward pressure with my hands until Deputy Weldon #4534 took control
of the legs. I exited the cell, followed by my partners, and the door was secured.
I had no further contact with Maradiaga.

On 02/24/2024, | was assigned to the Contraband and Narcotics Interdiction Team (CNIT) Intake Deputy position at the San
Diego Central Jail (SDCJ) when | contacted Incarcerated Person (IP) Maradiaga, Jose BN 24707521.
At approximately 1543 hours, | contacted Maradiaga in Transfer Holding #10 on the 1st Floor of SDCJ. Maradiaga needed to
be escorted to the 2nd Floor to continue the booking process. In my prior contacts with Maradiaga during safety checks and
meal servings, Maradiaga was compliant with my instructions. | opened the cell door slightly to evaluate Maradiaga's
compliance. Maradiaga appeared compliant, and | escorted him out of the cell. To maintain control of Maradiaga, | grabbed
hold of Maradiaga's arm and guided him to the 1st Floor IP elevator well.
At approximately 1545 hours, | escorted Maradiaga into Elevator #3. Once inside the elevator, Maradiaga immediately
attempted to turn his body towards me. To prevent Maradiaga from facing me, | pushed Maradiaga into the elevator wall using
both hands on his upper back and arm. The force was ineffective as Maradiaga continued to push himself off the wall and
face me. | gave Maradiaga numerous commands to ""stop,"" which he refused. After Maradiaga continued not to follow my
instructions and attempted to face me, | determined | would place him in handcuffs to control him.
| ordered Maradiaga to put his hands behind his back, but he refused. As | grabbed Maradiaga’'s right arm and attempted to
pull it behind his back, Maradiaga suddenly cocked his right elbow back in my direction to strike me. Simultaneously,
Maradiaga turned his body toward me. Due to Maradiaga's assaultive behavior, utilizing both of my hands to Maradiaga's
upper body, | pulled him and took him to the floor of the elevator.

On 2/23/2024, at 1507 hours, Officer J. Hernandez and I were in full police uniform driving a marked
police vehicle when we responded to a radio call of an occupied stolen 1995 Chevrolet Silverado pickup
at Meade Ave. and Van Dyke Ave. San Diego.  The victim's
, spotted the pickup truck driving in the area and called 911.
4500 40th Street, San Diego, between 1600 hours on 2/18/2024 and 1130 hours on 2/20/2024.
did not give anyone permission to take or drive his vehicle.  The estimated value of the vehicle
is $8,000.  There were no witnesses to the crime and no one was is in custody.
Officer Hernandez and I arrived in the area and observed the pickup truck with a male driver and female
passenger traveling west bound at 4200 Meade Ave.  We initiated a traffic stop using our emergency
lights and sirens.  The pickup truck failed to yield and began speeding up.  The pickup turned north on
42nd St then made a left (west) turn onto Monroe Ave failing to make a full and complete stop at the
posted stop sign in violation of 22450 CVC-Failure to stop at a stop sign.  The vehicle then turned south
onto Marlborough Ave St then west onto Meade Ave again failing to make a full and complete stop at the
posted stop sign in violation of 22450 CVC.  The pickup continued on Meade Ave,  turned south on 41st
St, then west on El Cajon Blvd once again violating of 22450 CVC.
The pickup truck continued west on El Cajon Boulevard then turned north onto the 15 freeway.  Average
speeds were approximately 30 mph due to heavy traffic.  We then merged onto the 8 east freeway. The
pickup exited Fairmont Ave but began driving north in the south bound lanes in violation of 21651(B)
CVC-Driving the wrong way.  We continued to follow the pickup in the north bound lanes.  The pickup
then entered the 8 west on-ramp and we continued to follow it west on the 8 freeway.  Speeds averaged
around 85 mph due to decreased traffic.  We continued the pursuit west on the 8 freeway until Morena
Blvd exit.  The pickup truck exited Moreno Blvd heading north.  Officer Colvin #1512 deployed spike
sticks at the Moreno Blvd ramp puncturing all four tires of the pickup truck.  See Officer Colvin's report for
The pickup continued north on Moreno Blvd then turned west on Savannah Street which is a dead end.
As the pickup truck came to a stop, the male driver, later identified by his California driver's license as
Evan Baltsas, attempted to flee on foot west up an embankment with a black backpack towards Tecolote
Rd.  The female passenger, later identified by her California driver's license as
truck and was detained and handcuffed by officers.
SDPD Canine Officers were able to detain Baltsas before he could make it up the embankment as
myself and other officer's approached Baltsas.  See SDPD Canine Officer's reports for further
information.  I pointed my department approved handgun at Baltsas as I approached him.  Baltsas did
not resist further and was handcuffed and taken back to our patrol vehicle.
A record check of Baltsas showed he had two active felony warrants.
was issued on 10/23/2023 for 459 PC by Judge L. Parsky of the San Diego
was issued on 11/02/2023 for 11379 HS by Judge R. Shelton with a $75000 bail
During a search of Baltsas's black backpack I discovered a medium vacuum-sealed plastic bag with a
white crystalline substance inside the smaller outer pouch.  In the main pouch of the backpack, I
discovered a small plastic baggie of a white crystalline substance.  Based on my training and experience
I believed it to be a controlled substance.
Also in the main compartment of his backpack contained a black extendable baton.  During a search of
the pickup truck, I located two shaved keys.  One was found on the center console and the other below
the center console on the carpet.  Both shaved keys were able to start the stolen pickup.
Pictures of the truck, white crystalline substance, baton and the shaved keys were uploaded to
Evidence.Com via the Axon Capture application.

On 12-11-2023 | was assigned to the Movement Sergeant Position at the San Diego Central Jail (SDCJ), when | obtained a
statement from Incarcerated individual Dryer, Gino BN23749321.
At approximately 1030 hours, | spoke with Dryer in a holding cell on the 8th floor regarding a use of force that occurred
several days prior. Prior to entering the holding cell, | activated my department issued body worn camera to record our
conversation. While in the holding cell | advised Dryer | was there to speak with him regarding a use of force that that took
place several days ago. Dryer immediately stated, ""| may have been disrespectful towards the deputies because | felt | was at
the end of my rope."" Dryer went on to state how he felt he keeps getting arrested for no apparent reason. Dryer also stated
that while in the search room he was instructed to bend over at the waist. Dryer stated at no point did he tell the deputies he
wasn't going to listen to their instructions. Dryer went on to state that a deputy approached him and asked him to bend at the
waist and when he didn't, the deputy just punched him. Dryer then began to talk about other issues that he had during our
conversation such as his property being misplaced, the same cops contacting him while he's on the streets, and how he
doesn't feel safe around law enforcement. | then ended my conversation with Dryer.
| had no further contact with Dryer.

On 12/4/23, | was assigned at the Search Deputy position on the Second Floor of the San Diego Central Jail (SDCJ).
At approximately 0710 hours, Deputy Harter #4907 and | were notified by SDCJ Nurse (aye that she had completed
her medical assessment on incarcerated person Gino Dryer BN 23749321 and that he was cleared to continue the booking
Deputy Harter and | escorted Dryer inside the search room on the Second Floor of SDCJ with the intention to dress him out in
jail clothing and perform a visual cavity search. Dryer refused to follow instructions when asked to separate his buttocks with
his hands so that we could perform a visual cavity search. Dryer only slapped his buttocks with his hands when we repeated
our instructions. We ordered Dryer to face the wall and put his hands behind his back for handcuffing. Dryer did not comply
and displayed assaultive behavior by using his right hand to swat Deputy Harter's hand away when he attempted to handcuff
Deputy Harter initiated a takedown by pulling Dryer to the floor. Dryer ended up on his right side on the floor while | was near
his head in a kneeling position with his back facing me. | used my left and right fists to strike Dryer in the face and the rear of
Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By
$H3627 - CHEN, ANDY 142 | SDCJ - San Diego Central Jail SH7609 - NESMITH, PATRICK
NetRMS_CASDOR. rif v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: January 20, 2024 - 1:07 PM
his head for a total of six times. I did this in order to deter further assaultive behavior by Dryer. If I had not used this force,
Dryer may have continued his assaultive behavior and possibly injured Deputy Harter. The use of force was unsuccessful, as
Dryer began to thrash his arms.
Dryer began to thrash his arms once he was on the floor, which I interpreted as an assaultive gesture. Dryer had also grabbed
onto Deputy Harter's equipment belt with his left hand and appeared to be reaching for Deputy Harter with his right. I delivered
five hammer fists to Dryer's upper shoulder and back with my left and right hands and one strike to the back of his head. I did
this in order to get Dryer to release his grasp on Deputy Harter's equipment belt. If I had not used this force, Dryer may have
been able to take equipment from Deputy Harter's belt and use it against us. The use of force was successful, as the strikes
caused Dryer to release Deputy Harter's belt.
I placed my right hand on Dryer's head and applied downward pressure for approximately one minute to pin it to the floor. I did
this in order to gain control of Dryer so that he could be restrained in a prone position and placed in handcuffs and leg
restraints.  If I had not used this force, Dryer would have continued to remain uncontrolled in an inefficient position for
handcuffing. The use of force was not successful, as Dryer remained on his right side while continuing to refuse to place his
Dryer displayed assaultive behavior by attempting to kick Deputy Harter when he attempted to restrain his legs. Dryer also
raised his left arm towards me in what I interpreted as an attempt to grab me.  I used my left fist to strike Dryer in the face
three times. Dryer also grabbed my right hand with his right arm. I did this to deter Dryer from attempting to kick Deputy Harter
and stop him from grabbing me. If I had not used this force, Dryer may have attempted to kick Deputy Harter again or grab
me. The use of force was successful, as Dryer did not attempt to continue to kick Deputy Harter and let go of my right hand.
Dryer refused to follow instructions to place his left arm behind his back. I used my left hand to pull Dryer's left hand away
from his body and behind his back. I did this so that Dryer could be handcuffed. If I had not used this force, Dryer would have
remained uncontrolled. The use of force was successful, as it allowed deputies to place handcuffs on Dryer's left wrist.
Dryer refused to follow instructions to place his right arm behind his back. I used my left hand to pull Dryer's right hand away
from his body and behind his back. I did this so that Dryer could be handcuffed. If I had not used this force, Dryer would have
remained uncontrolled. The use of force was successful, as it allowed deputies to place handcuffs on Dryer's right wrist.
Deputies arrived on scene with a gurney. I supported Dryer's left shoulder as he was assisted onto the gurney.
SDCJ Health staff arrived on scene to evaluate Dryer. It was determined that Dryer would need to be transported to the
hospital to treat a wound above his eye.
I escorted Dryer via gurney to the vehicle sallyport on the First Floor of SDCJ with the assistance of other deputies. Dryer was
transported to UCSD Hillcrest without further incident.
I had no further contact with Dryer.

On 12/4/2023, at about 0708 hours, | was working as the Kitchen Deputy at San Diego Central Jail (SDCJ). While on the
second floor | responded to a use of force occurring in the search room. The incarcerated person (IP) was later identified as
IP Dryer was on his right side and was resisting deputies’ attempts to put his hands behind his back. | instructed Dryer to
place his hands behind his back. Dryer was on his right side thrashing his body side to side and refusing to place his hands
behind his back. Cpl. Aguilera #4166 was able to place Dryer's left arm behind his back. Dryer was refusing to put his right
arm behind his back. | instructed Dryer to put his hands behind his back or he would be tazed. Due to Dryer trying to kick
Deputy Harter, | pointed my conducted electrical device (CED) at Dryer and yelled Taser to signify that | was going to deploy. |
pulled the trigger and the CED failed to deploy but did arc. At no time did the CED contact Dryer.
Dyer was rolled onto his stomach and Cpl. Aguilera was able to get Dryer's left arm behind his back. Deputy Sanders #6869
placed handcuffs on Dryer's wrist. Leg chains were applied to Dryer's ankles.

On 12/04/2023, | was working the Intake Deputy Position at the San Diego Central Jail. | was involved in a use of force with
At approximately 0708 hours, | heard yelling coming from the Search Room on the Second Floor. | ran into the Search Room
and saw Corporal Chen (3627) and Deputy Harter (4907) attempting to place Dryer on his stomach. Dryer was violently
thrashing his body from side to side, refusing to follow instructions and tucking his arms into his stomach area. Dryer
attempted to prevent us from turning him onto his stomach to apply handcuffs. | immediately assisted Corporal Chen and
Deputy Harter by getting a hold of Dryer's left arm. | pushed Dryer onto his stomach with my right hand and simultaneously
pulled Dryer's left arm with my left hand then placed his left arm behind his back. | then grabbed a hold of Dryer's right arm
and pulled it out from underneath his stomach and placed it against his back. Dryer's wrists were secured in handcuffs, and he
stopped resisting. The force used was effective as | was able to assist in placing Dryer on his stomach and secure his wrists
in handcuffs. If | had not used force on Dryer, Dryer could have stood up and continued to fight the other deputies.
Once we all had control of Dryer, Dryer was assisted on a medical gurney and medically evaluated.
It was determined that Dryer would need further medical treatment at a hospital.
Dryer was escorted to the first-floor vehicle sally port and was transferred to the ambulance gurney. Dryer was transported to
UCSD Hillcrest Medical Center via ambulance. No additional force was used.
| had no further contact with Dryer.
BWC captured a portion of this incident.

Alcohol manufactured by persons who are incarcerated is commonly referred to as ""pruno"" in the
jail/prison system.  Although there are numerous ways of manufacturing ""pruno"" in jail, the most common
procedure is for incarcerated persons to mix fruit, sugar, and bread in a plastic bag with warm water,
allowing the contents to ferment for a period of time.  All ingredients in the bag eventually develop
alcohol content which produces side effects similar to those of traditional alcoholic beverages.
At approximately 1618 hours, I completed my safety check of the housing unit, and returned to A Module
to investigate Cell #109 which emitted the odor of what I believed to be ""pruno"" inside. Deputies Juarez
#3055, Trejo #4354, Lozada 3349, and I entered  A Module to conduct a cell search inside Cell #109.
The cell door was opened, and I observed two incarcerated persons (IP), later identified as
and Carlos Ramirez #23741438, standing near the back of the cell. I instructed both IPs
to step outside the cell so we could conduct a search.
was hesitant to follow my instructions, but
ultimately began slowly walking towards me while Ramirez remained in the back of the cell. While
standing in the threshold of the cell door, I observed a clear plastic bag containing a red liquid substance
sitting in the sink which I believed to be ""pruno"" (IP manufactured alcohol). As
he quickly turned and grabbed the ""pruno"" and began dumping it in the cell toilet. To prevent
further destroying evidence, I entered the cell and grabbed him by his arms with both of my hands. My
dropped the plastic bag which still contained a small amount of ""pruno""
inside of it. Had I not used force on
he would have been able to destroy evidence  and dispose of
the ""pruno"" before it could be collected. I continued to hold
arms and could feel he tensed up his
arm and attempted to escape my grasp. I attempted to pull
down to the ground, however IP
Ramirez rushed towards me from the back of the cell and struck me in the back, chest, and back of my
head with a closed fist. I observed Deputy Juarez attempting to gain control of Ramirez, but Ramirez
continued his attack and struck Deputy Juarez in the back of his head, knocking his hat off his head (See
I used both hands to push
away from me and turned to assist Deputy Juarez. I immediately felt
what I believed to be a closed fist strike to the right side of my back and could feel my duty belt being
pulled back towards the cell door. I turned back around and observed
and taken down by Deputy Lozada (See Officer's Report by Deputy Lozada). I refocused my attention
towards Ramirez who was still actively fighting Deputy Juarez. Deputy Trejo was now inside the cell, and
I observed him attempting to gain control of Ramirez (See Officer's Report by Deputy Trejo). I observed
Deputy Juarez wrap his arms around Ramirez and pull him down to the ground. Ramirez landed on his
back and immediately began kicking Deputy Juarez and was pulling Deputy Trejo by his exterior vest
simultaneously. To prevent Ramirez from continuing his attack on us and to prevent him from inflicting
further injuries, I knelled beside him and delivered approximately four closed fist strikes to Ramirez'
abdomen. My force was ineffective, and Ramirez continued his attack and struck me in the face with a
closed fist. I gave verbal commands for Ramirez to stop fighting and delivered approximately four knee
strikes to his right thigh. My force was again ineffective, and Ramirez continued kicking his legs at us and
refused to place his hands behind his back. I observed Ramirez kick Deputy Juarez in the stomach and
immediately delivered approximately four additional knee strikes to Ramirez' right thigh. My force was
effective, and Ramirez stopped kicking his legs, but refused to place his hands behind his back. Had I
not used force on Ramirez he would have continued to attack and kick deputies, which could have
resulted in serious injuries. Ramirez remained defiant on the cell floor and would not allow his hands to
be removed from underneath his body so he could be secured in handcuffs.
A radio call for ""Cover Now"" (Deputies need help/11-99) was transmitted over the GBDF Tac 1 channel
and multiple deputies and supervisors from the George Bailey Detention Facility responded to House 1A
at Rock Mountain. Corporal Romo #3261, Deputy Sanchez #4751, and Deputy King #4211 were the first
additional deputies on scene and entered Cell #109 to help gain control of Ramirez (See Officer's
Reports by Corporal Romo, Deputy King & Deputy Sanchez). To gain control and secure Ramirez in
handcuffs, I grabbed Ramirez by his left arm and pulled it out from underneath his stomach. My force
was effective, and Ramirez was no longer able to keep his hands underneath him and allowed Deputy
Juarez to handcuff him. Had I not used force on Ramirez he could have continued to have control of his
hands and punch deputies again. I maintained control of his left arm while Deputy Juarez handcuffed
him. Deputy King was able to secure Ramirez' right arm and Deputy Juarez was able to secure the
handcuff on Ramirez' right wrist. I could hear a gargling sound and observed Ramirez spitting onto the
cell floor. To prevent any of the spit contacting deputies, I placed a spit sock over his head. Additional
deputies arrived on scene and Ramirez was secured in leg chains by Deputy Lake #3304.
Lieutenant Jensen #7052 authorized the use of a gurney to escort Ramirez out of the module. While
supporting Ramirez' left shoulder, I lifted him off the ground and placed him on the gurney in the prone
position. Ramirez was secured with safety straps and escorted out of the module and into the House 1
Entry Hallway to be assessed by RMDF Health Staff. Corporal Kerns #3999 was assigned as the Safety
Officer and monitored Ramirez' wellbeing. While still on the gurney, Ramirez released from the gurney
straps temporarily so he could be placed on his side in a recovery position before being evaluated.
evaluated Ramirez and determined his injuries required further
evaluation and requested he be transported to the hospital via ambulance. Corporal Smith #7074 notified
RMDF Central Control to activate 911. While Ramirez was being evaluated by Nurse
had been escorted out of the module by Deputy Lozada and Deputy Gourley #4421. They

Lieutenant Jensen took photographs of Ramirez and the injuries he sustained for evidence purposes. At
approximately 1700 hours, Ramirez was escorted through RMDF Processing, was placed into AMR #38,
and was transported to the hospital. In total, Ramirez was secured on the gurney for approximately 35
I entered the House 1 Recreation Yard and took photographs of Deputy Juarez and Deputy Trejo and
their injuries for evidence purposes. Deputy Trejo photographed me and my injuries for evidence
purposes as well. I entered A Module and recovered a small amount of ""pruno"" from the plastic bag and
secured it inside a plastic container. I took photographs of the scene and secured the cell door.
I entered the RMDF Evidence Room and copied all photographs and Facility Closed Circuit Television
Footage (CCTV) related to this incident onto a Compact Disc (CD). I retrieved the ""pruno"" and poured a
sample of the liquid into a Nalgene container which contains preservatives to stop the fermentation
process and prevent the liquid from spoiling. The Nalgene bottle was secured and transported to the
GBDF Evidence Refrigerator, pending laboratory testing. Photographs of the ""pruno"" were copied onto a
Compact Disc (CD) and secured in GBDF Evidence Locker #12. The CD containing photographs and
CCTV Footage was processed and secured in GBDF Evidence Locker #12.
On 11/25/2023, at approximately 1200 hours, I contacted Ramirez who had since returned from the
hospital and was housed in Medical Observation Cell
I conducted an interview with Ramirez.
I read Ramirez the Miranda Admonishment verbatim from a department issued Deputy's Notebook. I
asked Ramirez if he understood his rights and he stated he did. I asked Ramirez if he was willing to
speak with me and he replied, ""Yes, I will speak to you.""
I asked Ramirez if he remembered what happened the day prior. He stated  he does and I asked him to
explain what he thought happened. Ramirez responded by saying, ""You guys tell me man, you guys
started it."" I explained to Ramirez  I was attempting to conduct a cell search for ""pruno"" when
attempted to flush it down the toilet.  I went on to tell him I  tried to stop him from dumping
the bag when he (Ramirez) charged towards me and struck me in the head and chest. Ramirez
acknowledged  he did in fact attack me and stated, ""You guys know our rules, I have to get involved if
you are fucking with one of us."" I asked Ramirez if he realized  he punched and kicked multiple deputies
and he stated  he did and stated, ""I had to handle business… it is what it is."" I asked Ramirez if he had
any additional comments or questions and he said, ""No.""
I concluded my interview with Ramirez.
Based on the information above, I placed both incarcerated persons under arrest and B Booked them at
the George Bailey Detention Facility on the following charges:
Carlos Ramirez - 243(C)(2) PC - Battery Against Police Officer w/ Minor Injury (F) (x3), 69 PC -
Obstruct/Resist Executive Officer (F) (x3), 4573.8 PC Poss Drugs/Alcohol in Jail/Prison.

not used force on Ramirez he would have continued to attack and kick deputies, which could have
resulted in serious injuries. Ramirez remained defiant on the cell floor and would not allow his hands to
be removed from underneath his body so he could be secured in handcuffs.
A radio call for ""Cover Now"" (Deputies need help/11-99) was transmitted over the GBDF Tac 1 channel
and multiple deputies and supervisors from the George Bailey Detention Facility responded to House 1A
at Rock Mountain. Corporal Romo #3261, Deputy Sanchez #4751, and Deputy King #4211 were the first
additional deputies on scene and entered Cell #109 to help gain control of Ramirez (See Officer's
Reports by Corporal Romo, Deputy King & Deputy Sanchez). To gain control and secure Ramirez in
handcuffs, I grabbed Ramirez by his left arm and pulled it out from underneath his stomach. My force
was effective, and Ramirez was no longer able to keep his hands underneath him and allowed Deputy
Juarez to handcuff him. Had I not used force on Ramirez he could have continued to have control of his
hands and punch deputies again. I maintained control of his left arm while Deputy Juarez handcuffed
him. Deputy King was able to secure Ramirez' right arm and Deputy Juarez was able to secure the
handcuff on Ramirez' right wrist. I could hear a gargling sound and observed Ramirez spitting onto the
cell floor. To prevent any of the spit contacting deputies, I placed a spit sock over his head. Additional
deputies arrived on scene and Ramirez was secured in leg chains by Deputy Lake #3304.
Lieutenant Jensen #7052 authorized the use of a gurney to escort Ramirez out of the module. While
supporting Ramirez' left shoulder, I lifted him off the ground and placed him on the gurney in the prone
position. Ramirez was secured with safety straps and escorted out of the module and into the House 1
Entry Hallway to be assessed by RMDF Health Staff. Corporal Kerns #3999 was assigned as the Safety
Officer and monitored Ramirez' wellbeing. While still on the gurney, Ramirez released from the gurney
straps temporarily so he could be placed on his side in a recovery position before being evaluated.
evaluated Ramirez and determined his injuries required further
evaluation and requested he be transported to the hospital via ambulance. Corporal Smith #7074 notified
RMDF Central Control to activate 911. While Ramirez was being evaluated by Nurse
had been escorted out of the module by Deputy Lozada and Deputy Gourley #4421. They
to the House 1 Multi-Purpose Room. I entered the House 1 Multi-Purpose Room and
he was under arrest and would be receiving additional charges. I read
Miranda Admonishment verbatim from a department issued Deputy's Notebook. I asked
understood his rights and he stated he did. I asked
if he was willing to speak with me and he
replied, ""About what? I didn't do anything there was nothing in there."" I again asked
to speak with me and he did not give me a response.
for evidence purposes, and he was subsequently transported via Deputy car
to GBDF House 6A, pending disciplinary sanctions.
was also afforded the opportunity to be
evaluated by RMDF Health Staff, but
denied medical attention. He later signed a medical refusal
Lieutenant Jensen took photographs of Ramirez and the injuries he sustained for evidence purposes. At
approximately 1700 hours, Ramirez was escorted through RMDF Processing, was placed into AMR #38,
and was transported to the hospital. In total, Ramirez was secured on the gurney for approximately 35
I entered the House 1 Recreation Yard and took photographs of Deputy Juarez and Deputy Trejo and
their injuries for evidence purposes. Deputy Trejo photographed me and my injuries for evidence
purposes as well. I entered A Module and recovered a small amount of ""pruno"" from the plastic bag and
secured it inside a plastic container. I took photographs of the scene and secured the cell door.
I entered the RMDF Evidence Room and copied all photographs and Facility Closed Circuit Television
Footage (CCTV) related to this incident onto a Compact Disc (CD). I retrieved the ""pruno"" and poured a
sample of the liquid into a Nalgene container which contains preservatives to stop the fermentation
process and prevent the liquid from spoiling. The Nalgene bottle was secured and transported to the
GBDF Evidence Refrigerator, pending laboratory testing. Photographs of the ""pruno"" were copied onto a
Compact Disc (CD) and secured in GBDF Evidence Locker #12. The CD containing photographs and
CCTV Footage was processed and secured in GBDF Evidence Locker #12.
On 11/25/2023, at approximately 1200 hours, I contacted Ramirez who had since returned from the
hospital and was housed in Medical Observation Cell
I conducted an interview with Ramirez.
I read Ramirez the Miranda Admonishment verbatim from a department issued Deputy's Notebook. I
asked Ramirez if he understood his rights and he stated he did. I asked Ramirez if he was willing to
speak with me and he replied, ""Yes, I will speak to you.""
I asked Ramirez if he remembered what happened the day prior. He stated  he does and I asked him to
explain what he thought happened. Ramirez responded by saying, ""You guys tell me man, you guys
started it."" I explained to Ramirez  I was attempting to conduct a cell search for ""pruno"" when
attempted to flush it down the toilet.  I went on to tell him I  tried to stop him from dumping
the bag when he (Ramirez) charged towards me and struck me in the head and chest. Ramirez
acknowledged  he did in fact attack me and stated, ""You guys know our rules, I have to get involved if
you are fucking with one of us."" I asked Ramirez if he realized  he punched and kicked multiple deputies
and he stated  he did and stated, ""I had to handle business… it is what it is."" I asked Ramirez if he had
any additional comments or questions and he said, ""No.""
I concluded my interview with Ramirez.
Based on the information above, I placed both incarcerated persons under arrest and B Booked them at
the George Bailey Detention Facility on the following charges:
Carlos Ramirez - 243(C)(2) PC - Battery Against Police Officer w/ Minor Injury (F) (x3), 69 PC -
Obstruct/Resist Executive Officer (F) (x3), 4573.8 PC Poss Drugs/Alcohol in Jail/Prison.

On 11/24/2023, | was assigned to work the Floor Deputy position at the Rock Mountain Detention Facility (RMDF) when |
contacted incarcerated persons (7/@yEy (b)(6)(B) and Carlos Ramirez# 23741348 inside Cell A109.
At approximately 1620 hours, Corporal Mansheim #4147 and | entered 1A Module to conduct a cell search inside A109, due
to the cell emitting a strong odor of ""Pruno” (jail manufactured alcohol). Corporal Mansheim instructed both incarcerated
persons to exit the cell in order for us to safely conduct the search. IP @@@ began walking towards the door, when he
suddenly lunged towards a small bag of ""Pruno” which was sitting in the cell sink. Corporal Mansheim immediately entered the
cell and grabbed to prevent him from destroying evidence (See Officer's Report by Corporal Mansheim).
| observed IP Ramirez lunge towards Corporal Mansheim and punch him once in the back and once in the face area. | quickly
entered the cell and attempted to grab Ramirez to prevent him from striking Corporal Mansheim any further. While attempting
to gain control of Ramirez, Ramirez turned towards me and hit me with his elbow on the right side of my head, which made
my hat fall off my head. To prevent Ramirez from assaulting me again, | delivered approximately two closed fist strikes to his
face with my right and left hand. The force was effective, and Ramirez was knocked backwards and lost his balance. Had | not
used force on Ramirez, he would have continued to assault me resulting in serious injuries.
| lunged towards Ramirez and encircled my arms around his torso. | used my body weight and downward pressure to pull him
down to the ground. My force was effective, and Ramirez was successfully taken down to the ground. Ramirez landed on his
back and immediately punched me in the chest twice. To prevent Ramirez from punching me any further, | attempted to turn
Ramirez on his stomach and place his hands behind his back, but Ramirez started kicking me in the legs and stomach. To
prevent Ramirez from assaulting me again, | delivered approximately two closed fist strikes to his stomach with my right hand.
The force was effective, and Ramirez stopped kicking me. Ramirez rolled onto his side. | gained control of Ramirez’ legs. |

On 11/24/2023, | was assigned as the Central Rover at the Rock Mountain Detention Facility (RMDF) when Corporal
Mansheim #4147 and Deputy Juarez #3055 notified me Module A Cell #109 smelled of jail manufactured alcohol (pruno)
At approximately 1618, Corporal Mansheim, Deputy Juarez, Deputy Lozada #3349 and | approached Module A Cell #109 to
conduct a search due to the smell of pruno coming from the cell. Upon approaching the cell, we observed a bag of pruno on
top of the toilet. Incarcerated persons (IP's) Ramirez, Carlos BN 23741438 and Qjy@yep TED) were instructed
to exit Cell #109. Upon exiting the cell, IP gig} grabbed the bag of pruno and attempted to dump it into the toilet. When
Corporal Mansheim attempted to handcuff @g@ey Ramirez rushed behind Corporal Mansheim and struck him in the back.
| went inside of Cell #109 to prevent Ramirez from further injuring Corporal Mansheim and to secure Ramirez in handcuffs.
While inside of the cell Ramirez struck me in the chest with his hand using a closed fist. Due to Ramirez’ active assaultive
behavior, | struck the left side his forehead twice with my right closed fist. This force was effective and caused Ramirez to
stumble and fall to the floor.
Ramirez landed on his back on the cell floor and landed underneath the desk between the wall and stool. | attempted to roll
Ramirez onto his stomach to be handcuffed, however he continued to resist by pushing away my hands. While still on the
floor, Ramirez grabbed toward my vest and duty belt. In order to handcuff Ramirez, prevent him from further attacking my
partners and I, and to prevent Ramirez from trying taking hold of me, | struck Ramirez with two additional closed fist strikes. |

On 11/24/2023, | was assigned to George Bailey Detention Facility (GBDF) as the Central Sergeant. At approximately 1618
hours, | responded to radio traffic from Rock Mountain Detention Facility (RMDF) for ""Cover"" to House 1, A Module Cell #109.
When | arrived on scene, | observed several deputies inside Cell #109 attempting to gain control of an incarcerated person
later identified as Ramirez, Carlos BN 23741438. After deputies gained control of Ramirez, he was handcuffed and leg
chained. Ramirez was lifted off the floor and secured onto a gurney. Ramirez was escorted via gurney to the corridor area
where health staff was standing by to conduct an evaluation. Nurse @jy@re) determined Ramirez would need
additional medical evaluation from an area hospital. 911 was activated and Ramirez was escorted via gurney to the RMDF
Vehicle Sally Port and awaited transportation to Sharp Chula Vista.
Ramirez returned to GBDF the night of 11/24/2023 after being evaluated and treated at Sharp Chula Vista Hospital. Ramirez
was diagnosed as having sustained a fractured nasal cavity after a CT scan was performed.
On 11/25/2023, at approximately 1138 hours, | conducted an interview with Ramirez at GBDF Medical Isolation Cell 2M) due
to the major injury he sustained.

I introduced myself to Ramirez and informed him I was there to speak to him about the incident that occurred the previous
day.  I asked Ramirez what happened, and he said, ""They [Deputies] walked in and approached
] and I practically helped him out."" I asked Ramirez to describe what he meant. Ramirez said the deputies came
into the cell and dropped his juice in the toilet so he decided to ""help""
out. Ramirez informed me he was an alcoholic and
was upset the alcohol had been thrown out. I asked him what happened after, and Ramirez said he punched the deputy
because he was upset about the alcohol being discarded away. I asked Ramirez if he had alcohol in the cell. Ramirez
confirmed there was alcohol in the cell and it belonged to him. Ramirez said he punched the deputy in the face and then it
was, ""game over."" I asked Ramirez what he meant by ""game over."" Ramirez said there wasn't much he could do because
there was what he estimated to be five deputies present.  Ramirez said after he punched the deputy, the deputies present
took care of it."" Ramirez did not describe in detail what he meant. Ramirez said he didn't remember the whole incident.
Ramirez confirmed he was sent to the hospital where he was informed he fractured his nose, but sustained no additional
major injures.  Ramirez did not know the names of the deputies involved. Ramirez had no additional information to add to the
I ended the interview at approximately 1143 hours and had no additional contact with Ramirez.
Audio of the interview was attached to the Case URL.

Anderson is approximately 6'1'' 300 lbs. Due to his size and agitated state I felt I would need at least another deputy to reason
and escort Anderson to court holding in order to avoid any potential issues.
At approximately 0400 hours Deputies Sosa #3509, Castillo #4897, and Rondero-Rojo #4336, and I entered House 1B
Module to speak to Anderson about his court refusal. To see if Anderson would react differently to another Deputy I stepped
to the side and let Deputy Sosa speak to Anderson. Deputy Sosa let Anderson know it was time to go to court. Anderson
complied with Deputy Sosa's instruction but was groaning and mumbling incoherent words. The muscles in his face were
tense and his face was red. Anderson put on his jail issued blues and stated, ""I don't know why you guys are fucking making
me do this, I don't want to go to fucking court."" Deputy Sosa explained to him it is a part of jail operations and we are doing
our job. Deputy Sosa convinced him to leave the quad. Anderson walked out of the module on his own with his cane. We
escorted Anderson outside of the module. Once we arrived at the House Corridor he stopped walking, turned around and
faced me and said, ""I don't have to go to fucking court."" I told him to face away and keep walking or else I would place him in
handcuffs for not obeying my instructions. Anderson complied. He turned around and walked down towards GBDF
Processing. During our escort to GBDF Processing, Anderson said ""You're a bitch for this."" He continued cursing specifically
at me and called me a bitch a couple more times.
Once we arrived at Processing, Deputy Sosa instructed Anderson to face the wall and stop talking, while we determined
which holding cell he would be secured in. Anderson ignored Deputy Sosa's instructions and turned to face me. Anderson
tensed up his body and said, ""You ain't nothing but a bitch."" After that he took a bladed stance, stared at me and said, ""Take
off your badge and let's see what you're about."" I instructed him to turn around and face the wall. Anderson then quickly raised
his arms with closed fists and lunged towards me with his upper body as if he was going to attack me.
In order to prevent Anderson from assaulting me I delivered an elbow strike to his face. I saw that Anderson raised his arms
and I felt he might try to strike me. To stop him from doing this I delivered two closed fist strikes to his face. The first strike was
with my left hand and the next one was with my right hand on the left side of his face. Deputies Sosa and Castillo grabbed
Anderson by an arm on each side. I grabbed Anderson on the back of the neck and shoulder area. I applied downward
pressure to push him to the floor. I gave verbal commands to stop resisting as I felt his body tense up as I pushed him to the
floor. My force was successful in preventing Anderson from assaulting me or any of the other deputies present. We were able
to force Anderson onto the floor. Once on the floor Anderson was compliant.
Deputies Mccullen #3124 Enciso #6191 Denison #3743 and Calderon #4384, who were assigned to Processing were present
during the incident. Deputies Mccullen and Enciso handcuffed Anderson. Anderson continued to be compliant.
At approximately 0410 hours, Sgt. Romero #7800 arrived on scene and was informed about the incident.
GBDF Health staff and a gurney was requested to processing. Once they arrived, Deputies Mccullen, Calderon, and Denison
assisted Anderson onto the gurney. Anderson rolled himself to his side. Deputy McCullen took hold of Anderson's left arm and
Deputy Denison took hold of Anderson's right arm and assisted him to his feet. Once Anderson was on his feet, he sat on the
gurney. Deputy Calderon grabbed Anderson's right shoulder and helped Anderson slide higher on the gurney as he was in the
seated position. Deputy McCullen was the safety deputy during the escort to medical. Deputies Do #0361 and Robledo
#4453, who were assigned to GBDF Medical escorted Anderson to the GBDF Medical where he was evaluated and treated by
GBDF Health staff. Anderson was then transported to the Alvarado Hospital via Ambulance for further evaluation and
At 0500 hours, I went to Concentra Urgent Care for evaluation and was treated for my injured right thumb.
I had no further contact with Anderson.
At approximately 0500 hours on 10/28/2023 I uploaded the digital photographs and CCTV footage of the incident onto a
compact disc for evidence. I submitted all related evidence into GBDF Evidence locker #12.
Description: Compact Disc with video footage and two (2) digital photographs
Anderson sustained a fractured nose and was treated at Alvarado Hospital.
Deputy Gonzalez sustained a sprained right thumb.

involved in a use of force with Incarcerated Person (IP) Anderson, Ryan (BN23741609) while escorting him to processing for
At approximately 0400 hours, Deputy Castillo 4897, Gonzalez 4398, Rondero-Rojo 4336, and | were escorting I/P Anderson
to processing because he was refusing to go to court.
While in the House 1 corridor, I/P Anderson began to us profanity toward us. | instructed him to face the wall to cuff up, but
Anderson refused to follow instructions. After speaking with Anderson we were able to have him walk to processing without
Once we arrived in processing, | instructed Anderson to face the wall until we figured out what holding cell, he was going in.
Anderson said, ""I'm going to fuck you guys up.” and refused to follow the instructions. | saw Anderson turn towards Deputy
Gonzalez and make fists with his hands and took a bladed stance. Anderson lunged toward Deputy Gonzalez.
Before Anderson could strike Deputy Gonzalez, Deputy Gonzalez threw three strikes at Anderson, hitting him on his face. To
prevent Anderson from hitting Deputy Gonzalez, | grabbed Anderson's right arm with my left hand and pulled him to the floor.
My force was effecting as it stopped Anderson from striking Deputy Gonzalez.
Once on the floor, | took hold of Anderson right wrist with my right hand and placed it to the small of his back, Anderson did
not offer any resistance. | maintained my hold until Anderson was handcuffed by Deputy McCullen 3124 and Enciso 6191.

On 10/26/2023, | was assigned to work the Northside Sergeant position at the George Bailey Detention Facility (GBDF), when
| heard a radio call for assistance of GBDF medical staff to the Court Processing area.
At approximately 0412 hours, | arrived at the GBDF Court Processing area to see an Incarcerated Person (IP) later identified
as Ryan Anderson BK#23741609, on the floor with handcuffs on. Deputy McCullen #3124 advised me a use of force occurred
with Anderson and escorting deputies. Deputies assisted Anderson onto a gurney and GBDF Medical staff started assessing
Anderson for any injuries. GBDF Medical staff asked deputies to move Anderson to the Medical Dispensary to better assess
Anderson. The deputies moved Anderson to the Medical Dispensary.
| walked to the Watch Commander's office to retrieve a digital recorder so | may interview Anderson about the use of force
At about 0425, | conducted a recorded interview with Anderson in the GBDF Medical Dispensary. Anderson said he was
offered his court medications but refused. He also told the deputies in the house that he refused to go to court. After talking to
a couple of the housing deputies he decided to go to court. Anderson said while in the sallyport he was calling the deputies
names and turned towards one of the deputies (Deputy Gonzalez #4398) and said, ""What are you going to do about it?"" While
facing Deputy Gonzalez, Anderson put his foot forward. Anderson said, ""I intimidated him. He got scared like a little bitch and
assaulted me."" | asked Anderson if he took a fighting stance. Anderson said he took a defensive stance. Anderson said he
didn't want to g to El Cajon court because it's an all-day process and he didn't want to wait. Anderson claimed the deputy
struck him ten times with his right hand.
| concluded my interview and had no further contact with Anderson.

They requested | assist them with a male, identified as Zachariah Iban (27), who was believed to be
armed with a firearm and barricaded inside someone else's apartment. Iban reportedly walked away from
officers during a hot stop, which stemmed from a call of him being intoxicated, acting aggressively, hitting
cars and reportedly having a gun. The incident occurred at 817 Eta Street #2502 in National City. After
more than two hours of commands to exit the house, Iban came outside and ignored commands. My
canine partner, Nike, was deployed off lead to apprehend Iban. Iban was taken into custody, without
Zachariah lban was transported to Paradise Valley Hospital by AMR 419, where he was treated by
Doctor @@g). |ban sustained 10 lacerations on his upper, right arm from being bit by my canine, and
