Sergeant Serrato #4079 of the Sheriff's Lakeside Substation and Sergeant Carrillo #2821 of the Sheriff's
Division of Inspectional Services responded to the hospital for follow-up investigation regarding the
utilization of a Sheriff's canine. Sergeant Leyva #3394 of the Sheriff's Canine Unit was notified of the
Officer Garcia #550 of the National City Police Department arrested and booked Zachariah Iban into the
San Diego County Central Jail for residential burglary, resisting arrest and a probation violation warrant.
Lieutenant Ramirez #422 of the National City Police Department was the incident's commander. They
documented their investigation under case number 2320896.
I took photographs of the scene, Zachariah Iban and Iban's injuries, which were placed into evidence at
I reported this incident to the San Diego County Department of Animal Services.
This incident was captured on body worn camera.
On 08/19/23, at approximately 1447 hours, I was dispatched to 817 Eta Street, in National City, to assist
the National City Police Department. The National City Police Department informed Sheriff's
Communications they wanted a canine unit to assist them with a call of an intoxicated male who was
hitting vehicles, possibly had a gun and walked into an apartment, against officers' commands.
At the time of this incident, I was on-duty, in full uniform and driving a marked, Sheriff's, canine vehicle. I
was working my regularly scheduled shift as a canine handler for the Lakeside Substation. I responded
to the request for canine assistance from the area of El Cajon. While driving to the call, the National City
Police Department cancelled the request and I returned to my service area.
At approximately 1521 hours, the National City Police Department contacted Sheriff's Communications
and requested I return to the same incident. I responded to the request for canine assistance from the
I arrived on scene at approximately 1539 hours.
Upon arrival, I met with Sergeant Shanahan #393. Sergeant Shanahan informed me his officers were
dispatched to a call of a male being aggressive, intoxicated and hitting cars. Sergeant Shanahan said the
paramedics were also dispatched to the incident and, upon arrival, were told the male had a gun, so they
backed out. When the officers arrived, they attempted to conduct a pedestrian hot stop, but the male
walked away and entered apartment 2502. Sergeant Shanahan informed me the male was reaching and
grabbing at his waistband while walking away from his officers.  Since that time, officers were able to
identify the male as Zachariah Iban, determined he was a high-risk probationer who was on probation for
assault with a deadly weapon and confirmed he did not live in that apartment. Sergeant Shanahan said
his officers made contact with the
who stated they did not know the male,
had left their door unlocked and did not want him inside. The
permission to go inside. Sergeant Shanahan claimed his officers had remained on scene the entire time,
ensuring me Iban was still inside the apartment.
Officer Garcia #550 informed me she had spoken to the
no one else inside the apartment, but stated they had a small dog inside. Officer Garcia reiterated the
fact that Zachariah Iban was reaching for his waistband when he walked away from them and into the
apartment. I questioned the source of information about Iban possessing a firearm and she claimed it
was reported to the fire department from citizens, but they were unable to reach the fire department for
I contacted Sergeant Leyva #3394 of the Sheriff's Canine Unit. I briefed him of the incident's details and
expressed my concern for safety of officers who might have to enter an apartment occupied by a male
who resisted arrest and was reportedly armed with a firearm, despite the fact he was only wanted for
trespassing and resisting arrest at the time. He agreed that officer safety was priority and believed the
utilization of a canine during such a search was reasonable. We discussed possible solutions to working
around the fact there was a dog inside the apartment and decided it was likely best to enter the
apartment with my canine partner, Nike, on a leash in order to try to get the dog out of the apartment or
locked into a bathroom before continuing the search.
Lieutenant Ramirez #422 of the National City Police Department arrived on scene, assuming the position
of incident commander. I briefed with Lieutenant Ramirez and Sergeant Shanahan. I informed them I
was willing to assist them with a canine search inside the apartment, if they chose to make entry, but
expressed my concerns for there being a dog inside. I told them I might have to start the search on lead
until the dog was removed from the search area. Lieutenant Ramirez informed me one of his tactical
officers was retrieving their armored vehicle and bringing it to the scene. He said they would start by
giving announcements from their armored vehicle and go from there.
While awaiting the arrival of the armored vehicle, I opened my vehicle's front doors and placed old
ballistic vests over each window. This provided me with more ballistic coverage should Zachariah Iban
start shooting from the apartment. I then retrieved my department-issued rifle from the back of my vehicle
and placed it on my passenger seat, for quick access.
The apartment into which Zachariah Iban fled was a second story unit on the southeast corner of an
eight-unit building. There were two upper units and two lower units facing east, with the other units facing
west. The entrance to the units was recessed into the middle of the eastern wall. From my position, I
could see all the apartment's windows, but could not see the doorway. I could only see the lower steps of
the stairwell, which led to the door. Some of the apartments windows were open.
The armored vehicle arrived and parked next to my patrol vehicle. I remained on the south side of the
building with Sergeant Shanahan, Lieutenant Ramirez, a couple tactical officers, an agent and another
patrol officer. A contact team was established at a patrol car positioned off the northeast corner of the
building. The officers moved the vehicle south a short distance in order to better observe the doorway
and stairwell, should Zachariah Iban exit.
Officers began making announcements from the public announcement system on the armored vehicle.
After a few rounds of announcements, I noted the volume appeared low. Wanting to ensure Zachariah
Iban could hear the announcements, I requested they turn up the speaker's volume. The officer adjusted
the volume and continued. After making the adjustment, I felt content with the speaker's volume and
believed officer's commands were sufficiently loud that they would be heard by Iban, even if he was
sleeping in the apartment. Officers continued giving commands for Zachariah Iban to come out of the
apartment, calling him by name and giving the apartment number. Most of the officer's commands
included the fact they had a police dog present and stated if he did not come out the dog would be sent
inside and he would be bit. I believe it fair to say they gave dozens of canine warnings during the
During the time when officers were giving commands, I coordinated with an officer on the contact team
who was holding a specialty munitions shotgun. I told him if Zachariah Iban came out of the apartment
and was not following commands, I might request he deploy the specialty munitions shotgun in order to
give my canine a safer opportunity to approach, potentially preventing Iban from drawing a firearm or
being able to quickly retreat back into the apartment. The officer informed me he would deploy, upon my
Officers were able to evacuate the rest of the building's residents, except those who lived on the opposite
side of the landing. Officers gave those residents an order to shelter in place in a back bedroom, not
wanting them to overexpose themselves during an evacuation.
Throughout this incident, large crowds of residents, including children, were gathered around our
periphery. The groups were asked to leave multiple times, but kept returning. Ultimately, officer placed
crime scene tape around a large portion of the complex to prevent onlookers from getting too close,
interfering or being in harm's way.
I was informed officers were attempting to contact probation and was later told they were obtaining a
probation hold warrant. This led me to believe Zachariah Iban was now arrestable for violating his
probation, which they said was for
This crime is for committing an
. Having been convicted of such a crime, I believed Iban
arrived on scene and expressed their concern for their dog,
was inside the apartment. They informed me they heard her bark and were worried for her safety.
Officers started making requests to Zachariah Iban to open the door and let the dog out, but Iban did not
After officers made request for Zachariah Iban to release the dog from the apartment, I noticed
movement in a window. This was the first sign of movement, to this point. Until this point, I did not see or
hear any movement from the apartment. Shortly thereafter, other officers confirmed they could see
Zachariah Iban pacing back and forth, viewing him through the living room window. I looked through the
living room window and saw him walking away from the apartment's front door, back toward the middle of
the apartment. Another officer later noticed Iban look out a window on the south side of the building,
stating he moved the blinds and put his face up to the glass. This activity led me to believe Iban was
aware of our presence and likely plotting his next move. I was concerned there was the potential Iban
might start shooting at us and was possibly assessing our locations for possible avenues of escape.
Lieutenant Ramirez informed me the dog inside the residence was reportedly a small chihuahua, which
said might be aggressive toward other dogs. I informed Lieutenant Ramirez my concern was
not for the safety of Nike, rather, that if he was released into the apartment, he might start fighting with
the small dog, distracting us from the danger Zachariah Iban posed. I suggested if we made entry into
the apartment, two officers with guns enter in front of me and said I would follow with Nike on lead,
I informed Lieutenant Ramirez I thought a flash bang could be useful, believing it might get Zachariah
Iban's attention and possibly convince him to exit. I would rather contact Iban outside the apartment than
be forced to make entry into the apartment. If we had to make entry into the apartment, Iban would
certainly have the tactical advantage. Since I knew he was aware of our presence and possibly armed
with a gun, I worried it was possible Iban used furniture to barricade the apartments door, could be lying
in wait, prepared for an ambush, or might ambush us on our approach to the apartment, up the narrow
I was informed Lieutenant Ramirez was calling out their SWAT team and a CNT negotiator.
At approximately 1724 hours, just over two hours after my arrival on scene and more than two and a half
hours after the arrival of the National City Police Department, an officer advised the door was opening. At
the time of this announcement, I was standing on the rear, driver's-side corner of the armored vehicle.
There were no officers with me on that side. I decided to move forward to the driver's door of the armored
vehicle, as a position of cover. I planned on using the door to give me a closer position from which to
safely deploy Nike, if necessary. As I moved toward the front of the vehicle, Zachariah Iban had already
stumbled out into the street, from the stairs. He stumbled quickly in the direction of the contact team.
Officer began giving him commands to put his hands up, but he was not complying. I yelled, ""Hands up!""
When Iban regained his balance, he turned away from the officers of the contact team, not complying
with their commands, and started moving in my direction. I yelled at him to get on the ground three times,
but he continued walking toward me. While giving him commands to get on the ground, he raised his
hands up slightly, exposing his palms, looked at me and pointed forward, with his right, index finger. I
could see he did not have anything in his hands, but was unable tell if there was a gun or other weapon
Standing by myself on the driver's side of the armored vehicle, with Zachariah Iban advancing in my
direction, ignoring all commands to put his hands up, stop or get on the ground, I feared for my safety.
There were a handful of officers in the contact team on the other side of the apartment, but none of them
would be able fire if Iban produced a weapon, because I was standing on the other side of him. Further,
knowing there was a crowd gathered all around our scene, I worried Iban might try to flee and make his
way into the crowd. Based upon the fact the call originated because Iban was being aggressive to
residents, reportedly had a gun and was hitting cars, I worried he might attack anyone of the onlookers or
potentially take them hostage. Further, if Iban reached the crowd, my force options to subdue him would
be greatly limited because they might put others at risk of injury. Because of this, I believed I had to stop
him before he got to me and certainly before he reached the crowd. Not wanting to go hands on with a
potentially armed person, I believed the safest way of stopping Iban was to deploy Nike. No other force
option I had at my disposal would allow me to do so, without sacrificing the safety of distance or
compromising my chances of success. I believed deploying Nike would likely prevent Iban from reaching
for a weapon or at least make it more challenging for him to manipulate one and prevent him from
reaching me or getting to the crowd.
I removed Nike's traffic lead and released my grip on his collar, giving him the command to bite
Zachariah Iban. Nike ran at Iban, jumped and bit him on the inside of his upper, right arm. As Nike bit
Iban, I ordered him to get on the ground. I drew my pistol and began walking at Iban, pointing my gun at
him to be better prepared, should he produce a weapon. I continued to order Iban onto the ground and
he sat down. Iban was holding Nike's front, right leg with his left hand and had his right arm around the
back of Nike's neck. Iban responded to my commands to get on the ground, saying, ""Okay,"" and laid on
his right side. With Iban showing signs of compliance, both lying down and replying okay to my
commands, I believed it was safe to holster and detain him. Further, with Iban lying on his back and
moving to his side, I had more time to scan his body for weapons and did not see any. I put my gun away
and grasped Iban's left hand, requesting the officers move in to assists by calling out, ""Hands."" The
officers ran up and took control of Iban's left hand. I informed them not to grab his right arm and moved
around to gain physical control of Nike. As I grasped Nike's collar with my left hand, I could see the
officers had sufficient control of Iban, so I used my break stick to release Nike from the bite. Nike
instantly released his grasp of Iban and I stepped back. The officers detained Iban in handcuffs and
checked him for weapons. I later reviewed my body worn camera and found Nike was actively biting
I returned to my patrol car and placed Nike in the back seat.
I asked the officers if they had requested paramedics respond to evaluate Zachariah Iban's injuries and
I used my vehicle's radio and requested Sheriff's Communications inform the Lakeside Substation's
supervisor of the canine contact. Sergeant Serrato #4079 acknowledged the notification.
American Medical Response's Medic 419 arrived on scene and the paramedics began evaluating
Sergeant Carrillo #2821 of the Sheriff's Division of Inspectional Services contacted me by phone. He

Zachariah Iban to Paradise Valley Hospital for treatment. He informed me he would meet me there.
I contacted Sergeant Serrato by phone to inform him of the incident's details. He informed me he would
meet me at the hospital for follow-up.

The officers did not find a firearm on Zachariah Iban's person. I asked the homeowners if they would

Officer Garcia #550 of the National City Police Department informed me she was the arresting officer and

I took photographs of Zachariah Iban and the injuries to his upper, right arm. There were numerous small

On 08/19/23, at approximately 1447 hours, I was dispatched to 817 Eta Street, in National City, to assist
the National City Police Department. The National City Police Department informed Sheriff's
Communications they wanted a canine unit to assist them with a call of an intoxicated male who was
hitting vehicles, possibly had a gun and walked into an apartment, against officers' commands.
At the time of this incident, I was on-duty, in full uniform and driving a marked, Sheriff's, canine vehicle. I
was working my regularly scheduled shift as a canine handler for the Lakeside Substation. I responded
to the request for canine assistance from the area of El Cajon. While driving to the call, the National City
Police Department cancelled the request and I returned to my service area.
At approximately 1521 hours, the National City Police Department contacted Sheriff's Communications
and requested I return to the same incident. I responded to the request for canine assistance from the
I arrived on scene at approximately 1539 hours.
Upon arrival, I met with Sergeant Shanahan #393. Sergeant Shanahan informed me his officers were
dispatched to a call of a male being aggressive, intoxicated and hitting cars. Sergeant Shanahan said the
paramedics were also dispatched to the incident and, upon arrival, were told the male had a gun, so they
backed out. When the officers arrived, they attempted to conduct a pedestrian hot stop, but the male
walked away and entered apartment 2502. Sergeant Shanahan informed me the male was reaching and
grabbing at his waistband while walking away from his officers.  Since that time, officers were able to
identify the male as Zachariah Iban, determined he was a high-risk probationer who was on probation for
and confirmed he did not live in that apartment. Sergeant Shanahan said
his officers made contact with the
who stated they did not know the male,
had left their door unlocked and did not want him inside. The
permission to go inside. Sergeant Shanahan claimed his officers had remained on scene the entire time,
ensuring me Iban was still inside the apartment.
Officer Garcia #550 informed me she had spoken to the
no one else inside the apartment, but stated they had a small dog inside. Officer Garcia reiterated the
fact that Zachariah Iban was reaching for his waistband when he walked away from them and into the
apartment. I questioned the source of information about Iban possessing a firearm and she claimed it
was reported to the fire department from citizens, but they were unable to reach the fire department for
I contacted Sergeant Leyva #3394 of the Sheriff's Canine Unit. I briefed him of the incident's details and
expressed my concern for safety of officers who might have to enter an apartment occupied by a male
who resisted arrest and was reportedly armed with a firearm, despite the fact he was only wanted for
trespassing and resisting arrest at the time. He agreed that officer safety was priority and believed the
utilization of a canine during such a search was reasonable. We discussed possible solutions to working
around the fact there was a dog inside the apartment and decided it was likely best to enter the
apartment with my canine partner, Nike, on a leash in order to try to get the dog out of the apartment or
locked into a bathroom before continuing the search.
Lieutenant Ramirez #422 of the National City Police Department arrived on scene, assuming the position
of incident commander. I briefed with Lieutenant Ramirez and Sergeant Shanahan. I informed them I
was willing to assist them with a canine search inside the apartment, if they chose to make entry, but
expressed my concerns for there being a dog inside. I told them I might have to start the search on lead
until the dog was removed from the search area. Lieutenant Ramirez informed me one of his tactical
officers was retrieving their armored vehicle and bringing it to the scene. He said they would start by
giving announcements from their armored vehicle and go from there.
While awaiting the arrival of the armored vehicle, I opened my vehicle's front doors and placed old
ballistic vests over each window. This provided me with more ballistic coverage should Zachariah Iban
start shooting from the apartment. I then retrieved my department-issued rifle from the back of my vehicle
and placed it on my passenger seat, for quick access.
The apartment into which Zachariah Iban fled was a second story unit on the southeast corner of an
eight-unit building. There were two upper units and two lower units facing east, with the other units facing
west. The entrance to the units was recessed into the middle of the eastern wall. From my position, I
could see all the apartment's windows, but could not see the doorway. I could only see the lower steps of
the stairwell, which led to the door. Some of the apartments windows were open.
The armored vehicle arrived and parked next to my patrol vehicle. I remained on the south side of the
building with Sergeant Shanahan, Lieutenant Ramirez, a couple tactical officers, an agent and another
patrol officer. A contact team was established at a patrol car positioned off the northeast corner of the
building. The officers moved the vehicle south a short distance in order to better observe the doorway
and stairwell, should Zachariah Iban exit.
Officers began making announcements from the public announcement system on the armored vehicle.
After a few rounds of announcements, I noted the volume appeared low. Wanting to ensure Zachariah
Iban could hear the announcements, I requested they turn up the speaker's volume. The officer adjusted
the volume and continued. After making the adjustment, I felt content with the speaker's volume and
believed officer's commands were sufficiently loud that they would be heard by Iban, even if he was
sleeping in the apartment. Officers continued giving commands for Zachariah Iban to come out of the
apartment, calling him by name and giving the apartment number. Most of the officer's commands
included the fact they had a police dog present and stated if he did not come out the dog would be sent
inside and he would be bit. I believe it fair to say they gave dozens of canine warnings during the
During the time when officers were giving commands, I coordinated with an officer on the contact team
who was holding a specialty munitions shotgun. I told him if Zachariah Iban came out of the apartment
and was not following commands, I might request he deploy the specialty munitions shotgun in order to
give my canine a safer opportunity to approach, potentially preventing Iban from drawing a firearm or
being able to quickly retreat back into the apartment. The officer informed me he would deploy, upon my
Officers were able to evacuate the rest of the building's residents, except those who lived on the opposite
side of the landing. Officers gave those residents an order to shelter in place in a back bedroom, not
wanting them to overexpose themselves during an evacuation.
Throughout this incident, large crowds of residents, including children, were gathered around our

interfering or being in harm's way.

On 08/19/2023, | responded to Paradise Valley Hospital to conduct a follow up investigation reference a canine contact, which
occurred at 817 Eta Street in National City.
Upon my arrival, | contacted Deputy Balinger #0069 who provided a brief regarding the canine contact. Deputy Balinger
advised me the suspect Zachariah James Iban was currently receiving treatment. Once medical staff completed treating Iban,
| entered his hospital room and introduced myself to Iban. | told Iban | was assigned to the Lakeside Patrol Station. | explained
to Iban, | understood he was arrested, and | was conducting a follow up reference the incident involving the use of a Sheriff's
canine. | advised the date was August 19th, 2023 and the start time for the interview was 1959 hours.

I asked Iban if he was aware I was recording our conversation. Iban replied ""no sir."" I explained to Iban I was recording our
I asked Iban if he had been diagnosed with any type of mental illness. Iban replied ""yes sir"", I asked Iban if he could tell me
what type of mental illness he suffered from. Iban stated ""plenty"", I asked Iban if he could elaborate as to what type of mental
illness he suffered from. Iban replied ""no sir."" I once again asked Iban if he could elaborate to what type of mental illness he
suffered from and he replied, ""no sir.""
I asked Iban if he had any problems with his eyes or ears. Iban replied ""yes sir."" I asked Iban what type of problems he
suffered from. Iban replied ""I can't elaborate.""
I asked Iban if he was taking any medications. Iban stated ""yes sir."" I asked Iban what medications he was taking he replied, ""I
I asked Iban if he heard a warning the dog would be sent or an order to surrender. Iban replied ""I did not know."" I asked Iban
what he did not know. Iban stated ""I did not know the dog would be sent."" I asked Iban if he heard the announcements a
police dog would be used. Iban replied ""no sir.""
I asked Iban why he did not comply with officers. Iban stated ""I didn't hear anything."" I explained to Iban, I believed they were
possibly using a PA system to make announcements. I asked Iban if he still did not hear the announcements. I once again
asked Iban if he heard the announcements a police dog would be used. Iban once again replied ""no sir.""
I asked Iban how long the police dog had bit him. Iban replied ""I can't recall.""
I asked Iban if he could tell me where the police dog had bit him. Iban stated ""Obviously, you can see."" I asked Iban to explain
to me where he had been bit. ""Well, you can see."" I observed Iban had been contacted on the inner bicep of his right arm. I
asked Iban if that was correct, and he stated ""whatever.""
I asked Iban if he could explain to me how the police dog was taken off him. Iban replied ""you saw it."" I explained to Iban I was
not at the scene. Iban stated ""well then your partner saw."" I asked Iban if he could explain to me how the police dog was
I asked Iban if there was anything about the use of the police dog, he wanted to tell me. Iban replied ""excessive"", I asked Iban
if he could elaborate, he once again stated ""excessive, yes sir, yeah put the dog down."" I asked Iban if he felt the use of the
police dog was excessive and he replied, ""yes sir.""
I asked Iban if there was anything else he wanted to add. Iban replied ""not at the moment.""
I completed my interview with Zachariah Iban at 2002 hours.
1. Interview with Zachariah Iban was placed on a compact disc and logged into evidence at the Lakeside Station.
See Deputy Balinger's report for details on Iban's injuries.

On 7/1/23 at approximately 1948 hours, | received a be on the lookout (BOL) of a stolen white 1997 Ford
F150 (CAG) driving eastbound on Palomar Airport Road from Melrose Drive in Carlsbad. |
located the stolen vehicle travelling eastbound on San Marcos Boulevard near South Rancho Santa Fe
Road in the city of San Marcos within the county of San Diego. | attempted to initiate a high-risk traffic
stop on the vehicle at 805 W San Marcos Boulevard. The driver of the F150, later identified as Brent
Ebert, failed to yield which resulted in a vehicle pursuit which lasted approximately 2.1 miles and
approximately 3 minutes. Throughout the pursuit, Ebert drove at high rates of speed, made numerous
unsafe lane changes, and drove on the wrong way of a divided roadway. The pursuit ended when Ebert
drove to the dead end of 877 Custer Avenue. Ebert fled on foot and failed to obey law enforcement's
commands to stop running. Deputies apprehended Ebert in the backyard of 877 Custer Avenue. As
Deputies attempted to detain Ebert, he resisted which resulted in a use of force, which caused injury to
Deputy Druda, Deputy Maldanado, Deputy Manibusan, and Ebert.
Sgt. Frierson was notified of the use of force.

On 7/1/23 at approximately 1948 hours, I received a be on the lookout (BOL) of a stolen white 1997 Ford
) driving eastbound on Palomar Airport Road. (E8631935)
On 7/1/23 at approximately 1948 hours, Corporal Vicencio (0426) and I received a be on the lookout
(BOL) of a stolen white 1997 Ford F150 (CA/
) driving eastbound on Palomar Airport Road from
Melrose Drive in Carlsbad. I was driving southbound on South Rancho Santa Fe Road and located a
vehicle matching the description. The vehicle was crossing South Rancho Santa Fe Road traveling
eastbound on San Marcos Boulevard in the city of San Marcos within the county of San Diego.
I turned eastbound onto W San Marcos Boulevard, followed the vehicle, and confirmed the license plate
as the stolen vehicle. Corporal Vicencio radioed the suspect vehicle's information and additional units
responded to the area. Once additional units were in place, I attempted to initiate a high-risk traffic stop
at the 800 block of W San Marcos Boulevard. The driver of the F150, later identified as Brent Ebert
pulled into the parking lot of the shopping center on the south side of W San Marcos Boulevard.  Ebert
failed to yield and sped out of the parking lot, driving over the curb and barely missing Corporal Buckley's
(4063) patrol vehicle which was blocking the driveway to the parking lot. Ebert headed north on S Bent
Ave and turned eastbound onto W San Marcos Boulevard. Ebert entered the eastbound State Route 78
and exited at Twin Oaks Valley Road where he failed to stop for the red light and headed southbound on
Twin Oaks Valley Road.  At Craven Drive, Ebert veered into the northbound lanes of South Twin Oaks
Valley Road and continued southbound until turning eastbound onto Village Drive. We terminated the
pursuit, turning off our overhead lights, following the vehicle at a safe distance.  Ebert was observed
turning eastbound onto Wandering Way, southbound onto Savona Lane, eastbound onto Garland
Avenue and finally northbound onto Custer Avenue. The vehicle pursuit lasted approximately 2.1 miles
and approximately 3 minutes. Throughout the pursuit, Ebert drove at high rates of speed, up to 82 miles
per hour on the freeway and 60 miles per hour on surface streets. Ebert made numerous unsafe lane
changes and drove on the wrong side of a divided roadway.
At the dead end of Custer Avenue, Ebert exited the vehicle and fled on foot. Since Ebert did not place
the vehicle's transmission into park, it rolled back into the lead patrol vehicle. The patrol vehicle suffered
minor damage to the front end. Traffic Deputy, Corporal Guerrero (0817) investigated the collision (see
Deputy Druda (0639) began a foot pursuit and followed Ebert who climbed the fence on the side of the
house located 877 Custer Avenue. Deputy Druda went through the gate and as he attempted to
apprehend Ebert, a use of force ensued (see Deputy Druda's officer report). Corporal Maldonado came
to assist Deputy Druda and was also involved in the use of force (see Corporal Maldonado's officer
report). Deputy Haggerty (4097) and Deputy Manibusan (0640) assisted detaining Ebert (see Deputy
Haggerty's officer report and Deputy Manibusan's officer report). During the use of force, Deputy Druda
suffered redness and swelling to his left knee. Deputy Maldanado sustained redness and bruising to his
right knee. Deputy Manibusan sustained scratches, redness, and minor bruising to his right forearm and
wrist. Ebert suffered a laceration above his left eye, a fracture to his left cheek bone, an abrasion to his
nose and two cuts to his right wrist.
San Marcos Fire Department Engine #141 and RA #141 responded to the scene and transported Ebert
to Palomar Medical Center for evaluation.
Deputy Druda contacted the register owner of the stolen vehicle and released the vehicle to the owner at
the scene. Deputy Druda contacted Stolen Vehicle System and removed the vehicle as stolen. A records
check indicated the vehicle was stolen out of the city of San Diego on 06/17/2023. California Highway
Patrol took the initial stolen vehicle report
recovered vehicle and of Deputy Druda and Deputy Manibusan.
At Palomar Medical Center, I admonished Ebert per my deputy notebook and Ebert provided the
Ebert said he got the vehicle from his friend
, earlier today. Ebert became uncooperative and did not

(F), and 12022.1 - PC - COMMIT FEL ON BAIL OR O/R RELEASE (BAIL+).
Ebert was transported to Vista Detention Facility (VDF) for booking.

On 7/1/23 at approximately 1948 hours, | received a be on the lookout (BOL) of a stolen white 1997 Ford
F150 (CA(Q@GIEE driving eastbound on Palomar Airport Road from Melrose Drive in Carlsbad. |
located the stolen vehicle travelling eastbound on San Marcos Boulevard near South Rancho Santa Fe
Road in the city of San Marcos within the county of San Diego. | attempted to initiate a high-risk traffic
stop on the vehicle at 805 W San Marcos Boulevard. The driver of the F150, later identified as Brent
Ebert, failed to yield which resulted in a vehicle pursuit which lasted approximately 2.1 miles and
approximately 3 minutes. Throughout the pursuit, Ebert drove at high rates of speed, made numerous
unsafe lane changes, and drove on the wrong way of a divided roadway. The pursuit ended when Ebert
drove to the dead end of 877 Custer Avenue. Ebert fled on foot and failed to obey law enforcement's
commands to stop running. Deputies apprehended Ebert in the backyard of 877 Custer Avenue. As
Deputies attempted to detain Ebert, he resisted which resulted in a use of force, which caused injury to
Deputy Druda, Deputy Maldanado, Deputy Manibusan, and Ebert.
Sgt. Frierson was notified of the use of force.
Deputy Druda sustained bruising to his left knee. Deputy Maldanado sustained redness and bruising to
his right knee. Deputy Manibusan sustained scratches, redness, and minor bruising to his right forearm
and wrist. Ebert suffered a laceration above his left eye, a fracture to his left cheek bone, an abrasion to
his nose, and two cuts to his right wrist.
Ebert was placed under arrest for 10851 (A) - VC - TAKE VEHICLE W/O OWNER'S
CONSENT/VEHICLE THEFT (F), 69(A) - PC - OBSTRUCT/RESIST EXECUTIVE OFFICER WITH
MINOR INJURY (F), 496 D (A) - PC - POSS STOLEN VEH/VESSEL (F), 12500 (A) - VC - DRVG
WITHOUT VALID DRVR'S LIC (M), 2800.2 (A) - VC - EVADE PEACE OFCR WITH WANTON
DISREGARD FOR SAFETY (F), 2800.4 - VC - EVADING A PEACE OFFICER:WRONG WAY DRIVER
(F), and 12022.1 - PC - COMMIT FEL ON BAIL OR O/R RELEASE (BAIL+).
Ebert was medically cleared by Palomar Medical Center staff. Ebert was transported to Vista Detention
Body worn cameras documented the incident.

On 7/1/23 at approximately 1948 hours, I received a be on the lookout (BOL) of a stolen white 1997 Ford
) driving eastbound on Palomar Airport Road. (E8631935)
On 7/1/23 at approximately 1948 hours, Corporal Vicencio (0426) and I received a be on the lookout
(BOL) of a stolen white 1997 Ford F150 (CA/
) driving eastbound on Palomar Airport Road from
Melrose Drive in Carlsbad. I was driving southbound on South Rancho Santa Fe Road and located a
vehicle matching the description. The vehicle was crossing South Rancho Santa Fe Road traveling
eastbound on San Marcos Boulevard in the city of San Marcos within the county of San Diego.
I turned eastbound onto W San Marcos Boulevard, followed the vehicle, and confirmed the license plate
as the stolen vehicle. Corporal Vicencio radioed the suspect vehicle's information and additional units
responded to the area. Once additional units were in place, I attempted to initiate a high-risk traffic stop
at the 800 block of W San Marcos Boulevard. The driver of the F150, later identified as Brent Ebert
pulled into the parking lot of the shopping center on the south side of W San Marcos Boulevard.  Ebert
failed to yield and sped out of the parking lot, driving over the curb and barely missing Corporal Buckley's
(4063) patrol vehicle which was blocking the driveway to the parking lot. Ebert headed north on S Bent
Ave and turned eastbound onto W San Marcos Boulevard. Ebert entered the eastbound State Route 78
and exited at Twin Oaks Valley Road where he failed to stop for the red light and headed southbound on
Twin Oaks Valley Road.  At Craven Drive, Ebert veered into the northbound lanes of South Twin Oaks
Valley Road and continued southbound until turning eastbound onto Village Drive. We terminated the
pursuit, turning off our overhead lights, following the vehicle at a safe distance.  Ebert was observed
turning eastbound onto Wandering Way, southbound onto Savona Lane, eastbound onto Garland
Avenue and finally northbound onto Custer Avenue. The vehicle pursuit lasted approximately 2.1 miles
and approximately 3 minutes. Throughout the pursuit, Ebert drove at high rates of speed, up to 82 miles
per hour on the freeway and 60 miles per hour on surface streets. Ebert made numerous unsafe lane
changes and drove on the wrong side of a divided roadway.
At the dead end of Custer Avenue, Ebert exited the vehicle and fled on foot. Since Ebert did not place
the vehicle's transmission into park, it rolled back into the lead patrol vehicle. The patrol vehicle suffered
minor damage to the front end. Traffic Deputy, Corporal Guerrero (0817) investigated the collision (see
Deputy Druda (0639) began a foot pursuit and followed Ebert who climbed the fence on the side of the
house located 877 Custer Avenue. Deputy Druda went through the gate and as he attempted to
apprehend Ebert, a use of force ensued (see Deputy Druda's officer report). Corporal Maldonado came
to assist Deputy Druda and was also involved in the use of force (see Corporal Maldonado's officer
report). Deputy Haggerty (4097) and Deputy Manibusan (0640) assisted detaining Ebert (see Deputy
Haggerty's officer report and Deputy Manibusan's officer report). During the use of force, Deputy Druda
suffered redness and swelling to his left knee. Deputy Maldanado sustained redness and bruising to his
right knee. Deputy Manibusan sustained scratches, redness, and minor bruising to his right forearm and
wrist. Ebert suffered a laceration above his left eye, a fracture to his left cheek bone, an abrasion to his
nose and two cuts to his right wrist.
San Marcos Fire Department Engine #141 and RA #141 responded to the scene and transported Ebert
to Palomar Medical Center for evaluation.
Deputy Druda contacted the register owner of the stolen vehicle and released the vehicle to the owner at
the scene. Deputy Druda contacted Stolen Vehicle System and removed the vehicle as stolen. A records
check indicated the vehicle was stolen out of the city of San Diego on 06/17/2023. California Highway
Patrol took the initial stolen vehicle report
recovered vehicle and of Deputy Druda and Deputy Manibusan.
At Palomar Medical Center, I admonished Ebert per my deputy notebook and Ebert provided the
Ebert said he got the vehicle from his friend
, earlier today. Ebert became uncooperative and did not
Ebert was medically cleared by the Palomar Medical Center staff. While at the hospital Deputy Vicencio
Ebert was placed under arrest for 10851 (A) - VC - TAKE VEHICLE W/O OWNER'S
CONSENT/VEHICLE THEFT (F), 69(A) - PC - OBSTRUCT/RESIST EXECUTIVE OFFICER WITH
MINOR INJURY (F), 496 D (A) - PC - POSS STOLEN VEH/VESSEL (F), 12500 (A) - VC - DRVG
WITHOUT VALID DRVR'S LIC (M), 2800.2 (A) - VC - EVADE PEACE OFCR WITH WANTON
DISREGARD FOR SAFETY (F), 2800.4 - VC - EVADING A PEACE OFFICER:WRONG WAY DRIVER
(F), and 12022.1 - PC - COMMIT FEL ON BAIL OR O/R RELEASE (BAIL+).
Ebert was transported to Vista Detention Facility (VDF) for booking.
Body worn cameras documented the incident.
Deputy Druda suffered redness and swelling of his left knee.
Deputy Maldanado sustained redness and bruising to his right knee.
Deputy Manibusan sustained scratches, redness, and minor bruising to his right forearm and wrist.
Ebert suffered a laceration above his left eye, a fracture to his left cheek bone, an abrasion to his nose
and two cuts to his right wrist.
Minor front end damage to patrol vehicle (#20357).

column1: | sustained a scuff with redness on my left knee, a scratch on my right elbow, and pain to my right hand.
On 07/01/2023 at 1948 hours, Carlsbad Police broadcasted a Be On the Lookout (BOL) for a stolen 1997 Ford F-150
(CA(@Gym) that was seen driving eastbound into the city of San Marcos, San Diego County.
On 07/01/2023 at about 1951 hours, San Marcos Patrol Deputies located the stolen vehicle and attempted to initiate a traffic
stop at the 700 Block of West San Marcos Boulevard, in the city of San Marcos. The driver failed to yield to deputies and a
traffic pursuit was initiated. The traffic pursuit came to a stop at the dead end near 877 Custer Avenue, in the city of San
Marcos. The driver of the vehicle fled on foot, a foot pursuit was initiated, and a use of force ensued to effect an arrest and
The following is a summary of my investigation and is not intended to place recordings of the incident. For exact narrative and
statements, refer to my body worn camera (BWC) footage.
Moments prior to the foot pursuit, | observed an unknown male adult exit from the driver's side position of the stolen F-150.
The driver, who had already committed multiple felonies (10851(A)CVC & 2800.2CVC), fled on foot toward the side of a
residence at the dead end of Custer Avenue. As | pursued the fleeing felon on foot toward the side yard of the residence, |
observed a black truck parked in the driveway. | yelled at the suspect to ""Get on the fucking ground” multiple times and the
suspect continued to flee toward a wooden side gate that led into the backyard of the residence. Due to the time of day and
the truck observed in the driveway, | believed the residents were home and the suspect may have tried running into their
Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By
SH0639 - DRUDA, AUSTIN 122 | SMS - San Marcos Station SH3652 - FRIERSON, WILLIAM
NetRMS_CASDOR. rif v11-15-06 Printed By SH5865 Printed: August 30, 2023 - 9:42 PM
The suspect continued to flee despite my commands and proceeded to jump over the closed gate that led into the backyard. I
observed the suspect fall headfirst over the five-to-six-foot tall gate and briefly lost observation of him for about two to three
seconds. Based off my training and experience, fleeing felons and vehicle thieves are known to carry firearms or deadly
weapons, and will use physical force against law enforcement to avoid being arrested. I caught up to the wooden gate and
pushed it open and regained visual observation of the suspect. I observed the suspect roll onto his back and use his feet to
kick me to prevent me from gaining control of him. I used my bodyweight to prevent him from continuing to kick at me and felt
him grab onto my gear near the right side of my waist where my firearm was holstered. I continued to yell ""Get on the fucking
ground"" as he pulled on me and attempted to stand up. He continued to grip onto my gear and pull me closer to his body.
To prevent the suspect from gaining control of me or any of my issued gear, to include a deadly weapon, I used a closed fist
with my right hand and punched the suspect in the face four to five times until I felt him release his hand from my gear. I
attempted to gain control of the suspect's left arm with my hands to roll him onto his stomach and place him in handcuffs. The
suspect continued resist by interlocking his left hand to his right arm above his head. He asked, ""Why are you fucking
punching me man"" and I stated, ""Because you're grabbing my fucking waist."" He continued to grip onto his right arm with his
left hand and I used my left hand and punched him in the arm one time, which caused him to release his right arm and
allowed me to gain complete control of his left arm.
Additional Deputies arrived to assist, and we were able to place him in handcuffs without further incident. The suspect was
immediately rolled into the recovery position and escorted to the street to be evaluated by paramedics. He was identified as
) by a Deputy on scene. Ebert has an extensive criminal history to include the following charges:
Force was necessary to prevent Ebert from escape
column2: self-defense
column3: and to prevent him from possibly running into an occupied

column1: residence or backyard which could have resulted in injury to innocent bystanders. Due to the time of day and warm summer
weather, there was a likelihood that the residence had an open backdoor or window, which Ebert could have entered through.
The force used was effective and ultimately resulted in safely detaining him in handcuffs and preventing further injury to
During the physical altercation, I sustained a scuff with redness on my left knee, a scratch on my right elbow, and pain to my
right hand. Medical treatment was not necessary for my injuries. Ebert had apparent bleeding from his face, which was
unknown to have resulted from him falling headfirst over the five to six foot gate or because of the necessary force used
against him. Ebert was transported to Palomar Medical Center for further medical evaluation and treatment.

On 7/1/23 at 1948 hours, Carlsbad Police (CBPD) broadcasted a Be on the Lookout (BOL) for a stolen white 1997 Ford F-150
(CA/LIC 4) that was seen driving eastbound into the city of San Marcos in the County of San Diego.
On 7/1/23, at about 1951 hours, deputies located the occupied stolen vehicle driving eastbound on San Marcos Boulevard in
the City of San Marcos. A traffic enforcement stop was initiated, and the driver failed to yield which initiated a traffic pursuit.
Deputy Druda #0639 and | were directly behind the stolen vehicle when the traffic pursuit came to an end at a Cul-de-Sac of
877 Custer Avenue. | observed Deputy Druda dynamically exit his patrol vehicle and run after the male subject, later identified
as Brent Ebert (@y@y), towards a residence. | exited my vehicle and attempted to catch up to both as | was in fear that Ebert
may attempt to run into someone's residence or backyard or attack Deputy Druda. As | ran past the stolen vehicle, | observed
the vehicle roll backwards into Deputy Druda’'s patrol vehicle. | quickly glanced and did not see any other subjects in the
vehicle. As | turned the corner of the residence, | observed Deputy Druda and Ebert fighting on the ground. As | got closer, |
could see Ebert flailing his legs towards Deputy Druda and attempting to grab his duty gear on his vest. At one point, Ebert
had a hold of Deputy Druda's vest with one hand and was trying to stand up. | yelled ""Hey. Get on the ground,"" and used both
of my hands to push Ebert towards the ground to get him off Deputy Druda. | could hear Deputy Druda yell, ""Get off my waist,”
so | used my right forearm and elbow to strike Ebert in the face. | believed Ebert was trying to pull Deputy Druda to the ground
and trying to gain control of one of Deputy Druda's force options such as his taser, OC spray, baton, or firearm. Once | saw
Ebert had let go of Deputy Druda, | used both of my hands to pin down his left arm. Once deputies were able to roll Ebert onto
his stomach, | used my upper body to apply downward pressure to his upper back to prevent him from getting up. | noticed
Ebert's arm was tucked under his body, so | got off his back which allowed deputies to gain control of his right arm. | used my
right knee to apply downward pressure to his back to allow the deputies to detain him in handcuffs. While controlling Ebert, |

On 07/01/2023, at about 1948 hours, Carlsbad Police Department put out a be on the lookout for a stolen White F150
(LAGS /CA) traveling eastbound towards the City of San Marcos.
07/01/2023, at about 1952, Corporal Vicencio #0426 and Deputy Brauer #0521 located the stolen vehicle, a white F-150
(LP#@@ay CA), traveling eastbound on San Marcos Boulevard at Pacific Street. Deputies initiated a traffic stop, near San
Marcos Boulevard and Bent Avenue, the vehicle failed to yield resulting in a traffic pursuit. | was the second unit in the pursuit
and provided dispatch with radio traffic regarding the vehicle's direction of travel and speed. The vehicle fled eastbound on W
San Marcos Boulevard through Grand Avenue before ultimately merging on to the SR78 Eastbound. The vehicle proceeded in
the number one lane at speeds of about 80 miles per hour (MPH). The vehicle quickly cut across all four lanes of traffic and
exited southbound onto Twin Oaks Valley Road, running the red light. The vehicle then merged into opposing lanes of traffic
at North City Drive. The vehicle continued on the opposing side of traffic through Craven Road, at which point the pursuit was
discontinued. | slowed down but had not turned off my lights yet, when | observed the vehicle turn eastbound on Village Drive
on the correct lanes of traffic. | observed two Deputies continue the pursuit and followed behind responding units. The vehicle
came to a stop at the dead end of 877 Custer Avenue, in the City of San Marcos, County of San Diego. The driver, later
identified as Brent Ebert, ran from the vehicle on foot. | observed Deputies Druda #0639 and Maldonado #0511 chase Ebert
on foot towards the backyard of the residence.
Ebert was face down on the ground, kicking his legs around, and had his right arm tucked underneath his body. To prevent
Ebert from kicking my partners, | placed my hands on Ebert's ankles and applied downward pressure. Ebert continued to
move his legs around, | placed my left shin on the back of Ebert's calves and applied downward pressure utilizing my

bodyweight. This force was effective in restricting Ebert's movement. If I had not used force, Ebert could have continued to
kick his legs around and struck one of my partners in the back resulting in injury. Ebert was subsequently detained in
handcuffs and placed in the recovery position. Ebert was assisted to his feet and later evaluated by paramedics on scene.

Line 2: If the suspect was committing a crime and force was used to stop or apprehend the subject, document the appropriate penal
code.  If the UOF occurred in the performance of the officer's duties, document the incident description, i.e. officer transport, officer
escort, making arrest, detaining suspect, cell extraction etc.
Primary Reason for Using Force: Check appropriate box(s).
Subject Appeared To Be: Check if applicable.
Number of Officers on Scene: List number of officers present.
Number of Officers Using Force: List number of officers that used force.
Level(s) of Resistance Encountered: Check appropriate box(s).
L.E. Tool/Technique Used: Check appropriate box(s).  If known and/or applicable, include duration (approximate length of time)
tool/technique was used.  If known and/or applicable, include the number of contacts (approximate number of strikes, impacts, etc.)
Was Initial Use of Force Effective?  If initial force used was effective, check “Yes.”  If initial force used was ineffective and additional
Was Additional Control or Force Needed:  If initial force used was ineffective and additional force was necessary, check “Yes.”  If
initial force used was effective, check “No.”
Target Distance: If applicable (refers primarily to less lethal weapon systems), approximate distance or provide range (i.e. 7-15 feet,
15-20 yards, etc.) from subject during application of force.
Subject Injured: Check “Yes” if medically treated for injury sustained as a possible result of force applied by a officer(s) – does not
include previous injuries suffered prior to officer contact.  Check “No” if subject was not injured or simply complains of injury/pain
suffered as a result of force applied by an officer(s) and refuses medical attention.  Any complaints of pain shall be documented in the
use of force report narrative (whenever any physical force used by a officer results in a complaint of injury or an injury that necessitates
medical treatment of a subject, a supervisor will be notified immediately).
Extent of Treatment: Check appropriate box. Check none if subject was evaluated and no treatment was required.  Specifically, check
“Treated at Scene” if subject was treated at scene by EMS for injuries that may have resulted due to force applied by officer(s).  Check
“Treated at Hospital” if subject was transported to hospital for treatment of injuries that may have been sustained as an apparent result
of force applied by officer(s).  Check “Hospitalized” if subject was admitted to the Hospital as a result of injuries that were sustained as
a result of force applied by officer(s).
Officer Injured:  Check appropriate box (see above).
Extent of Treatment:  Check appropriate box. Check none if officer was evaluated and no treatment was required.  Specifically, check
“Treated at Scene” if officer was treated at scene by EMS for injuries.  Check “Treated at Hospital” if officer was transported to hospital
for treatment of injuries.  Check “Hospitalized” if officer was admitted to the Hospital as a result of injuries.

column1: On June 16, 2024, at approximately 9:00 a.m., Fremont Police Officers responded to a carjacking in
the parking lot of a store on the 44000 block of Osgood Road. The suspect was armed with a knife
and left the scene prior to officers’ arrival. A short time later, an officer located a male subject
nearby who matched the description of the carjacking suspect. The suspect was still armed with a
knife and walking on Automall Parkway just west of Osgood Rd. The officer directed the suspect to
stop. The suspect brandished the knife at the officer and advanced toward him.  Despite numerous
commands to stop, and the officer repositioning to create space and distance, the suspect
continued to advance toward the officer while holding the knife. The officer discharged his service
weapon, striking the suspect once. Officers on scene rendered medical aid to the suspect, who was
subsequently transported to an area hospital. The suspect is currently in stable condition.  No
officers were injured in this event.
Involved Fremont Police Officer: Officer Jonathan Laforteza, two years of service in law
enforcement, with almost a year of service with the Fremont Police Department.  Officer Laforteza
Suspect: Sean Patrick McMahan, 31 years old, out of Fremont.
The Fremont Police Department Crime Against Persons Unit is investigating this incident. It remains
an active and ongoing investigation.  In the coming days, additional cases involving criminal charges
against the suspect will be presented to the Alameda County District Attorney’s Office.
Fremont Police Department is currently developing an in‐depth, detailed release of information, to
include body-worn camera video, store surveillance video, and evidence of the related crimes. This
information is anticipated to be available and released in the near future.
Anyone who witnessed the incident or with information regarding the incident, please contact
Detective Michael Gebhardt at mgebhardt@fremont.gov or by calling our Investigations Unit at
(510) 790-6900 . We also accept anonymous tips. Text 'Tip FremontPD' followed by your short
message to 888-777 or via the web at https://www.fremontpolice.gov/TIP.

Wheelchair-accessible entrances are located on Van Ness Avenue and Grove Street.  Please note the
wheelchair lift at the Goodlett Place/Polk Street is temporarily not available.  After multiple repairs
that were followed by additional breakdowns, the wheelchair lift at the Goodlett/Polk entrance is being
replaced for improved operation and reliability.  We anticipate having a functioning lift after the
completion of construction in May 2025.  There are elevators and accessible restrooms located on every floor.
For questions about the meeting please contact (v) 415.837.7070. The ringing of and use of cell phones, pagers and similar sound-producing electronic
devices are prohibited at this meeting. Please be advised that the Chair may order the removal from the meeting room of any person(s) responsible
for the ringing or use of a cell phone, pager, or other similar sound-producing electronic devices.
KNOW YOUR RIGHTS UNDER THE SUNSHINE ORDINANCE
Government's duty is to serve the public, reaching its decisions in full view of the public. Commissions, boards, councils, and other agencies of the
City and County exist to conduct the people's business. This ordinance assures that deliberations are conducted before the people and that City
operations are open to the people's review. For information on your rights under the Sunshine Ordinance (Chapters 67 of the San Francisco
Administrative Code) or to report a violation of the ordinance, please contact: Sunshine Ordinance Task Force Administrator in Room 244 at City Hall,
1 Dr. Carlton B. Goodlett Place, San Francisco, CA 94102-4683. (Office) 415-554-7724
Sunshine Ordinance can be obtained from the Clerk of the Sunshine Task Force, the San Francisco Public Library and on the City's website at
www.sfgov.org. Copies of explanatory documents are available to the public online at http://www.sfbos.org/sunshine or, upon request to the
Commission Secretary, at the above address or phone number.
Per the Language Access Ordinance (Chapter 91 of the San Francisco Administrative Code), Chinese, Spanish and or Filipino (Tagalog) interpreters will
be available upon requests. Meeting Minutes may be translated, if requested, after they have been adopted by the Commission. Assistance in
additional languages may be honored whenever possible. To request assistance with these services please contact the Police Commission at (v)
415.837.7070 at least 48 hours in advance of the hearing.  Late requests will be honored if possible.
Police Commission hearings are held in Room 400 at City Hall, 1 Dr. Carlton B. Goodlett Place in San Francisco. City Hall is accessible to persons using
wheelchairs and other assistive mobility devices.
Ramps are available at the Grove, Van Ness and McAllister entrances. The closest accessible BART station is Civic Center Station. For information
about SFMTA service, please call 311. This meeting will be broadcast and captioned on SFGovTV.
Assistive listening devices, real time captioning, American Sign Language interpreters, readers, large print agendas or other accommodations are
available upon request. Please make your requests for accommodations to the Police Commission at (v) 415.837.7070. Requesting sign language
accommodations at least 4 business days prior to the meeting will help to ensure availability. Allowing a minimum of 48 business hours for all other
accommodation requests (for example, for other auxiliary aids and services) helps ensure availability. To request accommodation, please contact
Remote public participation is available upon request for individuals who cannot attend in person due to disability. Making a request to participate
remotely no later than one (1) hour prior to the start of the meeting helps ensure availability of the meeting link.
Individuals and entities that influence or attempt to influence local legislative or administrative action may be required by the San Francisco Lobbyist
Ordinance [SF Campaign & Governmental Conduct Code 2.100] to register and report lobbying activity. For more information about the Lobbyist
Ordinance, please contact the San Francisco Ethics Commission at 25 Van Ness Avenue, Suite 220, San Francisco, CA 94102

Grant Street in the city of Calexico to assist the District Attorney's Office regarding an officer involved
At approximately 0115 hours, after leaving the Calexico Police Station located at 420 East Sth
Street, | was asked to respond t(j to process the scene.
Upon arrival at approximately 0145 hours, | met with District Attorney Investigator's V. Dominguez
#208, M. Lopez #212, and R. Peraza #5 who briefed me and gave me a walk-through of the scene. |
was instructed to assist in documenting the scene and collect evidence.
Using a department-issued Nikon D7500 digital camera, | photographed the scene. Moving in a
counter-clockwise direction, took overall photographs of the area. | took overall, mid-range, and
close up photographs of all items with a placard.
it should be noted that placard numbers were placed prior to my arrival.

Next, District Attorney Investigator's M. Lopez #212 and R. Peraza #5, handed over to me a consent
to search to conduct a search on a vehicle. The consent to search was signed by Maria E. Lecia.
| photographed the exterior and interior of a white 2005 Toyota Corolla, bearing California license
plate The vehicle had one (1) suspected bullet hole on the driver side door. |
photographed the bullet hole with and without a measuring scale. The bullet hole measured
approximately half (1/2) inch in length and approximately half (1/2) inch in width.
District Attorney Investigator's V. Dominguez #208, M. Lopez #212, R. Peraza #5 and | conducted a
search on the vehicle, no bullet was found.

broadcasted updates to the pursuit and at times stated the Lexus travelled at speeds in excess of 100mph all while
running numerous posted stop signs. Fresno Sheriff helicopter ""Eagle one"" was responded and took over broadcast
At about Bethel Ave. and Manning Ave. I observed the described white Lexus travelling northbound on Bethel Ave.

At about Manning Ave. and Newmark Ave. I observed a Reedley PD officer deploy stop sticks as the road bottle

As I turned onto J St. I lost sight of the vehicle. ""Eagle one"" broadcasted the vehicle had ""blacked out."" I then

I observed the Lexus make an eastbound turn onto Tulare St. traversing through the residential roadways of Parlier.
The driver of the Lexus once again continuing through posted stop signs. ""Eagle one"" broadcasted the Lexus had
now made a northbound turn onto the major roadway which was Zediker Ave. As I turned onto Zediker Ave. I
observed the Lexus's taillights in the far distance. I trailed the Lexus as it made a westbound turn onto Adams Ave.
once again continuing through multiple posted stop signs on county roads.
At about Adams Ave. and Del Rey Ave. the Lexus began to slow as I observed the Lexus lose a passenger side tire.
Deputy Loredo and I re-engaged and attempted to stop the vehicle by activating our emergency lights and siren. Our
emergency lighting equipment consisted of a steady forward facing red light. The driver of the Lexus then drove
south onto Del Rey Ave. followed by an eastbound turn into multiple mature orange orchards. While driving through
the orange orchards at a high rate of speed the branches and oranges on the trees knocked both my driver and
passenger side spotlights off my patrol vehicle.
In the orchard I lost visual of the vehicle due to the driver's erratic driving. However, ""Eagle one"" maintained visual.
The driver eventually stopped and fled from the Lexus on foot. ""Eagle one"" was overhead and followed the driver as
the suspect ran through the orchard. A perimeter was quickly set by assisting deputies and Reedley PD officers.
At about 0101 hours, K9 announcements were made by deputies utilizing a PA (public address system) from patrol
vehicles. ""Eagle one"" also made PA announcements into the orchard for the driver to surrender. ""Eagle one"" advised
the suspect was making his way through the orchard in a northbound direction. The suspect was about 30 rows
south of Adams Ave. ""Eagle one"" later advised they last observed the suspect in the third row south of Adams Ave.
and he may have attempted to conceal himself. It shall be noted patrol units were on Adams Ave. directly north of the
suspect's location with emergency lighting equipment activated. This possibly caused him to conceal himself rather
than to continue to evade by flight.
Deputy O'Donnell (#11491) utilized his department issued drone and located a possible location for the suspect in
the third row as described by ""Eagle one."" I viewed Deputy O'Donnell's screen and gained a visual representation
and aerial view of the orchard. I observed patrol units directly north of the hot spot's location. Deputy O'Donnell
advised he would utilize the drone's spotlight to help deputies gauge the suspect's location.
At about 0112 hours, I formulated a search team and began a search from a dirt easement westbound into the
orchard. The search team consisted of Deputy North (#11309), Deputy H. Sims (#11545), Reedley PD Sgt. Rivera,
and my K9 partner ""Roy"" and I. ""Roy"" was secured to a 30 ft leash.
At the start of the search I announced, ""Sheriff's Office you need to surrender now, we'll be searching with a dog."" As
we continued the search I again announced, ""Fresno County Sheriff Office K9 unit, come out now with your hands
up, we'll be searching with a dog when he finds you he will bite you."" This announcement was given twice throughout
the search. Given my repeated announcements we received no response.
Deputy North pointed out movement into one of the orange trees. At this point ""Roy"" had not alerted to the suspect's
presence. A plan was devised that Deputy North and Deputy H. Sims would search under the mature orange tree
where it was believed the suspect had concealed themselves.
Shortly after Deputy North and Deputy H. Sims entered underneath the tree I heard them commanding the suspect
to show them their hands. I stood in the orchard row and ordered the suspect, ""surrender or you're going to get bit."" I
then heard Deputy North exclaim, ""he's fighting!""
Due to the suspect continuing to resist arrest and refusing to surrender peacefully, I elected to deploy my K9 partner
“Roy”, based on the following officer safety reasons:
The suspect was wanted for VC 2800.2(a), a felony.
The suspect was wanted for PC 148(a)(1), a misdemeanor.
The suspect was actively and physically resisting arrest.

enforcement during the course of the pursuit.

SOURCE: On December 29, 2023 at about 0038 hours, I attempted to conduct an enforcement stop on a white
sedan for vehicle code violation 22450(a), failure to stop at stop sign at the intersection of Adams Avenue and Lac
Jac Avenue. The vehicle failed to yield and a pursuit ensued.
INVESTIGATION: On the above date and time, I was working uniformed patrol and driving a marked Fresno County
Sheriff's patrol vehicle. At the time, I was traveling north on Lac Jac Avenue approaching Adams Avenue, County of
Fresno, when I observed a vehicle traveling east on Adams Avenue approaching Lac Jac. As the vehicle approached
the intersection, I saw that it failed to come to a stop at a posted stop sign. This intersection as clearly posted stop
signs for traffic traveling east and west on Adams Avenue.
As the vehicle turned south onto Lac Jac, I turned and began following the vehicle. As I followed, I noticed that the
vehicle began traveling at a high rate of speed. I began attempting to catch up to the vehicle and saw that I was
traveling at 100 miles per hour and was not gaining on the vehicle. I then activated my overhead emergency lights,
which included a solid forward facing red light, to conduct the enforcement stop for the traffic violation. The vehicle
failed to yield and continued south on Lac Jac. I then activated my siren and informed Dispatch that I was now in
As the vehicle reached the intersection of Lac Jac and Manning, the driver of the vehicle failed to come to a stop at a
circular red light. This intersection is controlled by traffic lights for all traffic and the light was red for south bound
traffic on Lac Jac. The vehicle continued south on Lac Jac at a high rate of speed until it arrived at the intersection of
Lac Jac and Dinuba Avenue. The vehicle slowed and turned west bound onto Dinuba Avenue. It was at this time I
was able to obtain a license plate on the vehicle as well as a make. The license plate on the vehicle was identified as
and registered to a Lexus 4 door sedan. This make was confirmed by me using the Lexus emblem
attached to the trunk lid of the vehicle.
I continued to pursue the vehicle west on Dinuba Avenue. The vehicle continued at a high rate of speed. The vehicle
reached the intersection of Smith and Dinuba. This intersection is a four way stop controlled by posted stop signs.
The driver of the vehicle failed to come to a stop and continued through the stop sign at a high rate of speed and
continued west on Dinuba. The next controlled intersection was Zediker Avenue where there are posted stop signs
for east and west bound traffic. There are not stops for south and north bound traffic. The driver of the vehicle again
failed to stop at the posted stop sign and continued through the stop sign.
I continued following the vehicle which continued to travel at over 100 miles per hour to the following intersection of
Dinuba And Mendocino Avenue. This intersection has posted stop signs for traffic traveling east and west bound on
Dinuba Avenue. There are not stops for traffic traveling north and south on Mendocino. At this time, the vehicle had
gained distance of almost 1/2 miles ahead of me. As I kept visual of the vehicle, Fresno County Sheriff's air support
unit, Eagle 1 arrived overhead and obtained visual of the vehicle.
The vehicle had reached the intersection of Dinuba and Academy. This intersection is a four way stop intersection
and the driver of the vehicle failed to come to a stop at this intersection. As Eagle 1 advised they had visual of the
vehicle, I deactivated my emergency lights and siren and discontinued my pursuit but continued to follow at a
distance. The vehicle continued west on Dinuba Avenue to the intersection of Dinuba and Bethel where the vehicle
made a north bound turn onto Bethel. The vehicle continued north on Bethel until reaching Manning Avenue where
the vehicle turned east onto Manning.
I continued following the vehicle as well as several other assisting Deputies. The vehicle continued east on Manning

Deputy Sims and I located the suspect about 5 feet off the ground in the tree. The suspect was hiding his hands and
was still trying to hide. Deputy Sims asked him what he had in his hands multiple times.
Considering the following factors, I chose to attempt to force the suspect out of the tree:
The suspect posed an immediate threat to deputies as he just led Deputies on a pursuit that reached speeds
The suspect ran from the vehicle and was hiding while concealing his hands
We had 4 law enforcement officers and a K9 in the immediate area
The suspect was given dozens of announcements by voice, Vehicle PA system, and Eagle One's PA system
It was unknown at the time if the suspect was under the influence of drugs or alcohol
The suspect did not seem to be mentally impaired as he just drove at over 100 MPH and ran from a vehicle
The suspect gave no signs of not understanding how to comply with commands
The suspect was not searched and had a sweater and baggy pants on which could conceal weapons
The suspect had not been restrained
I had a Department issued Monadnock collapsible baton and OC Spray at my disposal
The suspect was wanted for VC 2800.2 (vehicle pursuit with wanton disregard for public safety)
I considered my training and experience with suspects hiding in elevated positions
I considered the possibility of injuries to deputies on scene and the public if the suspect was not immediately
The suspect had already attempted to evade arrest by flight twice
The risk of the suspect escaping would put the public in danger
The apparent need for immediate control of the subject and prompt resolution of the situation
I had never contacted the suspect before
Based on these factors, I grabbed the suspect by his sweater and pulled him out of the tree. As the suspect was
falling out of the tree, he swung his right hand back with a closed fist and struck me in the right side of my face in
The suspect hit the ground and I delivered one elbow strike to his upper right shoulder blade. The suspect
immediately hid his right hand under his body and started flailing all his other limbs in what appeared to be an
attempt to assault myself and Deputy Sims. I advised Deputy Perez the suspect was fighting us.
Deputy Sims yelled at the suspect to give us his hands and to put them behind his back multiple times without
success. Deputy Perez then utilized his K9 (see Supplemental #1 for further information).
The suspect immediately put his hands behind his back and surrendered after the K9 application. Deputy Sims and I
took the suspect into custody and walked him to a patrol car.

) which was a White Lexus Sedan. I searched the vehicle and located a

Less Lethal Weapons Systems: Those munitions that can be fired, launched, or otherwise propelled
for the purpose of engaging compliance, overcoming resistance, or preventing serious injury without
posing a significant potential for causing death.
The circumstances justifying the use of less lethal weapons systems include, but are not limited to:
1.Restoration or maintenance of order during jail or civil disturbances
3.Situations where the first line supervisor or Commanding Officer deem necessary to safely resolve
the incident with a lesser potential of serious injury to citizens and deputies.

Sting Ball Grenade, which is a is a device that delivers rubber pellets, a bright flash and sound. The

initial 1.5 second delay that initiates fuze assembly separation, followed by another .5 second delay
before the blast which is sufficient to project the rubber balls in an approximate 50 foot radius.

On February 21, 2024, at approximately 10:04 p.m., the Calexico Police Department (CPD) requested the Imperial
County District Attorney (ICDA) Bureau of Investigation (BOI) investigate an Officer Involved shooting (OIS
that involved one of their officers who discharged their weapon at a subject. The OIS occurred at a
Calexico, CA, 92231 and involved officers from CPD.
This report documents the initial notification and request for assistance by CPD to ICDA-BOI Commander
(Cmdr.) O. Espino. Below is a summary of the investigative actions taken by Cmdr O. Espino.
On February 21, 2024, at about 10:04 p.m., I, Cmdr. Orlando Espino, received a telephone call from CPD Chief
of Police (COP) A. Orozco advising CPD was involved in an officer involved shooting and that the Imperial
County District Attorney’s Office was being requested to conduct the investigation.
| reached out to ICDA-BOI Chief Investigator Justin Matus, who instructed CPD to contact the California
Department of Justice (CAL DOJ) in accordance with AB 1506. I subsequently relayed this information to COP
Orozco and directed him to contact CAL DOJ, providing him with the necessary contact details.
After a brief period, COP Orozco informed me that Special Agent Sean Richardson from CAL DOJ had advised
him to refer the incident to ICDA. Following this, I contacted Chief Matus, Cmdr. Armstrong, and DAI's Victor
Dominguez, Marco Lopez, Albert Llanas, and Rafael Peraza.
At approximately 11:00 p.m., | reached the general vicinity of the Officer-Involved Shooting (OIS) and was met
away from the OIS scene by COP Orozco and Sergeant (Sgt.) M. Carbajal. From my vantage point, | observed
CPD had secured the area with yellow tape and had assigned a CPD Ofc. to monitor the scene with a log. I then
inquired about the status of the public safety statement and COP Orozco confirmed that it had been furnished to
Sgt. Carbajal. He then proceeded to brief the following:
Ofc. Hernandez and Sgt. Carbajal were dispatched TTD -<carding a reported burglary. Upon arrival,
they observed a familiar male, identified as CHRISTIAN Plancarte, whom they had encountered on multiple
occasions at that location. According to COP Orozco, CHRISTIAN approached Sgt. Carbajal wielding a crowbar
in an apparent attempt to strike him. Officer Hernandez then discharged his weapon three times, hitting
CHRISTIAN once in the torso, grazing his leg, and striking a vehicle in the driveway.
Following the incident, CHRISTIAN received first aid from Sgt. Carbajal, Ofc. Hernandez, and Ofc. Torres
before being taken to a hospital by the Calexico Fire Department. I subsequently departed from the scene and
awaited the arrival of the responding ICDA DAI’s.
Prior to my arrival, CPD requested the Imperial County Sheriff's Office (ICSO) Scientific Investigations Unit
(SIU) assistance in processing both the officers and scene.
Investigator note: On February 26, 2024, at approximately 11:45 a.m., I called COP Orozco and asked if (on the
date of the OIS) he instructed Ofc. Hernandez and Sgt Carbajal to not discuss the incident with anyone except
union representatives or DAI’s. COP Orozco replied he had not.
At approximately 12:00 a.m., COP Orozco and Sgt Carbajal met with the following DAI’s and provided a in
depth briefing: Chief Investigator Matus, Cmdr Armstrong, Dominguez, Lopez, Llanas, Peraza, and me. They
