The incident involving Deputy Maldonado occurred on December 1, 2023, at approximately 0200
hours, when Deputy Maldonado engaged in a consensual sexual encounter while on duty. The
encounter originated from a chance meeting at Safeway parking lot in the City of American
Canyon, escalating when Deputy Maldonado and the complainant, a later
convened in an undeveloped subdivision. Despite Deputy Maldonado's initial refusals of physical
interaction due to on-duty constraints, J persisted, leading to consensual sexual activity in
her vehicle. Deputy Maldonado, expressing remorse, acknowledged the potential policy violation
and ended all communication with a after the internal affairs complaint was initiated. The
detailed account, obtained during the interview conducted on January 16, 2024, offers insight into
Deputy Maldonado's actions, motivations, and the context surrounding the alleged misconduct.
RE: Napa Sheriff's Department Policy 324.3.4 (aa) ~ Performance (Sustained)
1. Complainant's Targeting of Deputy Maldonado: Based on the investigation, it appears
that {J may have intentionally targeted Deputy Maldonado, initiating contact at
Safeway and persisting in her pursuit of him. Gee behavior, making explicit remarks
in public and meeting Deputy Maldonado in an isolated location, raises concerns about
her motives and intentions during the encounter.
2. Threats and Retaliation: J behavior took a troubling turn when Deputy
Maldonado declined to engage in an ongoing relationship. Her persistent attempts to
coerce Deputy Maldonado into continuing the relationship, coupled with threats and
agitation when he declined, suggest potential manipulation and retaliation. This aspect of
the incident raises questions about aa intentions and underscores the need to
consider her actions in the broader context of the encounter.
3. Impact on Deputy Maldonado: Deputy Maldonado’s personal struggles, including learning
about his girlfriend's recent infidelity, may have influenced his judgment during the
encounter. However, the complainant's targeted actions and threats, as described, further
complicate the dynamics of the situation. Understanding the impact of these external
factors on Deputy Maldonado's decision-making is crucial in assessing the incident
4. Complainant's Uncooperativeness: BM almost immediate uncooperativeness after
reporting the incident raises suspicions of a purposeful effort to inflict distress and
simultaneously hinder the investigation. This aspect adds a layer of complexity to the case,
requiring careful consideration of [MJ motivations for reporting the conduct and
5. Policy Violation and Accountability: Deputy Maldonado's admission of engaging in
consensual sexual activity while on duty represents a clear violation of departmental
policy. The circumstances surrounding the encounter, including Deputy Maldonado’s
recognition of the policy violation and his subsequent remorse, are important
considerations in determining the appropriate level of accountability and potential
6. PC 832.7 (B): The provisions outlined in 832.7 (B) of the relevant statute establish clear
guidelines regarding the conduct of peace officers concerning sexual acts involving
Subsection (ii) of the statute states, “As used in this subparagraph, ""sexual assault"" means
the commission or attempted initiation of a sexual act with a member of the public by
means of force, threat, coercion, extortion, offer of leniency or other official favor, or
under the color of authority. For purposes of this definition, the propositioning for or
commission of any sexual act while on duty is considered a sexual assault.”
The investigation conducted into Deputy Maldonado’s conduct on duty did not reveal any
evidence of force, threat, coercion, extortion, offer of leniency, or other official favor.
However, Deputy Maldonado’'s conduct did violate the prohibition against engaging in
RE: Napa Sheriff’s Department Policy 324.3.4 (aa) - Performance
1. Any on-duty or off-duty conduct that an employee knows or reasonably should know is
unbecoming a member of the Department or is contrary to the good order, efficiency, or
morale, or reflects unfavorably upon the Department or its members.
Based on my investigation, with scrutiny concerning {J motivations and her sudden
uncooperativeness, | find that Deputy Maldonado did engage in a consensual sexual encounter
while in uniform and on duty. | also find that Deputy Maldonado was aware that his actions were a
clear violation of department policy that could result in discipline at the least, and his conduct was
unbecoming of himself and the Napa County Sheriff's Department. Deputy Maldonado put the
department and himself in an unnecessary vulnerable position that was completely avoidable. The
dynamics of the encounter should shape the findings, and inform the appropriate course of
action, balancing accountability with an understanding of the incident's nature.
Therefore, my finding regarding the violation of this section is sustained.
With respect to the allegation that Deputy Maldonado’s conduct constituted a
violation of 324.3.4 (aa) - Performance. The finding is:

At approximately 1000 hours, I arrived at the Antioch Police Department.  Upon arrival, I met

is seen entering the storage yard via the rear gate, located at the end of Vineyard Drive.
The panel van then can be seen pushing a white 1987 Chevrolet Monte Carlo (Cal.
) out of the south gate of the storage yard onto E. 18th Street.

On Sunday, October 1, 2023, at approximately 0741 hours, CSO Graham was conducting
his patrol duties, when he noticed a white Chevrolet Monte Carlo backed into the
The Monte Carlo was covered with a tarp.  CSO
Graham noticed a blue panel van backed into the carport next to the Monte Carlo.  CSO
Graham believed the blue panel van was similar to the one he saw involved with the
theft of the Monte Carlo on Thursday, September 26, 2023.  Based on this, CSO Graham
contacted dispatch, and requested assistance from patrol.  K-9 Officer Marques
responded to assist CSO Graham, as did Officer Dibble, Officer Mulholland, and his
Officer Marques arrived on the scene followed by Officer Dibble.  The officers
approached the suspected stolen Monte Carlo, pulled back the tarp, and discovered it
Contra Costa County District Attorney’s Office
was unoccupied.  Officer Marques confirmed the Monte Carlo was the stolen vehicle
CSO Graham had been investigating on Thursday, September 26, 2023.  Officer Marques
then conducted a record check of the blue panel van which had a license plate of
.  This vehicle returned with an expired registration in 2018.  Officer Marques
began looking into the interior of the blue panel van through the side cargo door
windows on the passenger side.  As Officer Marques did this, he noticed someone (later
identified as suspect Daniel Mackin) was sleeping in the rear cargo area of the vehicle
with a handgun lying next to him in plain view.
Officer Marques advised dispatch of this observation, and the officers quickly backed
away from the suspect vehicle and took cover near their patrol vehicles.  At this point,
Officer Mulholland and his trainee, Officer Posey arrived on the scene.  Hearing this
information over the radio, Officer Borg, and his trainee, Officer Armstrong responded as
well.  Officers noticed that Mackin was now awake, and looking out the front windshield
at the Antioch Police Officers surrounding the van.  Officers began giving Mackin orders
to step out of the van with his hands up, however, he did not comply.  Officers Borg and
Officer Armstrong arrived on the scene and took a position near Officer Marques' patrol
At this time, Mackin got into the driver's seat of the van and started it.  Mackin then
attempted to flee, by driving the van through the apartment building's parking lot over a
curb/green belt area, and onto A Street.  The van then hit a utility box, and a street sign
pole, at which time it became stuck.  Officers continued to give Mackin orders to come
out of the van, but Mackin refused.  Mackin began to back up and drive forward several
times, in an attempt to free the van and escape.  At this time, Officer Mulholland utilized
a 40mm less lethal weapon to break out the driver's side window of the van.  After four
unsuccessful attempts to break the van's driver's side window, Mackin fled on foot out
the side cargo doors of the van.
As Mackin fled from the van he was holding something in his waistband or hooded
sweatshirt front pocket with his left hand.  As Mackin fled eastbound on A Street, Officer
Marques deployed his police K-9 to apprehend him.  As Mackin fled he was followed by
Contra Costa County District Attorney’s Office
a small dog that had been inside the van.  The small dog distracted the police K-9, which
prevented the K-9 from apprehending Mackin.  As Mackin ran, the officers could now
see a chrome handgun in his right hand.
As Mackin continued to run east, he turned several times toward the police officers
pursuing him, and was now pointing the handgun in their direction.  The pursuing
officers, then fired several times at Mackin as he fled.  At one point Mackin fell to the
ground and came to rest in a seated position on the north curbline, still pointing the
handgun at the officers.  Officers then fired additional shots at Mackin as he got to his
feet, still pointing the handgun in the direction of pursuing officers.  Mackin continued to
run eastbound on A Street, with the handgun in his right hand.  As Mackin ran, he threw
the handgun, over his head in a northern direction.  The handgun landed on the north
sidewalk of A Street, where it was later recovered fully, loaded with six live rounds.
Once the handgun was discarded, officers verbally announced Mackin had discarded it,
and no other shots were fired.  Mackin ran approximately another 10-15 yards until he
came to a stop, went to his knees, and laid down on the ground in the middle of A
street.  Officers approached Mackin who had sustained one through and through
gunshot wound to his torso.  Mackin was immediately handcuffed, and emergency
medical personnel were requested.  Officers obtained a medical kit from a patrol vehicle,
and began administering first aid.  Fire and ambulance personnel arrived and Mackin
was transported to John Muir Hospital, Walnut Creek Campus.  Per medical staff at John
Muir Hospital, Mackin had sustained injuries to both lungs as a result of being shot.
Mackin was intubated and was being treated for his injuries.

however, he declined.  Officer Borg had nothing further to add, so we ended our interview.

Department Procedure 5.03 – EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY, dated September 2,
A. Members shall be permitted a work atmosphere free from discrimination and
harassment of any form. Members shall not discriminate against, nor harass other
members. It shall be the responsibility of all supervisors to ensure a nondiscriminatory
4. Federal and state law makes it illegal to discriminate on the basis of race, color,
gender, creed, religion, national origin, age, marital status, ancestry, medical
condition (history of cancer), pregnancy, disability, transgender status, or
sexual orientation. The Department’s EEO policy builds upon this foundation
and extends to every employee our commitment to provide a workplace that is
consistent with the law and actively supports and implements behavior that
reflects our Vision, Values and Mission Statement.
All employees shall be treated equally without regard to race, color, gender, creed,
religion, national origin, age, marital status, ancestry, medical condition (history of
cancer), pregnancy, disability, transgender status, or sexual orientation in all employment
matters, including, but not limited to, promotions, transfers, job rotation, training, work
assignments, hiring, merit increases, overtime, awards, and discipline.
1. All employees shall be provided a work environment free from harassment.
Behavior constitutes harassment, as defined by this policy, when it is unwelcome
and unsolicited, offends or otherwise causes distress, and is undertaken because of
a person’s race, color, gender, creed, religion, national origin, age, marital status,
ancestry, medical condition, disability, pregnancy, transgender status or sexual
orientation. Examples include the use of derogatory comments, slurs, jokes, or
2. The City of San Diego and the Police Department have a 100% Response Policy
regarding harassment. The Department prohibits any harassment of employees, as
defined above, and actively responds to all allegations of violations of this
procedure. Such inappropriate conduct may be in violation of this policy and result
in discipline the first time such behavior occurs. Prior incidents of harassment can
be considered when assessing the facts and circumstances of a later complaint.
3. Whether an alleged action constitutes harassment, as defined above, will be
determined on a case-by-case basis by assessing the entire record and the totality of
the circumstances. Factors, such as the nature of the behavior and the context in
which the alleged incidents occurred, will be considered in assessing the allegations
and in determining the appropriate resolution.
1. Retaliation is defined as an adverse employment action taken against an
employee because that employee complained of discrimination or participated in an
2. An adverse employment action can include, but is not limited to, unwanted
transfers, change in work assignment or location, denial of leave requests,
demotions, negative performance evaluations, unsupported discipline, ostracism,
harassment, or other actions that adversely affect the work environment.
3. Retaliation is illegal and should be reported immediately. The Department will
not tolerate retaliation. Any employee found to have retaliated against another
Department member would be subject to discipline.

Whether or not harassment occurred depends not on whether the act was intended
to cause harm, but the impact of the act on the individual’s employment or work
environment.  For example, a person who teases in a sexual or racial manner, or
tells sexual or racial jokes, may create an offensive work environment for another
worker even though the person intended such action merely to be “good fun.”  This
applies to the field, as well as office positions.  If one’s behavior is harassing to an
individual or a group of individuals, it will not suffice that the harasser failed to
It is not a requirement that the complainant be the intended target of the offensive
conduct.  Witnessing offensive behavior between other employees may be grounds
1. Sexual harassment is a form of illegal gender discrimination. It is defined by law

a. Submission to such conduct is made either explicitly or implicitly a term
or condition of an individual's employment

2. Unwelcome is used in the sense that the offended employee did not solicit or
incite the conduct and regarded it as undesirable or offensive.
3. The following are examples of sexual harassment. Behavior that constitutes
sexual harassment as defined by this policy is not limited to these examples:
a. Verbal harassment - sexual innuendo, sexually suggestive comments,
jokes, teasing of a sexual nature, discussing sexual exploits, spreading
rumors of a sexual connotation, or continued requests for social or sexual
b. Physical harassment - unwelcome contact, touching, or impeding
c. Visual harassment - sexually suggestive or derogatory posters, videos,
cartoons, drawings, documents, writings, electronic mail, texting, staring, or
d. Sexual favors - unwanted sexual advances or conditioning an
employment benefit on an exchange of sexual favors.

and was sent by Sergeant David Ramirez. The message was of an elephant with a large penis
with the caption that read “Sometimes you get more than you originally wanted”. Officer took this to
mean “I am the big dick here” or if he was going to get the “dick” meaning he was going to get screwed from

investigation is over, he is going to be retaliated against. Lastly, Officer [said he has not received a

allegation he has filed against Sergeant Ramirez.

This is a confidential sworn personnel investigation.
You may be subject to discipline as a result of this confidential sworn personnel investigation,
should the findings indicate that such action is warranted. Therefore, you have the right to
have a representative present at this time.
The purpose of this confidential sworn personnel investigation is to obtain information to
assist the City of San Diego in determining whether administrative disciplinary action is
warranted against you. The City is not questioning you for the purpose of bringing or
substantiating any criminal charge against you.
You are directed to answer all of the questions posed to you completely, truthfully, and to the
best of your knowledge. You may consult with your representative before answering any
question, but your representative may not answer the question for you. If you refuse to
answer a question, it will be considered insubordination and you may be subject to discipline.
If information indicates that you may be or have been charged with a criminal offense, you
have the right to remain silent and the right to the presence and assistance of counsel.
However, you do not have the right to refuse to answer any question during this confidential
sworn personnel investigation, including on self-incrimination grounds. While you have the
right to remain silent and not incriminate yourself generally, your silence or refusal to
answer during this administrative confidential sworn personnel investigation will be
considered insubordination and may lead to administrative discipline, up to and including
Therefore, any statement made by you during this confidential sworn personnel investigation,
compelled by the threat of discipline, as well as any fruits of those statements, cannot be
used against you in any criminal proceeding.
The City of San Diego has a strong interest in protecting the integrity of its confidential
sworn personnel investigations, preserving evidence, preventing fabrication, and protecting
witnesses from harassment, intimidation, and retaliation. You are directed not to engage in
any harassing, intimidating, or retaliatory conduct toward anyone. You also must not try to
interfere with the investigation in any way. Any violation of these directives may result in
erstand these instructions, please sign your name below.

The subject has sustained four gunshot wounds. There are Taser prongs in the

Gunshot wound #1: This is a wound to the right of center in the chest that is 1 cm
from midline to its inner edge. It is 56 inches from the bare heel. There is a
corresponding hole in the shirt. The wound has a partial rim of soot and searing
from approximately 7-9-10 o'clock that has a width of 1 cm. There is also a
triangle shaped pattern of soot extending from approximately 3 o'clock that
progressively widens toward midline and measures 2 x 2 cm. The marginal
abrasion is the faint. There appear to be 3 to 4 powder stipple marks at
approximately 9 o'clock, 5 mm lateral from the soot margin, that cover an area of
1 cm in diameter. The stipples average less than 1 mm. The exit wound is in the
left axilla 57.5 inches from the bare heel and measures 2.1 x 2 cm. There is no
corresponding hole in the shirt. It would appear that the projectile was trapped
inside the shirt and moved toward the anterior chest when the body was moved,
where the fully expanded projectile was recovered beneath the shirt. The wound
course would be from right to left, front to back, and upward. Gunshot wound #1
shatters the upper sternum and enters the chest cavity at the level of left second
rib. The right chest cavity is unremarkable. The left chest cavity contains 500-600
ml of blood. The projectile exited the left chest cavity at the level of the fifth and
sixth ribs producing a 2 cm in diameter hole. It then exited the skin as described.
it perforated the upper lobe of the left lung. No injuries to the heart, aorta or the
left carotid artery and left subclavian artery were found.
Gunshot wound #2: This is a grazing wound in the left lower abdomen. The
upper edge is 43 inches from the bare heel, begins 5 cm to the left of midline,
and has a downward course from medial to lateral. It measures 4.5 x 1.7 cm and
has corresponding holes in the shirt as well as in the left front pocket of the
Gunshot wound #3: This is a wound that is a perforating wound in the right
forearm just below the elbow. The entrance wound measures 1.1 x 1 cm and has
a halo of soot around it that is most pronounced on the upper outer edge for 3 x 2
cm. The exit perforation is located 4 cm from it and is an irregular stellate wound
with several skin tags around it that measures 3 x 2.5 cm. A probe connects the
two wounds. There is damage to the head of the ulna bone and imaging studies
show what appears to be a fragment of retained projectile. The wound is
examined internally and shows on exploring the wound that the ulna is shattered.
The largest fragment of the projectile is recovered along with two smaller
fragments of lead and copper jacket.
Gunshot wound #4: It is a perforating wound. The entrance wound is in the
anterior lateral left arm 12 cm below the top of the shoulder. The wound
measures 1.1 x 1 cm, has faint marginal abrasion, and shows faint stippling on
the lower and medial edge for 2.5 x 2 cm. The exit perforation is in the posterior
lateral arm 12 cm above and behind the entrance wound. The exit wound
measures 3 x 1.3 cm. The wound course is upward, front to back, and courses
tangentially underneath the skin without damaging the humerus bone.

On 11-29-23, at about 2234 hours, Officer Whitmore and Officer J. Flores were dispatched to the above
apartment complex for a reported domestic violence incident.  The reporting party/victim stated the father of
her child ""socked"" her on her mouth and her lip was bleeding.  The victim later updated the call that the male
suspect was back at her apartment and ringing the doorbell, texting her asking to not call the police and
knocking on the door. Officers Whitmore and J. Flores arrived on scene first, contacted an adult male who
appeared heavily intoxicated at the porch of the target residence. The male was non-compliant, pounding on
the front door while asking the victim to open up.  The male refused to get onto the ground and reached
inside his pockets.  Officer Whitmore requested additional officers.
Officer C. Lane arrived on scene and noticed the male suspect laying on his stomach on the porch of the
apartment.  The suspect continued to refuse instructions to crawl away from the door.  Officer Lane was
unsure if the suspect possessed any weapons as he had not been searched and did not have a full view of the
porch to determine if the suspect could retrieve an item and use it as a weapon.  Officer Lane stated he was
unable to effect an arrest from the position they were in.
Per Officer Lane, in order to gain control of the suspect, take him into custody and prevent his escape, he
grabbed ahold of his left arm and pulled him away from the porch as he laid on the ground.  During the
pulling movement, the suspect's head struck the wood siding of the porch wall resulting in an approximate
two inch laceration to his right eyebrow.  The suspect was taken into custody.
AMR and Salinas Fire were summoned to the scene and provided aid to the suspect.  The suspect was highly
intoxicated, could not sit up without assistance and mumbling incoherent words.  A statement was
unattainable.  The suspect was transported to NMC by AMR for medical treatment where he received 7-8
stitches.  He was medically cleared and booked into jail for felony domestic battery and
Based on the available information, this use of force appears to be objectively reasonable and within policy.

During this use of force investigation, I reviewed body-worn-camera videos, and in-dash vehicle
videos, interviewed officers, interviewed the suspect, interviewed a witness, and read the Salinas
On 10/20/2023 at approximately 1425 hours, California Highway Patrol requested a K9 officer to
assist with a suspect, Ruben Ayon Jr., who was wanted on an assault with a deadly weapon on
an officer. California Highway Patrol officers were pursuing Ayon who was actively fleeing in his
vehicle and making his way towards the city of Salinas on Davis Road. I informed K9 Officer
Anthony Garcia who had just arrived at the station for a second watch briefing of the request.
Officer Anthony Garcia left the station and Sergeant Roman advised he would be Officer
Garcia’s cover officer. Officer Anthony Garcia headed towards the pursuit as it was coming into
the city and at West Alisal and Church Street, the California Highway Patrol turned over the
Officer Anthony Garcia assumed the primary vehicle as he pursued Ayon and Sergeant Roman
assumed the secondary pursuing unit. Officer Anthony Garcia attempted to conduct a Pursuit
Intervention Technique (PIT) numerous times as he pursued Ayon. Officer Anthony Garcia
attempted to conduct the PIT to stop Ayon and prevent any danger to the public. Each time
Officer Anthony Garcia attempted to PIT Ayon, Ayon would brake or maneuver his vehicle side
to side to avoid a successful PIT by Officer Anthony Garcia. The pursuit was approximately 1.38
miles long and went throughout the southside of Salinas until a successful PIT was initiated by
Sergeant Roman in the area of Alameda Avenue and East Romie Lane.
Sergeant Roman took over as the primary pursuing vehicle in the area of Alameda Avenue just
north of East Romie Lane after Officer Anthony Garcia was unsuccessful in conducting a PIT on
Ayon’s vehicle. Sergeant Roman was able to conduct a successful PIT on Ayon’s vehicle as they
were heading south on Alameda Avenue approaching East Romie Lane. The PIT caused Ayon’s
vehicle to head into the driveway of
East Romie Lane. Ayon then reversed his vehicle to
flee, however Sergeant Roman was able to block his exit with his patrol vehicle. Ayon then
struck the patrol vehicle and drove forward back into the driveway of
Ayon pulled into the driveway, Officer Anthony Garcia attempted to pin Ayon’s rear passenger
quarter panel with his patrol vehicle’s push bumper to prevent Ayon from fleeing. Ayon again
reversed out of the driveway and Sergeant Roman drove his patrol vehicle forward, making
contact with the rear-end of Ayon’s vehicle, to prevent him from fleeing.
Officer Anthony Garcia started to yell out verbal commands to Ayon to get on the ground and
turn off the vehicle. Sergeant Roman exited his patrol vehicle and gave Ayon verbal commands
to stop. Sergeant Roman pointed his department-issued firearm at Ayon while giving him
commands. Ayon refused to follow commands and he accelerated forward and was now further
into the driveway. Sergeant Roman then got back into the patrol vehicle and drove the patrol
vehicle to pin the patrol vehicle against Ayon’s vehicle. As Sergeant Roman was getting in his
patrol vehicle and sitting in the driver's seat, Ayon reversed at a fast rate and rammed into
Sergeant Roman’s patrol vehicle. Sergeant Roman’s driver door was still open when the
ramming occurred. Sergeant Roman then accelerated his patrol vehicle and pushed Ayon’s
vehicle into the driveway and up on a wooden fence and lemon tree that was situated to the right
of the driveway. A parked vehicle in the neighboring residence was in the driveway next to the
fence and lemon tree, it appeared the fence and lemon tree rested on the vehicle parked in the
neighboring driveway. This caused Ayon’s front end to be suspended up against the fence and
Several commands were given to Ayon to place his hands up and Ayon disobeyed commands
and continued to reach around inside the vehicle. Ayon also repositioned the vehicle's mirrors to
get a visual of Sergeant Roman who was situated behind him near the patrol vehicle. Ayon
refused commands for approximately 3 minutes and continued to reach around inside the
vehicle. Officer Munoz arrived on scene and deployed the 40mm less-than-lethal kinetic
projectile launcher and deployed (4) foam baton rounds to break out the windows of Ayon’s
vehicle. Officer Anthony Garcia then deployed K9 Bolt into the rear passenger windows to assist
with the apprehension of Ayon. K9 Bolt was able to assist with apprehending Ayon and officers
immediately approached the vehicle to assist with taking Ayon into custody and releasing K9
Bolt from him. Ayon suffered several K9 bite injuries to his upper right arm which required 35
During my interview with Ayon at Natividad Medical Center, Ayon advised he knew officers were
pursuing him and he panicked. Ayon stated he complied with placing his hands up when the
officers shot the window out. Ayon complained of pain in his neck, and he believed it was from
the collision. Ayon agreed if he could do it all over again, he would have pulled over right away
and listened to the officer's commands. Ayon admitted to fleeing from the other pursuing agency
before Salinas Police got involved. Witness
the street from where the pursuit was terminated.
advised he could hear officers give
commands to the suspect several times during the incident.
Ayon presented life-threatening resistance by fleeing after committing an assault with a deadly
weapon on an officer and continued to flee without due regard for the public as officers pursued
him. Ayon also rammed Sergeant Roman’s patrol vehicle while he was seated inside it. Officers
attempted to de-escalate the situation by attempting to conduct PIT(s) numerous times. Officers
also attempted to de-escalate the situation after Ayon rammed Sergeant Roman’s vehicle with
Sergeant Roman sitting inside by using verbal commands to gain compliance. Ayon presented
active resistance by hiding his hands while inside the vehicle as officers commanded him to
place his hands up and stop reaching around the vehicle. The threats officers faced from Ayon
were his actions with his vehicle, the prior assault on the officer that led to the pursuit, and the
repositioning of his mirror in an attempt to get a visual of Sergeant Roman who was behind him.
Officers used intermediate force by deploying K9 Bolt into the vehicle after several minutes of
verbal commands while attempting to gain compliance by placing his hands up.
Based on the totality of the circumstances it is my opinion, that Sergeant Roman, Officer
Anthony Garcia, and Officer Jeff Munoz used reasonable force during this incident and was

On 9/23/23, at approximately 0223 hours, EGPD dispatch received a call from
Eunice APPLING claiming that an unknown subject was banging on her door at
EE. APPLING then told dispatch that the suspect kicked in her
door. APPLING repeatedly claimed she did not know who the person was.
Officer Carlos Rodriguez was first to arrive on scene at approximately 0228
hours. Officer Rodriguez staged one residence south and waited for backup
officers to arrive. Officer Rodriguez then heard a female screaming from within
the house. Given the circumstances, Officer Rodriguez felt that the female may
be in danger and entered the residence.
Officer Rodriguez entered and announced “Elk Grove PD” twice. The front door
of the residence had signs of forced entry. He entered a hallway and saw a
male, later identified as Leroy DANIELS, in a bedroom with APPLING. Officer
Rodriguez ordered DANIELS to put his hands up twice at gunpoint. DANIELS
did not comply and left his arms at his sides.

burglary or home invasion. Officer Rodriguez ordered both APPLING and
DANIELS to put their hands up again and they complied. Officer Rodriguez
ordered APPLING and DANIELS to come toward him three times. DANIELS
DANIELS continued to be verbally non-compliant with Officer Rodriguez and told

DANIELS refused and approached Officer Rodriguez rapidly while yelling at him

LASSEN COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE CONFIDENTIAL DOCUMENT
On Sunday, 12-10-23, | (Deputy Acuna #118) was working patrol in Lassen County. | was wearing a full
department uniform and was operating a fully marked patrol unit. At approximately 1106 hours, | was
dispatched to PY for a report of a verbal fight between family members. Dispatch stated the
reporting party, David Arthur Garfield, reported his son, David Dean Garfield, was threatening him and his wife.
David Arthur stated David Dean was currently outside their trailer, throwing unknown objects at it.
David Arthur stated this incident began because he unhooked David Dean’s trailer from the property power
supply. David Arthur stated David Dean lives on the same property but does not pay bills. David Arthur stated
David Dean has not been sleeping the past few nights and is acting erratic. David Arthur stated David Dean was
currently armed with a baseball bat, but had access to a “sawed off shotgun” in his trailer. David Arthur advised
me that prior to him entering his trailer to shelter himself from David Dean, David Dean “came at him"" (David
Arthur) with the bat. David Arthur explained that David Dean came within 10 feet of him with the bat. David
Arthur stated he was afraid at that moment and thought David Dean was going to harm him with the bat. David
Arthur stated David Dean was wearing a white shirt and a black baseball hat.
While speaking with David Arthur on the phone, | heard David Arthur say something to the affect of, you broke
my fucking window. David Arthur stated he’s had enough and would be loading his pistol to defend himself.
David Arthur stated he would not be responsible to whatever happens to his son. When asked what he meant by
that, David Arthur stated he would shoot his son in self defense if he had to. | advised David Arthur to use sound
judgment and again advised him | was currently in route. | elected to terminate the phone conversation at that
time. This is because of the new developing details | just heard and | believed a Code-3 response was necessary.
| contacted Sgt. Loflin (#110) and updated him on the situation. He agreed a Code-3 response was appropriate.
While in route, Deputy Kennemore (#121) and Deputy M. Lee (#113) advised they were at Milford Grade (OHV
Patrol) and would meet us at Doyle Grade and US 3955S. Dispatch advised us that a CHP Unit would meet us at
While in route, Dispatch received several 911 calls from surrounding neighbors. The calls are summarized as
One caller stated there was a male outside of the residence, acting erratic, and was armed with a shotgun. A
separate caller stated they witnessed the subject (David Dean) chasing his brother down the driveway, while
being armed with a shotgun. Another caller stated they heard several gunshots coming from the residence. As |
arrived on scene, another call came in stating an unknown individual was leaving the residence on foot. The
caller stated the subject that left was wearing black clothing and was carrying a red unknown item in their hand.
| met with all other responding units and a plan was decided on. Myself, Deputy Kennemore and CHP Office
Bruce would be utilizing deadly force options (Patrol Rifles). Sgt. Loflin and Deputy M. Lee would be utilizing non-
lethal options (non-lethal shotgun and 40mm launcher). A perimeter would be set and we would call out David
Dean using a patrol vehicle’s PA system.
Prepared By: Date: Approved By: Date:
LASSEN COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE CONFIDENTIAL DOCUMENT
We proceeded to respond to the residence. While in route, we contacted a female matching the description of
the individual that left the residence on foot. That individual was identified as David Dean’s mother, Donna
Garfield. The red item Donna had was a sweatshirt. Donna stated she had to run away from her residence
because David Dean was threatening them (David Arthur and herself) with a shotgun. Donna stated while she
was running, she heard two shotgun shots being fired. Donna believed David Dean was firing at her and David
Arthur. Donna stated her husband and son were still at the residence and her son was currently armed with a
shotgun. Donna was approximately 500 yards from her property and arrived at her current location by running
through an undeveloped field. | advised Donna to walk further down Doyle Grade and a Deputy would contact
her when the scene is made safe.
We proceeded to the property where | contacted a male (later identified as David Arthur) who was just north of
the property. David Arthur stated he had to run way from David Dean and stated David Dean took “two shots at
me.” David Arthur stated David Dean was still on scene and was possibly in his (David Dean’s) trailer. | advised
David Arthur to leave the immediate area and a Deputy would recontact him.
As we positioned our vehicles, | could hear loud music coming from David Dean’s trailer. Once there was a break
in the music, Deputy M. Lee began to call out David Dean via PA system. Deputy M. Lee and Deputy Kennemore
are part of the LCSO Hostage Negotiator Team. They handled the following communication with David Dean.
David Dean exited the trailer and had a cellphone is his right hand and a Corona beer bottle in his left hand.
David Dean matched the description provided by David Arthur. David Dean continuously spoke about his
displeasure with the LCSO due to a lack of response regarding prior threats made to his son, et is
important to note that David Dean did not contact the LCSO regarding these alleged threats, but rather contacted
a third party in hopes the message would be relayed to the LCSO. David Dean was extremely agitated and
continuously disregarded orders to exit the property and speak with us. David Dean was on the other side of a
locked metal gate that was approximately 30 yards from our location. David Dean spoke with LCSO HNT from
approximately 1150 hours until approximately 1530 hours. During that time frame, LCSO HNT utilized patrol
vehicle’s PA system and was also able to establish communication via cellphone. David Dean continuously
refused to comply with orders. At one-point David Dean entered his trailer and exited his trailer with more
Corona beer. David Dean was also on the phone with his son Bens demanded be brought to the
scene so he could say bye to him. Due to the nature of the call, it was decided ould not be brought to
the scene. David Dean also stated he would fight law enforcement and would not be taken to jail. At one point,
David Dean asked the officers on scene to drop their weapons and fight him.
LCSO SWAT was activated and arrived on scene. | was relieved from my position and | proceeded to act as a
Drone Visual Observer for Deputy Falchetta who utilized LCSO Drone #1. LCSO Drone #1 was utilized as
overwatch for SWAT. SWAT developed a plane to take David Dean into custody. See Sgt. Loflin’s Report for further
details regarding the apprehension of David Dean and statements from Donna and David Arthur Garfield.
After David Dean was taken into custody, SEMSA Medic 5 arrived on scene and checked on David Dean. SEMSA
Medic 5 treated David for a wound to his right-hand index finger and right triceps. David Dean was placed in my
Prepared By: Date: Approved By: Date:
LASSEN COUNTY SHERIFI'S OFFICE CONFIDENTIAL DOCUMENT
patrol vehicle while | photographed the scene.
| walked to the scene and took several photographs of the entire scene with my body worn camera (BWC). The
trailer door was open and | took photographs as | was entering the trailer. To the immediate left of the front
door, inside the trailer, was a wooden baseball bat. | took photographs of the bat in its original location. | later
seized the bat and booked it into an LCSO evidence locker. On the couch inside the trailer was a shotgun. The
shotgun barrel was removed from the stock. The barrel appeared to have been painted with a rhino lining type
paint that was black in color. The stock of the shotgun had a side saddle that contained 5 live 12-gauge
Winchester Super X bird-shot shells. Deputy Meier (#126) advised me that when he rendered the shotgun safe, a
single expended shotgun shell ejected from the chamber. That expended shell was in the same location of the
shotgun. | photographed the aforementioned items in place with my BWC. | later collected the items and they
were booked into an LCSO evidence locker.
| proceeded to photograph the rest of the trailer and search for any additional firearms and ammo. In the master
bedroom, left of the bed was a cabinet. Inside the cabinet, | located an open box of 12-gauge Winchester Super X
Birdshot. Inside the box was 15 live shotgun shells. | photographed the box in place and seized it as evidence.
The box was later booked into an LCSO evidence locker. | took additional photographs of the trailer. All my BWC
footage was later uploaded to Visual Labs.
Due to the statements provided by Donna and David Arthur, coupled with the statements provided by the
additional 911 calls and the evidence seized on scene, | placed David Dean under arrest for the following charges:
2 counts of PC 245 (a) (2) (assault with deadly weapon, firearm), 1 count of 245 (a) (1) (assault with deadly
weapon, non-firearm), PC 594 (a) (2) (felony vandalism), 2 counts of PC 422(a) (terrorist threats), 2 counts of PC
368 (b) (1) (elder abuse), PC 69 (threat of violence to peace officer), and PC 417 (c) (brandish firearm to peace
| proceeded to transport David Dean to Banner Lassen Medical Center to be medically cleared to be booked into
At BLMC, David Dean was treated for his injured (possibly broken) ring finger. While waiting for David Dean’s
treatment, | elected to obtain David Dean’s statement. | activated my BWC and read David Dean his Miranda
Rights verbatim from a prepared Miranda warning card. David Dean stated he understood and wanted to provide
his statement. David Dean provided the following in summary:
David Dean stated the entire incident started due to the prior threats made to his son. David Dean stated he has
not been able to sleep because he was worried about his son’s well-being. David stated he was worried about
the location of his trailer and requested his father move the trailer. David Dean stated his father did not help,
which angered him. David Dean stated this morning, his trailer was disconnected from power. David Dean stated
he did not know who unplugged the trailer. David Dean exited his trailer with the baseball bat to confront the
individual. David Dean stated he realized it was his father who disconnected the power and a verbal altercation
took place. David Dean stated he was wielding the bat at that time but he never threatened his father with the
Prepared By: Date: Approved By: Date:
LASSEN COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE CONFIDENTIAL DOCUMENT
bat. David admitted to having a heated argument with his father and mother but was adamant that no threats
were made. David Dean stated his parents entered their trailer while he was still outside. David Dean admitted to
throwing rocks at their trailer but was unsure if damage was done. David Dean stated if damage was done, he
would pay for the repairs. David stated while throwing rocks, he accidentally broke the passenger side window of
his father’s suburban. David stated he witnessed his mother leave the property on foot. David Dean admitted to
yelling at his mother while she was leaving but again, stated he never threatened her. David Dean stated he was
unaware his father left the property and believed he was still on scene during the entire incident. David Dean
stated he did not possess the shotgun during the incident. End of original statement.
| advised David Dean that we received several additional 911 calls stating he was witnessed being in possession
of a shotgun, chasing a subject off of the property and shotgun blast being heard. David Dean changed his
statement and said he was in possession of a shotgun, but his parents never saw him holding the firearm. David
Dean strongly denied the allegation’s of him firing the shotgun. | asked David Dean if his mother or father have a
shotgun. David Dean stated they did not. | advised David Dean that Sgt. Loflin informed me of several live
shotgun shells being located around his parents trailer. | also advised David Dean that a shotgun wad was located
inside his father’s suburban. David Dean stated that was a lie. | advised David Dean | was not lying to him and he
again stated that was not possible. | advised David Dean that a expended shotgun shell was ejected from the
shotgun when being made safe. David Dean again stated that was not true, and that there should have been 1
live shell in the chamber and 5 live shells affixed to the shotgun (shotgun saddle). David Dean stated the last time
he fired the shotgun was when he fired a warning shot at an unknown individual on a different date. David Dean
stated that incident took place approximately 3 weeks ago. | advised David Dean that his parents both stated
they believed he fired the shotgun at them. David Dean again was adamant that he never fired the shotgun.
David Dean did again state he was in possession of the shotgun during a portion of the incident. David Dean
stated he has a camera on scene that would exonerate himself. David Dean stated the video footage would not
show anything (because it faces the road) but it would pick up any sounds (i.e. shotgun blast). | advised David
Dean | would provided him a consent to search form and view the footage. David Dean stated that he would be
willing to provide consent to search his cellphone for the video footage. End of summary.
| was relieved at BLMC by Deputy Leighton (#130). Deputy Falchetta later transported David Dean to the Lassen
County Jail where he was booked for the aforementioned charges.
All my BWC footage was later uploaded to Visual Labs.
Case status: David Dean placed under arrest for aforementioned charges. Follow- up needed: contact additional
reporting parties for their statements. Obtain video footage from David Dean’s cellphone.
Prepared By: Date: Approved By: Date:

On 12/10/23 at about 1103 hours, |, Sgt. M. Loflin #110, was on duty with the Lassen County Sheriff's Office
(LCSO). | was in full uniform driving a marked patrol vehicle in Susanville. | was notified by Dispatch that Deputy
Acuna #118 was responding to i (0: the report of a domestic disturbance. Dispatch advised
that RP, David Garfield Sr., stated that his son, David Dean Garfield Jr., had chased after him and his wife, Donna
Garfield, with a baseball bat. Furthermore, Garfield Sr stated that David had been drinking and he was scared.
Deputy Acuna #118 and | responded to the aforementioned residence from the Sheriff's Office. While en route,
Deputy Acuna contacted the RP, who advised that David was actively damaging his trailer with a baseball bat. As
a result, Deputy Acuna and | expedited our response by activating our emergency lights and sirens. | requested
Dispatch contact CHP for additional units. In addition, Deputy D. Kennemore #121 and Detective M. Lee #113
responded as well. During this time, Dispatch received two more 911 calls from neighbors advising that they
heard gun shots in the area. Deputy Acuna attempted to contact the Garfield's by phone, to no avail.
At approximately 1140 hours, | contacted victim, Donna Garfield, about 500 yards east of the residence on Doyle
Grade. Donna told me that David was armed with a shotgun, had fired two shots, and Garfield Sr was still on the
property. | advised Donna to stay away from the residence and wait to be contacted by law enforcement.
At approximately 1142 hours, County Units along with a unit from CHP arrived on scene. The property can be
described as a 2.79 acre parcel with several trailer trailers and outbuildings. On the south side of the property,
nearest Doyle Grade, there is a driveway leading to a travel trailer and three 10X12 prefabricated outbuildings. |
was advised that this area of the property was where David stayed. Approximately 25 yards behind David's
trailer, | observed two more travel trailers and another 10X12 outbuilding. | was advised that the Garfield's lived
in that portion of the property.
INITIAL CONTACT WITH DAVID GARFIELD SR:
| contacted Garfield Sr ina field adjacent to the property. Garfield Sr told me that David fired two shots at or
near him with a 20 gauge sawed off shotgun. Garfield Sr stated that David had been drinking all night and was
intoxicated. Also, Garfield Sr told me that David suffers from mental health issues and had been self medicating.
| asked Garfield Sr for David's phone number. | was told that David is paranoid and often changes his phone
number. Moreover, Garfield Sr stated that his phone was still at the residence. | instructed Garfield Sr to wait
down the road with his wife until contacted by law enforcement.
Prepared By: Date: Approved By: Date:
LASSEN COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE CONFIDENTIAL DOCUMENT
At 1150 hours, County Units set up a perimeter and started calling David out of the property. David exited his
trailer and walked to a gate near the driveway. David was unarmed but highly agitated. David was holding a
cellphone in one hand and a bottle of alcohol in the other hand. David refused to exit the gate and come
towards us as instructed. David was yelling at us to leave his property. David made several threats that he would
fight us should we come any closer. David stated that his parents were lying about the incident. In addition,
David stated that he did not like law enforcement because his son had recently been threatened by David
Detective Lee and Deputy Kennemore, who are both certified crisis negotiators (CNT), began communicating
directly with David utilizing their public address system. During this time, David continued to make threats
towards us. David was pacing near the gate and shouting obscenities. Several times during our negotiations,
David started walking back to his trailer. It had been reported that David's shotgun was located inside his trailer.
At one point, David stated that he would retrieve his gun from the trailer for us to inspect. David was told not to
retrieve the firearm, or return to the trailer. David made several statements that he had not fired the shotgun,
other than a warning shot. David continued to state that his parents are liars and he wanted to see his son. At
one point, David's son, Brody Garfield, arrived in a beige sedan. | instructed Brody to return to the vehicle. |
informed the adult driver of the vehicle to take Brody away from the residence, to which he agreed. Afterwards,
CHP closed Doyle Grade to traffic by having Doyle Fire block the intersection of Doyle Grade and US 395.
Deputy Kennemore and Detective Lee continued negotiating with David for more than two hours. During this
time, communications with David would break down and he would walk away or stop talking to us. Several
methods of communication were utilized. This included the use of a PA system, phone calls directly to David,
and direct verbal communication. However, David refused to comply with our commands.
Based on the nature of the call, David's level of agitation, and his refusal to surrender
column2: | requested the Lassen

column1: County Special Weapons and Tactics (SWAT) Team be deployed. In addition, | requested Deputy Falchetta #115
At approximately 1427 hours, SWAT arrived on scene. David was commanded to exit the property unarmed with
his hands in the air. David refused to comply with our lawful orders. CNT with David continued. David continued
At approximately 1445 hours, two three-man arrest teams converged on David. Several commands were given
to David to get on the ground and surrender. David began to run away from us and towards his trailer. Asa
result, K9 Hank was deployed to apprehend David. It should be mentioned
column2: David's trailer door was opened and

column1: his shotgun was reported to be inside the trailer. Due to the fact that David was running towards his trailer with
access to weapons, | utilized my department issued less lethal 40 mm launcher. | fired one less lethal direct
impact round at David. The munition failed to strike David. The round struck a vehicle behind him, causing
damage to the front passenger headlight. David retreated to his trailer and grabbed a sawed off shotgun.
Prepared By: Date: Approved By: Date:
LASSEN COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE CONFIDENTIAL DOCUMENT
Deputy Meier #126 informed units that David was at the front door, inside the trailer, holding a firearm. Based
on the fact that David was armed with a firearm, barricaded inside his trailer, failed to submit to commands, and

column2: | positioned myself in line with David's front door with my less lethal 40 mm

column1: launcher. At one point, | observed David standing near the door yelling at us. | could not see David's left arm.
David turned back inside the trailer and | deployed another direct impact less lethal round from my 40 mm
launcher. The round struck David's right hand and he retreated further inside the trailer. SWAT deployed three
CS aerosol gas canisters inside the trailer. In addition, several mussel blast flash bangs (diversionary devises)
rounds were fired. However, David refused to exit the trailer.
Detective Lee continued CNT with David. After about one hour, David exited the trailer and was placed in
custody. David had visible injuries to his right hand and right triceps. As a result, medical was requested to our
location. David was evaluated and treated by SEMSA medics. Afterwards, David was transported to Banner
Lassen Medical Center for evaluation, treatment, and medical clearance.
Deputy Acuna used his BWC to take scene photos and collect evidence. Refer to Deputy Acuna's report for
At approximately 1607 hours, | responded 1 TE 3: contacted David Garfield Sr and Donna
Garfield for victim statements. It should be mentioned
column2: my BWC had been recording for the entire time | was on

column1: scene and had died. As a result, my conversation with Garfield Sr and Donna weren't recorded.
Garfield Sr provided me with the following statement in summary:
Garfield Sr stated that David had been acting erratically since Friday (12/8/23). Garfield Sr told me that David
had been drinking heavily and self medicating on prescription drugs. Garfield Sr stated that David suffers from
anxiety and depression and had attempted suicide two years ago. Today, David was playing his music extremely
loud, which prompted phone calls from the neighbors. Garfield Sr stated that he went to David's trailer and
turned off his music by disconnecting the power. David chased after Garfield Sr with a baseball bat. Garfield Sr
stated that David was saying, ""I'm going to get you."" Garfield Sr told me that David had a dead look in his eye
and he was worried that David would harm him. Garfield Sr retreated towards his trailer and David started
chasing after his wife with the baseball bat. Garfield Sr stated that David took a bat to his trailer and broke out
the back window. Afterwards, David returned to his trailer and grabbed a shotgun. During this time, Garfield Sr
ran away from the residence. Garfield Sr stated that he heard two gunshots as he was running away from David.
Garfield Sr stated that Donna ran in the opposite direction. Garfield Sr stated that he retreated to a neighboring
field and waited for law enforcement's arrival. End of statement.
| contacted Donna for a statement. Donna provided me with the following statement in summary:

Donna stated that David is violent when he has been drinking. Donna told me that David had been drinking
today and an argument ensued when Garfield Sr turned off David's music. Donna stated that David chased after
her and Garfield Sr with a baseball. During this time, David was making statements that he was going to kill
them. Donna stated that David said, ""You fucking cunt, I'm going to kill you."" Donna retreated to her trailer and
heard David hitting the trailer with the baseball bat. Donna stated that she observed David walk back to his
trailer, so she left her trailer and started running away from the property. Donna told me that David retrieved a
gun from his trailer and chased after her saying, ""I'm going to kill you."" Donna stated that she was in fear and
continues to be in fear from David.
Donna stated that as she was running away from David, she heard two gunshots in close proximity but was
unsure if David had directly fired the weapon at her. This is because

column1: at this time. End of statement.

On Sunday, December 10, 2023, | (Deputy A. Meier #126) was called out with the Lassen County Sheriff's Office
Special Weapons and Tactics Team to assist Deputies with an armed non-compliant subject (David Dean
Garfield). David made statements of fighting law enforcement and was reported to have fired a shotgun at his
| deployed Canine Hank with the SWAT Team. Sergeant Russell, Deputy Lee, myself, and Canine Hank
approached the property and David through a creek bed. David continued to disobey lawful commands to be
taken into custody. Sergeant Russell, Deputy Lee, Myself, and Canine Hank emerged from the creek bed and
approached David. We identified ourselves and gave David verbal orders to get on the ground and show us his
hands. David did not comply with our orders and began running toward the open door of a camping trailer.
| gave Canine Hank a command to bite and released him toward David. There was a car between Canine Hank
and David. David entered the trailer and Canine Hank went to the left. | directed Canine Hank into the camp
trailer giving more bite commands. Canine Hank entered the trailer crashing into the cabinets. Canine Hank
exited the trailer and came back to me.
David came to the open doorway of the trailer and | gave Canine Hank an additional bite command. Canine
Hank entered the trailer and then came back out.
David left my sight and reappeared in the doorway. David held a shotgun in his right hand with the barrel
pointing to the ground. | took cover behind the car and pointed my department issued Glock 17 pistol at David. |
secured Canine Hank and ordered David to drop the gun and show me his hands.
David left my sight, stepping deeper into the trailer. | ordered David to come out and to show me his hands.
David looked through the doorway at me, keeping his body hidden. David showed me both his hands by flipping
me off with his middle fingers. | saw a small dark object in David's hand while he flipped me off. The item was
later identified as an electronic smoking device.
| continued to point my firearm at David while giving hims orders to come out of the trailer with his hands up.

On Sunday 12/10/2023 at about 1155 hours, | (Sgt. D. Russell #107) was notified the SWAT Team was being called
out for a barricaded subject. | was off duty and | am a SWAT Team member. | responded to the Sheriff's Office.
| was notified the suspect (David Garfield Jr) had been drinking alcohol. David Jr was reported to have chased his
mom with a baseball bat while threatening her. David Jr was also reported to have chased his mom and his dad
with a sawed-off shotgun and discharged the shotgun as his mom and dad fled. It was not clear if David Jr shot
Crisis negotiators were on scene and had established communication with David Jr. It was being relayed that
negotiations were good, then bad and unstable. David was continuing to drink alcohol, while units were on
The SWAT Team deployed from the Sheriff's Office with the Armored Rescue Vehicle (ARV). We staged less than
1-mile away from the scene. We were informed negotiations were going good at the time and we stood by. A
short time later, Sgt. M. Loflin #110 advised negotiations were breaking down and the suspect was getting more
The SWAT Team moved into the property and parked in the driveway near Doyle Grade. David Jr was standing
behind a locked gate to the property and yelling obscenities. Negotiations continued as we stood by. David Jr
was continuing to drink alcohol. David Jr had previously told the negotiators, he would fight law enforcement.
David Jr told negotiators his shotgun was in his trailer, which is a bumper-pull travel trailer. The travel trailer was
behind (north) David as he was talking to the units on scene. Negotiations had continued for approximately 3-
hours at this point. It was apparent rationalizing with David Jr to surrender was unlikely.
While negotiations continued, Deputy A. Meier #126 with K9 Hank, Deputy D. Lee #125 and | made our way to a
drainage east of the property David Jr was on. | was equipped with a 12 gauge less-lethal shotgun, loaded with
beanbag rounds. We made our way through the drainage and stayed undetected by David Jr. David Jr's travel
trailer door was open and this is where David said his shotgun was located. We made our way out of the
drainage in line with the travel trailer. We were moving in to cut David off from getting back to his trailer where
As we were trying to get into position behind David, he noticed us and began running toward his open trailer
door. | identified us and gave David Jr warnings, specifically, ""Sheriff's Office, get on the ground, you're going to
get shot, get on the ground, Sheriff's Office."" David Jr quickly made his way to the trailer and was nearing the
door. David Jr was un-searched and | did not know if David Jr was armed. David Jr had already told negotiators
his shotgun was inside of his trailer. David Jr had already told negotiators he would fight law enforcement. |
feared David was going to enter his trailer to arm himself with a shotgun. Furthermore, we were in a position
with no cover to shield ourselves from gunfire. Based on the totality of the circumstances, | deployed one
beanbag round at David Jr's mid-section in attempt to keep him from going into the trailer. It appeared David Jr
was impacted and he stumbled outside the door of the trailer, but he continued into the trailer. | deployed a
second beanbag round as he was in the doorway. | am unsure if David Jr was impacted by that round.
Prepared By: Date: Approved By: Date:
LASSEN COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE CONFIDENTIAL DOCUMENT
Now that David had entered his trailer and was out of sight, | yelled that we were compromised and to seek
cover. | ran to a shed south of the trailer to get cover. Deputy Meier was pinned down behind a car directly
outside the trailer door. Deputy Meier broadcasted that David Jr was now armed with a shotgun inside the
We moved our ARV between Deputy Meier and the trailer. Assistant Team Leader S. Lawton #116 fired 12 gauge
muzzle-blast diversionary rounds at the trailer door as Team member S. Rojas #214 deployed CS aerosol canisters
into the trailer. Crisis Negotiator, Detective M. Lee #113 came up and got in the ARV and continued negotiations
with David Jr. David Jr was refusing to come outside.
After approximately 16 more minutes of negotiating, David Jr continued to refuse to exit the trailer. Assistant
Team Leader Lawton fired 12 gauge muzzle-blast diversionary rounds at the trailer door as Team member S.
Rojas deployed CS aerosol canisters into the trailer.
Detective Lee continued negotiating with David Jr. David Jr asked Detective Lee for five more minutes. When
asked why, David Jr said he was praying and smoking (marijuana). Detective Lee continued talking with David Jr
and told him she would give him five minutes. Detective Lee set a timer for five minutes. Detective Lee
continued negotiations. After approximately six-minutes, Detective Lee told David Jr his five minutes was up and
asked him to come out. David Jr was yelling and not coming out.
David Jr asked for one more minute. After 1-minute, Detective Lee told David Jr it had been 1-minute and to
come out. David Jr did was not coming out. Detective Lee continued negotiations with Dave Jr. 11-minutes had
past since David Jr asked for five more minutes.
David Jr asked for another 30-seconds. After 30-seconds had passed Detective Lee told David Jr it had been
thirty-seconds. David Jr walked out of the trailer with his hands up. David Jr was handcuffed, searched and sat
down ona picnic table. Medical was already staged down the road and was asked to proceed to the scene.
David Jr was walked to the road an treated by medical.

On Monday, 12-11-23, | was conducting follow-up regarding this case.
| contacted Kathy Catron via telephone who provided the following in summary:
Kathy stated she was visiting her daughter at i. As soon as Kathy exited her vehicle, she
heard what she believed was a gunshot. Kathy stated she got onto her daughters porch which looked over the
Garfield's property. Kathy stated she heard a verbal altercation taking place. Kathy later saw a male in a white t-
shirt chasing an unknown subject. Kathy stated the male had an unknown object in his hand but it resembled a
stick. Kathy stated there was approximately 100 feet between both subjects. Kathy stated the subject getting
chased was running away very fast. Kathy stated she heard the male yell obscenities (cunt and bitch) to the
subject he was chasing. At one point, Kathy believed she heard the male yell something to the affect of, I'm
gonna kill you. Kathy stated she saw the subject being chased had a red object in their hand. Kathy later found
out the subject being chased was Donna Garfield. End of summary.
| contacted Rachael Winbar via telephone who provided the following in summary:
Rachael stated she lives iii. Rachael explained she works remotely from home. Rachael
explained she has contacted Donna and David Arthur regarding loud music coming form their son's trailer.
Rachael stated on the morning of 12-10-23, the loud music was again playing. She called Donna and David Arthur
to complain again. Rachael was told they were going to disconnect David Dean's trailer from power. A short time
later (after the music stopped) she began to hear yelling coming from David Dean and Donna's property. Rachael
called back to check on them and she was told they were going to call the Sheriff's Department. A short time
later, Rachael continued to hear yelling and heard a loud noise that she believed was a gunshot. Rachael looked
over to the property and saw two individual's running away from the property in unknown direction's.
Rachael explained she has seen David Dean exhibiting strange behavior since last Friday (12-9-23). Rachael stated
David Dean would play loud music all night. Rachael also stated that David Dean would open all the doors of his
vehicle, play music from his vehicle, and begin to pace around the property. Rachael stated David Dean only did
these strange activities when his son is not present. End of summary.
| later completed two separate suspected dependent/elder abuse reports for David Arthur and Donna. | later
faxed a copy of those reports to the Lassen County Adult Protective Services along with my original report.

On Thursday, November 16, 2023, at about 1305 hours, while at the Lake County Sheriff's Main Office on an
unrelated matter, | was contacted by Detective Antonio Castellanos regarding this investigation. Detective
Castellanos explained that he had received a Consent to Search authorization form from ii i but the
device was noted to have had about 300 GigaBytes (GBs) of data installed, and the resources at the office were
not conducive to conducting a timely extraction, so he asked for my assistance, which | obliged.
On Friday, November 17, 2023, at about 1430 hours, | used the Cellebrite Premium Software as a Service (SaaS)
forensic software suite to successfully conduct a data extraction on the Samsung SM-S910U mobile handset.
On Saturday, November 18, 2023, at about 0846 hours, | returned to the device to Detective Castellanos, and
transferred the data to a secure storage media at the Lake County Sheriff's Main Office. Additionally, | set the
Lake County Sheriff's Office forensic computer to produce the extraction report, which was later confirmed to
have been obtained and viewed by detectives of the Lake County Sheriff's Department.
For further information regarding this investigation, refer to the additional reports.

PLANCARTE, Christian Officer Involved Shooting February 21, 2024
Rafael Peraza Calexico Police Department Calexico PD 24-001058
Attorney's Bureau of Investigation investigate an officer involved shooting that occurred at
treet in the City of El Calexico and involved an officer from the Calexico Police
On February 21, 2024, the Calexico Police Department requested the Imperial County fl
The following report documents the interview of Calexico Police Officer Alexander Hernandez
and a review of the Officer Hernandez’ Body Worn Camera (BWC) footage.
On Monday February 26, 2024, at approximately 1245 hours, Imperial County District Attorney’s
Office (ICDAO) Investigator M. Lopez and I, District Attorney Investigator (DAI) Rafael Peraza,
conducted a voluntary interview with Calexico Police Officer (CPD) Alexander Hernandez, badge
number 547. The interview was conducted at the CPD Chief's Office conference room. Also
present during the interview were CPD Sergeant Sean Acuna and Matthew H. Gelfond, Attorney
with Rains Lucia Stern Law Firm.
The following is only a summary of the statements made by Officer Hernandez during the
interview. For a complete and thorough portrayal of the voluntary interview, please refer to the
audio recording of Officer Hernandez’ interview uploaded to evidence.com.

capacity, and Attorney Matt Gelfond, who is representing Sgt. Carbajal.

Sgt. Carbajal stated he is familiar with the residence, the female resident and individuals who

Sgt. Carbajal stated he had prior knowledge that Plancarte is a convicted felon and is on active

Sgt. Carbajal stated he and Officer Hernandez responded from the Calexico Police Department
and drove out together but took different routes. He stated on his way to the call he inquired about

attempting to break into the residence.
Sgt. Carbajal stated he arrived at the location first and Officer Hernandez arrived a few seconds

he exited his patrol unit and began walking to the target location.
He stated at this point he could hear banging and noises coming from the residence and this led
him to believe there was an active or in progress burglary occurring. Sgt. Carbajal stated by this
time Officer Hernandez was out of his patrol unit and could see and hear him (Officer Hernandez)
Sgt. Carbajal stated at this point he and Officer Hernandez “double timed” it to the front of the
residence. He stated he could still hear banging and believed it was still an active situation. He
stated as he approached the front yard of the residence he illuminated the front door area of the
residence with his flashlight. Sgt. Carbajal stated he saw and recognized Plancarte actively trying
to pry open the front door.
Sgt. Carbajal stated Plancarte had his back towards him. He stated as he illuminated him with his

Sgt. Carbajal stated at that point he identified himself as a Calexico Police Department officer and

it down”, referring to the crowbar.
Sgt. Carbajal stated that due to the circumstances and him having previous knowledge that
Plancarte had been violent towards his mother and law enforcement as well, he told Officer
Hernandez to switch over to his taser. Sgt. Carbajal stated he wanted to have a less lethal force
option available in case they needed it. He also stated that the reason he told Officer Hernandez to
switch to taser was in case the situation was where Plancarte did not want to put the crowbar down.
Sgt. Carbajal stated at this point Plancarte started walking towards him and had the crowbar at his

Sgt. Carbajal stated he verbalized to Officer Hernandez “taze him” because he thought he had his

stated at the time Plancarte charged at him, Officer Hernandez discharged his firearm at Plancarte.
Sgt. Carbajal stated he recalls Officer Hernandez fired two or three rounds at Plancarte.
Sgt. Carbajal stated he recalls Plancarte’s body moves changing. He stated he could tell and
identify that Plancarte had been shot by the way he reacted to the rounds. Sgt. Carbajal stated at
that point Plancarte began to lower the crowbar and fell to the ground. Sgt. Carbajal stated that as
Plancarte charged at him, he (Sgt. Carbajal) had him at gunpoint and had his finger on the trigger.
He stated at that point he was pulling the trigger of his firearm to the breaking point.
Sgt. Carbajal stated that Plancarte charging at him with the crowbar was an imminent threat of
serious bodily injury to him. He stated he feared for his safety due to Plancarte’s actions and
retreated backwards in an attempt to create distance and time. He stated he had Plancarte at
gunpoint and was pulling the trigger on his firearm at the same time Officer Hernandez fired his
rounds, Sgt. Carbajal stated he was getting ready to shoot Plancarte as well when Officer
Hernandez fired his firearm. Sgt. Carbajal stated Plancarte came about ten feet from him and if it
was not for his (Sgt. Carbajal’s) retreat, he believes Plancarte would have reached him.
Sgt. Carbajal stated after Plancarte fell to the ground, he approached him and kicked the crowbar
out of his reach. He stated he immediately began to restrain Plancarte and place him in custody.
Sgt. Carbajal stated he grabbed one of Plancarte’s arm and began to handcuff him and noticed he

Sgt. Carbajal stated he identified Plancarte had been shot in the stomach area and located a second

Sgt. Carbajal stated Officer Hernandez went to the front door of the residence to check on

Sgt. Carbajal stated additional units arrived on scene and he also requested additional resources

DAI Peraza asked Sgt. Carbajal if he had previously arrested Plancarte and he stated he had. DAI

On 11/17/2023, at approximately 1600 hours, I was in full police uniform and driving a fully marked Morgan Hill Police
Department (MHPD) patrol vehicle. At about this time, MHPD Dispatch advised us of a FLOCK activation of a white Ford
Transit van (CA/1498662) that was stolen from the Berryessa Bart Station on 11/17/2023. It should be noted MHPD
Dispatch subsequently conﬁrmed the Ford van was still listed as outstanding with Bart PD. Please refer to Bart PD’s report
Oﬃcer responded to the above location and circulated for the Ford van but were met with negative results. At approximately
1617 hours, Oﬃcer Hall #272, located the Ford van traveling southbound on Butterﬁeld Blvd from Cochrane Rd. Oﬃcer Hall
subsequently advised over the radio they had turned eastbound on Jarvis Dr, and then northbound through an alleyway
Upon my arrival, I saw Oﬃcer Hall traveling northbound through the above alleyway towards Skipper Ln, behind the Ford
van. I directed my patrol vehicle behind Oﬃcer Hall and assisted him as a ﬁll unit. I then saw the driver of the Ford van,
later identiﬁed as Joseph Cardoso drive around a roundabout and back towards Jarvis Dr. Joseph then drove westbound
on Jarvis Dr, towards Butterﬁeld Blvd, but unexpectedly stopped and parked.
Joseph opened the driver door and began to argued with us. I gave Joseph approximately ﬁve or more opportunities to exit
his vehicle, but he refused. I also informed Joseph that his failure to listen to my commands could result in force or deadly
force used against him. However, Joseph kept arguing and refused to follow our commands.
Joseph subsequently initiated a failure to yield and sped off westbound on Jarvis Dr, towards Butterﬁeld Blvd. It should
be noted Oﬃcer Broyer #193 was primary in the pursuit, Oﬃcer Hall #272 was secondary and I was third. Oﬃcer Broyer
attempted a PIT (precision immobilization technique) but was unsuccessful due to Joseph’s erratic driving. Please refer to
Oﬃcer Hall and Oﬃcer Broyer reports for further details on the pursuit.
It should be noted Cpl. Silva deployed his stop sticks in attempt to deﬂate/spike the tires so it could become disable. Please
refer to Cpl. Silva’s supplement report for further details.

On 11/17/2023, at approximately 1559 hours, MHPD oﬃcers received an Automated License Plate Reader notiﬁcation
of a stolen white 2016 Ford Transit Van (CA Exempt: 1498662) traveling westbound on Cochrane Road from US 101.
Oﬃcers located the vehicle and initiated a felony vehicle stop. The driver initially yielded but was uncooperative and verbally
assaultive towards oﬃcers. The driver ﬂed from oﬃcers and a pursuit was initiated. The pursuit lasted approximately 4
minutes and 24 seconds and covered approximately 2.76 miles. During the pursuit, the driver ran multiple red lights, drove
on the opposite side of the road, drove above the posted speed limits, and drove with a disregard for public safety. The
driver eventually yielded at the dead end of a residential neighborhood and stepped out of the vehicle. He continued to
disobey lawful orders, made furtive movements, refused to show oﬃcers his hands, and re-entered the vehicle. Less lethal
munitions were deployed and the driver was taken into custody without further incident. He was identiﬁed as JOSEPH
CARDOSA. JOSEPH, in addition to the on-viewed charges, had an outstanding Felony bench warrant ($20,000 bail) out of
San Jose PD for 10851(a) CVC and 368(c) PC. The warrant was conﬁrmed and JOSEPH was placed under arrest. He was
where he was admitted. JOSEPH was issued a Notice to Appear for the warrant
and released to hospital staff pursuant to 849(a) PC for the on-viewed offenses.
Case forwarded to DA for review.

cation of a stolen white 2016 Ford Transit Van (CA Exempt: 1498662) traveling westbound on Cochrane Road from US 101.

As I continued following the vehicle, I could see that the driver appeared to be a Hispanic Male Adult, approximately 35 years

I continued following the vehicle as it turned northbound onto Skipper Lane. The driver continued driving at a very slow
speed as it approached a roundabout on Skipper Lane, between Cochrane Road and Jarvis Drive. The driver bypassed three
exits in the roundabout making a full 180-degree turn, southbound on Skipper Lane. Based on those observations and the
decision to make a full 180-degree turn on the roundabout it was apparent to me that the driver was now aware he was
