me to be discreet while attempting to follow the stolen vehicle as I was in a large Ford Explorer painted black and white with
police lights and decals on all sides. That information immediately created an advantage for the driver of the stolen vehicle
as I was now going to be forced to react to whatever action he made. As we exited Skipper Lane back onto westbound
Jarvis Drive I saw Oﬃcer Rocha arrive and pull along side me.
The driver of the stolen vehicle elected to stop his vehicle on the north side of Jarvis Drive, facing west, which forced me
to respond. Based on my training and experience I know that suspects involved in criminal behaviors will often attempt
to ambush oﬃcers when it becomes obvious that they cannot avoid police contact. I have watched police videos and
attended police training where I was exposed to vehicular ambushes. I was concerned that the driver of this stolen vehicle
was attempting to do the very same thing and recognized that the most appropriate response to an occupied stolen vehicle
was a high-risk felony car stop. I immediately activated my patrol vehicle’s emergency overhead lights and manual siren
to alert the driver of the stolen vehicle that the Morgan Hill Police Department were now detaining him. I exited my patrol
vehicle to conduct a high-risk vehicle stop along with Oﬃcer Rocha #287. Oﬃcer Rocha was in a better position to give
verbal commands as he was angled towards the driver’s side door. I heard Oﬃcer Rocha give multiple commands to include
a Use of Force Admonishment pursuant to 835a PC.
Immediately after activating my lights and siren, the driver of the vehicle opened the driver door. Based on my training and
experience, I recognized this to be a “pre-ﬂight indicator” commonly displayed by criminals who plan to run from oﬃcers,
or plan to ambush/assault oﬃcers. I have made thousands of car stops and have been involved in more than a hundred
high-risk felony car stops. Opening the door of a vehicle immediately upon police contact is not a common behavior of
people who have been stopped by the police for a regular/low key traﬃc violation. Based on my own training and experience
I know that opening a door is a typical behavior associated to a person harboring criminal or nefarious intent. This speciﬁc
behavior prompted Oﬃcer Rocha #287 and I to give the driver clear commands to show oﬃcers his hands and comply with
our lawful and simple commands. The driver appeared to have something in his left hand which was later determined to

column2: however,

column1: de-escalation is only a tool that police can offer. We cannot force a person to accept that offer and it is their actions and

After approximately 4 minutes the stolen car was driving eastbound on Cochrane Rd towards Sutter Blvd when Cpl. Silva

column2: however, when the

column1: vehicle continued further east on Cochrane Rd I knew it was heading for a high pedestrianized area. The Target shopping

Upon termination of the pursuit, the driver drove the vehicle onto the sidewalk and front yard of 1400 Golden Eagle Drive. The

Oﬃcer Broyer #193 positioned his patrol vehicle behind the suspect vehicle, and I positioned my patrol vehicle north of the

The suspect continued to disobey commands and made frequent gestures with his hands. The suspect then began reaching

There were many unknown factors to consider at the time of this rapidly evolving event.
• Who the driver was and why he ﬂed from the police.

Understanding the nature of such rapidly evolving events I also recognized the following was happening and failing to take

• The driver was lawfully detained and would be placed under arrest.
• The driver was not compliant with oﬃcers.
• The driver jumped out of his vehicle to force a confrontation with oﬃcers and that was not typical behavior.
• The driver would not follow commands to keep his hands where oﬃcers could see them.
• The driver repeatedly reached into his front pants pockets, which is where police oﬃcers know many criminal actors
• The longer a confrontation continues between a combative subject and the police the greater the likelihood of a

On 11/17/2023 (Friday), at approximately 1617 hrs, I (Sergeant Woodrow #247) was wearing my full Morgan Hill Police
Department (MHPD) uniform and driving a fully marked MHPD vehicle (#165) when I responded to the area of Jarvis Dr
and Butterﬁeld Blvd on report of a high-risk felony car stop on a stolen vehicle.
As I was enroute I heard the vehicle ﬂed from oﬃcers attempt to make the arrest on Jarvis Dr. I stopped my vehicle on Main
Ave at Butterﬁeld Blvd to deploy spike strips/stop sticks as the vehicle may have chose to drive southbound on Butterﬁeld
Blvd. I was set up when I heard the vehicle travel in the opposite direction. I got back inside my vehicle and responded to a
I heard the vehicle was driving towards Monterey Rd on Cochrane Rd and I drove westbound on Jarvis Dr to Monterey Rd
to set spikes and prevent a stolen vehicle ﬂeeing towards the downtown area.
The vehicle made an unexpected U-turn at Monterey Rd and Cochrane Rd traveling eastbound again. I sent a unit to the
US 101 ramp to set spikes and heard Cpl. Silva was set at Sutter Blvd and Cochrane Rd. Cpl. Silva stopped traﬃc and
successfully and safely deployed spike strips into the #2 lane of eastbound Cochrane Rd at Sutter Blvd. The rear driver's
side tire hit the spike strips and started to deﬂate.
I heard the vehicle pursuit continue onto Golden Eagle Dr and I requested MHPD Communications advise me of the ""C side""
which is recognized in policing as the street adjacent to the target location. The purpose of the ""C side"" is to set a perimeter
and prevent a foot pursuit or continued chase. As I arrived on scene I saw that the ""C side"" was an open ﬁeld and not a good
location for me to drive so I pulled into Golden Eagle Dr to assist with the apprehension of the suspect and to supervise the
As I arrived I saw multiple residents and children in the street and potentially in danger as we did not know what weapons
the suspect had. Based on my training and experience, I knew one of the most dangerous circumstances for police oﬃcers
is when they are forced to take a suspect into custody. Adding a non-cooperative or combative suspect greatly enhances
that danger. Adding to that volatility was the fact that the arrest was a high-risk felony car stop with ﬁrearms drawn and
a statistically greater likelihood of the suspect possessing weapons, creates one of the most unpredictable and volatile
situations police oﬃcers are asked to resolve.
My ﬁrst priority was the safety and security of the community. I gave verbal instructions for the residents to retreat to their
homes and away from the scene and line of ﬁre.
My secondary priorities were the safety of the suspect and my fellow oﬃcers. I heard Ofc. Hall request permission to use
his less-than-lethal shotgun and trusted his judgement to utilize the de-escalatory tool in a manner consistent with policy
and law. I advised that I was arriving to the scene and I had the department-issued shield to assist with a safe apprehension

I then used my in-car public alert system (loud speaker) to give the driver clear commands and instructions.
I identiﬁed all oﬃcers on scene as Morgan Hill Police Oﬃcers, I then warned the occupant(s) that failure to follow the
commands of the oﬃcers could result in a use of force including deadly force pursuant to 835a PC.
I continued to offer de-escalation by:
1. Offering clear commands to put his hands out of the window.
2. Keep both  hands outside the vehicle where we can see them.
3. Explaining that we do not want to hurt the occupants but want to give them a safe way to be taken into custody.
4. Explaining what could be a consequence of not following commands (TASER, less-lethal, deadly force)
5. I spoke in a clear and calm voice using family friendly language and ﬁnishing each command with a ""please"".
I could see that the driver had placed one hand outside the vehicle but his other hand was not visible. I explained he was
not helping himself by failing to follow the instructions and I saw him comply and show both hands outside the window.
The driver ultimately exited the vehicle as instructed and kept his hands visible allowing the oﬃcers to approach with the
shield and take him into custody without further incident.

Automated License Plate Reader (ALPR) notiﬁcation on a reported stolen white FORD Transit van (CA Lic #1498662) in
the area of eastbound Cochrane Road and US 101 Freeway to circulate for the vehicle.
I drove northbound on the US 101 Freeway to Bailey Avenue and did not locate the vehicle. I drove southbound on the US
101 Freeway to return back to the city. While I was in heavy traﬃc on the US 101 Southbound freeway, Oﬃcer Hall (L272)
advised he had located the vehicle in the area of Butterﬁeld Boulevard and Cochrane Road. Shortly after, Oﬃcer Hall advised
he was conducting a high risk stop on the vehicle. I responded Code-3 (emergency lights and siren) from approximately
1 mile north of the Cochrane Road exit. Oﬃcer Hall advised the driver closed the door, and knowing the high-risk involved
with an uncooperative felony suspect in a felony vehicle stop, I continued driving to his location. Oﬃcer Rocha advised he
was with Oﬃcer Hall and Oﬃcer Broyer advised he was on scene shortly after.
As I approached Cochrane Road and Skipper Lane, Oﬃcer Hall advised the vehicle was taking off from them. I saw Oﬃcer

custody and Fire and EMS arrived on scene to assess JOSEPH.

Officers were dispatched to a burglary in progress. Officers arrived on scene and contacted the suspect's which
resulted in an Officer Involved Shooting. (A) Sergio Vargas Garibay, (A) Jose Aguilar, and (A) Brenda Prado were
taken into custody. Tracy Police Department's General Investigation Unit responded and assumed the investigation.
On 11/19/2023 (Sunday) at 0335 hours, I (1L22) was dispatched to 6653 Hopkins Road (Best Buy Warehouse)
regarding a burglary in progress. I arrived on scene at approximately 0345 hours.
The security guard at the business advised Tracy Police Dispatch two males were breaking in on the side of the
business. The security guard was on site and watching from the camera system at the guard shack. The subjects
were on the west side of the building. Both subjects were wearing all black with ski masks and driving a gray Infiniti
SUV. The security guard continued to provide information to dispatcher's and provided the license plate of the Infiniti
. The subjects broke into one of the trucks and were on the east side of the building on Hopkins.
The reporting party lost visual, and Officers arrived on scene.
While enroute to the called location, I heard Officer Bourassa via radio advise he along with Officer Ortega and
Officer Macias were checking the parking lot. Shortly after, I heard ""Shots Fired"" and two suspects were running
towards the north side of the parking lot. There were two suspects detained at the scene.
I arrived at the location and went to the north side of the scene on Promontory Parkway. I asked on the radio if all
Officers were okay at the scene of the Officer Involved Shooting. I had no other update and attempted drive to the
scene but could not get to them from the east. I went back to the north end and determined we did not have a
perimeter. I began setting up a perimeter and then drove the scene of the Officer Involved Shooting. Once at the
scene, I was informed a female later identified as (A) Brenda Prado was in the back seat of a patrol vehicle. Officers
on scene were tending to (A) Sergio Vargas Garibay who was struck by gunshots. Shortly after, American Medical
Response arrived on scene and paramedics tended to Sergio. Sergio was later transported to San Joaquin County
General Hospital for medical care and Officers at the scene were not injured.

notified me of an Officer Involved Shooting and to report to the Tracy Police Dept. The crime scene was located at

This supplemental report documents evidence collected in relation to this officer involved shooting investigation.
Refer to original report for further details.
On 11/19/23, while serving as the on-call Crime Scene Technician, I received a call from the Crime Scene Unit (CSI)
supervisor M. Tankersley at approximately 0432 hours. I was requested to respond to work to assist with an officer
involved shooting investigation. I arrived at Tracy Police Department (TPD) at approximately 0523 hours and was
requested to take overall photographs of Officer Bourassa (who was one of the officers involved in the shooting).
I met with Officer Bourassa at the Corporal office and, using my department issued Nikon camera, took overall
photographs of Officer Bourassa with and without his outer carrier vest. Refer to PHOTOGRAPHIC EVIDENCE ITEM
for details. It should be noted photographs were taken with and without a photographic identification
card, which includes a full color chart and measuring scale.
After taking photographs of Officer Bourassa, I was advised that the General Investigations Unit (GIU) and CSI unit
would be having a briefing at approximately 0700 hours to discuss the investigation before heading to the scene.
After the briefing, myself, CST P. Valles, and CST T. Santillan met with Department of Justice (DOJ) Criminalist's at
Senior DOJ Criminalist Meagan Gallagher and her team took their own photographs of all three officers involved in
the shooting and conducted a round count of all officer’s service firearms. While they were conducting a round count
for Officer Bourassa's service firearm, I took photographs of the Glock pistol, pistol magazines and live ammunition.
for details. CST Valles and CST Santillan took
photographs of the other officers involved. Refer to their reports for further details.
After completing the round count for Officer Bourassa, Criminalist Gallagher provided me with the following items (to
be immediately booked into evidence so it could be released to DOJ's possession afterwards):

EVIDENCE ITEM 23-06009-7- GLOCK 9MM PISTOL MAGAZINE FROM OFFICER BOURASSA'S OUTER
EVIDENCE ITEM 23-06009-8- LIVE ROUND LOCATED IN ITEM 7 WITH HEADSTAMP ""WIN 9MM LUGER""

This report documents my actions during this incident. I completed search warrants for the officer involved shooting.
On 11/19/2023 I was assigned to the General Investigation Unit as a Detective at the Tracy Police Department. I was
assigned to assist with this investigation.
I completed a search warrant for 6653 Hopkins Road, Tracy, Ca. This is the Best Buy warehouse where the shooting
took place. The search warrant was approved and signed by San Joaquin County Judge Lauren Thomasson.
I then completed a search warrant requesting a DNA sample for the following subjects involved:
Sergio Vargas Garibay, date of birth 011/01/1984, described as a Hispanic male, approximately 5”10 tall, weighing
Brenda Prado, date of birth 11/09/1996, described as a Hispanic female, approximately 5’01 tall, weighing
Jose Aguilar, date of birth 05/29/1987, described as a Hispanic male, approximately 5”04 tall, weighing
The search warrant was approved and signed by San Joaquin County Judge Thomasson.
I was informed by Detective Ortiz the following cell phones were located inside the suspects vehicle:
Blue Motorola Android cell phone. Unknown make or model. Located in the front passenger seat of the Infiniti
Black Samsung Android cell phone. Unknown model.
I completed a search warrant for the two cellphones which were signed and approved by San Joaquin County Judge
All information was provided to Detective Steele and Detective Ortiz.

crime scene log. At 0611 hours, I began the crime scene log on the property of the Best Buy Warehouse (6653
Hopkins Road, Tracy, CA). I was located on the south side east side of the warehouse. At 1655 hours all
investigative personnel cleared from the scene.

The purpose of this supplemental report is to document my actions while assisting officers with this investigation. I
responded as the on-duty watch commander. I received a phone call from Corporal Smith who was the shift
supervisor, and he gave me a brief summary and advised that officers were involved in an officer involved shooting.
When I responded to the scene, I advised (I) Officer Manjit Singh to accompany (V) Officer Adrain Macias to the
police department and (I) Officer Manuel Fong to accompany (V) Officer Joseph Bourassa to the police department.
Prior to Officer Macias leaving the crime scene I secured his department issued M4 Carbine that he had slung over
his body. The rifle was secured in my department vehicles locked security box.
On 11-19-23, at 0413 hours, I received a phone call from Corporal Smith who was the on-duty supervisor on patrol. I
was the on-duty watch commander and was at home. Corporal Smith told me one of the officers on-duty had been
involved in an officer involved shooting while the officer(s) were investigating a in-progress burglary. While on the
phone Corporal Smith told me the scene was still active and there were 2 outstanding suspects. I told him I would
respond from home, and I notified Lieutenant Tim Bauer from the Bureau of Investigations on his phone.
I responded in my department issued vehicle and responded straight to the scene. When I arrived, I notified dispatch
via my police radio that I was on scene.
I met with Corporal Smith on scene and I learned that 3 officers were involved in the shooting. He told me officers
Ortega, Macias, and Bourassa were involved and had already provided him a public safety statement. At this point
we had called in the next shift of officers to assist and assigned Officer Manjit Singh to accompany Officer Adrian
Macias and Officer Manuel Fong to accompany Officer Joseph Bourassa to the police department. The officers were
instructed to not speak to each other regarding the investigation and to wait for investigators at the police
Prior to Officer Macias leaving with Officer Singh, I saw he had his department issued M4 Carbine rifle slung over his
body. I told him I would secure the rifle for the investigation.
I put on latex gloves and made the rifle safe. I removed the magazine and the round that was in the chamber. This
was recorded by Officer Macias' body worn camera. The rifle was placed in my department issued vehicle and
remained in my possession until it was collected by evidence technicians for further processing.
While waiting for investigators to respond to the scene I assisted Corporal Smith with keeping the crime scene
secure. We utilized officers for scene security and crime scene logs. While waiting, Corporal Smith and I walked the
area of the crime scene where the suspect vehicle came to a stop, and I relayed to Lt. Bauer a general overview of
Later in the morning, CST Tania Santillan responded to the scene. I met with her near the crime scene but on the
south end of the large warehouse.
At 1008 hours, CST Santillan and I photographed the rifle. I assisted in securing the chamber with a safety tag. She
photographed the rifle, magazine, and the round I removed from the chamber.
OCCURENCE START DATE / TIME - OCCURENCE END DATE / T ME

On 11/19/2023 at approximately 0441 hours, CST Supervisor M. Tankersley contacted me and requested my
assistance with an officer involved shooting investigation. I responded from my residence and arrived at the Tracy
When I arrived, Sgt. Silva instructed me to only take overall photos of Officer A. Macias. I took overall photos of

Officer Macias’ uniform pants with and without a measurement scale. Detectives advised a briefing would be held at
0700 hours including the District Attorney’s Investigators (DAI) prior to doing anything further and responding to the
After briefing, I met with Corporal K. Steele and the Department of Justice (DOJ) Criminalists to further photograph
) and magazines in the presence of Officer Macias’ lawyer
(photos TS 58-100). Meagan Gallagher, DOJ Senior Criminalist, conducted a round count of Macias’ Glock 17 and
each of Officer Macias’ magazines (located on his uniform). Corporal Steele advised the Glock and magazines did
not need to be collected as the Glock was not the weapon discharged by Officer Macias.
Sgt. Silva advised DOJ Criminalists would take possession of the rifles discharged by officers during the incident
which were still located at the scene. I left Tracy PD and responded out to the scene at approximately 1003 hours
which was located at 6653 Hopkins Rd (Best Buy Warehouse), . When I arrived, the scene was secured with yellow
crime scene tape and patrol vehicles. I checked in with Officer A. Taylor who was maintaining the crime scene log.
Lieutenant R. Hernandez had the rifle discharged by Officer Macias secured in his assigned unmarked vehicle.

. I photographed the rifle, magazine and ammunition (photos TS 101-133). I released the
M4 Carbine rifle, magazine, and ammunition to M. Gallagher on scene.
Lieutenant Hernandez advised Officer Macias had additional magazines located in his assigned patrol vehicle #5416.

The purpose of this supplemental report was to document the presentation of a photo lineup that was prepared by
Detective Ken Steele and presented by me on 11/19/23.
On 11/19/23 I was working as a Tracy Police Officer Unit F7, and I was dressed in full Tracy Police Department
uniform and wearing AXON body cameras. At approximately 1710 hours, I was contacted by Detective Lissette Ortiz
who requested that I present a photo lineup to Jose Aguilar regarding case number 23-06009.
I contacted Jose at approximately 1725 hours, at the Tracy Police Department North Annex located at 333 Civic
Center Dr, Tracy. in order to conduct a photo lineup. It should be noted that Detective Ken Steele prepared the photo
lineup, and he did not tell me who the allege suspect was in the photo lineup. I contacted Jose and I read Jose the
Simmons advisement. Jose understood the advisement and he identified photo number 1 as his friend. (It should be
noted the photo lineup was presented in the following order: 6,2,1,3,5,4)
I asked Jose how sure he was regarding the subject he identified, and Jose advised he was 100 percent sure. Jose
advised he recognized the subject in the picture because he has the same eyes, hair, and face as his friend who he's
known for a while. (It should be noted Sergio Vargas Garibay was the subject in photo number 1)
I advised Detective Lissette Ortiz of the above information.
On 11/24/23 I booked the hard copy of the photo lineup at the Tracy Police Department property division as
Hard copy of the photo lineup.
Supplemental only, attach to the original report.

This is to document my involvement in the search for outstanding suspects from a commercial burglary and being
On 11-10-23 at 0359 hours, I was called by TPD Dispatch to respond with K9 Zak to assist with a search of two
outstanding suspects that fled on foot from a commercial burglary. I responded to the area of Best Buy, located at
I first assisted Officer B. Singh in clearing the opened semi-trailers with use of K9 Zak. Due to several Officers in the
area, I placed K9 Zak on a 25’ long line. I gave a K9 announcement at 0437hours, prior to beginning our search. We
searched the area, finding numerous trailers where their locks were cut, but no one was located.
Ofc. B. Singh and I then checked the field just east and northeast of the location on foot.
Officer R. Figueroa located what appeared to a be a long-sleeved shirt on the roadway on the westbound lanes of
Promontory Pkwy believing it to have been discarded by one of the outstanding suspects. I attempted to have K9
Zak see if he could pick up scent to possibly attempt a track, but K9 Zak did not appear to do so.
Ofc. B. Singh and I went to clear the semi-trailers to the north of the location, finding an open gate and a cut lock on
the ground. As we were beginning to clear the area when drone operator Officer J. Jamora advised he located
someone in the open field just north of the location, north of Promontory Pkwy.
Ofc. B. Singh and I responded to the location and located a male subject, later identified as (S) Jose Aguilar, laying
in the field. We initiated a high risk stop, along with Officers Taylor and Figueroa. I had K9 Zak out of the vehicle,
holding him by his harness. I made a K9 announcement at 0530 hours and Ofc. B. Singh proceeded to give
commands to Aguilar. Aguilar was taken into custody without incident. I walked back to my patrol vehicle and
I responded back to the north side of the business and proceeded to finishing clearing the semi-trailers with Ofc.
Taylor. No one was located in the area.
I remained on scene where the open gate and lock was found on the ground until I was relieved by Officer Trine.

was directed to respond to the Tracy Police Department (1000 Civic Center Drive) to assist with an officer involved
shooting investigation. I arrived at the Tracy Police Department at approximately 0525 hours.
I was advised that the General Investigations Unit and CSI Unit would be having a briefing at approximately 0700
hours, to discuss the investigation and tasks before heading to the scene. Once the briefing concluded, I was tasked
to photograph Officer Ortega and his equipment.
I met with Officer Ortega in the Emergency Operations Center, located within the Tracy Police Department, at
approximately 0800 hours, and advised him that I would photographing him and his equipment. Using my
department assigned Nikon camera, I photographed overall views of Officer Ortega in uniform, with and without his
outer carrier vest. Photographs were taken with and without a photographic identification card, which includes a full
color chart and measuring scale All 42 digital photographs of Officer Arturo Ortega were booked as evidence item 23-
At approximately 0830 hours, I met with Department of Justice Senior Criminalist Meagan Gallagher and her team.
Gallagher and her team took their own photographs of Officer Ortega, his service pistol, and conducted a round
count. While Criminalist Gallagher conducted the round count for Ortega's service pistol, I photographed the Glock
pistol, ammunition magazine, and ammunition cartridges. All 6 photographs of Officer Ortega's service pistol and-
ammunition were booked as evidence item

Investigators, I was tasked to collect video surveillance from Best Buy Warehouse' security guards.

This supplemental report documents photographs taken for Tracy Police case #23-06009.
On November 20, 2023, Supervisor Melinda Tankersley asked me to respond to the Tracy Police Department North
Annex (1325 N. Mac Arthur Drive) to photograph a vehicle that had been involved in an officer involved shooting
investigation. The vehicle had suspected bullet holes in it, and she asked me to photograph it with trajectory rods in
At approximately 1109 hours, I met with Detective Phil Giusto at the North Annex (1325 N. Mac Arthur Drive.) At the
North Annex, I observed a grey colored Infinity SUV parked inside. The front driver’s side door panel was off and on
top of the vehicle. I photographed the exterior and interior of the vehicle. (Photographs – evidence item #23-06009-
I observed lettered stickers on the vehicle at suspected bullet holes/marks. Crime Scene Technician Pedro Valles
informed me that there had been lettered stickers at each hole/mark, but some had fallen off when the vehicle was
towed to the North Annex. I placed stickers at the suspected bullet holes that were missing a lettered sticker. My
stickers were labeled, “DMM##.” I photographed the vehicle with the stickers in place.
I then placed trajectory rods in each suspected bullet hole. I did not have enough of the smaller trajectory rods to
place in every hole before photographing the vehicle, so I photographed the vehicle in sections. I placed trajectory
rods in each of the following sections and photographed them:
Driver’s side front fender/quarter panel, hood of the vehicle, and driver’s side of the windshield
Interior of the vehicle – rear passenger seat and headrest
Dashboard, ceiling/headliner of vehicle, exterior top of vehicle, and front passenger side
The front driver’s door panel was taken off the roof of the vehicle and brought down onto the floor. I placed a
measuring sticker next to the suspected bullet hole on the door panel, and I photographed it.
At approximately 1435 hours, I cleared from the North Annex and transported my 251 photographs to Tracy Police
Department (1000 Civic Center Drive) where I booked them as evidence.

On Sunday, 11/19/2023, at approximately 0419 hours, I was the sergeant assigned to the General Investigations
Unit when I received a telephone call from Lieutenant Bauer requesting detectives and myself to respond to an
officer-involved shooting that had just occurred during a burglary in progress. I notified detectives to respond to the
I arrived at the investigations annex and read the call for service notes to learn about the incident. I then met with Lt.
Bauer, who told me he notified the District Attorney's Office to activate the officer-involved shooting protocol team of
investigators (DAI). After DAI arrived at the investigation's annex, we paired DAI's with detectives to investigate the
incident. The Department of Justice - Bureau of Forensic Services (BFS) assisted with collecting evidence.
Tracy PD crime scene technicians and BFS technicians photographed the officers involved in the shooting (Ortega,
Macias, Bourassa) and allowed them to go off duty after meeting with their attorney.
Detectives and DAI responded to the Best Buy Warehouse where the incident occurred. I arrived and saw crime
scene tape securing the area where the shooting took place. Detectives and DAI walked the scene before
conducting interviews. I stayed on-scene to supervise while BFS technicians and Tracy PD CSTs processed the
When all the evidence was collected, the suspect vehicle (2021 Infinite QX8) was towed to the Tracy PD Evidence
facility at my request. I followed directly behind the tow truck as it towed the Infinite from the crime scene to the
I turned in the CHP 180 Form to records.
Send a copy of this supplemental report to San Joaquin DDA Jonathan Mott.

The purpose of this supplemental report is to document (A) Brenda Prado’s statement. Brenda admitted to being in
the suspect vehicle (a silver Infiniti SUV) while she and three other subjects illegally entered the gated Best Buy
Warehouse parking lot looking for items to steal. Brenda confirmed she was sitting in the front passenger seat while
either Sergio [later identified as (A) Sergio Garribay] or Jose/Chito (yet to be identified) drove the vehicle during the
On 11/19/2023 at approximately 0420 hours, I was contacted by Sergeant Silva via telephone regarding an officer
involved shooting that occurred in Tracy, California. I arrived at the Tracy Police Department detective annex and at
approximately 0700 hours, a briefing was completed regarding the shooting.
During the briefing, video surveillance from the Best Buy Warehouse (6653 Hopkins Road in Tracy) was shown. I

column2: Macias, Bourassa, and Ortega all discharged their firearms when a

column1: vehicle attempted to run over Officer Macias and Bourassa. After the briefing, Detective Ortiz, San Joaquin County
District Attorney Investigator Sant, and I watched as one by one each officer was processed after the shooting.
All officers were wearing blue Tracy Police Department uniforms with BDU style pants. All three of the officers’ shirts
had blue and gold Tracy Police patches on each shoulder. Each officer was also wearing exterior police vests (refer
to photos) with their name and silver badge affixed to the vest. All involved officers also wore earpieces which goes
inside their ear and attached to their department portable radio. Please note, all involved officers were driving fully
marked black and white Tracy Police Department patrol vehicles during the time of this incident. Officer Bourassa’s
exterior vest said police on the front and back. Officer Bourassa also wore a black hat with a silver Tracy Police
badge attached to the front. Officer Macias and Officer Ortega wore exterior vests with the words police on the back.
For more information regarding what the officers were wearing the night of the incident, please refer to the
The processing of the officers included, photographs and round counts of their department issued firearms. There
were no statements regarding the incident provided by officers during this time.
Detective Ortiz, San Joaquin County District Attorney Investigator Sant, and I responded to the Best Buy Warehouse
parking lot where the incident occurred. We conducted a walk through of the scene. The scene was marked off with
crime scene tape. Inside the scene, I saw a silver four door Infiniti SUV bearing a temporary license plate of
. Through a CLETS inquiry, this license plate was determined to not belong on this vehicle. The Infiniti’s
front driver side exterior door shell was peeled away and found near a red fire hydrant.
Multiple expended rifle cartridges along with an empty rifle magazine were found on the driver side of the Infiniti. The
driver side airbags were also deployed. The bullets holes I was able to see at the scene were through the front of the
windshield, the driver side door, the driver side rear passenger door, and the rear hatch. Most of the bullet holes
were concentrated on the driver compartment of the vehicle.

This supplement documents the interview with (A) Jose Aguilar.
On 11/19/23, at approximately 1600 hours, I was at the TPD annex and was preparing to interview (A) Jose Aguilar.
Jose was the third suspect arrested by TPD officers.
At approximately 1602 hours, I entered the interview room with DAI Sant. I introduced myself to (A) Jose Aguilar and
told him I was the detective assigned to the case. The interview was conducted in Spanish at the request of Jose.
Below is a summary of the interview. For further details, please refer to the digital recording of the interview.
I began the interview by reading Jose his Miranda rights in Spanish per my Miranda card. I asked Jose if he
understood the rights I had read him and he replied, “Yes.” I asked Jose to walk me through the previous day (11/18
/23), prior to arriving in Tracy. Jose said he woke up at approximately 1300 hours at the “Welcome Inn” motel in
Oakland. He dropped off a letter to the wife of one of his friends whom he met at Santa Rita Jail. Afterward, he went
back to his hotel and was hanging out with a female. I asked if the female was Brenda, but he said no and said he
would rather not name her. Jose said at approximately 1900 hours, he got a phone call from Brenda telling him she
wanted to see him since he had just gotten out of Santa Rita jail on Friday (11/17/23). Jose picked her up and they
went back to his motel room.
Jose said he remained in his room with Brenda until 0200 hours of 11/19/23 when she received a phone call from a
“friend” asking if he and Brenda wanted to go to Tracy. Jose was told, the plan was to go to Tracy and pick up a car.
Jose and Brenda agreed, and they headed to Tracy with two other friends. When they exited the freeway, they
began to drive around the warehouses in the area. They arrived at the first warehouse, (unknown name) opened
some trailers, and saw they were empty, so they left.
They arrived at the Best Buy warehouse and opened a lot of trailers. He stated they located a trailer with a lot of
items, so they stopped. After a few minutes, Jose heard what he believed to be security officers arriving and began
shooting at them. Jose got into the vehicle and went down to the floor. After the shooting, Jose realized they had just
crashed. He said his friend who was driving yelled out that he had been shot. Jose said his friend who he only
named as “Chitapan” attempted to put the car into drive, but the car would not move. Chitapan then opened the front
passenger door, pushed Brenda out, then pushed the driver out of the car.
Jose clarified that Brenda was sitting in the front passenger seat and he was sitting behind the driver. I asked if
Sergio was driving, and Jose told me he did not know who Sergio was but knew the driver as “Tricky.” (Tricky was
later confirmed to be Sergio Garibay and will be referred to as Sergio from here on out). Jose said, as Sergio began
to yell out that he had been struck by gunfire, he also shouted he was stuck and could not move. Chitapan was
sitting behind Brenda. Jose said once Brenda and Sergio were out of the car, Chitapan exited the vehicle next, and
Jose was the last one. Jose said as he was exiting the vehicle, he no longer heard gunshots. Once he and Chitapan
were out of the car, they both fled on foot. I asked Jose where he ran to, he said left the Best Buy property and
OCCURENCE START DATE / TIME - OCCURENCE END DATE / T ME

vehicle. Chitapan had a saw with him and cut open the lock to the trailers. Once the locks were cut, Jose would go
inside the trailer and would start to unload items. Brenda did not have a role and was just a passenger. Sergio was
Jose told me the Infinity SUV belonged to Chitapan and he was the one who drove them from Oakland to Tracy.
However, when they arrived at the Best Buy warehouse, Chitapan exited the vehicle and began to search the

On 11/29/23 I interviewed Jeremy Ward (South County Fire Authority Firefighter) regarding his response to the
incident that occurred on 11/19/23 (case 23-06009). The interview was in person and took place at Station 91 in
Jeremy Ward is currently employed by the South County Fire Authority and is currently a Fire Captain. Ward has
worked with the South County Fire Authority for approximately 18 years. On 11/19/23, Ward was working his regular
scheduled shift at Station 94 in Tracy, CA.
Ward stated he was dispatched to the report of a shooting in the early hours of 11/19/23. Ward stated there were no
other details regarding the shooting. Ward stated they responded code 3 (lights and siren) from Station 94. Ward
said it took them approximately 5 minutes to get to the scene. Once they got to the scene, Ward said they got
cleared to enter by law enforcement almost immediately after getting there.
At the scene, Ward and his team were directed towards a patient that was sitting down next to a vehicle that was
behind some bushes. Ward sated AMR was already attending to the patient by the time they got there. Ward
assisted AMR in transferring the patient on a gurney and ultimately placing the patient in the back of an ambulance
for him to be transported to the hospital. Ward advised the treatment provided on scene was minimal because the
patient needed to be taken to the hospital. Ward remembers the patient kept saying he was thirsty.
Once the ambulance left with the injured patient, Ward was directed by police officers to do a medical assessment of
a female that was detained at the scene. Ward stated the female had no gunshot wounds or any type of traumatic
injury. Ward stated the female refused any type of medical treatment.
Ward and his team cleared the scene and drove to San Joaquin County Hospital to pick up his crew member who
had ridden in the ambulance during the patient transport to the hospital.

The interview with Officer Arturo Ortega
On 11/21/23, at approximately 1330 hours, TPD Officers Joseph Bourassa, Adrian Macias, and Arturo Ortega arrived
at the TPD annex accompanied by their attorney, Brian Gabriel. All three officers provided voluntary statements
which were audio recorded. For further details and full statements, please refer to audio recordings of the interviews.
The first officer to be interviewed was Ofc. Joseph Bourassa. Ofc. Bourassa was interviewed by District Attorney
Investigator (DAI) David Sant. Please refer to DAI Sant’s report for the full statement of Ofc. Bourassa.
Ofc. Bourassa was wearing a full TPD uniform with a body-worn camera which was activated throughout the entire
incident. For full details on the incident, please refer to Ofc. Bourassa’s video.
At approximately 1458 hours, DAI Sants and I met with Ofc. Macias and his attorney Brian Gabriel for a voluntary
statement. Ofc. Macias told me the following in summary:

Macias was wearing a full police uniform with a body-worn camera affixed to his vest. He was dispatched to the Best
Buy warehouse (6653 Hopkins Rd.) on a report of a burglary in progress along with officers Bourassa and Ortega.
He stated he drove code three, which means the lights and sirens on his police vehicle were activated. Prior to
arrival, he turned off his lights and sirens. Ofc. Macias entered the Best Buy parking lot and parked his vehicle along
the south/east corner of the parking lot. He noticed there was an open trailer and a cut lock on the ground. Ofc.
Macias stepped out of his vehicle and assisted officers Bourassa and Ortega with a search of the parking lot.
Ofc. Macias said he began to hear metallic clinking and movement, north of his location. He signaled to his partners
of the noises and began to walk towards the area of the noise. As they were walking past several trailers, Ofc.
Macias looked inside the open trailers to make sure there was no one inside.
Ofc. Macias said they continued walking northbound until they reached the end of the parked trailers. He stated he
began to shine his flashlight at several trailers and saw two pairs of feet. He stated the feet started running north.
Ofc. Macias announced himself as “Tracy Police” and yelled out to “Freeze! Stop! Put it down!” Ofc. Macias began to
run parallel to the truck trailers after the suspects.
Ofc. Macias said at that point, he believed the incident was just a foot pursuit. As he began to turn the corner of the
trailer, he saw Ofc. Bourassa was ahead of him. He then saw an SUV vehicle appear and was approximately five
yards away from Ofc. Bourassa. Ofc. Macias heard what he believed to be an engine revving up and tires squeaking

On 11/22/2023 I went to the South County Fire Station #91, located at 1701 W 11th St in the City of Tracy to
interview firefighter (I) Justin Dehart who responded to Best Buy in response to an officer involved shooting. Present
for the interview with Justin was Detective Zuniga, DAI Springmeyer and I. The interview was audio recorded on my
department issued Axon body worn camera, a copy of the interview was later booked into property and evidence.
The following is a summary of the statement Justin provided, for a direct transcript of the interview please refer to the
audio recording of the statement. Justin stated he has been employed with South County Fire for approximately 2.5
years and prior to working for South County Fire he worked for the Turlock Fire Department for 4 years, having been
a firefighter for a total of over 6 years. Justin stated he was working an overtime shift at South County Fire Station
#94 on 11/19/2023. Justin stated working with him that night was Paramedic Shawn Bracha and Captain Jeremy
Ward. Justin stated he was dispatched to stage at the Best Buy Warehouse during the early morning hours of 11/19
/2023 for a possible shooting. Justin stated upon arrival they were cleared in ""pretty quickly, so we did not stage long
at all"". Justin said when he arrived on scene AMR, police Officers with Tracy PD, and the San Joaquin County
Sheriff's Department were already on scene. Justin located an adult male laying on the back side of Best Buy next to
a vehicle. The male had obvious gunshot wounds, an obvious femur fracture to his leg, and a tourniquet on his leg.
Justin assisted AMR in checking the patient for additional wounds and moving the patient off of the embankment he
was laying on. He then loaded the patient onto a gurney and AMR transported the patient to San Joaquin County
On 11/22/2023 I went to the South County Fire Station #93, located at 1400 Durham Ferry Rd to interview firefighter
(I) Shawn Bracha who responded to Best Buy in response to an officer involved shooting. Present for the interview
with Justin was Detective Zuniga, DAI Springmeyer and I. The interview was audio recorded on my department
issued Axon body worn camera, a copy of the interview was later booked into property and evidence.
The following is a summary of the statement Justin provided, for a direct transcript of the interview please refer to the
audio recording of the statement. Shawn stated he is currently employed with the South San Joaquin Fire Authority
as a firefighter and has been for almost 10 years. Shawn said he was working at station 94 on 11/19/2023 and was
dispatched to the Best Buy Warehouse during the early morning hours for a report of a shooting. Shawn stated they
were dispatched to stage down the street until they were cleared in by law enforcement. Shawn stated they were
cleared in to the scene very quickly and that he believed they arrived approximately 30 seconds after AMR arrived on
scene. Shawn said upon arriving on scene he observed an SUV that appeared to have been in some sort of crash
and there were a number of law enforcement vehicles throughout the scene. Upon exiting the vehicle Shawn saw
rounds or casings"" on the ground, but he did not check to see if they were live or spent. AMR personnel were
treating a patient that was located next to the crashed vehicle and the patient was down an embankment. Shawn
approached the AMR personnel and asked them what they needed from the fire personnel. The AMR paramedic
indicated to Shawn that she wanted to get the patient loaded into the ambulance as soon as possible. Shawn said
they grabbed a tarp and rolled the patient ""one way and then the other"" to get the patient onto the tarp. Once on the
tarp they carried the patient up the embankment, placed him on a gurney, then loaded him into the ambulance.
Shawn described the patient as a Hispanic male adult in his 30's. Shawn stated he rode inside the ambulance while
they transported the patient to San Joaquin County General Hospital so he could assist the AMR paramedic in
treating the patient. While on their way to the hospital the patient indicated to Shawn that his name was Sergio.
Shawn stated it took them approximately 15 minutes to get the patient to the hospital. While on the way to the
hospital Sergio made the statement to Shawn that he was not driving the vehicle. End of statement.

I asked Sergio if he remembered getting out of the vehicle. He said he remembered when Brenda opened the door,

no idea where he was at or why he was shot at.
I told Sergio I had already spoken to Brenda and Jose (AKA Chema), and I knew he was lying to me. I told Sergio

After the interview, DAI Sant and I drove to the San Joaquin County Jail (999 W. Mathews Rd.) in French Camp.

REASON FOR STOP: Call for service wanted felon.
SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTIGATION: On August 19, 2023 at approximately 2149 hours, I was on routine patrol as the
on-duty Sergeant. My uniform consisted of a Navy-blue long sleeve shirt with a “City of Reedley Police” patch and
blue/gold chevrons on each arm. On the left breast of my shirt is a gold-colored badge and the right is a gold name
tag and a department issued body worn camera (BWC). I was wearing a pair of clear prescription glasses. I was
wearing a black leather duty belt, navy blue pants and black boots. I was driving Reedley PD unit 713, which has a
traditional black and white color pattern and is fully marked with red and blue emergency lights.
for a reporting party stating that they were advised to
call police if Ernesto Carrillo (9/17/86) returned to the residence. Ernesto was last seen wearing a gray shirt, blue
jeans and a red baseball hat. I recalled being briefed at the start of my shift, which occurred around 1900 hours, that
Ernesto had vandalized his girlfriend’s vehicle and fled prior to officers arriving. I was further advised that he had an
active and confirmed felony warrant for PC 273.5 and PC 236, and was yet to be arrested. I recalled a specific case
from about a month earlier where Ernesto had assaulted his girlfriend at the Edgewater Inn in Reedley. I
remembered that incident due to the numerous times he was arrested for felony and misdemeanor domestic violence
and for violating restraining orders. I was able to see his criminal history when I was reviewing the officers report
from the assault at the Edgewater Inn. I could not remember the last time I had seen so many arrests for domestic
violence by one person. I believed that Ernesto had a propensity for violence based off of his criminal history and
based off of his habitual drug use.
Prior to responding, I called dispatch via phone and confirmed the felony warrant was active. Shortly after hanging
up, I received a photograph of Ernesto from dispatch.
I activated my department issued BWC prior to arriving on scene. When I arrived on scene, prior to exiting my patrol
vehicle, I heard officers advise that Ernesto had left the apartment prior to our arrival. State Center Community
College District (SCCCD) Police Officer Serrano asked over the Reedley PD radio channel to confirm the subjects
name of who we were looking for. Officer Serrano was advised it was Ernesto Carrillo and he stated that he had just
contacted him in the Reedley College parking lot, for further refer to SCCCD report number 23-564.
While responding to the area Officer Serrano stated that Ernesto was in the front yard of a residence with a white
picket fence on Reed Ave. in the area of Kip Patrick Ave. As I was driving towards that intersection, Officer Serrano
advised that Ernesto was south of Kip Patrick Ave. on Reed Ave. I believed that Ernesto was still going to be on the
east side of Reed Ave. when either myself or another officer would contact him. I requested an officer go to
Riverview Ave. south of Kip Patrick Ave. in case Ernesto ran east bound from Reed Ave. I believed that Ernesto
would run based off a prior radio transmission from Officer Cardinalle regarding Ernesto running and the severity of
the warrant for his arrest. I wanted a perimeter set up quickly in case he fled, because I did not want him to escape. I
feared that if he escaped, the female who was the victim of the felony assault and false imprisonment, may be at risk
of retaliation from Ernesto if she called.
EVENT START DATE / TIME - EVENT END DATE / TIME
Report # 23-0002747 - Supplemental - B Report Reedley PD
Mark43 RMS Form v2.0 generated by P. Staggs #L052 on Feb 14, 2024 09:35.
Officer Serrano asked for a Reedley Unit to drive south on Reed Ave. to contact Ernesto. When I turned southbound,
I observed a moderate amount of traffic on the roadway. Along the roadway are streetlights that artificially light the
area. Some areas are dimly lit and others are moderately lit. I drove approximately 50 yards and Officer Serrano
advised me that Ernesto was to the left of my unit.
I briefly stopped and turned to contact a subject on the east sidewalk of Reed Ave. and did not recognize the subject
from the photograph as Ernesto. Officer Serrano stated that subject I was going to contact was not Ernesto. As I
turned and drove my unit south on Reed Ave. Officer Serrano advised he had his spotlight on Ernesto and he was
running south bound. I observed Ernesto running southbound approximately 50 yards south of me on the east
sidewalk of Reed Ave.. I activated my overhead emergency code 3 lights and my siren. My patrol vehicle was in the
north and southbound lane of Reed Ave and approximately 25 yards from Ernesto. Ernesto hands were swinging
from front to back above his waist as he was running. I observed his right hand to be empty. As his left hand was
brought back, as he was running, his left hand had a silver somewhat reflective object protruding from his hand. At
the time, I believed the object could possibly be a firearm or knife. While he was running Ernesto was illuminated by
passing vehicles headlights and turning his head over his right shoulder looking in my direction.
I passed at least one, possibly two vehicles and drove almost parallel to Ernesto along the east curb of S. Reed Ave.
As Ernesto was running, I could clearly see he was wearing baggy clothing that could easily conceal a weapon and
he was grabbing at his left pocket. I wanted to pull nearly parallel to Ernesto because I did not want him to run into
oncoming traffic, endangering himself and/or motorists. I had this in my mind at the time because of two separate
body cameras I had seen in the last month of subjects being hit by oncoming traffic while fleeing police. I rolled down
the driver side window of my patrol vehicle. My driver side mirror was approximately 3 yards behind Ernesto and 3
yards from his right side. I unholstered and activated my department issued Conducted Energy Device (CED). I told
Ernesto in a loud clear voice “Stop Police” but he continued running and looked over his shoulder and directly at me.
I pointed my CED at Ernesto at some point after I rolled my driver side window down. I once again said, “Stop Police”
in a loud clear voice and Ernesto continued running. At this point the area was dimly lit to me and I could not have a
clear and uninterrupted view of Ernesto’s hands. I warned him ""You're gonna get tased"", and he did not stop. I
deployed my department issued CED and Ernesto’s feet came fully of the ground and he landed on the concrete with
his face and upper chest area.
I stopped, put my patrol vehicle in park and exited my patrol vehicle as my department issued CED was completing
its pre-set five second cycle. Once the CED was finished cycling, Ernesto sat up and I saw a large amount of blood
dripping from his face and covering the sidewalk. I yelled at Ernesto to show me his hands, twice, which he did not
comply. I chose not to activate the CED again because of Ernesto’s injuries. As officers ran up to place Ernesto in
handcuffs, I requested EMS code 3 for Ernesto before the handcuffs were fully applied to his wrists. I requested EMS
code 3 due to Ernesto’s injuries to his head. Ernesto was making groaning noises, which I believed to be from pain
he was feeling. Within minutes Ernesto was talking to officers about the handcuffs being tight. During a search of
Ernesto, I observed officer Nava remove an object from Ernesto’s left pocket or waistband area. The object had a
black handle approximately four inches long and a silver piece of metal that protrude from the tool. When the object
was removed, I initially thought it was a “Zip gun”. A zip gun is a personally manufactured firearm from common
items. I then realized it was a “window punch”, which is a tool used to break car windows. I believe this item may
have been what Ernesto was running with but can not be certain, as I did not have a view of his left hand during the
I was also advised that Ernesto had a knife on him. I advised officers to place Ernesto on his side, to prevent him
from aspirating blood from the facial trauma. Ernesto sat up and I believed allowing him to be in a position of comfort
would be most beneficial for him. I did instruct officers not to allow him to lay on his back. I was able to see that one
probe from the CED struck Ernesto on the back of his upper neck and the other on the right side of his lower back.
During the call I photograph Ernesto and provided them to Officer Renteria to be attached to this report.

Shortly after the use of force, I wanted to check again if the caller was the female related to the warrant because I
worried that she may have been injured and dispatch advised me it was different caller. Dispatch advised the caller
was related to a prior vandalism call.
I asked Officer Cardinalle to conduct a neighborhood canvass for surveillance and witnesses to the incident. Ernesto
was transported to Adventist Health. I was later advised by Officer Cardinalle that Ernesto suffered severe injuries
from the fall and was going to be transported to Community Regional Medical Center (CRMC) for surgery. I
contacted Commander Ediger and advised him of the case.
Ernesto was transported to CRMC and is currently listed in critical but stable condition.

On 08/18/2023 at approximately 2149 hours during uniform patrol and driving a marked patrol vehicle, I assisted
Officer Renteria on a unwanted subject call for service. The location provided for
PD dispatch advised the subject's name is Ernesto Carrillo and he had an active Felony warrant.
I worked the night before and was aware of Ernesto's warrant. The night before Ernesto was involved in a vandalism
(for further information regarding the vandalism see case number 23-2741). I have had prior contacts with Ernesto
I advised assisting officers over the radio that he had priors for felony domestic violence.
I arrived on scene and started a perimeter at the apartments to the north.
Assisting officers arrived on scene to contact Ernesto. Officer Renteria advised over the radio that the reporting party
(RP) stated Ernesto left the scene. Officer Renteria advised he was last seen wearing a gray shirt and blue jeans.
Officer Serrano from State Center Community College District (SCCCD) advised over the radio that a male matching
the description was on Reed Ave walking southbound. Officer Serrano stated over the radio that it was Ernesto, and
he was now running southbound Reed Ave.
I drove southbound in the 1200 block N. Reed Ave east alleyway in case Ernesto ran eastbound.
Sgt. Puryear advised over the radio that he was contacted Ernesto and he was actively running. Shortly after Sgt.
Puryear asked for EMS to respond with lights and sirens.
I arrived on scene and observed Officer Renteria standing by Ernesto while Ernesto was handcuffed and sitting on
the curb. I walked up with my medical bag and notice Ernesto was bleeding from his nose. I did not want to make it
difficult for Ernesto to breath so I tried to keep him leaned forward so he would not choke from his blood.
Ernesto kept trying to get up so I told him multiple times to stay seated. He would move around so I tried to keep him
still to avoid any further injuries.
Officer Renteria stood by Ernesto so I could stay available for any other calls for service.

On Friday September 13, 2024, Tenderloin Station Officer Phong Nguyen #69, Officer Colin Ryan
#1538, and Officer Bartholomew Sullivan #6 were the involved members in Officer-Involved Shooting
24-003 (SFPD Incident #240-576-334) which occurred at the Powell Bart Station Concourse.
On Wednesday, September 18, 2024, pursuant to Department General Order 8.11, a Return to Duty
Panel initially convened to determine if the officers should be returned to duty.  At that meeting, the
panel voted to recommend the officers not be returned to duty until completion of their required
debriefs and voluntary interviews with ISD and the District Attorney Office’s Independent
On Friday September 27, the Return to Duty panel reconvened to discuss whether it was appropriate
for the involved officers to return to their regular duty assignments.  The panel was comprised of the
• Acting Assistant Chief Peter Walsh (Chair) – Chief of Staff
• Acting Deputy Chief Eric Vintero – Field Operations
• Acting Captain Daniel Manning – Tenderloin Station
• Acting Captain Timothy O’Connor – Risk Management Office
• Lieutenant Lisa Springer – Internal Affairs Division
• Sergeant Art Howard – Behavioral Science Unit
Also present were ISD Sergeant Yukio Oshita, ISD Sergeant Rodney Fitzpatrick, and Administration
CITY AND COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO
The panel called upon the following disciplines to summarily report on any updates and discuss the
factors that are taken into consideration when determining whether to return an officer to duty:

the panel. The briefing was an overview of the incident discussing the currently known facts and
evidence related to this incident.  Sergeant Oshita and Sergeant Fitzpatrick reported that the involved
officers completed their voluntary interviews with ISD and the District Attorney Office’s Independent
Internal Affairs Division (IAD):  Lieutenant Springer reported the involved officers successfully
completed their post-discharge Range Debriefs and Force Options Refresher on September 25, 2024.
Behavioral Science Unit (BSU):  Sergeant Howard reported that each of the involved officers were
debriefed by the Behavioral Science Unit on September 16, 2024.
Tenderloin Station Acting Captain Manning reported that he was in contact with each of the involved
placed on administrative duty pending their return to full duty.
The panel noted that the involved officers had completed all necessary debriefs required prior to
returning to duty after involvement in an OIS.  After hearing the presentations and ensuing discussion,
the panel unanimously recommended that Officer Phong Nguyen #69, Officer Colin Ryan #1538, and
Officer Bartholomew Sullivan #6 be returned to their regular duty assignment.
My decision whether to return these officers to duty, including the aforementioned mandatory
debriefings and factors supporting the decision, is scheduled for presentation to the Police
Commission in closed session on October 2, 2024.  I look forward to discussing my decision with you

Officer Involved Shooting Review for Calexico Police Officer Alexander
The following facts are based upon bodycam footage, computer aided dispatch logs, and
interviews of witnesses and involved officers
On February 21, 2024, at about 9:43 P.M., Calexico Police Officers were dispatched to 736
Grant Avenue in the City of Calexico for a report of a burglary in progress.  The suspect was
broadcasted as Christian Plancarte (“Christian”).  The reporting party was Christian
.  Officer Alexander Hernandez and Sgt. Miguel Carbajal
arrived on scene at about 9:45 P.M.  Officer Hernandez and Sgt. Carbajal were in uniform.
Upon arrival, Officer Hernandez and Sgt. Carbajal observed Christian at the door of the
residence.  Both officers illuminated Christian with their flashlights.  Christian was holding a
crowbar in his right hand.  Sgt. Carbajal yelled Calexico Police Department and ordered
Christian to “Put that down.”  Officer Hernandez told Christian to “Drop it.”  Christian
walked towards Sgt. Carbajal who was standing near the edge of the driveway.  Within a
second, Christian then moved from a walk to a run towards Sgt. Carbajal.  While Christian
was running toward Sgt. Carbajal, Christian lifted the crowbar up into a right-handed
“batting” position to swing it.  Sgt. Carbajal, moved backwards away from Christian and
ordered Christian to “Put it Down” several more times.
As Christian closed the distance between himself and Sgt. Carbajal, Officer Hernandez, from
the front yard, fired three shots from his service weapon striking Christian.  Christian fell to
the ground approximately five feet away from Sgt. Carbajal’s position.  Christian dropped
Paramedics from the City of Calexico responded to the scene and provided medical aid.
Christian sustained a single gunshot wound to the abdomen and grazing gunshot wound to
his left thigh.  Christian survived his gunshot wound.
During his interview by our Bureau of Investigation, Sgt. Carbajal stated that when Christian
charged at him with the crowbar, he believed he was about to suffer great bodily injury.  Sgt.
Carbajal told investigators that he feared for his safety and retreated backwards when he was
rushed by Christian.  Sgt. Carbajal stated that he was in the process of pulling the trigger on
his own firearm to shoot Christian, however Officer Hernandez shot first and stopped the
During his interview by our Bureau of Investigation, Officer Hernandez stated that at the
time Christian began running towards Sgt. Carbajal, he believed that Christian was going to
strike Sgt. Carbajal with the crowbar and cause great bodily harm to him.  Christian ignored
their commands to drop the crowbar and he therefore fired his duty pistol three times at
Christian.  Officer Hernandez believed that when Christian started to run towards Sgt.
Carbajal, Christian was about 15-20 feet from Sgt. Carbajal.  Officer Hernandez stated that
within a about three seconds Christian was able to close the gap about 5-10 feet.
Following the initial charging of a criminal case against Christian (JCF007622), a
preliminary hearing was held on June 4, 2024.  Christian was bound over on charges of
1) Attempted Murder of a Peace Officer, 2) Attempted Burglary, and 3) Assault with a
Deadly Weapon.  Trial is currently scheduled for August 12, 2024.
Legal principles related to officer involved shootings
Possible criminal charges against an officer involved in a shooting not involving death

column2: attempted voluntary manslaughter
assault with a deadly weapon (§ 245)
column3: and assault by a police officer (§

column1: 149). (All section references hereafter will be to the Penal Code). To convict an officer of
any of these charges it would be necessary to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that no legal
justifications existed for the officer’s actions. (People v. Adrian (1982) 135 Cal.App.3d 335,
340-342.) Several possible legal justifications may apply in any given case and § 835a
outlines some of those possible justifications as specifically applied to peace officers.
As is relevant in this matter, § 835a(c)(1) states that “a peace officer is justified in using
deadly force upon another person only when the officer reasonably believes, based on the
totality of the circumstances, that such force is necessary for either of the following reasons:
(A) To defend against an imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury to the officer or to
another person. (B) To apprehend a fleeing person for any felony that threatened or resulted
in death or serious bodily injury, if the officer reasonably believes that the person will cause
death or serious bodily injury to another unless immediately apprehended. Where feasible, a
peace officer shall, prior to the use of force, make reasonable efforts to identify themselves
as a peace officer and to warn that deadly force may be used, unless the officer has
objectively reasonable grounds to believe the person is aware of those facts.”
§ 835a(d) states that “A peace officer who makes or attempts to make an arrest need not
retreat or desist from their efforts by reason of the resistance or threatened resistance of the
person being arrested. A peace officer shall not be deemed an aggressor or lose the right to
self-defense by the use of objectively reasonable force in compliance with subdivisions (b)
and (c) to effect the arrest or to prevent escape or to overcome resistance. For the purposes of
this subdivision, ‘retreat’ does not mean tactical repositioning or other deescalation tactics.”
§ 835a(e) clarifies some of the above sections by creating the following definitions: (1)
“Deadly force” means any use of force that creates a substantial risk of causing death or
serious bodily injury, including, but not limited to, the discharge of a firearm. (2) A threat of
death or serious bodily injury is “imminent” when, based on the totality of the circumstances,
a reasonable officer in the same situation would believe that a person has the present ability,
opportunity, and apparent intent to immediately cause death or serious bodily injury to the
peace officer or another person. An imminent harm is not merely a fear of future harm, no
matter how great the fear and no matter how great the likelihood of the harm, but is one that,
from appearances, must be instantly confronted and addressed. (3) “Totality of the
circumstances” means all facts known to the peace officer at the time, including the conduct
of the officer and the subject leading up to the use of deadly force.
The relevant Criminal Jury Instruction as written by the Judicial Council of California and
set forth in CALCRIM 3470 permits a person being assaulted to defend themself from attack
if, as a reasonable person, they had grounds for believing and did believe
that bodily injury was about to be inflicted upon them or upon another person. In doing so,
such person may immediately use all force and means which they believe to be reasonably
necessary, and which would appear to a reasonable person, in the same or similar
circumstances, to be necessary to defend against that danger and to prevent the injury which
The law as detailed in CALCRIM 3470 and in well-settled caselaw therefore permits a
person, if confronted by the appearance of danger which arouses in his/her mind, as a
reasonable person, an honest fear and conviction that he/she or another person is about to
suffer bodily injury, to act in self-defense or defense of others upon such appearance of
danger. The person’s right of self-defense is the same regardless of whether the danger to the
person is real danger or merely apparent danger.  (People v. Jackson (1965) 233 Cal.App.2d
The above justifications must be interpreted in light of United States Supreme Court
precedent that limits the right of a police officer to use deadly force.  (People v. Martin
(1985) 168 Cal.App.3d 1111, 1124.)  A relevant decision of the United States Supreme Court
can be found in Tennessee v. Garner (1985) 471 U.S. 1, 11-12, where the Court outlined the
constitutionally permissible parameters of the use of deadly force against a fleeing suspect:
“Where the officer has probable cause to believe that the suspect poses a threat of serious
physical harm, either to the officer or to others, it is not constitutionally unreasonable to
prevent escape by using deadly force. Thus, if the suspect threatens the officer with a weapon
or there is probable cause to believe that he has committed a crime involving the infliction or
threatened infliction of serious physical harm, deadly force may be used if necessary to
prevent escape, and if, where feasible, some warning has been given.”
The United States Supreme Court in Graham v. Connor (1989) 490 U.S. 386, determined
that an officer’s right to use force is to be analyzed under the Fourth Amendment’s
“objective reasonableness” standard. As part of its analysis, the Court stated that “[t]he
‘reasonableness’ of a particular use of force must be judged from the perspective of a
reasonable officer on the scene, rather than with the 20/20 vision of hindsight.” Id. at 396.
“The calculus of reasonableness must embody allowance for the fact that police officers are
often forced to make split-second judgments—in circumstances that are tense, uncertain, and
rapidly evolving—about the amount of force that is necessary in a particular situation.” Id. at
Officer Hernandez reasonably believed based upon the totality of the circumstances that
deadly force was necessary to stop the imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury to
Sgt. Carbajal.  The bodycam footage of the shooting supported the statements of the involved
officers that the threat of serious bodily injury was clearly imminent, and that the officer’s
fear was reasonable to justify the use of deadly force.  Therefore, it is my opinion that
Officer Hernandez is not criminally liable in his use of force in this matter.

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me.

Officer Monay Officer Involved Shooting November 25, 2023
The Merced County District Attorney’s Office has conducted an investigation into the fatal officer-
involved shooting by Officer Monay of Sergio Hernandez-Castillo on November 25, 2023.
The purpose of the investigation by the District Attorney’s Office is to determine if any violation of
criminal law may have occurred on the part of the officer.  A prosecutor should file criminal charges only
if the prosecutor reasonably believes that the charges are supported by probable cause, that admissible
evidence will be sufficient to support conviction beyond reasonable doubt, and that the decision to the
charge is in the interest of justice.
Possible criminal charges against Officer Monay are: Possible criminal charges against an officer
involved in a shooting include murder (Penal Code Section 187)
column2: manslaughter (Penal Code Section
assault with a deadly weapon (Penal Code Section 245)
column3: and assault by a police officer (Penal

column1: Code Section 149).  In order to convict an officer of any of these charges, however, it would be
necessary to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that no legal justifications existed for the officer’s actions.
(People v. Adrian (1982) 135 Cal.App.3d 335, 340-342.)  Justifications for an officer’s actions are set
forth in Penal Code Sections 196, 197 and 835a.
Pursuant to Penal Code Section 835a, peace officers may use deadly force when necessary, in defense of
human life.  A decision should be evaluated from the perspective of a reasonable officer in the same
situation, based on the totality of the circumstances known at the time, rather than the benefit of
hindsight.  The totality of the circumstances should include considering situations in which officers are
forced to make quick judgments about using force.  Penal Code Section 835a further provides a peace
officer is justified in using deadly force when the officer reasonably believes, based on the totality of the
circumstances such force is necessary to defend against imminent threat of death or serious bodily
In this case, Officer Monay arrived on scene to assist Officer Cole on a call for service for an unknown
person in reporting party’s backyard.  Prior to arrival, Officer Monay heard Officer Cole state over the
radio that the suspect had a firearm.  Upon Officer Monay’s arrival, Officer Monay retrieved his
department issued rifle.  Officer Cole had his firearm drawn and was giving commands to the suspect to
“put [his] hands up.”  Officer Monay pointed his rifle at the suspect and continued giving commands in
Spanish to raise his hands.  Officer Monay observed a firearm in front of the suspect on a brick wall.  He
observed the suspect move toward the firearm with a “hand raised.”  Officer Cole continued to give
commands, but the suspect continued to move his hand toward the firearm.  Officer Monay estimated
the suspect’s hand to be less than a foot from the gun.  Officer Monay then fired five shots at the suspect
through the fence.  Officer Monay fired because he was in fear that the suspect would shoot him, Officer
Cole or the reporting party inside the house.  Officer Monay stopped firing once he saw suspect’s hand
Here, officers gave the suspect several commands and opportunity to comply with commands before
resorting to deadly force.  Officer Monay used deadly force when he believed his life and the life of
others were in danger.  Officer Monay’s belief was reasonable and the use of force necessary to defend
against imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury.
Officer Monay is justified in using deadly force in this case.

On Saturday, November 25, 2023, at 0914 hours, Los Banos Police Department Communications Center
received a call from MM reported Sergio Hernandez-Castillanos was trespassing in his
backyard at JH” Street, Los Banos, California. J stated that Hernandez-Castillanos had been in
his backyard for approximately 15 minutes and “was talking to himself.” Los Banos Police Department
(LBPD) Officer Cole was dispatched to the trespassing call at 09:16:26 hours. Officer Cole arrived at
Officer Cole observed Hernandez-Castillanos in the backyard of JH” Street and broadcasted over
his police radio that Hernandez-Castillanos “appeared to have a firearm” and requested additional police
units to respond. Officer Cole gave Hernandez-Castillanos commands to “drop the firearm.” LBPD
Officer Ricardo Monay arrived at JH” Street, Los Banos at 09:18:57 hours to assist.
Officer Cole and Officer Monay took a position of cover behind a large tree in the front yard of| | | “H”
Street. A cinder block fence separated the front and back yard of the residence. There was a wooden
gate, approximately three (3) feet wide, between the cinder block fence and the residence that allowed
for access from the front yard to the back yard. The large tree where the officers were positioned was
approximately six (6) feet north of the cinder block fence.
Hermandez-Castillanos remained in the backyard while Officer Cole and Officer Monay were in the
front yard. Hernandez-Castillanos placed a black semi-automatic pistol, (later determined to be a “ghost
gun” or gun with no serial number or manufacturer markings) on top of the cinder block fence. Officer
Monay and Officer Cole moved from behind the tree and began to walk towards the wooden gate and
cinder block fence. As Officer Cole and Officer Monay made their approach, Hernandez-Castillanos
reached for the pistol. Officer Monay discharged his patrol rifle five (5) times, hitting Hernandez-
Castillanos with rounds through the wooden gate. Hernandez-Castillanos fell to the ground before
retrieving the pistol. Officers Cole and Monay climbed over the cinder block fence to gain access to
Hermandez-Castillanos as the wooden gate was locked. Hernandez-Castillanos was pronounced
deceased at the scene by Los Banos Battalion 1 fire personnel at 0942 hours. Officer Cole later
examined the decedent’s firearm, it was a real firearm that was not loaded.
The Los Banos Police Department CAD Incident Report showed the call for service initiated at
09:14:53. The address of the incident was given as JH” Street, Los Banos. The suspect description
was given as “HMA (Hispanic male adult) grungy coat, gray-pants, black jacket with different pictures
poss advertisement for motor oil, subj jumped the fence to rp’s back yard / subj has been there about 15
min / subj has been talking to himself.”
At 09:18:08 “721 requesting another unit appears to have firearm unk if it is real.” (721 is the radio call
At 09:18:57 “738 onscen.” (738 is the radio call sign for Officer Monay)

with different pictures on it, advertisement for motor oil.” The dispatcher confirmed Hernandez-
Castillanos was in the back yard, and replied, “yes, he is wandering around.”
