Officer Monay was interviewed on November 25, 2023, at 1435 hours. The interview was recorded via
body worn camera, with only the audio function activated.  Officer Monay’s legal counsel, Nicole Pifari,
requested the voluntary interview be recorded with no video.  The interview was conducted by LBPD
Sergeant Parras and Detective Moreno.  I was also present at the interview.  The following is a summary
Officer Monay confirmed he has been as a police officer for “just over seven (7) years.”  Officer Monay
stated he has been with Los Banos Police Department “just over two (2) years.”  Officer Monay is
assigned to patrol, with collateral duties of “officer in charge and field training officer.” He stated he was
currently assigned to day shift weekends, Thursday to Sunday, 0630 hrs. to 1630 hrs.  Sergeant Parras
confirmed with Officer Monay that there were three (3) officers and a Sergeant on duty at the time of
this incident. Officer Monay stated he was rested before reporting for his shift, having slept “six or so
Sergeant Parras asked Officer Monay how the call for service at “H” Street came out and what
information he had received.  Officer Monay said the call came out over his in-car mobile data computer
or “MDC” and he opened the call.  The call was listed as “trespassing at a residence.” Officer Monay
said the notes read, “Hispanic male adult, want to say said something to the effect of something like
scruffy, on the property for about ten minutes, talking to himself.”
There was radio traffic regarding this call that followed. Officer Monay said he remembered, “Officer
Cole was diverted to the “H” Street address, that’s what I recall.”  When Officer Cole was diverted to the
call, Officer Monay assigned himself to assist the call.  Officer Monay recalled that Officer Cole, put
over the radio, he needed another unit because he thought the suspect, Hernandez-Castillanos had a
firearm.  Officer Monay said once Officer Cole broadcast that Hernandez-Castillanos had a gun, he
activated his emergency lights and siren and continued towards the residence. When he arrived, Officer
Monay stated that he parked in the driveway of the “H” Street residence and that he saw that Officer
Cole was the only officer on scene. Officer Monay deployed his department issued rifle and took a
position to the left of the large tree in the front yard, where Officer Cole was standing on the right, with
his duty pistol out and pointed toward the backyard of the residence. Officer Monay stated that Officer
Cole was giving commands to the suspect in the backyard to “put your hands up.”
Officer Monay explained that Officer Cole left cover behind the tree, and he told Officer Cole to “move
back.”  Officer Cole moved back momentarily and then broke cover again.  Officer Monay said that at
that time, he also broke cover, pointing his rifle at the subject in the back yard and shouting, in Spanish,
for the suspect to “raise his hands.”
Sergeant Parras asked Officer Monay what he saw when he broke cover.  Officer Monay said he saw
“somebody in the backyard of the residence, and they are a couple feet away from the wooden door and
brick wall.”  Sergeant Parras asked Officer Monay what he saw when he looked over the fence and
Officer Monay responded, “What I see is umm a cement and brick wall, with a wooden gate, and then
just immediately beyond, on the other side of that gate and brick wall, umm I could see the top portion
of a man.”  Officer Monay clarified he could see “the top of his [suspect] shoulders and up but could not
see his hands.” Officer Monay described Hernandez-Castillanos as “having dark black curly hair, dark
brown skin, male and heavy grey jacket.”
Sergeant Parras asked Officer Monay what happened next, and Office Monay responded “So, after
Officer Cole leaves cover, what I saw is the man on the other side of the fence begin approaching the
fence.  So, it wasn’t until his hand went up in the air that then I saw there was a firearm on that brick
wall, immediately right of the wooden gate, on top of the brick wall.”  Officer Monay confirmed that he
did not see the firearm prior to his approach.  Officer Monay explained the firearm, a black semi-
automatic pistol, was laying on its left side with the barrel pointing west and the magazine pointing
north.  Officer Monay said the suspect was moving toward the firearm “with a hand raised.” Officer
Monay stated that he and Officer Cole were approximately 5-8 feet from the firearm.
Although Officer Cole was continuing to shout commands, the suspect continued to move toward the
firearm. Officer Monay recalled that “his (Hernandez-Castillanos) hand just kept on moving. The
subject’s hand just kept moving” and Officer Monay stated he remembered thinking “How long are you
going to wait?”  It was at this point in the interview that Officer Monay became audibly emotional as he
recalled the moments before discharging his rifle. Officer Monay then indicated with his hand that
Hernandez-Castillanos’ hand got “about a foot or less from the gun” and that’s when Officer Monay
discharged his rifle in the direction of Hernandez-Castillanos.
Officer Monay explained that when he and Officer Cole “were approaching and the subject was also
approaching the fence, he saw the gun, it all clicks.”  Officer Monay said in his mind “now it’s a race for
the gun.  When I see the hand approaching the gun, I made that decision to fire the rounds out of my
rifle.  I only stopped firing because I saw his hand moving away from the handgun.”
Sergeant Parras asked Officer Monay what he thought Hernandez-Castillanos was going to do?  Officer
Monay stated “So, in my mind, he was going to shoot at Cole, he was going to shoot at me, or he was
going to shoot at somebody else in the house, and I couldn’t take that chance.”
Sergeant Parras asked Officer Monay if he knew if Officer Cole had also shot at the suspect, and he said
Officer Cole “did not shoot.”  Sergeant Parras then asked Officer Monay, when he was aiming his rifle,
what was he aiming at?  Officer Monay said he began to lower his rifle on the approach because he was
going to transition to his sidearm until he saw the handgun.  Officer Monay said as all this was going on
Attorney Nicole Pifari asked Officer what type of patrol vehicle he was driving at the time of this
incident, and he said a” Chevy Tahoe, number 005, fully marked patrol vehicle.” He confirmed that
when he arrived at the residence, he had turned off the siren, but his emergency lights were still
activated. Officer Monay stated that he was in full department uniform when he arrived on scene.
Pifari asked Officer Monay if he had heard of the terms, “opportunity and intent.” Officer Monay stated
that he had, and she went on to ask him if Hernandez-Castillanos had the means to harm him. Officer
Monay responded, “He had a firearm, umm, in his presence and he did have the means.”  Pifari then
asked Officer Monay, “When dealing with a firearms situation, would somebody have the opportunity to
harm you with the firearm?”  Officer Monay said, “When they have it on their person or easily
accessible.”  Officer Monay explained Hernandez-Castillanos “had the intent” when Hernandez-
Pifari asked Officer Monay “Did you believe if he got his hands on that gun that he was going to try to
kill you or your partner or other people in the neighborhood?” and Officer Monay responded “Yes.”
Officer Monay confirmed that he and Officer Cole had not spoken to each other since they left the scene.
Pifari allowed me to ask some additional questions of Officer Monay. I asked Officer Monay if he
“H” Street prior to this morning, and Officer Monay did not recall ever
“H” Street prior.  I asked Officer Monay what was going through his mind, after
Officer Cole put out over the radio that he was dealing with a man with a gun, while he was driving to
“H” Street.  Officer Monay said “to get there fast, but safe.  It is a life and death situation for Officer
Cole if I don’t get there fast enough.”
Officer Cole was interviewed by LBPD Detective Beltran and Detective Moreno in a conference room at
Los Banos Police Department on November 25, 2023, at 1250 hours. I listened to the interview live via
cellular phone. The following is a summary of the interview.
Detective Beltran confirmed with Officer Cole that he is a sworn police officer with Los Banos Police
Department (LBPD) and has been so employed for 11 years. Officer Cole was scheduled to work the
day shift on November 25, 2023, and was assigned to Beat 1. Officer Cole stated he was rested before
reporting for his shift, having slept approximately 7 % hours the previous night.
Officer Cole said he had been dispatched to this incident with a report only of “a male subject in the
backyard of ma “H” Street.” Detective Beltran asked if there was any description or additional details
in the call and Officer Cole said he couldn’t remember exactly what the description was. He believed it
was “an HMA” but could not recall specifics.
Officer Cole explained that when he arrived, he was initially at the wrong house first, then went to Jj
“H” Street. As he was approaching the front of the house, he “saw someone walking in the back yard,
HMA, long hair.” Officer Cole said that he thought he activated his body camera when he got out of his
patrol unit, however the investigation showed that no body worn camera footage was captured. Officer
Cole said he motioned to the subject in the backyard to “Come here.” Cole described this motion by
making a waving motion with his right arm as he was explaining this. He recalled that the subject was
not responding and “at one point he, I could see a gun clearly, in black handgun. He [Hernandez-
Castillanos] was pointing [the gun] east, behind the house. The house was obstructing my view of what
he was pointing at.” Officer Cole said that he drew his pistol and held it at low ready and began yelling
commands at the subject “to come to him.” Officer Cole requested another officer as backup to his
location and advised over the radio “he [suspect] has a firearm.”
Officer Cole said he thought there may have been a language barrier “since the guy was not really
responding to him.” Officer Cole described the suspect started walking towards him with the gun
pointed down towards the ground and stated, “If I remember right, he was holding the gun in his right
hand.” Officer Cole said he knows very little Spanish and the best he could come up with was “Armas
on the ground.” Officer Cole stated that the suspect, “wasn’t really listening” and they were separated
by a brick wall and a wooden gate.
Officer Cole recalled when Officer Monay arrived on scene and remembered hearing Officer Monay
“rack his rifle.” Officer Cole says by that time, he had positioned himself behind a tree and Officer
Monay approached on his (Cole’s) left side. He remembered that Hernandez-Castillanos started to walk
towards him, and “I can’t see what he is doing with his hands.” Officer Cole stated he yelled at
Hemandez-Castillanos “a few times to drop the gun in English,” and yelled “Manos arriba.” Officer
Cole remembered he was trying anything he could think of to get some sort of compliance. Officer Cole
said Officer Monay took over commands in Spanish, but Hernandez-Castillanos would still do what they
Officer Cole said that at one point the suspect then reached up and placed the gun on the backyard brick
wall. Officer Cole believed he started to advance toward Hernandez-Castillanos at that point, but he
couldn’t be sure. He did recall that the suspect “then reached for the gun, placed his hand on the gun and
hearing possibly 3 rounds but there may have been more.”  Officer Cole said that he and Officer Monay
then began trying to figure out how to get over the brick wall, so he grabbed the gun from the fence and
Officer Cole said he went and got Officer Monay’s patrol car and moved it to the wall.  He used the push
bumper to get over the wall.  Officer Cole confirmed that once he got over the wall, he handcuffed
Hernandez-Castillanos began checking for injuries. Officer Cole says he could not initially locate any

California Penal Code, Section 196 details the circumstances when a public officer’s intentional killing of
another is justified. CALCRIM 507, a jury instruction, uses plain language to describe the elements of
...1f he killed someone while acting as a public officer. . . [s]uch a killing is justified, and
1. The [person who killed another] was a public officer
2. The killing was committed while overcoming actual resistance to some legal process or
while performing any other legal duty
3. The killing was necessary to accomplish one of those lawful purposes
4. The [public officer] had probable cause to believe that the decedent posed a threat of
death or great bodily injury, either to the [public officer] or to others or that [the
decedent] had committed (insert applicable crime here) and that crime threatened the
[public officer] or others with death or great bodily injury.
A person has probable cause to believe that someone poses a threat of death or great bodily
injury when facts known to the person would persuade someone of reasonable caution that
the other person is going to cause death or great bodily injury to another.
Great bodily injury means significant or substantial physical injury.  It is an injury that is
greater than minor or moderate harm.
The People have the burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the killing was not
justified.  If the People have not met this burden, [a jury] must find the [public officer] not
guilty of murder or manslaughter.  (As was intended by the authors, the language above
was modified or removed to correspond to the circumstances of this case.  Changes are
shown in [brackets].  The full text of CALCRIM 507 is attached in the appendix.)
A peace officer who has reasonable cause to believe a person has committed a public offense or is a danger
to others may use reasonable force to detain or arrest the person, to prevent the person’s escape, or to
overcome the person’s resistance.  (California Penal Code, Section 835a
column2: CALCRIM 2670.)  An officer

column1: who detains or arrests a person does not need to retreat or stop his or her efforts if the person resists or
threatens resistance.  Moreover, using reasonable force does not make the officer an aggressor or cause
him or her to lose the right to self-defense.  (California Penal Code, Section 835a.)  The person being
detained or arrested has a duty to permit himself or herself to be detained, and the person must refrain
from using force or any weapon to resist arrest.  (People v. Allen (1980) 109 Cal.App.3d 981, 985
A peace officer may use deadly force under circumstances where it is reasonably necessary for self-
defense or defense of another.  (California Penal Code, Sections, 196 and 197.)  California law permits
the use of deadly force if the person actually and reasonable believed he/she or another was in imminent
danger of death or great bodily injury.  It is the reasonable appearance of danger to the officer and
his/her honest belief in that danger which is controlling.  If an officer actually believes that deadly force
is necessary and that belief is reasonable under the circumstances, the officer’s actions are lawful even if
it is later determined that the danger did not actually exist.  (CALCRIM 505, 507
column2: People v. Toledo
People v. Jackson (1965) 233 Cal.App.2d 639.)  Further, the officer need not

column1: prove that he/she had the right to use deadly force. Rather, it is the prosecution which must prove that
the officer did not have that right.

Re: Officer Wilkins Officer Involved Shooting October 26, 2023
The Merced County District Attorney’s Office has conducted an investigation into the fatal officer-
involved shooting of Gilbert Garibay by Officers Wilkins on October 26, 2023. The criminal
investigation was led by the Merced Police Department. The District Attorney’s Office Bureau of
Investigations conducted a review of the incident.
The purpose of the investigation by the District Attorney’s Office is to determine if any violation of
criminal law may have occurred on the part of either officer. A prosecutor should file criminal charges
only if the prosecutor reasonably believes that the charges are supported by probable cause, that
admissible evidence will be sufficient to support conviction beyond reasonable doubt, and that the
decision to the charge is in the interest of justice.
Possible criminal charges against Officer Wilkins are: Possible criminal charges against an officer
involved in a shooting include murder (Penal Code Section 187)
column2: manslaughter (Penal Code Section
assault with a deadly weapon (Penal Code Section 245)
column3: and assault by a police officer (Penal

column1: Code Section 149). In order to convict an officer of any of these charges, however, it would be
necessary to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that no legal justifications existed for the officer’s actions.
(People v. Adrian (1982) 135 Cal.App.3d 335, 340-342.) Justifications for an officer’s actions are set
forth in Penal Code Sections 196, 197 and 835a.
Pursuant to Penal Code Section 835a, peace officers may use deadly force, when necessary, in defense
of human life. In decision should be evaluated from the perspective of a reasonable officer in the same
situation, based on the totality of the circumstances known at the time, rather than the benefit of
hindsight. The totality of the circumstances should include considering situations in which officers are
forced to make quick judgments about using force. Penal Code Section 835a further provides a peace
officer is justified in using deadly force when the officer reasonably believes, based on the totality of the
550 W. Main Street * Merced, CA 95340 + Telephone (209) 385-7381 + Fax (209) 725-3669 * Victim Witness Telephone (209) 385-7385
445 I Street * Los Banos, CA 95635 * Telephone (209) 710-6070 + Fax (209) 724-4066
circumstances such force is necessary to defend against imminent threat of death or serious bodily
In this case, Officer Wilkins responded to a dispatch call surrounding a subject who was possibly
suicidal. Officer Kusomo also arrived on scene at some point to assist. While on scene, Officer Wilkins
stated over the radio that he had “one at gunpoint, has a knife won’t put it down.” He then stated,
“responsible walking towards us with knife.” Body camera footage depicts Garibay opening a folding
knife and Officer Wilkins then drawing his firearm. He warned Garibay to drop the knife. Investigators
estimated Garibay was approximately 10 feet from Officer Wilkins at this point. Garibay then advanced
toward Officer Wilkins while Officer Wilkins advised him to “drop the knife” seven times. Garibay told
the officers “shoot me” three separate times. Both officers continued to tell Garibay to drop the knife.
Officer Wilkins retreated as Garibay advanced with the knife as he continued to give commands
including “you’re going to shot, stop.” During the entirety of the contact, it is estimated that Garibay
advanced towards Officer Kusomo and Officer Wilkins over 78 feet as they retreated and gave
commands. After giving multiple commands and the subject failing to comply, Officer Wilkins fired
four rounds from his firearm. Officer Kusomo fired three rounds. Garibay died from gunshot wounds.
Based on Investigator Nelson’s training and experience, individuals with sharp weapons can present
fatal danger to others within 21 feet of others. Here, Officer Wilkins gave multiple commands and gave
Garibay several opportunities to comply before resorting to deadly force as Garibay closed the distance
between himself and Officer Wilkins. Although Officer Wilkins did not give a statement specifically
stating what his state of mind was at the time of using deadly force, circumstantial evidence along with
Investigator Nelson’s opinion support the conclusion that Officer Wilkins reasonably believed it was
necessary to defend against imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury.
Officer Wilkins was justified in using deadly force in this case.

Officer Involved Shooting Case No. MCDA #047-587151 & 047-587153
Shooting Officer(s): Merced Police Department Officers Brandon Wilkins and Saggalih
The District Attorney’s Office has completed an independent review of the above referenced officer
involved shooting which occurred on October 26, 2023. This memorandum serves only to address the
issues of criminal culpability in connection with Officers Brandon Wilkins and Saggalih Kusumo
discharge of their service weapons at the suspect, Gilbert Garibay, and does not take into account any
issues of civil liability, tactics, training, departmental policies or procedures.
The Merced County District Attorney’s Office completed the criminal investigation and reviewed
written reports and other information including:
• Merced Police Department’s (MPD) case number 2023-56604 and supplemental reports

The subject in the median was later identified as Gilbert Garibay. Garibay walked directly in front of

hold the open knife in his right hand and advanced towards the officers. Several more announcements
were made by both officers for Garibay to, “Drop the knife.” Garibay said “shoot me” two more times
and then began to walk faster towards Officer Wilkins. According to the measurements provided by
MPD’s Crime Scene Response Team’s diagram Officer Wilkins walked backwards approximately 78
feet and 10 inches. This measurement was taken from the left front tire of Officer Wilkins’ patrol unit
and where Garibay’s knife was found. Officer Wilkins then announced, “You’re going to get shot,
stop.” Officer Wilkins fired his duty weapon four times at Garibay, and Officer Kusumo fired her duty
Medical aid was provided to Garibay immediately following the shooting by Officer Wilkins.
Responding officers also assisted in providing medical aid and relayed over the radio that it was safe for
emergency medical services (EMS) personnel to come to their location. Medical aid continued until
Garibay was pronounced deceased at 0109 hours, by the Riggs Paramedic Jeffrey Kuhne.

On October 27, 2023, Forensic Pathologist Sam Andrews with NAAG Forensic PC performed an
autopsy on Gilbert Garibay at the Merced County Sheriff’s Office Coroners Facilility.  Dr. Andrews
determined the cause of the death to be “gunshot wounds.”  In addition, the other significant
contributory cause(s) of death were “atherosclerotic and hypertensive cardiovascular disease.”
Garibay had gunshot wounds to his neck, two to the right side of this chest, right shoulder, right thigh,
lower right leg, lower left leg, and a graze gunshot wound to the right side of his face.  The gunshot
wound to Garibay’s neck caused major injuries to the thyroid gland, trachea, esophagus, spinal cord,
thoracic vertebrae, and left lung.  The gunshot wounds to Garibay’s upper right chest caused injuries to
his right lung, right clavicle, right ribs, and right arm.  The gunshot wounds to Garibay’s legs were soft
Dr. Andrews’s incidental findings revealed enlargement of the heart

INVESTIGATOR NELSON’S TRAINING AND EXPERENCE WITH EDGED WEAPONS
Throughout my 25 years as a law enforcement officer, I have received ongoing firearm and defensive
tactic training.  It has been consistently taught to me that edged weapon attacks are highly fatal.  In
addition, a subject with an edged weapon has the ability to close the distance of 21 feet before I can
identify the threat, make a decision and react properly with deadly force.
California Penal Code, Section 196 details the circumstances when a public officer’s intentional killing of
another is justified.  CALCRIM 507, a jury instruction, uses plain language to describe the elements of
. . . if he killed someone while acting as a public officer. . . [s]uch a killing is justified, and
1.  The [person who killed another] was a public officer
2.  The killing was committed while overcoming actual resistance to some legal process or
while performing any other legal duty
3.  The killing was necessary to accomplish one of those lawful purposes
4.  The [public officer] had probable cause to believe that the decedent posed a threat of
death or great bodily injury, either to the [public officer] or to others or that [the
decedent] had committed (insert applicable crime here) and that crime threatened the
[public officer] or others with death or great bodily injury.
A person has probable cause to believe that someone poses a threat of death or great bodily
injury when facts known to the person would persuade someone of reasonable caution that
the other person is going to cause death or great bodily injury to another.
Great bodily injury means significant or substantial physical injury.  It is an injury that is
greater than minor or moderate harm.
The People have the burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the killing was not
justified.  If the People have not met this burden, [a jury] must find the [public officer] not
guilty of murder or manslaughter.  (As was intended by the authors, the language above
was modified or removed to correspond to the circumstances of this case.  Changes are
shown in [brackets].  The full text of CALCRIM 507 is attached in the appendix.)
A peace officer who has reasonable cause to believe a person has committed a public offense or is a danger
to others may use reasonable force to detain or arrest the person, to prevent the person’s escape, or to
overcome the person’s resistance.  (California Penal Code, Section 835a
column2: CALCRIM 2670.)  An officer

column1: who detains or arrests a person does not need to retreat or stop his or her efforts if the person resists or
threatens resistance.  Moreover, using reasonable force does not make the officer an aggressor or cause
him or her to lose the right to self-defense.  (California Penal Code, Section 835a.)  The person being
detained or arrested has a duty to permit himself or herself to be detained, and the person must refrain
from using force or any weapon to resist arrest.  (People v. Allen (1980) 109 Cal.App.3d 981, 985
A peace officer may use deadly force under circumstances where it is reasonably necessary for self-
defense or defense of another.  (California Penal Code, Sections, 196 and 197.)  California law permits
the use of deadly force if the person actually and reasonable believed he/she or another was in imminent
danger of death or great bodily injury.  It is the reasonable appearance of danger to the officer and his/her
honest belief in that danger which is controlling.  If an officer actually believes that deadly force is
necessary and that belief is reasonable under the circumstances, the officer’s actions are lawful even if it
is later determined that the danger did not actually exist.  (CALCRIM 505, 507
column2: People v. Toledo (1948)
People v. Jackson (1965) 233 Cal.App.2d 639.)  Further, the officer need not prove

column1: that he/she had the right to use deadly force. Rather, it is the prosecution which must prove that the officer
SAN JOAQUIN COUNTY OFFICER INVOLVED CRITICAL INCIDENT
FROM: MARK OTT: CHIEF DEPUTY DA
column2: HOMICIDE

column1: The San Joaquin County District Attorney's Office has concludedats review of the San
Joaquin County Officer-Involved Critical Incident Protocol Joint Investigation (“Investigation”)
by the San Joaquin County Sheriff's Office (“SJSO”), the City of Stockton Police Department

column2: San Joaquin County’s Office of the Medical

column1: Examiner (“SJCOME”), and the San Joaquin County District Attorney's Bureau of Investigations
(“SJDA-BOI”), of the fatal, solo vehicular collision occurring on October 8, 2023. The driver
and solo occupant, CHRISTAIN SHANE PANELA (“Panela”) (DOB: 08/20/1974), died from
his injures because of his vehicle collided with a tree and he suffered severe blunt force trauma.
Despite the immediate medical intervention efforts, Panela succumbed to his injuries.
After a thorough review of the reports, interviews, witness statements, documents,
photos, diagrams and evidence, including video footage, in the investigation, we have concluded
that the pursuing officers — San Joaquin County Sheriff s Deputy M. Doble (“Doble”), and San
Joaquin County Sheriff Deputy Q. Washington. (“Washington.”) both officers (collectively
referred to as “SO Officers”), — did not detain, arrest, or otherwise seize Mr. Panela by assertion
of authority or physical force. The actions of the SO Officers involved were lawful enforcement
actions and not the cause of the solo, fatal collision.
Therefore, no criminal charges are warranted.
This review of the Investigation reports, witness statements, video review, photos,
diagrams, expert opinions, and evidence of the Investigation resulted in the following findings:
In addition, they were a distinctively marked SJSO Patrol Vehicle (“Sheriff's Vehicle”).
The patrol vehicle was a black and white Chevrolet Caprice with gold ""SHERIFF""
markings equipped with functioning siren, functioning overhead light bar and emergency
flashing red lights. Deputy Washington was operating the fully marked SJSO Patrol
Vehicle with his Field Training Deputy, Michael Doble. Deputy Washington had been
training with Deputy Doble for approximately four weeks.
On the date reference above, they were driving south bound on Filbert Avenue
approaching Main Street. AS they did so, they heard the sound of tire squealing in the
area. They opened their windows and determined the tire squealing was coming from the
west. Deputy Washington began to drive west bound on Main Street, toward the sound of
the tire squealing. As he did so, he saw a dark colored vehicle doing ""donuts"" in an
intersection. The vehicle was a Pontiac Firebird Trans Am, (“the Pontiac”) and being
driven by Panela. Panela was observed doing approximately four ""donuts"" and ""spinning
out"" in the area of Main Street and Searchlight Avenue. “Donuts"" is a widely known
driving maneuver in which the rear or, front of the vehicle rotates around the opposite set
of wheels in a continuous motion, creating a circular pattern. This is typically
accomplished with near wide-open throttle acceleration, breaking traction of the driven
tires, while feathering the brake and throttle. One then steers in their chosen direction.
Doing donuts is a violation of the California Vehicle Code. See CVC 23103.
Deputy Washington made a U-turn to get behind the Pontiac and activated his
overhead emergency lights, which included a forward facing red light. Deputy
Washington aired that they were attempting fo stop a vehicle for reckless driving. The
Pontiac continued eastbound on Main Street. Deputy Washington estimated that the
Pontiac was traveling at approximately 50 to 60 MPH in violation of the posted speed
limit. The Pontiac made a northbound turn onto Filbert Street from Main Street and
accelerated. Deputy Washington noticed that his siren was not on and he activated it at
this point. Deputy Washington explained that some patrol vehicles are equipped to have
the siren turn on automatically when the code 3 lights are activated while some are not.
The suspect vehicle made one or two more ""donuts"" in the intersection then it drove
toward the deputies and passed them going eastbound on Main Street. Deputy
Washington made a U-turn to follow the vehicle. Deputy Doble said the suspect vehicle
hooked the corner"" turning northbound on Filbert Avenue.
While at the intersection of Main Street and Filbert, Deputy Washington aired over
the radio, to San Joaquin Sheriff's Office Dispatch, that he was going to make a traffic
stop and that the suspect vehicle failed to yield. Deputy Doble aired the suspect vehicle
plate (California Plate 46EFP396). He aired that their ""want"" on the vehicle was for
reckless driving. Deputy Doble said that speeds at that moment approximated 80 miles
per hour, again in violation of the posted speed limit.
The Pontiac was traveling at a high rate of speed and did not slow for signal lights.
Deputy Washington was able to keep the Pontiac in his view at a distance as he slowed to
clear intersections. Deputy Washington indicated that the Pontiac failed to stop for
multiple red traffic signals. As the Pontiac continued northbound on Filbert Street just
south of the Crosstown Freeway, it pulled over to the opposite side (west side) of the
roadway and did one donut. The deputies continued northbound on Filbert Avenue
passing Myrtle Street with the suspect vehicle pulling away from them in northbound
lanes of travel. The Pontiac nearly collided into another vehicle at Filbert Street and
Fremont Street. The suspect vehicle ran the red light at Fremont Street. The Pontiac
swerved to the left (west) to avoid colliding with an uninvolved vehicle which was
traveling northbound in the #1. The Pontiac sped up and Deputy Washington estimated
at this point that the Pontiac was now traveling at 90 to 100 MPH. When the Pontiac was
approaching Harding Way, Deputy Washington lost sight of it as there was a curve in the
roadway. Deputy Washington estimated he was approximately 100 yards behind the
Pontiac. Deputy Washington said he heard the ""burning rubber sound"" when the Pontiac
was at Main Street and Filbert Street. During the pursuit, Deputy Washington saw smoke,
which appeared to be coming from the Pontiac's tires.
Deputy Doble aired out that the Pontiac ran the stop sign at Harding Way and he
had not seen the vehicle brake at all. Deputy Doble estimated the Pontiac’s speed to be
90-100 mph at that time he lost visual of the vehicle. As they continued through the
curve in the roadway and came to Harding Way, they saw that the Pontiac had crashed,
and was facing sideways in the roadway. Deputy Doble could not see anyone in the
Pontiac, and he was unsure if anyone was inside the vehicle or if they had fled on foot.
At this time, a second SJSO Patrol Vehicle arrived on scene. Field Training Deputy
Nathan MATCHAK and his trainee, Deputy Markus PALACIO, occupied the second
patrol vehicle. The actual collision occurred outside the direct line of sight of any of the
pursuing deputies or the other responding deputies. The entirety of Pontiac was severely
Body Worn Camera (BWC) footage from deputies Washington and Doble was
activated at the scene of the crash. The suspect driver, identified as Christian Shane
Panela, was found inside the vehicle, laying across the driver seat and passenger seat.
His leg appeared to be pinned under the driver side dashboard of the vehicle. Christian
PANELA was laying across the front seats with his eyes looking to the ceiling of the
vehicle and was unresponsive. Deputy Doble said another unit arrived on scene and
assisted them with CPR. Deputy Doble, SJSO Deputies Matchek and Palacio attempted
to open the driver side door but it was too damaged to open. Deputy Palacios then
climbed into the vehicle through the driver side door and began chest compressions. He
was assisted by other the Deputies in providing CPR efforts.
Deputy DOBLE said the condition/position of the (driver's side) seatbelt was
unlatched. He indicated that it was “hanging”. He said the seat belt pulled a little due to
the way it was pinched between the driver's seat and the B-pillar from the collision. He
said it did not appear the suspect was buckled prior to the collision. Deputy DOBLE said
he cut the seat belt so that fire and medics could have better access to the suspect. Deputy
DOBLE was unable to open the vehicle doors. However, fire units were able to pry the
doors open. The fire department units took over advanced life saving measures upon
removing Panela from the vehicle. PANELA appeared to have severe injuries.
A subsequent search of the Pontiac, pursuant to a subpoena, found an “empty, 50 ml
New Amsterdam Vodka plastic bottle located on the front drivers floor board.
Asa result of this crash Panela sustained blunt force trauma of his torso, caused an
aortic transection, which resulted in acute blood loss and his death. Panela was
pronounced deceased at the crash utilizing telephonic protocols by Dr. Lima at San
It was determined that four parked vehicles suffered collision damage from being struct
by Panela’s vehicle and in turn propelled them into each other. There was no apparent
damage from a collision to any SJSO patrol vehicles involved. The distance from the
intersection of Filbert Street and Main Street to 1418 N. Filbert Street (location Pontiac
came to rest) is approximately | .4 miles. There are eight intersections controlled by
traffic signals and one intersection controlled by a stop sign. Railroad tracks cross Filbert
The postmortem examination of Panela included the collection of a blood sample
for toxicology analysis for Central Valley Toxicology, Inc (“CVT”). CVT detected the
presence of ethyl alcohol to be .18, a concentration (twice the legal limit o 0.08) and
detected the presence of Cannabis (delta-9-THC = 1.4 n/g/mL
column2: delta-9-THC-COOH = 7.6
delta-9-THC-OH < 1.4 n/g/m/L. Based upon these results it is opined that Mr.

column1: Panela was under the combined influence of alcohol and drugs at the time of this crash.
It was determined that Panela was in violation of CVC for reckless driving while
doing donuts. He fled in wanton disregard in violation of CVC 2800.2. He was driving
while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage, a violation of CVC 23152.
No police unit Vehicle or law enforcement personnel ever made physical contact
with Mr. Panela’s Vehicle or Mr. Panela prior to the collision. Upon inspection, the
Sheriff's Vehicle involved in the direct pursuit suffered no physical damage of any kind.
Based on evidence at the scene and witness' statements, it appears Panela was operating
his Vehicle on October 8, 20220n or about 2:27 A.M. in an unsafe manner, committing
numerous moving California Vehicle Violations, fleeing from a marked San Joaquin County
Sheriff Vehicle that had its forward facing solid red light and siren activated at a high rate of
speed. It would appear that during the pursuit, Panela even attempted to “taunt” the deputies by
continuing to taunt them with additional donut maneuvers. As Panel’s vehicle was heading
eastbound on N. Filbert at the intersection with E. Harding way, he was unable to stay on the
roadway and collided with a curb. Due to Mr. Panela’s high rate of speed, influenced no doubt
by his intoxication on alcohol and marijuana, he was unable to control his vehicle through the
intersection and cause the collision(s) that took his life.
Based on the evidence and statements it is apparent that Panela caused the collision by
being in violation of: (VC)23103 (a) Reckless Driving
column2: VC 2800.1, Intention to Evade Peace
and VC 2800.2, Attempting to Evade Peace Officer While Driving

column1: Recklessly and being under the influence VC 23152.
Deputy Doble and Deputy Washington had reasonable and articulable suspicion to stop
and detain Mr. Panela for moving violations, his immediate driving conduct while fleeing and after
he failed to stop. No SJSO Deputy exerted any physical force on Panela or the vehicle he was
driving. Mr. Panela’s death is attributable to his active flight and unsafe driving conduct which
caused him to lose control of his vehicle, while not wearing a seatbelt, resulting in his death.
In applying the prevailing legal standards, the totality of the circumstances, and in light of
all of the evidence obtained from the multi-task force Investigation, it is the opinion of the District
Attorney that the death of Mr. Panela was caused by Mr. Panela’s decisions and actions and
therefore, no criminal charges are warranted.

SUBJECT: Notice of Reprimand and Disciplinary Transfer
This memorandum is being hand delivered to you to advise you of a disciplinary reprimand
and disciplinary transfer to another division. In addition to this reprimand and disciplinary
transfer, you will be required to complete two (2) hours of Equal Employment Opportunity
refresher training. This training will be completed on City time and paid for by the City.
On Labor Day weekend in 2023, you and other officers were in the line-up room prior to the
beginning of your shift. A female officer brought in food that her girlfriend had made for
everyone. In front of multiple officers, you offered to, “provide a baby” and essentially be a
sperm donor for the female officer and her girlfriend.
On October 14, 2023, you were talking to a couple of officers about a supervisor who was
allegedly cheating on their spouse. You said something similar to, “You can stick your dick in
whatever you want, bro. I don’t judge as long as you’re there for your kids.”
A disciplinary transfer is necessary because your comments of a sexual nature offended a
female officer assigned to Central Division. In addition, multiple officers who were
interviewed during the Internal Affairs investigation agreed that your comments were
inappropriate in the work setting. If you were to remain at Central Division, there is a
likelihood the same type of interactions would continue thus leading to future complaints
You have violated Civil Service Rule XI, Section 3(b), (d) and (i), in that you have been
offensive in your conduct toward fellow employees, you have violated lawful or official
regulations, and you are guilty of conduct this is unbecoming of an officer.

Re: Decision whether to return Officer Gabriel Artiga #2741 and Officer Russell Luicia
#2490 to duty following their involvement in Officer Involved Shooting #23-004.
Officers Gabriel Artiga #2741 and Russell Lucia #2490, currently assigned to Tenderloin
Station, were the involved members in the Officer-Involved Shooting (OIS 23-004) which
occurred on Monday August 28th, 2023. The OIS occurred at PD ones Street in San
Francisco. The involved officers were on-duty and in uniform at the time of the shooting.
On Tuesday, September 5, 2023 at 1120 hours, pursuant to Department General Order
8.11.I1.G.4, the Return to Duty panel convened to discuss whether it was appropriate for the
involved members to return to duty.
The panel was comprised of the following:
e Deputy Chief Peter Walsh-Administration Bureau (Chair)
e Deputy Chief Julian Ng-Field Operations Bureau
e Commander Derek Lew-Field Operations Bureau-Mid-City Division
e Acting Commander Mark Im-Risk Management Office/Chief of Staff
e Acting Captain Angela Wilhelm-Internal Affairs Division/Risk Management Office
e Lieutenant David Do-Investigative Services Detail
e Sergeant Art Howard-Behavioral Science Unit
Also present was Sergeant Joseph Minner of the Administration Bureau.
The panel called upon the following disciplines to summarily report on any updates and
discuss the factors that are taken into consideration when determining whether to return an
Investigative Services Detail (ISD): Lieutenant Do provided a brief recap of the incident to
the panel. The briefing was an overview of the incident discussing the currently known facts
and evidence of this incident. This included a review of available body worn camera footage
and cell phone video captured by a witness to the incident. Lt. Do advised the involved
officers have been interviewed by ISD and the District Attorney Office’s Independent
Internal Affairs Division (IAD): Acting Captain Wilhelm advised both officers completed
the Firearm Range debrief on Friday September Ist, 2023 at the Lake Merced Range. The
debrief was completed satisfactorily and the range staff has no concerns regarding the officers
returning to duty. A/Capt. Wilhelm advised the administrative investigation is ongoing.
Behavioral Science Unit (BSU): Sergeant Howard advised that Officer Artiga had
completed the mandatory BSU Department Critical Incident debriefing on August 30th,
2023. Officer Lucia completed his BSU debriefing on September Ist, 2023. (Ae
about returning the officers to duty.
After discussion and consideration of the presentations to the panel, the Return to Duty panel
voted unanimously to recommend that the officers be returned to duty at this time. My
decision whether to return these officers to duty, including the aforementioned mandatory
debriefings and factors supporting the decision, is scheduled for presentation to the Police
Commission in closed session on Wednesday, September 13th, 2023. I look forward to
discussing my decision with you at this Police Commission meeting.
OFFICE OF THE CHIEF OF POLICE
From: Jose L. Garza, Chief of Police
Subject: Case Closure and Exoneration of Sergeant Steven Puryear
After a thorough investigation and consideration of all pertinent evidence, it has been determined that
the allegations against Sergeant Steven Puryear are unsubstantiated, and therefore, is exonerated of
The investigation included interviews with witnesses, a review of body camera footage, and an
examination of any other relevant documentation. Additionally, discussions were held with Sergeant
Puryear to gather their account of the incident in question.
Based on the comprehensive review conducted by the internal affairs team, it has been concluded that
Sergeant Puryear acted within departmental policies and procedures during the encounter in question.
The use of force employed was deemed to be reasonable and justified, given the circumstances

This policy provides guidelines on the reasonable use of force. While there is no way to specify
the exact amount or type of reasonable force to be applied in any situation, every member of
this department is expected to use these guidelines to make such decisions in a professional,
to those methods, techniques, and tools set forth below, the guidelines for the
in this policy shall apply to
the potential use of force, including but not limited to the Control Devices and Techniques and
Retaliation prohibitions for reporting suspected violations are addressed in the Anti-Retaliation
Definitions related to this policy include:
Deadly force - Any use of force that creates a substantial risk of causing death or serious bodily
injury, including but not limited to the discharge of a firearm (Penal Code § 835a).
or carried out under the circumstances
successfully achieve the arrest or lawful objective without increasing risk to the officer or another
Force - The application of physical techniques or tactics, chemical agents, or weapons to another
It is not a use of force when a person allows him/herself to be searched, escorted,
Serious bodily injury - A serious impairment of physical condition, including but not limited to

column1: Totality of the circumstances - All facts known to the officer at the time, including the conduct
of the officer and the subject leading up to the use of force (Penal Code § 835a).
The use of force by law enforcement personnel is a matter of critical concern, both to the public
and to the law enforcement community. Officers are involved on a daily basis in numerous and
varied interactions and, when warranted, may use reasonable force in carrying out their duties.
Officers must have an understanding of, and true appreciation for, their authority and limitations.
This is especially true with respect to overcoming resistance while engaged in the performance
Copyright Lexipol, LLC 2024/02/07, All Rights Reserved.
Published with permission by Reedley Police Department
The Agency recognizes and respects the value of all human life and dignity without prejudice to
anyone. Vesting officers with the authority to use reasonable force and to protect the public welfare
requires monitoring, evaluation and a careful balancing of all interests.
Any officer present and observing another law enforcement officer or an employee using force
that is clearly beyond that which is necessary, as determined by an objectively reasonable officer
under the circumstances, shall, when in a position to do so, intercede (as defined by Government
Code § 7286) to prevent the use of unreasonable force.
When observing force used by a law enforcement officer, each officer should take into account
the totality of the circumstances and the possibility that other law enforcement officers may have
additional information regarding the threat posed by the subject (Government Code § 7286(b)).
FAIR AND UNBIASED USE OF FORCE
Officers are expected to carry out their duties, including the use of force, in
and unbiased (Government Code § 7286(b)). See the Bias-Based Policing Policy for additional
Any officer who observes a law enforcement officer or an employee use force that potentially
exceeds what the officer reasonably believes to be necessary shall immediately report these
As used in this subsection, ""immediately"" means as soon as it is safe and feasible to do so.
An officer who has received the required training on the duty to intercede and then fails to act to
intercede when required by law, may be disciplined in the same manner as the officer who used
force beyond that which is necessary (Government Code § 7286(b)).
Officers shall use only that amount of force that reasonably appears necessary given the facts
and totality of the circumstances known to or perceived by the officer at the time of the event to
accomplish a legitimate law enforcement purpose (Penal Code § 835a).
The reasonableness of force will be judged from the perspective of
scene at the time of the incident. Any evaluation of reasonableness must allow for the fact that
officers are often forced to make split-second decisions about the amount of force that reasonably
appears necessary in a particular situation, with limited information and in circumstances that are
Given that no policy can realistically predict every possible situation an officer might encounter,
officers are entrusted to use well-reasoned discretion in determining the appropriate use of force in
each incident. Officers may only use a level of force that they reasonably believe is proportional to

USE OF FORCE TO EFFECT AN ARREST
Any peace officer may use objectively reasonable force to effect an arrest, to prevent escape,
or to overcome resistance. A peace officer who makes or attempts to make an arrest need not
retreat or desist from his/her efforts by reason of resistance or threatened resistance on the part

RESTRICTIONS ON THE USE OF CAROTID CONTROL HOLD
Officers of this department are not authorized to use a carotid restraint hold. A carotid restraint
means a vascular neck restraint or any similar restraint, hold, or other defensive tactic in which
pressure is applied to the sides of a person’s neck that involves a substantial risk of restricting
blood flow and may render the person unconscious in order to subdue or control the person
Copyright Lexipol, LLC 2024/02/07, All Rights Reserved.
Published with permission by Reedley Police Department
USE OF FORCE TO SEIZE EVIDENCE
In general, officers may use reasonable force to lawfully seize evidence and to prevent the
destruction of evidence. However, officers are discouraged from using force solely to prevent
a person from swallowing evidence or contraband. In the instance when force is used, officers
should not intentionally use any technique that restricts blood flow to the head, restricts respiration
or which creates a reasonable likelihood that blood flow to the head or respiration would be
restricted. Officers are encouraged to use techniques and methods taught by the Reedley Police
As time and circumstances reasonably permit, and when community and officer safety would
not be compromised, officers should consider actions that may increase officer safety and may
decrease the need for using force:
Summoning additional resources that are able to respond
Formulating a plan with responding officers before entering an unstable situation that
does not reasonably appear to require immediate intervention.
Employing other tactics that do not unreasonably increase officer jeopardy.
In addition, when reasonable, officers should evaluate the totality of circumstances presented at
the time in each situation and, when feasible, consider and utilize reasonably available alternative
tactics and techniques that may persuade an individual to voluntarily comply or may mitigate the
need to use a higher level of force to resolve the situation before applying force (Government
Code § 7286(b)). Such alternatives may include but are not limited to:
If reasonably available, the use of crisis intervention techniques by properly trained
RESTRICTIONS ON THE USE OF A CHOKE HOLD
Officers of this department are not authorized to use a choke hold. A choke hold means any
defensive tactic or force option in which direct pressure is applied to a person’s trachea or windpipe
Terms such as ""positional asphyxia,"" ""restraint asphyxia,"" and ""excited delirium"" continue to
remain the subject of debate among experts and medical professionals, are not universally
recognized medical conditions, and frequently involve other collateral or controlling factors such
as narcotics or alcohol influence or pre-existing medical conditions. While it is impractical to restrict
an officer's use of reasonable control methods when attempting to restrain a combative individual,
officers are not authorized to use any restraint or transportation method which might unreasonably
impair an individual's breathing or respiratory capacity for
a period beyond the point when the
individual has been adequately and safely controlled. Once the individual is safely secured, officers

If an objectively reasonable officer would consider it safe and feasible to do so under the totality
of the circumstances, officers shall evaluate and use other reasonably available resources and

Officers shall not use deadly force against a person based on the danger that person poses to
themself, if an objectively reasonable officer would believe the person does not pose an imminent
threat of death or serious bodily injury to the officer or to another person (Penal Code § 835a).
Additionally, an officer should not use deadly force against a person whose actions are a threat
An ""imminent"" threat of death or serious bodily injury exists when, based on the totality of the
circumstances, a reasonable officer in the same situation would believe that a person has the
present ability, opportunity, and apparent intent to immediately cause death or serious bodily injury
to the officer or another person. An officer's subjective fear of future harm alone is insufficient as
an imminent threat. An imminent threat is one that from appearances is reasonably believed to
SHOOTING AT OR FROM MOVING VEHICLES
Shots fired at or from a moving vehicle are rarely effective and involve considerations and risks
in addition to the justification for the use of deadly force. When feasible, officers should take
reasonable steps to move out of the path of an approaching vehicle instead of discharging their
firearm at the vehicle or any of its occupants. An officer should only discharge a firearm at
vehicle or its occupants when the officer reasonably believes there are no other reasonable means

available to avert the imminent threat of the vehicle, or if deadly force other than the vehicle is
directed at the officer or others (Government Code § 7286(b)).
Officers should not shoot at any part of a vehicle in an attempt to disable the vehicle.
Given that individuals might perceive the display of a firearm as a potential application of force,
officers should carefully evaluate each tactical situation and use sound discretion when drawing

This policy provides guidelines for the issuance and use of the conducted energy device (CED).
The CED is used in an attempt to control a violent or potentially violent individual. The appropriate
use of such a device may result in fewer serious injuries to officers and suspects.
Only members who have successfully completed department-approved training may be issued
The Rangemaster should keep a log of issued CED devices and the serial numbers of cartridges/
CEDs are issued for use during a member's current assignment. Those leaving a particular
assignment may be required to return the device to the department inventory.
Officers shall only use the CED and cartridges/magazines that have been issued by the Agency.
Cartridges/magazines should not be used after the manufacturer's expiration date.
Uniformed officers who have been issued the CED shall wear the device in an approved holster.
Officers who carry the CED while in uniform shall carry it in a holster on the side opposite the duty
All CEDs shall be clearly distinguishable to differentiate them from the duty weapon
For single-shot devices, whenever practicable, officers should carry an additional
cartridge on their person when carrying the CED.
Officers should not hold a firearm and the CED at the same time.
Non-uniformed officers may secure the CED
Officers shall be responsible for ensuring that the issued CED
good working order. This includes a function test and battery life monitoring, as required by the
manufacturer, and should be completed prior to the beginning of the officer's shift.
CEDs that are damaged or inoperative, or cartridges/magazines that are expired or damaged,
shall be returned to the Rangemaster for disposition. Officers shall submit documentation stating
the reason for the return and how the CED or cartridge/magazine was damaged or became
Copyright Lexipol, LLC 2024/02/07, All Rights Reserved.
Published with permission by Reedley Police Department
A verbal warning of the intended use of the CED should precede its application, unless
otherwise endanger the safety of officers or when
it is not practicable due to the circumstances.
The purpose of the warning is to:
Provide the individual with a reasonable opportunity to voluntarily comply.
Provide other officers and individuals with a warning that the CED may be deployed.
If, after a verbal warning, an individual fails to voluntarily comply with an officer's lawful orders
it appears both reasonable and feasible under the circumstances, the officer may, but is not
required to, activate any warning on the device, which may include display of the electrical arc,
an audible warning, or the laser in a further attempt to gain compliance prior to the application of
the CED. The laser should not be intentionally directed into anyone's eyes.
The fact that a verbal or other warning was given or the reasons
it was not given shall be
documented by the officer deploying the CED in the related report.
The CED has limitations and restrictions requiring consideration before its use. The CED should
only be used when its operator can safely deploy the device within its operational range. Although
the CED may be effective in controlling most individuals, officers should be aware that the device
may not achieve the intended results and be prepared with other options.
If sufficient personnel are available and can be safely assigned, an officer designated as lethal
a CED may be considered for officer safety.
The CED may be used, when the circumstances reasonably perceived by the officer at the time
indicate that such application reasonably appears necessary to control a person who:
Is violent or is physically resisting.
Has demonstrated, by words or action, an intention to be violent or to physically resist,
and reasonably appears to present the potential to harm officers, themself, or others.
Mere flight from a pursuing officer, without additional circumstances or factors, is not good cause
for the use of the CED to apprehend an individual.
The CED shall not be used to psychologically torment, to elicit statements, or to punish any
The use of the CED on certain individuals should generally be avoided unless the totality of
the circumstances indicates that other available options reasonably appear ineffective or would
present a greater danger to the officer, the subject or others, and the officer reasonably believes
that the need to control the individual outweighs the potential risk of using the device. This includes:
Individuals who are known to be pregnant.

Published with permission by Reedley Police Department
Individuals with obviously low body mass.
Individuals who are handcuffed or otherwise restrained.
Individuals known to have been recently sprayed with a flammable chemical agent or
who are otherwise known to be in close proximity to any known combustible vapor or
flammable material, including alcohol-based oleoresin capsicum (OC) spray.
Individuals whose position or activity is likely to result in collateral injury (e.g., falls
from height, located in water, operating vehicles).
Any CED capable of being applied
in the drive-stun mode (i.e., direct contact without probes
as a primary form of pain compliance) should be limited to supplementing the probe-mode to
complete the circuit, or as a distraction technique to gain separation between officers and the
subject, thereby giving officers time and distance to consider other force options or actions.

If circumstances result in one or more probes inadvertently striking an area
outside of the preferred target zones, the individual should be closely monitored until examined
by paramedics or other medical personnel.

Whether it is reasonable to believe that the need to control the individual outweighs

Whether the probes are making proper contact.

Whether verbal commands or other options or tactics may be more effective.

Immediately cease any force once a subject is under control

This is to advise you that | am proposing that you be terminated from your employment
as a Martinez police officer based on your conduct described below, effective at the
All the conduct occurred on August 18, 2023, when officers from the Martinez Police
Department were dispatched to the Velvet Dispensary for a report of a possible burglary
in progress. Four Martinez Police Department officers participated in an officer involved
shooting, firing at the suspect vehicle as it fled the scene. Both occupants of the vehicle
were struck by gunfire and the vehicle crashed a short distance away. An administrative
investigation was conducted that revealed that you violated several Martinez Police
Any future hearing officer or appellate body is advised that any one of the following
charges, standing alone, would support my decision to propose that you be terminated
from your employment as a Martinez police officer.

Officers shall use only that amount of force that reasonably appears necessary
given the facts and totality of the circumstances known to or perceived by the
officer at the time of the event to accomplish a legitimate law enforcement
e On August 18, 2023, you responded to the scene near the Velvet Dispensary
shortly after the officers fired on the suspects and the car had crashed. One
of the suspects (who had been shot) exited the vehicle at the direction of
officers and was then handcuffed without resisting. As another officer was
dragging the suspect away from the vehicle, you lifted the suspect by his
sweatshirt and assisted in pulling him into the street. While pulling him, you

delivered two or three knee strikes to the suspect’s head/face area. Given the

was handcuffed, not resisting and was not disobeying any commands that he
MARTINEZ POLICE DEPARTMENT POLICY 300.5.1 — NOTIFICATION TO
Any use of force by an officer shall be reported immediately to a supervisor,
including but not limited to the following circumstances.... As used in this
subsection, “immediately” means as soon as it is safe and feasible to do so.
On August 18, 2023, you responded to the scene near the Velvet
Dispensary shortly after the officers fired on the suspects and the car had
crashed. One of the suspects (who had been shot) exited the vehicle at
the direction of officers and was then handcuffed without resisting. As
another officer was dragging the suspect away from the vehicle, you lifted
the suspect by his sweatshirt and assisted in pulling him into the street.
While pulling him, you delivered two or three knee strikes to the suspect’s
head/face area. You failed to immediately notify the on-scene sergeant
that you had used force. Body worn camera footage from the scene and
witness statements make clear that there were ample opportunities right
after your use of force during which it was safe and feasible for you to
inform the on-scene sergeant, but you did not.
Criminal, dishonest, infamous or disgraceful conduct adversely affecting the
employee/employer relationship, whether on or off duty.
After you unjustifiably kneed the suspect in the head/face area (while he
was handcuffed), you learned that he had been shot by the officers. You
approached the suspect and told him, “Play stupid games, win stupid
prizes.” Making that taunting statement to someone who had been shot
and against whom you had used unjustified force was disgraceful and
On August 18, 2023, you responded to a scene where an officer involved
shooting had occurred (Martinez Police Department Case # 23-1720).
While you were on scene, another Martinez police officer (who had shot at
the suspects) approached you and asked to have a conversation with you
with the body worn cameras turned off. You declined. A few seconds later,
after you had walked away, that same officer approached you again, with
both of his hands behind his back, apparently in order to conceal from the
view of your camera what he was holding in his hands (behind his back).
Notice of Intent to Impose Discipline, IA No. |A23-07 and |A23-08
He asked you “Can you do me a favor?” There were two knives in his
hands. You reached behind the officer’s back and took the knives from
him, without asking any questions about the knives or why the officer
wanted you to take them. You then returned to your patrol vehicle, put the
knives in a backpack in your patrol vehicle, and then returned to where
you had been previously standing. Your acceptance and subsequent
storage of the knives in the immediate aftermath of an officer involved
shooting reveals that you did so for an illegitimate reason, most likely to
aid the other officer from being disciplined as a result of carrying the
knives. One of the knives is of a type that is prohibited to be worn on duty
and is also prohibited to be carried by anyone as a concealed weapon.
Your conduct was disgraceful and adversely affects the employer-

You were hired as a Martinez police officer in June 2021.
You have previously been disciplined for using unnecessary force in IA# |A23-02. In
November 2023, you received a 20-day suspension without pay based on the
Notice of Intent to Impose Discipline, [A No. 1A23-07 and 1A23-08
unnecessary force you used on a male subject at the Amtrak station on April 1, 2023. In
addition to the suspension, you were precluded from conducting any training for three
years. In the April 1, 2023 incident, you used unnecessary force, failed to report your
use of force to a supervisor, and failed to document your force in an appropriate report.
The use of force by a police officer is of critical concern to both the public and the law
enforcement community. You engaged in an unnecessary use of force towards the
suspect at the Velvet Dispensary. He was handcuffed and was not resisting any
commands at the time you kneed him. You failed to immediately report the force, and
instead found time to taunt the suspect by telling him, “play stupid games, win stupid
This incident occurred just months after | conducted a one-on-one training with you
regarding the use of force policy along with Commander Hurlbut and Lieutenant
Salamid. During that training, | reviewed the policy with you, including the requirements
to immediately report the use of force to a supervisor. Nevertheless, you have once
again used unnecessary force and failed to timely report it to a supervisor, and your
conduct in taunting a suspect, who had been shot, was disgraceful.
Your conduct regarding the knives given to you by another officer during this incident is
disgraceful and reveals that you cannot be trusted to perform the duties of a police
All of the rules you violated exist to ensure that the Martinez Police Department acts
with integrity, engenders and maintains the public trust, and mitigates potential liability.
| have no confidence that you would not continue to engage in this type of misconduct if
you were returned to your position as a Martinez police officer. For all these reasons, |
am recommending that your employment be terminated.

SUBJECT: ADJUDICATION, IA NO. 1IA23-07 OFC. TIRONA
An investigation was conducted by a private investigative service specializing in police
conduct investigations, Chaplin & Hill Investigative Services, LLC. The primary
investigator assigned was Brian Hill, an investigator for Chaplin & Hill. The complete
investigation report was provided to the Martinez Police Department on November 8,
The Martinez Police Department Command Staff consisting of myself and Lt. Salamid
were assigned to review the submitted investigation report and supporting documents to
include video and audio recordings. Having completed the review of the investigation
report and supporting materials the Command Staff met on November 9, 2023 to
discuss the investigation report and the recommendations within the investigation report
with regards to specific allegations. In addition, the Command Staff was tasked with
providing a recommendation for disciplinary action.
It is recommended that the allegations be classified as recommended by the
Command Staff agreed with the recommended findings as described in the
Ofc. Tirona was a probationary police officer at the time of this incident with 10 months
