PENAL CODE SECTION 197.  California law permits all persons to use deadly force to
protect themselves from the imminent threat of death or great bodily injury.  Penal Code
§197 provides that the use of deadly force by any person is justifiable when used in self-
defense or in defense of others.
The pertinent criminal jury instruction to this section is CALCRIM 505 (“Justifiable
Homicide: Self-Defense or Defense of Another”).  The instruction, rooted in caselaw,
states that a person acts in lawful self-defense or defense of another if:
He reasonably believed that he or someone else was in imminent danger
of being killed or suffering great bodily injury
He reasonably believed that the immediate use of deadly force was
necessary to defend against that danger
column2: and

column1: He used no more force than was reasonably necessary to defend against
(CALCRIM 505.)  The showing required under section 197 is principally equivalent to the
showing required under section 835a(c)(1), as stated supra.
IMMINENCE.  “Imminence is a critical component” of self-defense.  (People v. Humphrey
(1996) 13 Cal.4th 1073, 1094.) A person may resort to the use of deadly force in self-
defense, or in defense of another, where there is a reasonable need to protect oneself or
someone else from an apparent, imminent threat of death or great bodily injury. “An
imminent peril is one that, from appearances, must be instantly dealt with.”  (In re Christian
S. (1994) 7 Cal.4th 768, 783.) The primary inquiry is whether action was instantly required
to avoid death or great bodily injury.  (Humphrey, supra, 13 Cal.4th at 1088.) What a
person knows, and his actual awareness of the risks posed against him are relevant to
determine if a reasonable person would believe in the need to defend. (Id. at 1083.) In
this regard, there is no duty to wait until an injury has been inflicted to be sure that deadly
force is indeed appropriate. (Scott v. Henrich, supra, 39 F. 3d at 915.)
Imminence more recently defined in the context of use of force to effect an arrest, is
A threat of death or serious bodily injury is “imminent” when, based on the totality
of the circumstances, a reasonable officer in the same situation would believe
that a person has the present ability, opportunity, and apparent intent to
immediately cause death or serious bodily injury to the peace officer or another
person. An imminent harm is not merely a fear of future harm, no matter how
great the fear and no matter how great the likelihood of the harm, but is one that,
from appearances, must be instantly confronted and addressed.
REASONABLENESS.  Self-defense requires both subjective honesty and objective
reasonableness.  (People v. Aris (1989) 215 Cal.App.3d 1178, 1186.) The United States
Supreme Court has held that an officer’s right to use force in the course of an arrest, stop
or seizure, deadly or otherwise, must be analyzed under the Fourth Amendment’s
“reasonableness” standard. (Graham v. Connor, supra, 490 U.S. at 395.)
The ‘reasonableness’ of a particular use of force must be judged from the
perspective of a reasonable officer on scene, rather than with the 20/20 vision of
hindsight.... The calculus of reasonableness must embody allowance for the fact
that police officers are often forced to make split-second judgments—in
circumstances that are tense, uncertain, and rapidly evolving—about the amount
of force that is necessary in a particular situation.
The “reasonableness” test requires an analysis of “whether the officers’ actions are
‘objectively reasonable’ in light of the facts and circumstances confronting them, without
regard to their underlying intent or motivation.”  (Id. at 397, citations omitted.) What
constitutes “reasonable” self-defense or defense of others is controlled by the
circumstances.  A person’s right of self-defense is the same whether the danger is real
or merely apparent.  (People v. Jackson (1965) 233 Cal.App.2d 639.)  If the person’s
beliefs were reasonable, the danger does not need to have actually existed. (CALCRIM
505.)  Yet, a person may use no more force than is reasonably necessary to defend
When deciding whether a person’s beliefs were reasonable, a jury is instructed to
consider the circumstances as they were known to and appeared to the person and
considers what a reasonable person in a similar situation with similar knowledge would
have believed.  (CALCRIM 505.) It was previously held that in the context of an officer-
involved incident, this standard does not morph into a “reasonable police officer”
standard. (People v. Mehserle (2012) 206 Cal.App.4th 1125, 1147.)20 To be clear, the
officer’s conduct should be evaluated as “the conduct of a reasonable person functioning
as a police officer in a stressful situation.” (Id.)
The Graham court plainly stated that digestion of the “totality of the circumstances” is fact-
driven and considered on a case-by-case basis. (Graham v. Connor, supra, 490 U.S. at
396.) As such, “reasonableness” cannot be precisely defined, nor can the test be
mechanically applied. (Id.) Still, Graham does grant the following factors to be considered
in the “reasonableness” calculus: the severity of the crime committed, whether the threat
posed is immediate, whether the person seized is actively resisting arrest or attempting
Whether the suspect posed an immediate threat to the safety of the officer or others has
been touted as the “most important” Graham factor. (Mattos v. Agarano (9th Cir. 2011)
661 F.3d 433, 441-442.) The threatened use of a gun or knife, for example, is the sort
of immediate threat contemplated by the United States Supreme Court, that
justifies an officer’s use of deadly force. (Reynolds v. County of San Diego (9th Cir.
1994) 858 F.Supp. 1064, 1071-72 “an officer may reasonably use deadly force when he
or she confronts an armed suspect in close proximity whose actions indicate an intent to
attack.”) Again, the specified factors of Graham were not meant to be exclusive
column2: other

column1: factors are taken into consideration when “necessary to account for the totality of the
circumstances in a given case.” (Mattos v. Agarano, supra, 661 F.3d at 441-442.)
The use of force policies and training of an involved officer’s agency may also be
considered as a factor to determine whether the officer acted reasonably. (Sen. Bill No.
When undertaking this analysis, courts do not engage in Monday Morning
Quarterbacking, and nor shall we. Our state appellate court explains,
Under Graham we must avoid substituting our personal notions of proper police
procedure for the instantaneous decision of the officer at the scene.  We must
never allow the theoretical, sanitized world of our imagination to replace the
dangerous and complex world that policemen face every day.  What constitutes
‘reasonable’ action may seem quite different to someone facing a possible
assailant than to someone analyzing the question at leisure.
(Martinez v. County of Los Angeles, supra, 47 Cal.App.4th at 343, citing Smith v. Freland
(6th Cir. 1992) 954 F.2d 343, 347.) Specifically, when a police officer reasonably believes
a suspect may be armed or arming himself, it does not change the analysis even if
20 The legislative findings included in Penal C. section 835a(a)(4) suggest to the contrary that “the decision by a peace
officer to use force shall be evaluated from the perspective of a reasonable officer in the same situation”. As such, if
the officer using force was acting in an effort to effect arrest, as is governed by section 835a, then it appears the more
generous standard included there would apply.
subsequent investigation reveals the suspect was unarmed.  (Baldridge v. City of Santa
The Supreme Court’s definition of reasonableness is, therefore, “comparatively generous
to the police in cases where potential danger, emergency conditions or other exigent
circumstances are present.”  (Martinez v. County of Los Angeles, supra, 47 Cal.App.4th
at 343-344, citing Roy v. Inhabitants of City of Lewiston (1st Cir. 1994) 42 F.3d 691, 695.)
In close-cases therefore, the Supreme Court will surround the police with a fairly wide
“zone of protection” when the aggrieved conduct pertains to on-the-spot choices made in
dangerous situations.  (Id. at 343-344.) One court explained that the deference given to
police officers (versus a private citizen) as follows:
Unlike private citizens, police officers act under color of law to protect the public
interest. They are charged with acting affirmatively and using force as part of their
duties, because ‘the right to make an arrest or investigatory stop necessarily
carries with it the right to use some degree of physical coercion or threat thereof
(Munoz v. City of Union City (2004) 120 Cal.App.4th 1077, 1109, citing Graham v. Connor,
Diaz was on a golf course where multiple civilians were present during a busy summer
afternoon. The presence of civilians affected the officers' decision-making process,
forcing them to take swift action to protect the public. The officers feared that Diaz would
become an active shooter. Because the officers recognized this danger, they had no
choice but to locate and attempt to contain Diaz with haste.
Upon seeing Diaz near the putting green, Sergeant McLane, Corporal Campa, Officers
Mutter, Jones, and Sein approached him swiftly but with caution. Believing Diaz was
armed with two handguns, the officers held their firearms in hand as they approached
him. Sergeant McLane immediately began giving Diaz commands to show his hands, to
put his hands up, and not to reach for anything.
Sergeant McLane’s commands were loud, clear, and concise. The commands were
simple and easy to follow. Sergeant McLane repeatedly told Diaz to show his hands, to
put his hands up, and not to reach for anything. Sergeant McLane repeated the
commands as the officers continued advancing toward Diaz. Though multiple officers
gave commands, their commands were consistent with each other. The officers told Diaz
precisely what he needed to do: Keep his hands in the air and not reach for anything.
Though Diaz held his left hand in the air as if to comply with the officers, Diaz actively
searched for his handgun with his right hand. Corporal Campa, who believed Diaz was
reaching for a gun, warned his partners, telling them to watch Diaz's hand. Corporal
Campa then told Diaz, ""Don't do it, dude. Keep your hands up, keep your hands up!"" Diaz
still refused to comply and continued reaching for his gun. Corporal Campa repeated the
commands, yelling, ""Hey, hey! Don't do it!"" The other officers also yelled, ""Don't do it,""
Based on the body-worn camera video footage, the officers had less than 40 seconds
from the time they first spotted Diaz before Diaz pointed a gun at them. Though the
officers had little time to de-escalate the situation, they gave Diaz multiple commands and
attempted to gain his cooperation so they could safely approach him and take him into
custody. Despite the officers' best efforts to resolve the situation peacefully, Diaz
remained uncooperative. Instead, Diaz showed he was unwilling to comply and instead
picked up his gun and pointed it at the officers, thwarting every attempt the officers made
When Diaz showed up at the golf course armed with two handguns, his presence and
behavior sparked fear in all who encountered him. Employees and golfers ran to seek
cover and called 911 for help. Diaz was clearly in a state of mental distress and, armed
with two loaded handguns, he posed a danger to those present at the golf course.
Witnesses described Diaz’s behavior as abnormal and told investigators they thought
Diaz may have been under the influence of drugs or alcohol. Witness #1 told the 911
operator that Diaz was “having an episode,” and had shot a gun inside the residence.
Witness #1’s son told the operator that Diaz was “having a manic episode” and believed
someone was “in the walls of the house” and was trying to kill him. The toxicology results
(200 ng/mL of amphetamine and 2200 ng/mL of methamphetamine) revealed that Diaz
was under the influence of methamphetamine. It is possible Diaz was suffering from
methamphetamine-induced psychosis.21 Sergeant McLane, Corporal Campa, and
Officers Mutter, Jones, and Sein knew what the witnesses had reported. While the officers
did not know what was causing Diaz to behave this way, they correctly recognized that
Diaz posed a danger to those around him. In the face of danger, Sergeant McLane,
Corporal Campa, and Officers Mutter, Jones, and Sein responded to protect those
Sergeant McLane, Corporal Campa, and Officer Mutter listened to Witness #1’s 911 call
and heard first-hand her conversation with the dispatch operator. The distress in her voice
made clear the urgency of the situation. Over the course of her six minute, 39 second
phone call, Witness #1 advised that Diaz had fired a gun inside the house, that Diaz was
upset, was having “an episode,” and believed someone was going to kill him. Witness #1
told dispatch that Diaz was an off-duty sheriff’s deputy and had left on foot armed with his
duty weapon. During the 911 call, Witness #1’s son got on the call to advise that Diaz had

Witness #1 and her son reported because the information was provided to all responding
The officers were aware that Diaz’s residence was located within the Sierra Lakes Golf
Course community. Each of the officers knew that Diaz was in a state of crisis and that
he was walking around the community armed with two handguns. Before the officers
arrived, each of them felt a pressing concern that Diaz could become an active shooter
at the golf course. Based on their training and experience, the officers understood that

golf, would be unprepared and unable to effectively defend themselves. As the officers
headed to the golf course, urgent 911 calls flooded in from witnesses reporting a man
with a gun at the golf course, amplifying the officers’ fears and underscoring the gravity
Sergeant McLane called the Sheriff’s air unit to respond to the scene to assist. Fontana
Police Department’s armored vehicle was also dispatched to the scene to assist.
However, each officer understood the urgency of finding Diaz as quickly as possible.
Sergeant McLane, Corporal Campa, and Officers Mutter, Jones and Sein were the first
officers to arrive at the golf course. Unable to wait for assistance and determined to
prevent any potential harm to innocent lives, the officers immediately set out on foot to
locate Diaz. With limited opportunity to develop a tactical plan, the officers relied on their
collective training and experience. Almost immediately, the officers spotted Diaz about 40
yards away. Diaz was at the rear of two golf carts parked beside the putting green which
lay in front of the clubhouse. Diaz matched the description given by multiple witnesses.
When Sergeant McLane first spotted Diaz, Diaz was standing near the rear passenger
side of the golf cart. Sergeant McLane noted a ring of sweat on Diaz’s light gray shirt,
dark like someone’s shirt would look after an intense workout. This, combined with the
information relayed by Witness #1 and her son during the 911 call, led Sergeant McLane
to believe Diaz was experiencing “some type of manic physical response to reality.” Diaz
looked in Sergeant McLane’s direction and made eye contact but quickly looked away
and went down to his knees.
Corporal Campa first saw Diaz sitting down near the two golf carts. Corporal Campa saw
people standing at the clubhouse and asked them, “Where’s he at?” The people pointed
at Diaz. Corporal Campa heard Diaz yell something and saw Diaz point westward, as if
to direct the officers’ attention that direction. Corporal Campa believed Diaz was trying to
lure the officers into an ambush to kill them because the witnesses were pointing at Diaz
as the suspect, but Diaz was pointing the officers to the west, diverting their attention
away from him. Before spotting Diaz, Corporal Campa had seen three to four golfers
running north on the driving range, away from the two golf carts where Diaz sat, which
Like Corporal Campa, Officer Mutter also saw golfers running north on the driving range.
This is what brought Officer Mutter’s attention to the two golf carts and to Diaz, who stood
next to one of the carts. Officer Mutter saw Diaz point southward toward a thick tree line
and heard Diaz say there was someone with a gun in the bushes. Officer Mutter shared
Corporal Campa’s concern that Diaz was trying to get the officers closer and to divert
their attention away from himself so “he could try to kill” one of them. Like Sergeant
McLane, Officer Mutter also noted Diaz was drenched in sweat. Officer Mutter saw Diaz
turn toward the officers, fall to his knees, and put his hands in the air when the officers
Because Officers Jones and Sein had to run to catch up to Sergeant McLane, Corporal
Campa and Officer Mutter, they did not see Diaz until their partners were already walking
across the putting green toward him. When Officers Jones and Sein first saw Diaz, Diaz
was on his knees by the golf cart, just outside the putting green. Like Corporal Campa,
Officers Jones and Sein saw several people at the clubhouse. Diaz faced the officers and
held his left hand up, waving at the officers as if to wave them off. Officer Jones also saw
the handle of a black handgun in Diaz’s waistband. Officer Sein saw three people near
the driving range who looked like they had run away from the location. With so many
civilians in the vicinity, the officers knew they needed to contain Diaz as quickly and safely
Wasting no time, the officers began walking toward Diaz, and immediately began giving
him commands. Sergeant McLane calmly told Diaz, “Show us your hands, bro. Show us
your hands. Show us your hands,” and “Put your hands up, bro.” Diaz looked in Sergeant
McLane’s direction and made eye contact with him. Sergeant McLane was hopeful they
would be able to establish a positive line of communication with Diaz. Each officer had
the same goal: to safely establish communication with Diaz so they could de-escalate the
situation to a point where they could detain him to investigate what had occurred or
conduct a mental health evaluation to get Diaz assistance. To that end, the officers knew
they needed to reach Diaz and to safely disarm him. The officers did not simply charge
forward, running straight toward Diaz, and instead made their approach tactically, walking
toward him with great caution, all the while telling Diaz what he needed to do.
As they approached Diaz, none of the officers saw a gun in Diaz’s hand. However,
because Diaz was reportedly armed with two firearms, the officers had their guns drawn
and held them at the low-ready. As the officers continued advancing toward Diaz, they
repeated their commands. Diaz held his left hand in the air as if to comply but kept his
right hand concealed from the officers’ view. Though the officers could not see Diaz’s
right hand, based on the movement of Diaz’s right arm, it looked like Diaz was reaching
around as if searching for something on the ground beside him. Based on the information
and the officers’ observations of Diaz, they each reasonably believed Diaz was reaching
for a gun. Sergeant McLane told Diaz, “Don’t reach for nothing, bro. Don’t reach for
To reach Diaz, the officers had to traverse the putting green, which offered no cover or
concealment between the officers and Diaz. The clubhouse was adjacent to the putting
green. Multiple witnesses were inside the clubhouse, where they sheltered in place,
watching Diaz and the officers through the windows. Though inside the clubhouse, these
witnesses were in danger because of their proximity to Diaz, particularly if he began
As the officers crossed the putting green, they fanned out to position themselves between
the clubhouse and Diaz. Armed and in the midst of a severe mental health crisis, Diaz
posed a danger to everyone nearby, including those inside the clubhouse and those still
out on the golf course. While the officers did not see a gun in Diaz’s hands, they had
every reason to believe he was armed or attempting to arm himself. To prevent Diaz from
retrieving a weapon and potentially starting to shoot, the officers needed to contain him.
They could not walk away from Diaz when civilians in close proximity were at risk. As law
enforcement officers with the duty to safeguard the public, Sergeant McLane, Corporal
Campa, and Officers Mutter, Jones, and Sein knew they had no alternative but to confront
Corporal Campa warned his partners to watch Diaz’s hands. Corporal Campa distinctly
heard what he suspected was a gun falling to the ground and saw Diaz concealing the
movement of his right hand from the officers. Corporal Campa told Diaz, “Don’t do it,
dude. Keep your hands up.” Officers Mutter and Sein also noted that Diaz’s right arm was
down, moving around behind his body as if to find something on the ground. Unable to
see what Diaz was reaching for, the officers all feared Diaz was reaching for a gun. This
fear was reasonable based on everything the officers had learned and observed up to
Officer Mutter yelled at Diaz, “Stop reaching, stop reaching, don’t grab it!” At the same
time, Corporal Campa and Officer Sein repeatedly warned him, “Don’t do it!” Meanwhile,
Officer Jones, who had moved to the right of his partners, noticed that Diaz was reaching
for a black handgun lying on the ground beside him. Diaz continued to ignore the officers’
commands. Diaz went down onto his side and then onto his back, reaching behind him
for the gun. Diaz then grabbed onto the gun, and began to sit back up, pointing it at the
officers. When Diaz went down onto his back, Officer Jones saw Diaz grab onto the
handle of the firearm. Sergeant McLane, Corporal Campa, Officer Mutter, and Officer
Sein all saw Diaz fall onto his side or back, but they didn’t see that Diaz had grabbed the
firearm until he sat back up, swung his right arm toward the officers, and pointed the gun
When Diaz pointed his loaded handgun at the officers, the danger he posed escalated to
an immediate threat. This created an urgent, life-threatening risk not only to the officers,
but to the civilians sheltering in place inside the clubhouse. When the officers saw Diaz
point the gun at them, they each believed Diaz was going to shoot them. Sergeant
McLane, Corporal Campa, and Officers Mutter, Jones, and Sein honestly and reasonably
feared for their lives and those of the civilians in the clubhouse behind them. Confronted
with this critical threat to their safety and the safety of the nearby civilians, the officers
had no choice but to fire their weapons at Diaz to stop the threat.
Based on the facts presented in the reports and the applicable law, Sergeant McLane’s
use of deadly force was a proper exercise of his right of self-defense and defense of
others, and therefore, his actions were legally justified.
Based on the facts presented in the reports and the applicable law, Corporal Campa’s
use of deadly force was a proper exercise of his right of self-defense and defense of
others, and therefore, his actions were legally justified.
Based on the facts presented in the reports and the applicable law, Officer Mutter’s use
of deadly force was a proper exercise of his right of self-defense and defense of others,
and therefore, his actions were legally justified.
Based on the facts presented in the reports and the applicable law, Officer Jones’ use of
deadly force was a proper exercise of his right of self-defense and defense of others, and
therefore, his actions were legally justified.
Based on the facts presented in the reports and the applicable law, Officer Sein’s use of
deadly force was a proper exercise of his right of self-defense and defense of others, and
therefore, his actions were legally justified.
San Bernardino County District Attorney's Office
Location of Incident: 404 Hyland Drive, Salinas, CA
Involved Officers: MCSO Detective David Gonzalez & MCSO Deputy
The District Attorney’s Office has completed its investigation and review of the facts
surrounding the officer involved shooting that occurred on August 8, 2023. The scope of
this review is narrow. It is not to advise concerning best practices for law enforcement in
the field, but rather to determine if any officer committed a crime beyond a reasonable
Our review determined the evidence does not show beyond a reasonable doubt the officers
in question committed any crime. Specifically, there is insufficient evidence to prove
beyond a reasonable doubt the two officers who fatally shot Anthony Tovar did not have an
actual and reasonable belief that Anthony Tovar posed a danger of great bodily injury or
death to an officer or civilian when they fatally shot him.
The investigation conducted by the District Attorney’s Office included:
District Attorney Investigator interviews of the involved officers and civilian witnesses
Review of audio and video recordings by law enforcement, including dispatch
On August 8, 2023, at around 8:40pm, Anthony Tovar approached a residence and repeatedly
knocked on the door. While husband was not present, his wife and two-year old child were
home by themselves. Wife did not open the door but became alarmed and contacted husband
for assistance.  Tovar left before husband returned home.  Husband arrived and discussed the
events with his wife. He observed Anthony Tovar (25) on his Ring Camera footage and
recognized him as a neighbor from across the street.  The Ring videos show Tovar knocking
on the door at 08:40pm, 08:41pm, and 08:49pm. Husband then went to Tovar’s address at
407 Hyland Drive and contacted him. Tovar claimed that he had been looking for his dog.
Husband estimates that around ten minutes later, Tovar returned to husband and wife’s
residence. Husband opened the door and stepped outside to speak with Tovar. Tovar pushed
passed him and rushed into the house towards wife who was holding her small child. Tovar
pulled out a knife. Tovar said that husband had the ability to release Tovar’s friends from
incarceration. Husband begged Tovar to release his family and tried unsuccessfully to take
the knife from Tovar. Tovar held a large knife to wife’s throat as he forced her, with her child,
to the rear bedroom and barricaded all of them inside.  Husband frantically called 911 dispatch
asking for a law enforcement response at around 9:30pm.
MCSO Sergeant Gonzalez, MCSO Deputy Pantoja, MCSO Deputy Ramirez, and MCSO
Deputy Perez responded.  At 9:33pm, dispatch advised the responding units that the male
(Tovar) was inside the residence with a knife and had forced wife and child into the back
bedroom at knifepoint.  At 9:34pm, Sergeant Gonzalez arrived on scene and was flagged down
by husband who told him that a man (Tovar) was inside his residence with a knife and had his
wife and child.  Tovar had locked the door.
Sergeant Gonzalez, Deputy Ramirez, and Deputy Pantoja decided to immediately enter the
residence.  After entering the residence, they rushed to the locked bedroom door and verbally
announced “Sheriff’s Department.” Sergeant Gonzalez kicked the door multiple times and
was able to get it open between 12 and 18 inches.  Deputy Pantoja was to his left.  Deputies
yelled repeatedly for Tovar to “Open the door!”  Tovar had placed a dresser in front of the
door to act as a barricade.
Sergeant Gonzalez looked in the room and saw wife and child crying on the floor of the
bedroom.  He also saw wife embracing her child.  He saw Tovar facing them with a large
knife in his right hand.  The knife was over twelve inches in length.  Tovar was about five feet
from the wife and child while Sergeant Gonzalez was five feet away from Tovar.  Sergeant
Gonzalez pointed his handgun at Tovar and yelled several commands at Tovar to “drop the
knife!” Tovar refused, waived his hand in a “go-away motion,” and turned his attention back
to wife and child. Sergeant Gonzalez estimated the knife to be around 3 feet away from wife
and child. Sergeant Gonzalez fired one shot at Tovar hitting him in the torso. Deputy Pantoja
fired one shot and Sergeant Gonzalez fired two more shots. Tovar fell to the ground.  The
knife was removed from his hand, he was handcuffed, first aid was administered, and medical
personnel were dispatched. Tovar was pronounced dead on scene.
The California District Attorneys Association charge filing standard directs prosecutors to
assess whether the evidence would warrant conviction by a jury, which requires proof
beyond a reasonable doubt. The sole purpose of this review is to determine whether any
officer was criminally responsible for the death of Anthony Tovar.
On August 19, 2019, Governor Gavin Newsom signed Assembly Bill 392 into law, which
changed the law governing the use of deadly force by police officers and went into effect
Under PC 835a(c)(1), “a peace officer is justified in using deadly force upon another person
only when the officer reasonably believes, based on the totality of circumstances, that such
force is necessary . . . to defend against an imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury
to the officer or to another person.” It also allows for the use of deadly force, “[t[o
apprehend a fleeing person for any felony that threatened or resulted in death or serious
bodily injury, if the officer reasonably believes that the person will cause death or serious
bodily injury to another unless immediately apprehended. Where feasible, a peace officer
shall, prior to the use of force, make reasonable efforts to identify themselves as a peace
officer and to warn that deadly force may be used, unless the officer has objectively
reasonable grounds to believe the person is aware of those facts.”
“A threat of death or serious bodily injury is ‘imminent’ when, based on the totality of the
circumstances, a reasonable officer in the same situation would believe that a person has the
present ability, opportunity, and apparent intent to immediately cause death or serious
bodily injury to the peace officer or another person.” (Id. at subsection (e)(2).)
The statute states that totality of the circumstances “means all facts known to the peace
officer at the time, including the conduct of the officer and the subject leading up to the use
Under the law, any person—including a police officer—can use deadly force in self-defense
or in defense of others if the person reasonably believes the immediate use of deadly force is
necessary to defend against an imminent danger of great bodily injury or death. The danger
does not need to exist as long as the person reasonably believes the danger exists. Further, a
person acting in self-defense or defense of others is not required to retreat. The person is
entitled to stand his or her ground or even, if reasonable, to pursue an assailant until the
danger of death or bodily injury has passed. This is so even if safety could have been
Police officers can lawfully use deadly force even if from 20/20 hindsight other feasible
options may have existed. The situation must be viewed from the perspective of a reasonable
officer at the scene. Officers are forced to make split-second judgments—in circumstances
that are tense, uncertain, and rapidly evolving—about the amount of force that is necessary in
When a person has a genuine belief using force in self-defense, or defense of others, is
immediately necessary, a person is not guilty of a homicide unless the belief in self-defense,
or defense of others, was unreasonable at the time.
There is no basis to conclude that Sergeant Gonzalez and Deputy Pantoja had anything but a
genuine belief that deadly force was immediately necessary. Because Tovar kidnapped the
mother and her two-year-old child at knifepoint, imprisoned them in their rear bedroom
behind a barricaded closed door, displayed a deadly weapon, failed to follow the lawful
commands of deputies, and given the totality of these unpredictable and extremely dangerous
circumstances, the deputies could reasonably believe Tovar was an imminent threat to the
lives of his captors.  Therefore, insufficient evidence exists to prove beyond a reasonable
doubt that Sergeant Gonzalez or Deputy Pantoja committed any crime.
The role of the District Attorney is not to evaluate the efficacy of departmental tactics or
training, nor of course to consider issues of civil liability. Those processes may have the
goal of identifying areas for improvement in future similar encounters
column2: they may take

column1: advantage of the benefit of hindsight and information not known to the involved peace
officers. The role of the District Attorney in deciding whether to charge officers with a crime
requires judging their conduct and actions from the perspective of a reasonable officer on the
scene at the time of the incident with the information available in a rapidly evolving high-
stress encounter. Consequently, having found there is insufficient evidence to prove any
crime beyond a reasonable doubt, no further action by this office is contemplated or
On 08/08/2023, an Officer-Involved Shooting (OIS) occurred at 404 Hyland Dr. in Salinas.
Decedent Anthony Tovar forced his way into the residence, grabbed a female adult and placed a
knife to her neck while the adult female was holding her 2-year-old daughter. After Tovar
barricaded himself and the two victims inside a bedroom, Monterey County Sheriff’s Office
personnel breached the door and discharged their firearms fatally striking Tovar.
On 08/08/2023 at approximately 2220 hours, I was alerted that an OIS had occurred at 404 Hyland
Dr. in Salinas and I was requested to respond to the scene by District Attorney Investigative
Captain (DAIC) J. Ferreria. I arrived on scene at approximately 2310 hours. I was designated the
Lead Investigator by DAIC Ferreria. I was assisted by District Attorney Investigators (DAI) Smith,
Gomez, and Williams. It should be noted that DAIC Ferreria and DAI Williams left the scene to
photograph Monterey County Sheriff’s Office (MCSO) personnel involved in the shooting and
they conducted a round count of the associated OIS weapons. DAI Smith and I were then directed
to obtain a statement from the reporting party, Victim 1. It should be noted that Victim 1 was
seated in an MCSO patrol vehicle prior to the interview. It should also be noted that I audio-
recorded the interview with Victim 1 with my department-issued digital recorder (Item KH 1). The
following is a summary of the interview with Victim 1.
After exiting the patrol vehicle, DAI Smith and I identified ourselves to Victim 1 and he agreed to
speak with us. Victim 1 confirmed he lived at 404 Hyland Dr. with his wife, Victim 2, and their
two-year-old daughter, Victim 3. Victim 1 provided verbal consent to search the home regarding
our investigation. Victim 1 stated a male adult, later identified as Decedent Tovar, entered his
home, proceeded into the kitchen area of the home where he grabbed Victim 2 and Victim 3 and
took them into a rear bedroom of the residence utilized by Victim 3.
Victim 1 stated Tovar first approached the residence at approximately 2030 hours on 08/08/2023.
Victim 1 was not present at the residence but was informed that Tovar was knocking
“aggressively” on the front door and side door of the residence while Victim 2 was inside the
residence with Victim 3. Victim 2 did not open the doors. After arriving at the home, Victim 1 did
not see Tovar. However, Victim 1 accessed his Ring camera which was mounted next to the
residence’s front door. After he reviewed the Ring camera’s video to see who had been knocking
the residence’s front door earlier on 08/08/2023, Victim 1 said, “It seemed like the neighbor.”
Victim 1 stated he went across the street to attempt to discover why Tovar had been knocking on
the door. Victim 1 stated he observed Tovar come around the side of a pink residence (407 #A
Hyland Dr.) behind 407 Hyland Dr. According to Victim 1, Tovar stated he had been looking for
his dog at Victim 1’s residence earlier in the evening. Victim 1 and Tovar then parted ways.
Victim 1 stated Tovar returned to 404 Hyland Dr. and knocked on the front door about 10 minutes
after his first encounter with Tovar. Victim 1 opened the door and noted Tovar was “acting kind
of weird because he wanted to step inside the house.” Victim 1 stated he told Tovar they could
speak outside the residence. However, Tovar went around Victim 1, entered the residence through
the open front door, and approached Victim 2 in the kitchen area of the residence. Victim 2 was
holding Victim 3. After grabbing Victim 2 and Victim 3, Tovar brandished a knife. Victim 1 stated
that Tovar made several comments including, “you have to help me, because I have some friends
in prison, and you have power to get them out.” Victim 1 stated he pleaded with Tovar to release
Victim 2 and Victim 3 and to leave the residence. Victim 1 stated he began struggling with Tovar
and unsuccessfully attempted to grab of the knife. Tovar then forced Victim 2 and Victim 3 into
the residence’s rear bedroom and locked the door leaving Victim 1 outside the bedroom. Victim 1
Victim 1 confirmed Tovar had the knife prior to entering the residence. Victim 1 stated Tovar
made additional comments about friends in prison and that Victim 1 had the power to release these
individuals from incarceration. Victim 1 stated he didn’t know Tovar but believed Tovar was
associated with the pink residence behind 407 Hyland Dr.
Victim 1 stated after he called law enforcement, he continued to plead with Tovar to release his
family and to not hurt them. Victim 1 exited the residence and spoke with law enforcement when
they arrived. When law enforcement entered his residence, Victim 1 followed but was ordered to
leave the residence. Victim 1 confirmed he was inside the home when he heard gunshots. Victim
1 stated he did not hear anything prior to the gunshots. Victim 1 stated Tovar spoke mostly to
Victim 1 after entering the home in the kitchen area, mainly concerning the release of Tovar’s
incarcerated friends. Victim 1 stated he observed Tovar grab Victim 2 around her shoulders and
Tovar had the knife behind Victim 2.
Victim 1 stated when Tovar first knocked on the residence’s front door, Victim 2 contacted Victim
1 to inform him of the situation. Victim 1 arrived at the residence approximately 10 minutes later
and accessed his Ring camera system. Victim 1 stated he attempted to speak with Tovar through
his Ring camera system but the battery was low and he was unable to communicate with Tovar.
DAI Smith and I had no additional questions for Victim 1 and ended the interview at approximately
After the interview with Victim 1 was concluded, DAI Smith and I remained at the scene of the
OIS. MCSO Forensic Evidence Technician (FET) R. Okaneku arrived and began processing the
crime scene. DAI Smith accompanied FET Okaneku while FET Okaneku processed the crime
scene. DAI Smith also took digital photographs of the scene. I remained on scene with DAI Smith
and FET Okaneku (See reports from FET Okaneku and DAI Smith). I left the scene of the OIS at
On 08/09/2023, I assisted DAI Smith with processing several evidence items recovered from the
OIS scene (See DAI Smith’s report). Later on 08/09/2023, DAI Gomez and I contacted Victim 2
at 17105 El Rancho Way in Salinas. It should be noted that Victim 2 spoke Spanish only. DAI
Gomez, who is a certified Spanish speaker with Monterey County, conducted the interview (See
DAI Gomez’s report). During the course of the interview with Victim 2, DAI Gomez and I were
informed Tovar grabbed Victim 2’s pants and attempted to pull them down while Tovar held her
inside the bedroom at 404 Hyland Dr. causing her underwear to rip. Victim 2 provided the grey
underwear to DAI Gomez. I took two digital photographs (Item KH 3) of the grey underwear
before DAI Gomez collected them as evidence (Item LG 01). Item LG 01 was later booked into
evidence at the Monterey County District Attorney’s Office.
DAI Gomez and I were also informed Tovar’s grey sweatshirt/jacket had not been removed from
404 Hyland Dr. DAI Gomez and I accompanied Victim 1 to 404 Hyland Dr. and I recovered the
grey sweatshirt/jacket (Item KH 2) which was located on top of the bed in the rear bedroom where
the OIS occurred. I also took three digital photographs of the grey sweatshirt/jacket before I
collected the item (Item KH  4). Item KH 2 was later booked into evidence at the Monterey County
District Attorney’s Office. Items KH 1 and KH 3 – KH 4 were booked into digital evidence at the

On 08/08/2023, an Officer-Involved Shooting (OIS) occurred at 404 Hyland Drive in Salinas.
Monterey County Sheriff’s Office (MCSO) Deputies responded to a call of a man with a knife.
Anthony Tovar had forcibly taken a mother and her two-year-old child at knife point into a
bedroom and barricaded the door. MCSO Deputies breached the bedroom and observed Tovar
with a knife.  The deputies discharged their firearms striking Tovar.  Tovar did not survive.
On 08/08/2023 at 2219 hours, I received a request to respond to an OIS that had occurred on the
400 block of Hyland Drive in Salinas, CA.  I arrived at the scene at approximately 2236 hours.  I
contacted Chief District Attorney Investigator, Ryan McGuirk, and District Attorney Investigative
Captain, John Ferreria, who directed District Attorney Investigator (DAI), Hunsaker, and I to
interview the Reporting Party (RP), Jose De Jesus Valdivia.  During the interview, Valdivia gave
us verbal consent to enter and search his residence located at 404 Hyland Drive. Please refer to
DAI Hunsaker’s report for a summary of Valdivia’s interview.
Once we obtained consent to enter Valdivia’s home, DAI Hunsaker and I were tasked with locating
and documenting evidence within the residence.  We were notified that MCSO’s Forensic
Evidence Technician (FET), Rebeka Okaneku, was enroute and we would be assisting in
Once FET Okaneku arrived, I was tasked with taking digital photographs of the scene which
included the residence at 404 Hyland Drive, the evidence located within the residence, and photos
of the decedent. After the photographs were taken, we marked each evidence item with yellow
numbered placards.  I took additional photographs of the evidence items with the placards.
I stood by as FET Okaneku took multiple scans of the residence at 404 Hyland Drive.  Once the
scans were completed, I collected the following evidence from the residence:
• Item RS-002, 9mm shell casing WIN 9mm Luger (Placard 4)
• Item RS-003, 9mm shell casing WIN 9mm Luger (Placard 5)
• Item RS-004, Knife w/ black handle, approximately 300 mm in length (Placard 6)
• Item RS-005, 9mm shell casing WIN 9mm Luger (Placard 7)
It should be noted that placards 1 and 2 were placed next to black latex gloves that were found at
the scene.  The items were photographed, but the gloves were not taken as evidence.  The coroner
deputy arrived on scene to examine and prepare the decedent’s body for transport.  When the
coroner deputy moved the decedent’s body and searched his pants pockets, an iPhone, a Mercedes
car key, and a DeWalt box cutter were found in the pockets.  When the coroner deputy moved the
decedent’s legs a spent projectile (bullet) was found that had been under the decedent’s boots.  I
took photographs and collected the items that were found in the decedent’s pockets as well as the
mushroomed projectile (bullet).  They were labeled as the following evidence items:
• Item RS-006, Black iPhone w/ gray case
• Item RS-007, Mercedes car key w/ gray fob attached.
The evidence items were labeled, packaged, and placed in an evidence locker at the Monterey
County District Attorney’s Office for storage.  Two hundred and eleven photographs were taken
of the scene.  I uploaded the photographs into Evidence.com and labeled the folder as evidence
item RS-010.  Three additional photographs were taken of evidence item RS-004 (Knife) once I
was at the office.  I photographed the knife alongside a scale to show the length of the knife and
the blade.  I uploaded those photographs to Evidence.com as item RS-011.
Forward to District Attorney Investigative Captain for review.

conduct a round count with the two officers who had fired their handguns. Captain Ferreria and I
arrived at MCSO at approximately 2400 hours on 08/09/2023.

On August 8, 2023, at approximately 2300 hours, I, Monterey County District Attorney
Investigator (DAI)  Leo Gómez , arrived at the crime scene at Captain John Ferreria’s request. I
contacted Victim 1 at his parent’s home, which was located at 17105 El Rancho Way, Salinas CA
93907. Victim 1 signed a consent form (Item LG05) to search his residence. I signed this document
as a Witness, and I forwarded it to DAI Kris Hunsaker. Victim 1 also delivered to me four digital
videos (Item LG02) from his Ring camera that was installed at the front door of his residence.
These videos showed Decedent Tovar and his dog outside the victim’s front door. I also delivered
On August 9, 2023, at approximately 1104 hours, DAI Rachel Maldonado and I visited Tovar’s
home and we spoke to a number of Tovar’s family members who were gathered there praying.
Among the large group were Tovar’s parents, his sister and her husband. I spoke to these persons
in Spanish and I gathered additional information about Tovar’s mental history and whereabouts
the day before. One of the Tovar’s sisters (Noemí) spoke both English and Spanish. I recorded our
conversation using a digital device and I transferred the audio file to Evidence.com (Item LG03).
I also photographed the Tovar’s medication and a knife we found at the home, which resembled
the knife Tovar used to kidnap the victims. The following is a synopsis of my conversation with
Tovar’s relatives. For complete details, please refer to the audio file. The names of the family
members I spoke to were Berta Murillo and Ernesto Tovar (Tovar’s parents), Noemí Tovar
Tovar’s parents stated that Tovar had lived with them through his whole life and was unemployed
at the time of the officer-involved shooting (OIS). Tovar attended North Monterey County High
School for approximately two years but did not graduate. There was consensus among the relatives
that Tovar suffered from mental illness and was taking some medications but the length of his
illness,  depending on who spoke, was either three, four or ten years. Tovar’s parents did not
exactly know what Tovar’s diagnosis was, but Noemí indicated that he suffered from
schizophrenia. Ernesto and Berta stated that Tovar was being treated at Natividad Hospital for
mental illness and, sometime in the past, he had been housed at psychiatric facilities in Monterey
and Santa Cruz counties.  The Santa Cruz County stay lasted approximately one week and occurred
Bertha stated that Tovar’s illness began in adulthood and manifested with hallucinations. Bertha
described Tovar talking to invisible persons. Bertha also stated that Tovar “didn’t sleep” and spent
all night walking around their home. The relatives stated that Tovar was often profane and verbally
abusive towards his parents but he was never violent at home. The relatives also stated that Tovar
had been arrested multiple times for various reasons, including mental illness, bad temper, and for
entering a neighbor’s home without permission. Tovar’s relatives did not know that neighbor’s
name, but they indicated that the neighbor came to Tovar’s home and told his parents that he would
shoot Tovar with a gun if he ever entered his home again. Bertha stated that on one occasion, Tovar
called her from the Monterey County Jail and stated that he could see her and Ernesto inside the
Noemí and Jorge stated that they knew Tovar better than anyone else because Tovar often visited
them at their home (1157 Ranchero Drive, Salinas CA  93905) and he spent a lot of time with
them. They also stated that Tovar ‘s ex-girlfriend, whose first name was Destiny, was one of their
Noemí, Bertha, Ernesto and Jorge stated that Tovar used illicit drugs, including cannabis and
methamphetamine, which he obtained from friends. They also stated that Tovar’s mental illness
intensified with drug use. Noemí stated that Tovar began using drugs after he completed probation.
Noemí also stated that Tovar told her that he was anxious about finishing probation, so he could
Jorge stated that one or two days before the OIS, around 0400 hours, Tovar went to Destiny’s
home and climbed on the roof without permission. Jorge learned about this incident from Noemí,
who was informed by Destiny’s father, who saw him on the roof but did not call law enforcement.
Destiny’s father spoke to Jorge about that incident and he was upset.
On the date of the OIS, Tovar visited Noemí at her home and she became afraid of him because
he was “acting up.” Noemí was unable to explain what she meant by “acting up,” but she
mentioned that Tovar was moving and touching his face. Her description seemed to describe the
behavior of someone under the influence of a stimulant. Noemí also stated that Tovar was “out of
control” because he had broken up with Destiny. Tovar was still with Noemí when Jorge got home
from work at approximately 1900 hours, although he was outside the home in his car, which he
Jorge described that when he arrived home, Tovar was “OK” but lacked concentration, which he
attributed to the roof climbing incident at Destiny’s home. Jorge told Tovar that he did not want
him at his home anymore because of the trespassing incident at Destiny’s home.
Noemí cried (presumably at the prospect of not having Tovar visit her home again) and Tovar
apologized for his behavior and stated that he would not bother Destiny anymore. Tovar left Noemí
and Jorge’s home crying, in his vehicle, after Noemí also told him that she didn’t want him at her
home due to the ongoing drama with Destiny. She also told him that she feared he would do
something to her or her children when Jorge wasn’t home. Noemí explained that she feared Tovar
because he did not take his medication and he was abusive to her parents.
Tovar’s relatives did not know when Tovar had last slept or for how long before the OIS, but they
believed that he had been awake for 24 or 48 hours since the roof climbing incident at Destiny’s
Berta stated that sometime during the evening, prior to the OIS, she saw Tovar standing outside
her home, talking to a man. The man told Tovar in Spanish, “I saw you in the cameras” and “what
were you doing there?” Tovar told the man, “I went to get the dog. The dog went over there and I
went to get him.” Tovar’s relatives described Tovar’s dog as a white Chihuahua. Ernesto also heard
the conversation between Tovar and the man, and he provided a statement that substantiated
Bertha’s narrative. Sometime thereafter, Bertha noticed police vehicles near her home and she
went outside and called Tovar but he was nowhere to be seen. Ernesto stated that after speaking to
the man, Tovar entered his home through a rear door and went to the kitchen. Berta and Ernesto
didn’t know where Tovar went thereafter he was in the kitchen.
Inside Tovar’s home, on a kitchen shelf, I observed multiple medication containers, three of which
had labels from the CVS pharmacy located at 110 Laurel Drive, Salinas, CA 93906. The labels
indicated that the medications were prescribed to Tovar by doctors K. Routiher or M. Garuba.
The label on the first container was dated June 10, 2023, and read “15 mg Mirtazapine  tablet” and
“Take 1 tablet by mouth every day at bedtime.” The prescription was for 30 tablets and the
container held 29 tables labeled  “0 8 A”  which I verified on the drugs.com website as the imprint
for Mirtazapine, an antidepressant. The following two images are photographs of this medication:
The label on the second container, dated October 21, 2021, indicated a prescription for 60
Buspirone Hydrochloride 15 mg pills. The label read, “1 tab by mouth twice daily.” The container
held 57 intact tables labeled  “5 5 5 TV 1003”  and four half- tablets of the same medicine. The
drugs.com website indicated that the imprint on the pills matched the container label. The image
below is a photograph of this medication:
The label on the third container, dated July 20, 2022,  indicated a prescription for 30 Olanzapine
5 mg tablets. The label read, “take 1 tablet every day at bedtime.” The container held 26 intact
tables labeled  “CL 40.” The drugs.com website indicated that the imprint on the pills matched the
container label. The following image is a photograph of this medication:
The large number of tablets found in each container, coupled with the date of the prescriptions and
instructions, seemed to corroborate Noemí’s statement about Tovar not taking his medications.
On a counter, in Tovar’s kitchen, we found a knife similar to the one Tovar used during the
burglary and kidnapping. We did not find a knife set or any other knives. The image below is a
On August 9, 2023, at approximately 1423 hours, DAI Hunsaker and I spoke with Victim 2 at her
father-in-law’s home. Present during our conversation was her husband, Victim 1. I recorded our
conversation using a digital device (Item LG04) and I transferred the audio file to Evidence.com.
Victim 2 stated that she resided at her home with her daughter (Victim 3) and her husband. On the
date of the OIS she was at home with her daughter. Victim 1 arrived home from work  at
approximately 1500 hours to eat, and he returned to work at approximately 1600 hours.
At approximately 2030 hours, someone knocked on her front door, which was closed but unlocked.
Victim 2 believed that the person at the door was her husband, so she approached the door, looked
through the door glass, and noticed that the person outside was not her husband, but a young man
(Tovar) with a small dog. Tovar was wearing a hoodie, sweatpants and a gray or black item over
his face. Tovar made eye contact with Victim 2, hand signaled for her to open the door and
remained there for five or ten minutes. Victim 2 panicked and did not open the door.
Victim 2 took her daughter to her master bedroom, stayed there some time, called Victim 1 and
told him that a stranger was knocking at the front door. Victim 1 told Victim 2 that he was coming
home and would arrive in ten minutes. Tovar stopped knocking on the front door for approximately
three minutes and began knocking on the side door that was located on the home’s north side,
between the kitchen and Victim 3’s room. This door led from the kitchen to the driveway.
Victim 2 called Victim 1 a second time and he tried to talk to Tovar via their front door camera,
but the device was not working. Victim 1 also told Victim 2 that he was driving home and would
be there soon. When he arrived, Victim 1 told Victim 2 that, based on what he saw through the
front door camera, he believed Tovar was one of their neighbors. Victim 1 also told Victim 2 that
he was going to go talk to that neighbor (Tovar) to see what he needed or wanted.
Victim 1 walked to Tovar’s home, which was located in an alley perpendicular to the victim’s
street.  After speaking to Tovar, Victim 1 returned home and told Victim 2 that Tovar had gone to
their home looking for a dog. After talking to Tovar, Victim 1 returned to his residence, and
approximately ten minutes later, Tovar returned to the porch of the victim’s residence, while
Victim 1 was taking his work clothes off to get in the shower.
Victim 1 went outside and talked to Tovar, leaving his front door ajar. Tovar ran inside the victims’
residence, stood approximately 10 feet away from the front door and produced a knife, while
Victim 1 stood at the door. When Tovar entered the home, Victim 2 was in the kitchen and her
daughter was sitting at the kitchen counter, close to the dining room.
Tovar told Victim 1 to close the front door and made incoherent statements, demanding that Victim
1 help him get his family members and his daughter out of prison. Victim 1 told Tovar to go outside
with him and let his wife and daughter go.
At some point, Tovar moved closer to Victim 1  (farther away from the child), so Victim 2 took
advantage of this opportunity to run and pick up Victim 3 from the counter area. She held the child
in her arms and brought her to the kitchen, behind the counter, near the stove, and away from
Tovar. Victim 2 grabbed her cellular telephone to call 911 but Tovar told her not to call the police.
While Tovar was making his incoherent demands, Victim 2 attempted to escape with her daughter
through the aforementioned kitchen side door. Victim 2 held the child with her left arm against her
chest and handled the door knob with her right hand, but she was unable to open it.
When Victim 2 was facing the side door and struggling to open it, Tovar approached her, stood
behind her, and prevented her escape by wrapping his left arm across her chest and putting his
knife, with his right hand, against the right side of her neck. Victim 2 felt the blade against her
I asked Victim 2 if she could re-enact this frightening event and she demonstrated Tovar’s actions
by standing behind Victim 1, wrapping her left arm across his chest and placing her right hand
against the right side of his neck.
When Tovar held Victim 2 and her daughter hostage in the kitchen, Victim 1 had his cellphone in
his hands, and Tovar told him not to call the police. Tovar then turned Victim 2 and her daughter
around 180 degrees, away from the side door and made them face the kitchen refrigerator. Tovar
then turned Victim 2 and her daughter ninety degrees to the left of the refrigerator and pushed
them with force, against their will away from the kitchen, towards the child’s bedroom, which was
located to the east of the kitchen, down a short and narrow hallway.
Tovar kidnapped the Victim2 and Victim 3, closed the child’s bedroom door behind him and also
closed the bedroom’s window curtain. Tovar ordered Victim 2 to sit at the foot of the bed, which
she did, as she held her daughter close to her chest with both arms. Tovar began pacing along a
dresser that was located to the right of the bedroom door, along the bedroom’s west wall.
Tovar then handed Victim 2 his cellular telephone and told her to dial Victim 1’s number. Victim
2 complied and handed the phone back to Tovar, who continued walking around the room. Victim
2 did not know if Tovar was able to talk to Victim 1, but eventually Tovar placed his phone on a
dresser and told Victim 2 that nothing was going to happen to her or her daughter.
Tovar pulled all the dresser drawers out, looking for a gun and he asked Victim 2 if there was a
gun in her house. Victim 2 told him that there were no guns at her home. Sometime thereafter,
Victim 2 and Tovar heard sirens, and Tovar told her in Spanish, “I told your husband not to call
the police, now all of us are going to get fucked.”
Tovar then told Victim Guzmán to put down and let go of her daughter but she refused and
continued holding the child with both arms against her chest, while sitting at the foot of the child’s
bed. Tovar removed his belt from his pants, threw it somewhere and unbuttoned his pants.
Tovar, holding his knife in one of his hands, used his other hand to pull down Victim 2’s leggings.
Tovar grabbed the leggings and pulled them down with force from the waist area two or three
times. While describing this horrible ordeal, Victim 2 used her hands to re-enact her and Tovar’s
actions. Victim 2 moved her left arm away from her daughter, continued holding her against her
chest with her right arm, and swiftly grabbed the top of her leggings near the area where Tovar
was trying to pull them down and she prevented him from taking her clothes off. Victim 2 told
Tovar that she would ask Victim 1 not to let the police inside the room and she asked him to not
Tovar continued pulling Victim 2’s clothing with such force that he ripped her underwear and
pulled Victim 2 and her daughter off the bed. Victim 2 remained on the bedroom floor, holding
While describing the frightening assault, Victim 2 instinctively pulled her leggings down and
showed DAI Hunsaker and I the hole in her underwear, which she was still wearing. At the
conclusion of the interview, Victim 2 handed me her ripped underwear, which I delivered to DAI
Hunsaker for booking at the Monterey County District Attorney’s Office (Item LG01).
Victim 2 believed that Tovar was going to sexually assault her. She feared for her life and
expected Tovar to stab her with the knife at any time because she had already felt the blade against
her neck. Victim 2 told Tovar that she would ask Victim 1 not to let the police come inside the
room and she asked  him to not do anything to her. She also repeatedly yelled at Victim 1 not to
let the police enter the room, as Tovar had told her that he did not want law enforcement
involvement. Victim 2 specifically told Tovar, “I am telling him (Victim 1) not to let them in, so
don’t do anything to me, I’m pregnant.”
The deputies who rescued Victim 2 arrived at the barricaded bedroom door when Victim 2 was on
the floor, holding her daughter, with Tovar standing above them with his knife. Victim 2 heard the
rescuing deputies give commands to Tovar before they entered the bedroom but she did not
understand what they said because she did not speak English.
When the rescuing deputies forced the bedroom door open, Victim 2 was still on the floor holding
her daughter. Tovar stood up between Victim 2 and the deputies and they continued giving
commands to Tovar. Victim 2 did not understand the commands, but she believed the deputies
ordered Tovar to drop his knife. Sometime thereafter, Victim 2 heard a gun shot and she observed
blood and flesh coming out of one of Tovar’s forearms. Victim 2closed her eyes when she saw
Tovar’s blood hit one of the bedroom walls, and she covered her daughter’s eyes with her left
hand, as she heard two additional shots.

Toni Carmona, Monterey County Sheriff’s Office
On 08/08/2023, an Officer-Involved Shooting (OIS) occurred at 404 Hyland Dr. in Salinas.
Decedent Anthony Tovar forced his way into the residence, grabbed a female adult and placed a
knife to her neck while the adult female was holding her 2-year-old daughter. After Tovar
barricaded himself and the two victims inside a bedroom, Monterey County Sheriff’s Office
personnel breached the door and discharged their firearms fatally striking Tovar.
On 08/11/2023 at approximately 0940 hours, DAI Torres and I conducted an interview with MCSO
Acting Sergeant/Detective David Gonzalez who was involved in the OIS. The interview was
conducted at the Monterey County District Attorney’s Office in Salinas. Also in attendance was
Sgt. Gonzalez’s legal counsel, Terry Leoni. It should be noted that I audio-recorded the interview
with Sgt. Gonzalez with my department-issued digital recorder (Item KH 5). The following is a
summary of my interview with Sgt. Gonzalez.
SUMMARY OF INTERVIEW WITH MCSO SERGEANT DAVID GONZALEZ:
I confirmed with Sgt. Gonzalez that he had not been ordered, coerced, or compelled to be present
for the interview and he had spoken with his attorney prior to the interview. I also informed Sgt.
Gonzalez he could end the interview at any point and request any needed breaks. Two breaks were
taken and the audio recording was paused during each break. I obtained the following information
Approximately 8 years with the Soledad Police Department
Almost 8 years with the Monterey County Sheriff’s Office
Former SWAT Operator for approximately two years, two years prior to
Basic Police Academy, multiple law enforcement trainings for gangs and
narcotics, SWAT school. CIT training in 2018
In uniform on 08/08/2023. Black boots, green BDU pants, tan long-
sleeved shirt, Monterey County Sheriff’s Office patches on both arms,
load-bearing vest with “Sheriff” patch on front and back, badge on left
2 pistol magazines on chest, ASP on the right lower torso, radio on the
right torso area. OC spray in admin. pouch center right torso. 2 sets of
handcuffs on lower center of vest.
Duty belt had Taser on the left and a pistol/holster on the right.
Assigned vehicle, lights and sirens checked the night prior to 08/08/2023
Less than lethal shotgun in vehicle
How long has it been issued?
17 rounds. 1 fully loaded magazine inserted into the magazine well with 1
round chambered (18 total rounds). 2 additional fully loaded 17-round
magazines on front of the vest
After obtaining the information as noted above, I asked Sgt. Gonzalez to describe in detail the
incident that occurred on 08/08/2023 at 404 Hyland Dr. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he was near the west
end of Boronda Rd. near Hwy. 183 prior to the OIS. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he was informed by
dispatch that a male subject had entered a residence with a knife. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he made
sure the responding deputies were using their emergency lights and sirens enroute to Hyland Dr.
Sgt. Gonzalez advised dispatch he was near Hyland Dr. and stated he had not activated his
emergency lights and sirens to respond. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he was going to stage in the area
when he was advised the male subject had a knife and was with the reporting party’s (RP) wife
and child. Sgt. Gonzales stated he thought this situation was “a hostage/rescue kind of ordeal.”
Sgt. Gonzalez arrived at El Rancho Way and Hyland Dr. and was approached by the RP (Victim
1). Sgt. Gonzalez advised dispatch of his contact with the RP and that the RP had informed Sgt.
Gonzalez the suspect was in a rear bedroom with a knife along with the RP’s wife and child. Sgt.
Gonzalez observed another deputy behind him and told the deputy, “Let’s go. We’re going to make
entry into the house.” Sgt. Gonzalez entered the residence at 404 Hyland Dr. and was told by the
RP the suspect was in the back room and gave permission for Sgt. Gonzalez to kick down the
interior bedroom door. Sgt. Gonzalez kicked the bedroom door once and observed the door had
been barricaded by a “heavy object.” Sgt. Gonzalez stated when he noticed the barricade, “That
kind of like triggered in me like a different feeling. Like, this is serious and there is a lot of truth
to what this guy’s saying that there’s going to be, we’re going to open the door and we’re going to
be faced with some kind of scenario.”
Sgt. Gonzalez kicked the bedroom door harder a second time near the door handle breaking the
door panel. Sgt. Gonzalez was able to open the bedroom door approximately 1 – 1 ½ feet to look
inside the bedroom. When Sgt. Gonzalez kicked the bedroom door, Deputy Cristian Pantoja was
on Sgt. Gonzalez’s left side while Deputy Josue Ramirez was behind Sgt. Gonzalez and Deputy
Pantoja. Sgt. Gonzalez looked into the bedroom and saw a lady and child, later identified as Victim
2 and Victim 3 respectively, sitting on the floor of the bedroom in “the northeast corner.” Victim
2 was crying and holding Victim 3. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he observed the suspect, later identified
as Decedent Tovar, standing approximately five feet away from the female and child. Tovar was
facing toward Sgt. Gonzalez but was holding and pointing a knife at the female and child. It was
then requested to take a break in the interview.
After the break, Sgt. Gonzalez continued with his statement. Sgt. Gonzalez described the bedroom
as a small room. After kicking the bedroom door, Tovar was looking at Sgt. Gonzalez and Deputy
Pantoja. Sgt. Gonzalez saw the knife in Tovar’s hand which Sgt. Gonzalez described as a “kitchen
knife, 9 inches, he was holding it by the handle, pointing it at the lady and the child.” Sgt. Gonzalez
gave verbal commands to Tovar to drop the knife. Tovar looked at Sgt. Gonzalez before returning
his gaze towards the female and child. Sgt. Gonzalez then fired one round at Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez
said he had previously drawn his pistol upon entering the home and his pistol was kept at “low
Sgt. Gonzalez recognized the object blocking the bedroom door as a clothes dresser approximately
3 – 4 feet tall and the dresser did not allow the door to be fully opened. Sgt. Gonzalez also observed
a closet behind Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez stated, “What was going through my head at that point was
if he gets an opportunity, and he lunges at them with the knife, was that he was going to harm the
child or the lady, and if he came at us, I would get stabbed or my partner would get stabbed. And
so as soon as he turned to look at the lady, that’s when I fired my first shot.” Sgt. Gonzalez said
the shot struck Tovar in the front torso. Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar returned to “an aggressive
stance” and Tovar continued to hold the knife in his right hand. Sgt. Gonzalez ordered Tovar to
drop the knife and heard Deputy Pantoja also order Tovar to drop the knife.
Sgt. Gonzalez described Tovar as 5’ 6” to 5’ 8” with short hair and thin build. After the first shot,
Sgt. Gonzalez said Tovar again looked at Sgt. Gonzalez before returning his gaze toward the
female in the room. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he then fired three additional rounds striking Tovar at
least twice. Sgt. Gonzalez noticed a spent shell casing in the air and deduced Deputy Pantoja fired
his pistol as well. After being struck, Tovar fell to the floor. Sgt. Gonzalez heard someone state
that Tovar still had the knife. Another deputy removed the knife from Tovar and Sgt. Gonzalez
removed the female and child from the room. Sgt. Gonzalez turned over the female and child to
Deputy Perez and Sgt. Gonzalez returned to the bedroom where he observed the knife was on the
floor between Tovar and the female’s location prior to her removal from the room.
Sgt. Gonzalez provided his handcuffs to Deputy Ramirez who handcuffed Tovar. First aid was
then administered to Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez cleared the remainder of the home and cleared medical
personnel to enter the residence to continue to administer first aid to Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez directed
Deputy Perez to separate the female and the RP into separate vehicles. Sgt. Gonzalez assisted in
directing the set up of the crime scene and making the appropriate notifications of the OIS to
dispatch. Sgt. Gonzalez directed photographs be taken of the crime scene and the victims. Sgt.
Gonzalez then returned to MCSO. Sgt. Gonzalez said the RP indicated Tovar was a neighbor and
Sgt. Gonzalez could not state if he knew the suspect by sight from any previous encounters.
When I asked, Sgt. Gonzalez stated he did announce “Sheriff’s Office” after entering the residence.
Sgt. Gonzalez stated he did not attempt to force the door open further after kicking the door the
second time as he and Deputy Pantoja were able to see Tovar through the established opening. Sgt.
Gonzalez confirmed Tovar held the knife in his right hand. Sgt. Gonzalez was not given a
description of Tovar prior to encountering Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he ordered Tovar to drop
Sgt. Gonzalez did not believe he had any additional options available regarding his use of force
given the circumstances of the call. Sgt. Gonzalez stated, “At that point with what we were
addressing, we were presented with a deadly force situation where there was no time to react for a
Taser because a Taser could be ineffective.” Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar appeared to be unaffected
by the first gunshot. Sgt. Gonzalez said, “In my mind, there was no other option.” Sgt. Gonzalez
explained the use of a Taser had several drawbacks including agitating Tovar causing Tovar to
lunge at Sgt. Gonzalez or the female or child.
DAI Torres asked Sgt. Gonzales what was going through his mind when he fired the second volley.
Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar was still “looking for a target because the knife was, like he’s ready to
go, he’s looking to see, he looked at me and then he looked at the lady and that’s kind of where,
and the knife was so close to them where it would take one step, one half second, and he could
have injured like whether it’s fatally or not fatally, and that’s kind of where I thought that he was
going to take action with the knife.” Sgt. Gonzalez clarified “take action” to mean stabbing the
victims. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he constantly addressed Tovar and did not give commands to the
Sgt. Gonzalez also clarified that when Tovar looked at Sgt. Gonzalez, Tovar was “scanning for an
option to attack” and that was the basis for Sgt. Gonzalez’s first shot. Sgt. Gonzalez estimated the
distance between himself and Tovar to be approximately five feet and Tovar was also
approximately five feet away from the female and child who were on the floor. Sgt. Gonzalez
stated Tovar was standing, holding the knife while “scanning and looked like he was thinking
about what he was going to do. So if he had lunged at the lady, in my head, I thought we would
not be able to shoot because she would be part of the backdrop. I didn’t want to give him that
opportunity. Whereas if he had lunged at us, we would still have a clear shot.” Sgt. Gonzalez stated
other than his commands to Tovar to drop the knife, he did not have time to attempt any other
forms of de-escalation. Additionally, Sgt. Gonzalez stated he did not have time to discuss the use
of less than lethal options prior to entering the residence.
Sgt. Gonzalez estimated 1 – 2 minutes elapsed from the time he entered the residence until the
shots were fired. Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar did not say anything during the encounter. Sgt.
Gonzalez stated had there been ample time to retrieve the less than lethal shotgun, it could have
been feasible to use. Sgt. Gonzalez stated the call from dispatch, the information he obtained from
the RP, and the fact the bedroom door was barricaded, confirmed his belief Tovar was the intruder.
Sgt. Gonzalez said the female was seated on the floor and was “sheltering” the child by holding
the child with both arms.  While both were crying, neither victim made any comments during the
I asked Sgt. Gonzalez what he believed Tovar’s intent was when he first observed Tovar standing
in the room with the knife. Sgt. Gonzalez said, “To inflict like serious bodily harm on someone.”
Sgt. Gonzalez believed Tovar was intent on injuring somebody. Another break in the interview
After this break, I asked Sgt. Gonzalez several follow-up questions. I asked Sgt. Gonzalez to
describe the female’s position on the floor while holding the child. Sgt. Gonzalez stated the female
was sitting on the floor with her feet near her buttocks providing shelter for the child. Sgt. Gonzalez
estimated the child to be approximately 2 – 3 years old. Sgt. Gonzalez estimated the female to be
in her mid-20s. The female had her arms wrapped around the child. Sgt. Gonzalez said the female
and child were chest-to-chest facing each other. Sgt. Gonzalez stated the female appeared to be “in
fear for her life” as she was crying. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he believed the female was in fear of her
life because she was crying and she was sheltering the child from Tovar by wrapping her arms
around the child. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he thought Tovar was going to stab either the female or the
child with the knife because of the way Tovar was holding the knife and the way Tovar “target
scanned” by looking at Sgt. Gonzalez and then returning his gaze toward the victims attempting
to ascertain which target would be the easiest to stab. Sgt. Gonzalez estimated the knife was
approximately three feet away from the female and her child.
Based on his training and experience, I asked Sgt. Gonzalez what possibilities existed with a
suspect holding a knife three feet away from a potential victim. Sgt. Gonzalez responded, “A
person could get stabbed. It takes less than a second.” Sgt. Gonzalez did not recall Tovar moving
during the encounter. DAI Torres asked if the distance between Tovar and the female and child
changed during the encounter and Sgt. Gonzalez stated, “No.” Sgt. Gonzalez stated after the first
shot was fired, Tovar maintained the same position and the knife remained approximately three
feet away from the female and child. Sgt. Gonzalez could not remember if Tovar moved toward
the female and child after the first shot was fired.
Sgt. Gonzalez had no additional information to provide but said, “It was just a very dramatic
situation at the time.” When I asked Sgt. Gonzalez if he had previously encountered Tovar, he said
he recognized Tovar’s name after reviewing the CAD (Computer Aided Dispatch) and he knew
Tovar lived in the area. Sgt. Gonzalez said he knew Tovar, but he did not recognize Tovar during
the encounter inside 404 Hyland Dr. Sgt. Gonzalez said Tovar had previously registered with him
as part of Tovar’s 290 PC status.
I had no additional questions for Sgt. Gonzalez and ended the interview at approximately 1045

Technician T. Carmona which was later booked into evidence at the Monterey County District
Attorney’s Office. I also booked Item KH 5 into digital evidence at the Monterey County District

cellular phone. Items TT 1 and TT 2 were later uploaded into digital evidence at the Monterey
Deputy Pantoja confirmed this interview was voluntary, and he was not ordered, coerced, or

Deputy Pantoja was asked a series of questions regarding his assignment, equipment, training, and

Deputy Pantoja said he is employed with the Monterey County Sheriff’s Office and is a Deputy in

He has been employed with the Sheriff’s Office for 4 years and was a jail deputy prior to his

On the day of this interview, Deputy Pantoja was 29 years of age, and his current title is Deputy

is also assigned a patrol rifle.  The rifle is a Colt rifle that fires a .223 round.  The pistol and rifle
have an added department-issued flashlight attached to them.  The pistol has been issued to Deputy
Pantoja for approximately 4 years.  The rifle has been issued to him for approximately 1 year.
Deputy Pantoja does not carry a backup weapon.  Deputy Pantoja performs functions checks before

On the day of the incident, Deputy Pantoja was wearing a class A uniform which consists of a shirt

Deputy Pantoja also had a badge on his left chest and a name plate on the right chest.  Deputy

On the day of the incident Deputy Pantoja was in a marked Sheriff’s Office patrol car.  The vehicle
