Pantoja said the Monterey County Sheriff’s Office does not issue body worn cameras to deputies.
Deputy Pantoja went on to recall the events of the day of the incident.  Deputy Pantoja said he was
dispatched to a call that was a 911 hang up.  He was told by dispatch that a caller had said there
was someone with a knife and then the call was disconnected.  Deputy Pantoja was finishing a
traffic stop at the time he was contacted by dispatch.  After getting in his vehicle, a location was
given on Hyland Drive.  Deputy Pantoja activated his emergency lights and siren and responded
While driving to the location, additional information was being provided to Deputy Pantoja.
Deputy Pantoja said he was told that a suspect was locked in a room armed with a knife, with a
female adult and a child.  Upon arriving, Deputy Pantoja said he saw Sgt. Gonzalez running
towards the residence where the suspect was located.  Deputy Pantoja followed Sgt. Gonzalez into
Deputy Pantoja said due to the severity of the information he was provided, he unholstered his
firearm.  When he entered the residence, Deputy Pantoja saw a male adult in the living room of
the house.  He ordered the adult to exit which he did.  Sgt. Gonzalez went down a hallway inside
of the residence to a closed door.  Sgt. Gonzalez attempted to open the door, but it was locked.
Sgt. Gonzalez told Deputy Pantoja to take a “breach position.”  Deputy Pantoja believed this meant
they would kick the door open.  Sgt. Gonzalez kicked the door approximately two (2) times.
Deputy Pantoja said he began to feel fear because it was unknown what was inside of the room.
Deputy Pantoja said he knew someone had a knife and possible hostages inside of the room.
Deputy Pantoja said the door appeared to be barricaded and it opened only slightly after being
Deputy Pantoja said he looked inside of the room, and he could see a female adult who appeared
to be holding a small child and was in distress.  The female was crying as was the child and they
were on the bedroom floor.  Deputy Pantoja said the female adult appeared to be in fear for her
life.  Deputy Pantoja said he was holding his firearm in a low ready position and was scanning the
room.  Deputy Pantoja said he saw a Hispanic male adult holding what appeared to be a kitchen
knife in his hand.  Deputy Pantoja said he was afraid because he did not know the suspect’s abilities
with the knife.  Deputy Pantoja said he began to give the suspect commands such as “drop the
Deputy Pantoja said he felt afraid for his life as well as the life of the female and child.  The suspect
was in close proximity to the victims as well as the deputies.  Deputy Pantoja said that the suspect,
later identified as Anthony Tovar, was not listening to any of the commands the deputies were
giving him.  Deputy Pantoja yelled at Tovar and said, “look at me.”  Tovar looked at Deputy
Pantoja and waived his hand in a motion that Deputy Pantoja took as “go away.”  Tovar was in a
bladed stance and holding the knife out in front of himself.  Tovar then began to turn away from
Deputy Pantoja and Sgt. Gonzalez towards both victims.  Deputy Pantoja said he heard
approximately three (3) rounds go off from Sgt. Gonzalez’s pistol.  Tovar flinched and had a
physical reaction to the shots.  Deputy Pantoja said he believed the shots had struck Tovar.
Tovar then turned completely around with his back to the deputies.  He faced both the female and
the child with the knife still in his hand.  The blade of the knife was pointed at both victims.  Deputy
Pantoja said it was at this time he believed it was Tovar’s intention to kill both the woman and
child.  Tovar took a step in the victims’ direction with the blade of the knife pointed directly at
them.  Deputy Pantoja estimated Tovar was only a few feet away from the victims at this time.
Deputy Pantoja fired a single shot at Tovar.  Tovar stopped and showed a flinch or physical
reaction to the single shot.  Tovar then collapsed with the knife still in his hand.  Tovar was on the
floor motionless.  Deputies forced their way in the room and removed the knife from his hand.
Deputies rendered basic first aid to Tovar.  Fire and AMR were also requested over the radio.
Tovar was still breathing and had a pulse during this time.  Fire and AMR arrived and took over
first aid efforts.  At this time Deputy Pantoja was relived from the scene.  The interview ended

Attorney Terry Leoni, representing Deputy Ramirez, and Monterey County District Attorney
At approximately 1130 hours, I met with Monterey County Sheriff’s Office (MCSO) Deputy Josue
Ramirez, Attorney Terry Leoni, and Monterey County District Attorney Investigator Justin Bell at
the Monterey County District Attorney’s Office for an interview. The interview was audio
recorded using my department issued digital recorder, and officially began at 1158 hours.

for this interview.  The first interview will be labeled Interview Part 1, and the second, Interview
Deputy Ramirez stated that this interview was voluntary, and he was not ordered, coerced, or
compelled to provide a statement.  He also had the opportunity to consult with his attorney prior
Deputy Ramirez was asked a series of questions regarding his assignment, equipment, training,

Deputy Ramirez is currently assigned to the patrol division of the Monterey County Sheriff’s
Office (MCSO), which was the capacity he was working at the time of the Officer Involved
Shooting (OIS). Deputy Ramirez was also a breacher on the MCSO SWAT team, a drone operator,
and a Field Training Officer (FTO). Deputy Ramirez has been a sworn deputy with MCSO since
2015 (approximately 8 years).  He did not work for any other departments prior to MCSO. Deputy
Ramirez’s badge/CAD number is R8475, and on the day of the OIS his call sign was 1Z3.  Deputy
Deputy Ramirez has training in the police academy, CPR training, less lethal force options training
and arrest and control techniques training. He has not yet attended CIT training for Crisis
On the day of the OIS, Deputy Ramirez was carrying the following firearm:
This firearm is department-issued.  Deputy Ramirez has had this firearm for over 5 years.
The only modifications were a mounted flashlight and grip additions.  He last qualified
with this weapon in March of 2023, which was also the last time he did a function check.
The magazine was loaded to capacity (17 rounds) plus one in the chamber.
Deputy Ramirez did not fire his weapon during this incident.
At the time of his response to the scene, Deputy Ramirez was dressed in his patrol uniform which
consisted of a tan shirt, green BDU uniform pants, a tan outer carrier bearing a badge, name plate,
MCSO patches on both sleeves and a patch on the back of the carrier which read “Sheriff.” Also
on the carrier were a flashlight, pepper spray, taser, baton, handcuffs, magazines, and an admin
pocket with pens and a notepad. Deputy Ramirez wore a duty belt with only his firearm which was
in a drop-down holster attached to his leg.  He also wore tactical boots.
On the day of the OIS, Deputy Ramirez’s assigned vehicle was patrol unit 3089.  Deputy Ramirez
was working in an FTO capacity the evening of the shooting, and he shared this vehicle with his
trainee, Deputy Pantoja, who conducted an inspection on the vehicle prior to the start of the shift.
Deputy Ramirez believed all the equipment in the vehicle was functioning. The vehicle was
equipped with a less lethal shotgun.  Deputy Ramirez said the vehicle usually has a WRAP, which
is a device used to restrain combative individuals. He did not know if the WRAP was in the trunk
that evening since he did not inspect the vehicle. The vehicle was not equipped with any cameras.
Deputy Ramirez was then asked to explain in his own words the circumstances surrounding this
OIS.  The following is a summary of his statement:
Deputy Ramirez and Deputy Pantoja were on patrol and had just cleared a traffic stop in the city
of Salinas at Boronda Road and North Main St.  Dispatch advised of a 911 hangup call where a
reporting party (RP) reported a man was inside of his residence with a knife.  While enroute to the
scene, dispatch updated something regarding a mother and a child
column2: however, due to the chaos he,

column1: could not recall any more details.
Deputy Pantoja was driving, and they headed towards the residence with lights and sirens
activated.  Deputy Ramirez was the passenger and was talking to Deputy Pantoja making sure they
knew where they were going and the fastest route to take.
Deputy Ramirez heard Sergeant David Gonzalez advise he had arrived on scene just a few seconds
before he and Deputy Pantoja arrived.  Deputy Ramirez saw Sergeant Gonzalez speaking with a
male outside in front of the house.  As they were exiting the vehicle, they saw Sergeant Gonzalez
run into the home.  Deputy Pantoja immediately ran after Sergeant Gonzalez.  Deputy Ramirez
immediately followed Deputy Pantoja.  As he entered the home, Deputy Ramirez could see
Sergeant Gonzalez at the right side of a door in a hallway just past the kitchen.  Deputy Pantoja
met and stood to the left of that same door.  Sergeant Gonzalez began to kick in the door as Deputy
Ramirez arrived and stood directly behind Deputy Pantoja.  He said the room was at the northeast
As the door was kicked open, they noticed it was obstructed by an object, and they could not enter.
Deputy Ramirez could not see inside, but he knew Deputy Pantoja and Sergeant Gonzalez were
challenging someone as they shouted, “Drop the knife.”  As this was going on, Deputy Ramirez
was able to see into the opposite side of the room where a mother and a child were on the floor.
He described them as being terrified, trembling, and hugging each other.
Deputy Ramirez said commands continued towards the suspect to drop the knife.  Deputy Ramirez
said he also made commands to drop the knife even though he could not see the suspect.  Deputy
Ramirez then heard a firearm discharge followed by more commands to drop the knife.  Deputy
Ramirez heard a firearm discharge again, and then they entered the room.  As they entered, Deputy
Ramirez could see the suspect on the floor.  He also saw the knife.
Deputy Ramirez went directly to the mother and child, got them up and escorted them out of the
room.  Deputy Ramirez returned to the room, handcuffed the suspect, turned him over and began
to render medical aid (refer to the audio recording for details on Deputy Ramirez’s efforts to treat
the suspect).  AMR and fire personnel arrived a short time later and took over medical treatment
Deputy Ramirez recalled that the officers present during the shooting were Sergeant Gonzalez,
Deputy Pantoja, Deputy Perez and himself.
I followed up with questions for Deputy Ramirez regarding his mindset during this incident. After
hearing initial radio traffic, Deputy Ramirez was in fear for the mother and child.  He said he has
two daughters himself, so this was terrifying.
Deputy Ramirez said he had no prior knowledge of the suspect, and he did not know who the
suspect was.  Deputy Ramirez said he had no interactions with the suspect prior to the shooting,
and the only time he saw him was after deputies entered the room.  Prior to the shooting, Deputy
Ramirez did not hear or see the suspect.
Deputy Ramirez did not recall if any description of the suspect was broadcasted prior to his arrival.
Deputy Ramirez’s mindset upon arrival was that he needed to be with his sergeant and Deputy
Pantoja.  He said he did not know if Sergeant Gonzalez heard or saw something, but since he ran
into the house by himself, Deputy Pantoja and Deputy Ramirez immediately followed him so they
Deputy Ramirez said there was no plan formulated during this incident, and everything happened
so quickly that he could only react to the other officers’ actions. Deputy Ramirez did not hear
communication during the call amongst officers, but he was the last to walk up.  As he walked up,
he put his hand on the shoulder of Deputy Pantoja in preparation for room entry and to alert Deputy
Pantoja that Deputy Ramirez was behind him.  This was for tactical purposes as he was trained
during SWAT.  Deputy Ramirez said that had they been able to enter the room at that point, he
would have remained with Deputy Pantoja and provided him direction while dealing with the
situation.  Due to the circumstances, Deputy Ramirez was not able to do this.
Upon arrival at the scene, Deputy Ramirez recalled Sergeant Gonzalez talking to a male he
believed to be the reporting party.  The male appeared to be in a state of panic. Deputy Ramirez
Deputy Ramirez did not recall anyone on scene verbally identify themselves as law enforcement.
He said the command of “drop the knife” was given several times.  He said it was more than two.
He could not recall any background noise that would obstruct the suspect’s ability to hear
Deputy Ramirez described the layout of the residence as a living room that feeds into the kitchen.
The kitchen leads to a hallway where the door to the room is located.  This was where the four
officers were positioned as they challenged the suspect.  From where he was standing in the
hallway, Deputy Ramirez estimated he was 10 feet from the mother and child in the room.
Deputy Ramirez said he did not discharge his weapon.  Sergeant Gonzalez and Deputy Pantoja
I asked Deputy Ramirez what he thought the suspect was trying to do.  He mentioned there were
many unknowns regarding the suspect and he was worried he would violently hurt the mother and
the little girl. He was thinking the worst based on the fact he believed the suspect was a random
person in the home, and he was worried of a violent sexual assault.
DAI Bell asked Deputy Ramirez if any information he received gave him the sense of the type of
call this was, specifically to know whether this was a stranger or a domestic violence situation.
Deputy Ramirez responded that he could not discern what type of call it was, nor could he know
if there were issues with the RP. In his mind, Deputy Ramirez understood this to be a hostage
situation based on the information he was given.
Deputy Ramirez said that there were no other force options available to deal with the situation.  He
said that everything happened very quickly and the deputies that shot had to instantly react to what
was in front of them.  From the time they entered the home until the time of the shots, Deputy
Ramirez estimated it was less than a minute. In his mind, when he saw the door was intentionally
blocked by the suspect, he believed the suspect was trying to prevent anyone from entering the
DAI Bell asked Deputy Ramirez about the potential danger of a person with a knife, based on his
training and experience.  He said a knife can cause severe damage or life-threatening injuries.  It
could take seconds for a person with a knife to severely injure someone.  In this situation, there
was not enough time to run to a vehicle to get a less lethal option.  When they arrived, the
immediate instinct was to be with Sergeant Gonzalez, so he was not by himself, and Deputy
Ramirez needed to remain with Deputy Pantoja.
Deputy Ramirez said that upon opening the door, it opened about a foot.  With the layout of the
hallway and the amount of space available, they would not have been able to deploy a taser or
other less lethal options.  Deputy Ramirez did not have a good angle or view to deploy one of these
This concluded the interview of Deputy Ramirez.  The interview was concluded at 1241 hours.
Forward to Deputy District Attorney Investigative Captain J. Ferreria.

This report summarizes the interview of witness Deputy Jason Perez.
On 8/11/2023 at approximately 1305 hours, Investigator Maldonado and I interviewed
witness Deputy Jason Perez at the Monterey County District Attorney’s Office in Salinas. The
interview was regarding the deputy involved shooting that occurred on 8/11/2023 in the city of
Salinas. Deputy Perez was represented by his attorney, Terry Leoni from Full Service Labor &
Employment Law Firm. I audio recorded the interview and uploaded the interview to
Deputy Perez confirmed he was present to provide a voluntary statement, and that he had
been able to consult with his attorney prior the interview. Deputy Perez provided the following
information about his assignment, training, equipment and uniform:
Less Lethal training on taser, OC spray, baton, less lethal shotgun
Green BDU pants with exterior tactical vest
Two spare magazines on the vest
Duty belt with firearm and tourniquet
Marked black and white vehicle with Sheriff’s on the doors and
How long has it been issued?
Magazine Capacity and Loadout  17 rounds in the magazines plus one in the chamber
Deputy Perez told me the following in summary:
Deputy Perez is normally assigned to coastal patrol, but they were short staffed in Salinas
and he volunteered to be reassigned. Deputy Perez was with Deputy Ramirez and Deputy Pantoja
at a traffic stop at Boronda Rd. and North Main Street. At approximately 2132, hours he received
a dispatch call from Monterey County Communications that a male was reporting that a subject
was in his house with a knife locked in a room. He said the details were vague at that time.
Deputy Perez responded to 404 Hyland Drive with lights and sirens (code 3) behind Deputy
Ramirez and Deputy Pantoja. He received updates that the reporting party (RP) was asking them
to hurry, and said that the subject was in the house with his wife with a knife.
Deputy Perez heard Sgt. Gonzales attach himself to the call. They received an update that
there was a man with a knife locked in a room with the caller’s wife and child. Sgt. Gonzales
arrived and updated over the radio that he was being flagged down by a male.
Deputy Perez arrived on scene shortly after. Deputy Perez saw Deputy Pantoja and Deputy
Ramirez running towards the front of the house. Deputy Perez started running after them then
paused for a second and thought that he should get the less lethal shotgun out of his trunk. Deputy
Perez saw Sgt. Gonzales “basically leap into the house” and he felt that Sgt. Gonzales had more
information because he had arrived first and had spoken to the RP already. Based on Sgt. Gonzales’
actions and the information he had already received, Deputy Perez felt that the circumstances were
so exigent that there was not time to go back and get the less lethal shotgun. Deputy Perez ran
Deputy Perez said based on the information he had received from dispatch told him that
they needed to get into the house quickly. He felt that the subjects were in danger, and he felt that
there was just no time. Based on the information he had, he felt that the suspect’s intention was to
harm the woman and child or the responding deputies.
When Deputy Perez got to the front door of the residence, he, the RP, and another male
were standing just outside the house and he told them to get farther away. When he was inside, he
could hear kicking “bang bang” and the voice of Sgt. Gonzales yelling “open the door, open the
door” When Deputy Perez got to the hallway, he could see Sgt. Gonzales to the right and Deputy
Pantoja a little bit to the left. Deputy Perez was right behind Deputy Ramirez. He could see that
the door was open 1.5 to 2 feet and appeared to be barricaded by a dresser with a mirror attached
to it. He could see the deputies trying to push it but it would not move. At that time all he could
see through the opening in the door was the dresser blocking the doorway and the back wall of the
room. Deputy Perez could not see the mother and child or the suspect in the room. He then heard
“drop the knife, drop the knife” before hearing a bang, and then another bang. He said there was
about 5 seconds between the first bang and the second bang.
I asked if there was anything going on at the time of the commands to drop the knife that
would have prevented someone from hearing the deputies. He said there was not. I asked if he
heard any announcements that it was the police or sheriff’s department, and he said, “no.”
When Deputy Perez saw that the door was barricaded, Deputy Perez thought that meant
that the victims were in danger. That meant that the suspect was not going to come out, and was
going to harm the child or the mother, because he had barricaded himself in with them.
Deputy Perez turned around and saw the RP behind him and had to tell him to get back
Deputy Perez had to help get the door open because it was still barricaded. He saw the
suspect on the ground wounded and the mother and child huddled over in a fetal position crying
with the mother bear hugging the child. They ended up breaking the door basically in half and
climbed over the dresser to get inside the bedroom. Deputy Perez pulled the mother and child out
of the room and checked them to make sure they were okay. A little later AMR Ambulance arrived.
Deputy Perez put the mother and child into his patrol car, and put the husband into another patrol
Deputy Perez was told to remain with Deputy Pantoja and they did not discuss anything
I asked, based on his training and experience, what threat someone with a knife posed. He
said a knife could easily kill or seriously injure the victims.
I asked if Deputy Perez had the less lethal shotgun upon his arrival into the house, if it
could have changed the way the situation was handled. Deputy Perez said he did not think so.
Firstly, the less lethal shotgun has a standoff distance. Based on the fact that it was such a small
room he would not have been able to deploy it safely. Additionally, if the less lethal shotgun was
not effective, the suspect could have been angered and then taken out his aggression on the victims
while they were barricaded in the room. He said that door was so effectively barricaded that it took
the deputies substantial time and effort to get the door open even after the suspect was down.
Deputy Perez also described that he could not see the suspect from his position in the
hallway, and that he would have needed to get around and in front of the other deputies before he
would have an opportunity to use it, and in doing so he would have removed their ability to deploy
lethal force and have lethal cover.
Deputy Perez said he did not hear any sound from inside the room prior to the shooting,
and could not see the suspect. He did not hear any words from the suspect. He did not have any
prior knowledge of the suspect or the residence they had entered.
Deputy Perez thought that maybe 1 or 2 minutes passed between his arrival on scene and
the shooting. He said the whole scene was so dynamic and fast, everything happened in a split-
Deputy Perez never fired his weapon. Deputy Perez said he did not render medical aid to
the suspect because he was responsible for the victim and her child.
Deputy Perez said he did not think they had any other force options based on how quickly
the events transpired. They did not even get a chance to think about using OC or other options. He
said OC also would not have been a good option because everyone would have been effected by
it in such a confined space, and they would have lost control over the whole situation.
He felt that if they had tried a taser, people are aware of how to defeat the taser. He felt if
they had tried to tase the suspect and it failed, he would have been angered into action to harm the
victim and her child. Deputy Perez said the suspect had the advantage over them the entire time.
Based on what Deputy Perez saw once in the room, he understood the suspect was a lunge away
from the victims and it would have taken less than a second for him to harm them.
At the time of this investigation, I was employed as a Monterey County District Attorney’s Office
(MCDA) Investigator (DAI). On Friday, August 11th, 2023, I was assigned to attend the autopsy
of decedent Anthony Tovar at the Santa Cruz County Sheriff’s Office (SCSO) Coroner Autopsy
Suite. The autopsy was conducted by Chief Forensic Pathologist Dr. Stephany Fiore, it began
around 0900 hours and concluded at around 1500 hours. SCSO Criminalist Karyn Crawford, and
Autopsy Technicians Michelle Novak and Isabella Rotti were assisting. Monterey County District
Attorney Investigative Aide (DAIA) Tanya Nava and DAIA Vanessa Valle were in attendance.
Nava, Valle, and I witnessed the autopsy from a viewing room adjoined to the autopsy suite. We
viewed the autopsy suite directly through a glass partition and electronically via closed circuit
television monitoring. The rooms were equipped with two-way communication via an intercom
I observed the decedent in a white body bag labeled as “Anthony Tovar” and sealed with bag lock
#85571. I witnessed Criminalist Crawford taking photographs to document the postmortem
examination. I witnessed Criminalist Crawford and Technician Novak collect the following items
(include model, serial no., identifying marks, condition, etc.)
DNA sample collected by SCSO Tech Novak
Bag Lock #85571 collected by SCSO Criminalist
Decedent's R Shoe collected by SCSO Criminalist
Decedent's L Shoe collected by SCSO Criminalist
Decedent’s R Sock collected by SCSO Criminalist
Decedent's Left Sock collected by SCSO Criminalist
Decedent's Underpants collected by SCSO Criminalist
Decedent's Shirt collected by SCSO Criminalist
Projectile A from Right Chest Wall collected by SCSO
Projectile D from Right Chest Wall collected by SCSO
Projectile from Right Lung collected by SCSO
R Hand Fingernail Swabs collected by SCSO
L Hand Fingernail Swabs collected by SCSO
Two (2) Blank Water Swabs collected by SCSO
R Hand Fingernail Clippings collected by SCSO
L Hand Fingernail Clippings collected by SCSO
Digital Evidence from SCSO uploaded to Evidence.com
At the conclusion of the autopsy, Dr. Fiore stated that the cause of death was two (2) gunshot
wounds. One (1) projectile struck the left lung, the heart, and the right lung. The other projectile
struck the T-5 vertebrae and the right lung. The death occurred “within minutes” of the injuries.
On 08/18/23 I met with SCSO Evidence Clerk Emily Caterson at the SCSO Evidence Room
located on Chanticleer Ave. in Santa Cruz and received the above listed items of evidence (CQ01-
CQ17). I transported the items to the MCDA evidence room in Salinas where I logged each item
and placed them into intake for processing.
Forward to investigations Captain John Ferreria and Investigator Kris Hunsaker.

I walked through the alley across the street from-yland Dr. with DAI Captain

I returned to the scene and collected the key. I returned to the vehicle and the key
unlocked the vehicle. On the front passenger seat, Cap. Ferreria found several pieces
of mail with the name Anthony Tovar on them.
I contacted the Monterey County Records Department and asked them to conduct a

years old. They advised that they located an Anthony Tovar (7/22/98). I asked them to
send a photo of Tovar. They emailed me a photo of Tovar and I forwarded the photo to
Capt. Ferreria to assist with identification.
I then remained on scene until the scene was released to the homeowner.

column1: The City of Monterey previously produced to your organization all records required to be
released pursuant to Penal Code section 832.7 for incidents occurring since
2014. Specifically, the dates of the incidents for which records were previously
produced were October 6, 2015, December 17, 2017, July 11, 2020, and August 15,
2020. There is one new incident since the City's response last year. The City of
Monterey Police Department (MPD) responded to a mutual aid request from the City of
Seaside. This is documented in MPD Case No. YG2302302. | understand that this case
involved a suspect who sustained injuries to his face caused by a California Highway
With respect to the substance of your request, Government Code section 7923.600
generally does not require “...the disclosure of records of complaints to, or
investigations conducted by, or records of intelligence information or security
procedures of ... any state or local police agency[.J” Under no circumstance does
Government Code section 7923.600 “require the disclosure of that portion of those
investigative files that reflects the analysis or conclusions of the investigating
officer.” (Gov. Code, § 7923.605, subd. (b).) Accordingly, the full the police report,
including its analysis and the conclusions reflected therein, is exempt from disclosure
pursuant to the aforementioned Code sections. Subject to those restrictions,
Government Code sections 7923.610 and 7923.615 contain enumerated exceptions
allowing limited disclosure of specific, non-private information relating to arrests and to
complaints or requests for assistance. The City agrees to provide that information and
the two redacted reports are included as attachments.

Fatal shooting of Jason Hampton on August 6, 2023, by La Mesa Police Officer

column2: San Diego Police Department Case No. 23-033924
Deputy District Attorney assigned: Kristi Gill

column1: Dear Chief Sweeney and Chief Wahl,
We have reviewed the materials compiled by the San Diego Police Department's Homicide Unit
concerning the shooting of Jason Hampton on August 6, 2023. A District Attorney Investigator
responded to the scene and was briefed by detectives. This case was submitted to the District
Attorney's Office for review on November 7, 2023. The Medical Examiner's Report was
On August 6, 2023, La Mesa Police Department (LMPD) Officer Brian Heller drove to an
apartment complex near 8000 University A venue as part of an effort to locate Jason Hampton,
who was known to have a felony no-bail warrant. Heller parked his marked police vehicle in the
parking lot and observed a parked blue Chevrolet pickup truck he identified as being associated
Heller requested another officer to assist him in contacting Hampton. Another officer arrived at
Heller's location and parked next to Heller's vehicle. As Heller updated the officer on
Hampton's warrant, Hampton exited the apartment complex and walked to the passenger side of
the blue Chevrolet pickup. Heller alerted the other officer that he was going to contact Hampton.
Hampton had opened the front passenger side door of the truck and was standing between the
open door and the inside of the truck facing the front of the truck. Heller and the other officer
approached the truck, Hampton walking toward the front of the truck while the other officer
moved toward the rear of the truck.
As Heller approached, he said, ""Hey, Jason."" Hampton looked at Heller and responded by
voicing, ""Huh?"" Heller continued toward Hampton and inquired, ""You Jason?"" Hampton denied
by stating, ""No."" Heller walked a little closer, stood directly in front of Hampton, and said,
Jason."" Hampton raised a handgun with his right hand and pointed it directly at Heller. Heller
heard several clicks that were consistent with the sound of a trigger pull of a firearm.
Heller immediately ducked behind a vehicle parked to his left and drew his Glock 45 9mm
semiautomatic pistol. Heller saw Hampton move backward and away from the door of the truck
while still holding the gun in his hand. Hampton's arm was outstretched and he was pointing the
gun toward Heller. Heller fired five shots toward Hampton as Hampton ran behind several
parked vehicles in the direction of a heavily traveled roadway. Heller chased after Hampton and
saw that while running, Hampton was attempting to manipulate the firearm he was holding.
Hampton, with the firearm in hand, turned back toward Heller. Heller fired four additional
rounds at Hampton. One round struck Hampton in the back of the neck, fatally wounding him.
Hampton fell and the firearm dropped to the ground in front of him.
The investigation into the incident revealed that the gun Hampton had attempted to fire was
operable, but it did not discharge because of a temporary malfunction known as a ""stovepipe""
malfunction. This type of malfunction occurs when a live cartridge is in the chamber, and a
second cartridge or cartridge case becomes wedged between the slide and the firearm's ejection
port in a perpendicular position out of the side of the firearm.
The Medical Examiner conducted an autopsy and determined Hampton's cause of death was a
gunshot wound and the manner of death was homicide. Toxicological testing of Hampton's
blood was negative for alcohol or drugs.
Jason Clark Hampton was a 41-year-old resident of La Mesa, California. At the time of the
incident, Brian Heller had been a police officer for six years and three months.
CWl is Hampton's former girlfriend. They had recently ended their relationship. CWl and
Hampton shared a residence in the apartment complex but were in the process of moving out. To
CWI 's knowledge, Hampton did not have any firearms. CWl reported that on August 6, 2023,
she came home from running errands and Hampton left a short while later. After Hampton left,
CWl heard some noises outside. CWl described the noises she heard as ""pops"" but stated that
type of noise was not unusual for the area.
CW2 lives in the same apartment complex as Hampton. On August 6, 2023, between 4:00 and
4:30 p.m., CW2 was in his living room with his wife and young son. CW2 heard three shots he
recognized as ""gunfire."" He then heard a second volley of approximately four to five gunshots.
After the gunshots, CW2 and his wife looked out of their bedroom window, which faces the
entry driveway to the apartment complex. CW2 saw two police officers standing near the top of
the driveway. He also saw a person on the ground in front of the two officers whom he
recognized as Hampton. He stated Hampton drove a blue Chevrolet pickup truck which was
parked in the parking lot. CW2's vehicle was parked to the left of Hampton's truck and sustained
damage from gunshots that were fired.
CW3 lives in the same apartment complex as Hampton, and his residence was behind the parking
spaces where the shooting incident took place. CW3 reported that on August 6, 2023, at
approximately 4:15 p.m., he was in his living room with his wife and baby. CW3's daughter was
in her bedroom. As CW3 and his wife watched television, CW3 heard a loud ""snap"" and a
hanging wall calendar fell off the wall. CW3 saw smoke in the air and his lights went out. CW3
checked the area where the calendar had been hanging and noticed a hole in the wall. CW3
looked across the room and saw second hole in the wall directly across from the front door. CW3
checked his daughter's room and noticed two more holes in two walls in the bedroom. When
CW3 opened his front door to see what was going on, he noticed a fifth hole in a glass window
panel directly across from his front door.
CW4 was driving her vehicle westbound on University Avenue near the apartment complex. She
stopped her vehicle near the red signal light just west of the location of the shooting, next to an
electrical box. CW 4 heard shots. She noticed her vehicle had been struck when a piece of her
passenger door frame or mirror flew onto the dashboard. She could smell gunpowder after the
impact. She noted that there was some separation of time between gunfire. One of the last
booms"" she heard was when her vehicle was struck. CW 4 believed the shooting incident
occurred behind her. She immediately pulled over and tried to call 911. She then drove her
vehicle into a parking lot where she saw police officers with their guns drawn, and it appeared
officers were handcuffing someone on the ground.
LEI is a patrol officer with LMPD. On the afternoon of the shooting, he received a message
from Heller requesting assistance in contacting a subject with a felony warrant. LEI drove to
Heller's location and parked in the lot next to Heller. Heller stood outside of his police vehicle
and briefed LEI on the subject and his felony warrant.
Heller told LEI that he believed the suspect had just walked out of the apartment complex.
Heller started walking toward a blue Chevrolet pickup truck so LEI got out of his police vehicle
and walked approximately ten feet behind Heller in the same direction. LEI could see a subject,
later identified as Hampton, standing inside the open front passenger side door of the blue
Chevrolet pickup truck. Heller was walking toward the front of the truck, where Hampton was.
LEI stated that at that time he did not know Hampton's name, but heard Heller ask Hampton if
As LE 1 walked toward the back of the pickup truck, he heard two to three clicking sounds
coming from where Hampton was standing. At that point, LEI drew his firearm and heard shots
fired from where Heller was standing. Hampton disappeared from LEI 's view, so LEI continued
around the rear of the blue pickup truck and followed behind Hampton as Hampton ran down a
set of stairs away from LE 1.
LEI asked Heller ifhe was okay, but Heller didn't answer at first. LEI saw that Hampton was
running toward University Avenue and noted there wasn't anyone else in the area behind the
truck where Hampton had been standing. LE 1 continued to follow Hampton. He did not see
Hampton's hands as Hampton was running away. LEI then heard a couple more shots coming
from Heller's location and saw Hampton collapse near the end of the driveway going toward
LEI and Heller approached Hampton, who was lying on the ground. LEI saw a gun on the
ground in front of Hampton and noted it appeared to have experienced a ""stovepipe""
malfunction. Heller did not know ifhe had been shot or not, so LEI checked Heller's body and
confirmed Heller had not been shot. LE I then handcuffed Hampton for safety. An LMPD
sergeant arrived shortly after the shooting occurred and paramedics responded to the scene and
Heller is a patrol officer and has been a member of the SWAT team for three years. On August 4,
2023, Heller was searching for a subject with an active felony no-bail warrant, Jason Hampton.
Heller had independently confirmed the existence of the warrant and he had viewed prior
booking photos of Hampton to familiarize himself with Hampton's appearance. On August 4,
Heller was unable to locate Hampton. On August 6, 2023, Heller learned that Hampton drove a
blue Chevrolet pickup truck and Heller viewed two photos of the truck. Heller learned the truck
was parked at an apartment complex near 8000 University A venue.
At approximately 4:00 p.m., Heller drove to the 8000 block of University Avenue, where he saw
the blue Chevrolet truck backed into a parking space. Heller first surveilled the apartment
complex from a nearby shopping center, then moved to the apartment complex parking lot. He
contacted LE 1 to request cover so that he could safely contact Hampton. When LE 1 arrived at
the location, Heller briefed LEI on the information regarding Hampton and showed LEI a photo
of Hampton. From the corner of his eye, Heller saw a subject who matched Hampton's booking
photo approaching the passenger side of the blue Chevrolet pickup truck. Heller informed LE 1
that the subject he saw was likely Hampton and they decided to approach the subject. Heller
aired on his police radio that he would be contacting Hampton and activated his body worn
As Heller approached the blue pickup truck, he saw that Hampton had opened the front
passenger door of the truck and was standing between the open door and the cab of the truck,
facing Heller's direction. Heller said to Hampton, ""Hey Jason."" Hampton responded with,
Huh?"" Heller got a little closer to Hampton and said, ""You Jason?"" Hampton responded, ""No.""
Heller was now standing directly in front of and facing Hampton, who was standing in the
doorway of the truck. Heller again said, ""Jason."" Immediately, Hampton raised a dark-colored
handgun and pointed the barrel directly toward Heller's center chest and face. Heller heard one
audible ""click"" from the gun Hampton was holding. Heller knew this was consistent with the
trigger being pulled. Heller was terrified seeing the gun pointed at him. He instinctively ducked
down to his left to take cover behind the rear of the vehicle parked next to the truck and drew his
firearm. As Heller ducked down, he heard approximately three to five more audible clicks.
Heller knew, based on his training and experience, the clicking sound indicated a significant
After Heller drew his own firearm, his view of Hampton was obscured by the open door of the
truck. Heller fully stood up and pointed his gun in the direction of where Hampton was last
standing. Heller could see Hampton swiftly walking back behind other vehicles and then moving
toward University Avenue. Heller could see Hampton was holding something in front of himself
toward the center of his waistband. Heller described Hampton's gait as ""awkward"" and that it
seemed Hampton was more focused on what he was doing with the gun in his hands than on
Heller believed Hampton was attempting to manipulate the firearm so that it would be operable,
so he fired at Hampton, using a parked vehicle as partial cover. Heller fired several shots in
Hampton's direction. After Heller stopped firing, he realized Hampton had run down a set of
stairs and his view of Hampton was blocked by a van. Heller completely lost sight of Hampton
as Hampton ran southbound toward University A venue.
Heller was aware there was a nearby pedestrian crosswalk and just across University A venue, a
shopping center. Knowing this to be a very busy roadway with a high volume of foot and vehicle
traffic, Heller was concerned about the danger to the public. Heller took a cover position at the
front passenger side comer of a van parked in the lot, so that he would have readily available
cover if needed. Hampton reemerged from the stairwell into Heller's view. Heller could see
Hampton still had the firearm in his hands in front of his body. Heller was concerned Hampton
would try again to shoot him or would shoot another individual in the area and inflict serious
As Hampton continued to run southbound through the parking lot, he partially turned toward
Heller. Heller could see the dark-colored semiautomatic handgun in Hampton's right hand.
Heller was afraid Hampton had cleared the malfunction on the weapon and was turning toward
him, prepared to fire again. Heller fired four additional rounds toward Hampton, one of which
appeared to have struck Hampton. Hampton fell face forward. Heller estimated that, in total, he
The firearm Hampton was holding fell out in front of him. LEI emerged from the same staircase
that Hampton had gone down. LEI asked if Heller had been shot and Heller asked LEI to check
him to make sure he was okay. Heller then aired ""shots fired"" and requested medics. Heller was
unsure if Hampton had fired his weapon or ifhe had been hit. Once a patrol sergeant arrived at
the scene, Heller and LE I approached Hampton and secured him so that medics could respond
Heller took photographs of the scene, including of Hampton's firearm on the ground as it was
when Hampton dropped it. Heller put on a pair of gloves, retrieved the firearm, rendered it safe,
and stored it in the patrol sergeant's vehicle for investigators. Heller noticed the magazine was
partially ejected out of the firearm and that there was one unexpended round in the chamber. The
chamber was stuck in the open position on a second unexpended round that was horizontal to the
chamber with the bullet portion of the round facing to the right. Heller described the condition of
the gun as having experienced a combination of a double feed and a ""stovepipe"" malfunction.
Heller believed Hampton had attempted to kill him. Hampton had pointed his firearm directly at
Heller and pulled the trigger multiple times. Heller felt he had no option other than to use lethal
force because that was the level of force he was confronted with when Hampton pointed the
firearm at him and pulled the trigger. In addition, Heller was concerned about the serious public
Heller and LEI were equipped with body worn cameras and both cameras were activated during
the incident. Heller's camera best captured the interaction preceding the shooting incident as LE I
was behind Heller during their initial approach toward Hampton. LEI 's footage captured his
pursuit of Hampton between parked cars and the buildings in the apartment complex while
Heller's footage captured his pursuit of Hampton through the parking lot in front of parked cars.
Heller's camera footage shows Heller walk from his police vehicle to approach Hampton.
Hampton is seen standing on the passenger side of the pickup truck between the open passenger
door and the cab of the truck. Heller is heard saying, ""Hey Jason."" Hampton is captured looking
directly at Heller and responding, ""Huh?"" Heller continues to approach Hampton and asks, ""You
Jason?"" to which Hampton responds, ""No."" Heller is positioned in front of the hood of the
pickup truck and appears to be approximately ten feet in front of Hampton. Heller says, ""Jason,""
and Hampton immediately raises a black handgun and points it toward Heller. Heller drops down
to his left, moves behind a gold-colored vehicle parked next to the blue pickup truck, and draws
his firearm. Heller fires five rounds toward Hampton as Hampton runs southbound out of view.
Moments later, Hampton can be seen emerging from behind a concrete retaining wall into
Heller's view. Hampton is running in the direction of University Avenue but turns toward Heller.
Heller fires four rounds at Hampton, and Hampton falls to the ground. LE I emerges from behind
the same concrete retaining wall and asks Heller if he is alright. LE I checks Heller to determine
ifhe has been stuck by gunfire, and Heller performs a tactical reload of his firearm. Heller
camera continues to record as Heller photographs and secures Hampton's firearm while LEI
handcuffs Hampton. The two officers then wait for medics to respond.
LEI 's body worn camera shows him walking behind Heller as they approach a blue Chevrolet
pickup truck. After Heller's initial interaction with Hampton, Heller is seen ducking down to the
ground in front of the blue truck. Several ""clicks"" can be heard. LE I draws his firearm and
points it in the direction of the rear of the blue truck. At the same time, several shots are heard.
Next, Hampton is captured running down a set of concrete stairs, holding a gun in his right hand.
LEI broadcasts ""shots fired"" over the police radio and then asks Heller if he is alright. Four more
shots are heard as LEI follows Hampton's path down the concrete stairs. When LEI emerges
from the stairwell, Hampton is visible lying on the ground at the end of the driveway. LEI
checks Heller for any injuries and then handcuffs Hampton.
The incident took place in the city of La Mesa in a parking lot outside of an apartment complex
in the 8000 block of University Avenue. The scene was secured, photographed, and investigated
by the San Diego Police Department (SDPD) Homicide Unit. A complete review was conducted
of all officers' and detectives' reports, crime scene investigators' reports, audio recorded
interviews of civilian and law enforcement witnesses, all body worn camera footage, along with
the Medical Examiner's autopsy report and toxicology report. The events leading up to the
incident, and the incident itself, were captured on the officers' body worn cameras. All these
items were found to provide evidence which corroborates the officers' statements.
At the time of the incident, Heller was armed with a Glock 45, 9mm semiautomatic pistol. Heller
reported that prior to the incident, his pistol was loaded with a total of eighteen 9mm caliber
cartridges - seventeen rounds in the magazine and one round in the chamber. Heller also carried
on his duty belt three additional fully loaded magazines, each containing seventeen rounds.
During the incident, Heller performed a tactical reload of his firearm, removing his partially
loaded magazine and reloading with one of his fully loaded magazines. Following the shooting
incident, an SDPD Crime Scene Specialist collected Heller's firearm for processing. Heller's
firearm was received with one live cartridge in the chamber, and a fully loaded seventeen-round
magazine seated in the firearm. A partially loaded Glock 9mm magazine was recovered from the
scene. This magazine was loaded with eight unexpended cartridges. Heller retained two fully
loaded seventeen-round magazines attached to his duty belt. Based on the number of rounds that
were loaded into the pistol prior to the shooting incident, and the remaining rounds that that were
loaded in the partially loaded Glock magazine recovered at the scene, it was determined Heller
fired nine cartridges from his firearm. Consistent with this determination, nine 9mm casings that
matched the ammunition in Heller's firearm were found at Heller's two shooting positions. BWC
footage also confirmed Heller fired a total of nine rounds.
Hampton was in possession of a loaded Springfield Armory Model XDE-9 9mm semiautomatic
pistol. Following the shooting incident, the Crime Scene Specialist collected the pistol for
processing and documented that the weapon held a partially seated magazine containing six live
9mm cartridges. Photos taken at the scene confirmed there had been one live 9mm cartridge in
the chamber, and one live 9mm cartridge wedged in between the slide and the firearm's ejection
port in a perpendicular position out of the side of the firearm. This condition is known as a
stovepipe"" malfunction, which will render a firearm temporarily inoperable. All of the
cartridges had the headstamp ""Tulammo 9mm LUGER."" Hampton's pistol was determined to be
operable once the malfunction was cleared. A record check of the pistol revealed that previously
An SDPD Crime Scene Specialist identified bullet holes within CW3's residence, and in two
separate vehicles that belonged to CW2 and CW4. This is consistent with their account of what
they observed. Bullet fragments were recovered from the residence and CW2's vehicle. No
civilians in the vicinity were physically injured during the incident.
An autopsy was conducted on August 8, 2023. The Deputy Medical Examiner determined that
Hampton had suffered a gunshot wound to the back of the neck. The bullet struck the carotid
artery and fractured the cervical vertebrae as it passed through Hampton's body before it exited
his right cheek. During the internal examination, gray metal projectile fragments was recovered
and collected as evidence by a Forensic Evidence Technician, who was present during the
autopsy. The cause of death was classified as a gunshot wound and the manner of death was
Toxicological testing was conducted on a sample of Hampton's blood. The results were negative
for the presence of alcohol or drugs.
Penal Code section 835a(c) sets forth the circumstances in which a peace office may use deadly
force and the standard to evaluate the use of such force. The law provides that ""a peace officer is
justified in using deadly force upon another person only when the officer reasonably believes,
based on the totality of circumstances, that such force is necessary to defend against an imminent
threat of death or serious bodily injury to the officer or to another person."" Penal Code section
The statute defines deadly force as ""any use of force that creates a substantial risk of causing
death or serious bodily injury, including, but not limited to, the discharge of a firearm."" Penal
An imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury is one where ""based on the totality of the
circumstances, a reasonable officer in the same situation would believe that a person has the
present ability, opportunity, and apparent intent to immediately cause death or serious bodily
injury to the peace officer or another person. An imminent harm is not merely a fear of future
harm, no matter how great the fear and no matter how great the likelihood of the harm, but is one
that, from appearances, must be instantly confronted and addressed."" Penal Code section
The statute defines totality of the circumstances as ""all facts known to the peace officer at the
time, including the conduct of the officer and the subject leading up to the use of deadly force.""
The statue further states, ""In determining whether deadly force is necessary, officers shall
evaluate each situation in light of the particular circumstances of each case, and shall use other
available resources and techniques, if reasonably safe and feasible to an objectively reasonable
[T]he decision by a peace officer to use force shall be evaluated from the perspective of a
reasonable officer in the same situation, based on the totality of the circumstances known to or
perceived by the officer at the time, rather than with the benefit of hindsight. The totality of
circumstances shall account for occasions when officers may be forced to make quick judgments
about using force."" Penal Code section 835a(4).
Officer Heller knew Jason Hampton had an outstanding no-bail felony warrant when he located
and attempted to contact Hampton in the parking lot of an apartment complex. Heller called out
to Hampton, who was standing behind the open front passenger side door. Hampton denied being
the subject Heller was looking for. When Heller got to the front of the truck, approximately ten
feet from Hampton, Hampton suddenly pulled out a handgun, pointed it directly at Heller's upper
body, and quickly pulled the trigger several times. The loaded gun did not fire due to what was
later determined to be a ""stovepipe"" malfunction of the gun. But for the malfunction, the loaded
firearm was otherwise operable. Heller instinctively ducked down, drew his firearm, and
returned fire in Hampton's direction. Hampton fled. While running, Hampton continued to
manipulate the firearm he held in his right hand. He was headed toward University A venue, an
area with a high volume of pedestrian and vehicle traffic, when he turned toward Heller. Heller
fired four additional rounds, one of which struck Hampton, causing Hampton to fall and drop the
Hampton's actions made it clear he intended to evade Officer Heller and that he was willing to
shoot Heller in order to achieve that end. When Officer Heller discharged his firearm, he
reasonably believed that the use of deadly force was necessary to defend against the imminent
threat of death or serious bodily injury that Hampton posed. A reasonable officer in the same
situation would believe that Hampton had the present ability, opportunity, and apparent intent to
immediately cause death or serious bodily injury to the peace officer or another person.
Therefore, Heller bears no state criminal liability for his actions. A copy of this letter, along with
the materials submitted for our review will be retained in our files.
Captain Matthew Nicholass, La Mesa Police Department
Captain Richard Freedman, San Diego Police Department
CITY AND COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO
City and County of San Francisco
Decision whether to return Officer Peter Van Zandt #4142 and Officer Marko
Radin #1945 to duty following their involvement in Officer Involved Shooting #23-
Officers Peter Van Zandt #4142 and Marko Radin #1945, currently assigned to Bayview
Station were the involved members in the Officer-Involved Shooting (OIS 23-003)
which occurred on Wednesday July 26th, 2023. The OIS occurred at the intersection of
Fairfax Avenue and Catalina Street in San Francisco. The involved officers were on-
duty and in uniform at the time of the shooting.
On Wednesday August 2"" at 1000 hours, pursuant to Department General Order
8.11.I1.G.4, the Return to Duty panel convened to discuss whether it was appropriate for
the involved members to return to duty. The officers had not yet completed their Force
Options and Range Debriefs, and the Panel recommended they not be returned to duty at
that time. The panel decided to reconvene once all the debriefs were completed.
The reconvened panel met on August 17'"", 2023, at 1100 hours and was comprised of the
e Deputy Chief Robert O’Sullivan-Investigations Bureau (Chair)
e Deputy Chief Julian Ng-Field Operations Bureau
e Commander Eric Vintero-Field Operations Bureau-Golden Gate Division
e Acting Captain Angela Wilhelm-Internal Affairs Division/Risk Management
Also present were Sergeant Marilu Aguilar of the Internal Affairs Division and Sergeant
Joseph Minner of the Administration Bureau.
The panel called upon the following disciplines to summarily report on any updates and
discuss the factors that are taken into consideration when determining whether to return
Investigative Services Detail (ISD): In Lieutenant Do’s absence Lieutenant Wilhelm
provided an update regarding the ISD investigation. The investigation is ongoing and both
officers voluntarily submitted to interviews regarding the criminal investigation.
Internal Affairs Division (IAD): Lieutenant Wilhelm advised both officers satisfactorily
completed their FTFO Training Refresher Course, and the Firearm Range debriefs on
Tuesday August 8"""", 2023. The administrative investigation is ongoing.
Behavioral Science Unit (BSU): Sergeant Minner reported the BSU update provided to
him by Officer Aaron Cowhig of BSU. Both officers have completed their BSU
debriefs. Officer Cowhig has been in regular contact with both officers, F< en
about returning the officers to duty.
After discussion and consideration of the presentations to the panel, the Return to Duty
panel voted unanimously to recommend that the officers be returned to duty at this time.
My decision whether to return these officers to duty, including the aforementioned
mandatory debriefings and factors supporting the decision, is scheduled for presentation
to the Police Commission in closed session on Wednesday, September 6th, 2023. I look
forward to discussing my decision with you at this Police Commission meeting.

RE:  Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, Reference # IA 2023-003
You are hereby notified that the following disciplinary action is being recommended to the Sheriff regarding
your position as a Correctional Officer with the Nevada County Sheriff’s Office:
In June of 2021 you were hired by the Nevada County Sheriff’s Office as a Correctional Officer I and were
assigned to the Wayne Brown Correctional Facility. You progressed through the jail training program and
were granted solo officer status in December of 2021. You completed your CO I probationary period and
were promoted to a Correctional Officer II in June of 2022. You were assigned light duty in October of
2023, and then placed on administrative assignment in December of 2023. While on administrative
assignment, you resigned from the Sheriff’s Office on April 22, 2024.
As a Correctional Officer you are responsible for a multitude of duties, which also include some of the
• Reading and understanding department policies, rules, instructions, laws and ordinances.
• Adopting quick, effective, and reasonable courses of actions while considering surrounding hazards
• Understanding and following written and oral instructions.
• Exercising good judgement and making sound decisions under a variety of conditions.
• Adhere to local, state and federal laws and guidelines.
• Provide for the safety and security of inmates and other jail staff members.
• Adhere to your oath of office as a Correctional Officer.
• Conduct yourself in a manner consistent with this agency’s mission statement.
Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, re. IA 2023-003
An administrative investigation was conducted by Lieutenant Greene regarding an incident you were
involved in on July 4th, 2023. In that investigation you were the suspect of a criminal domestic battery
incident that occurred in the City of Grass Valley. During that same investigative period, you were involved
in another domestic battery incident that occurred at your residence on July 22, 2023.  Your conduct during
that incident was also investigated by Lt Greene.
In both incidents, it was determined that you knowingly provided false information to law enforcement
investigators while at the scene. Lieutenant Greene’s investigation also revealed that you knowingly failed
to disclose a personal relationship you were having with a convicted felon.  The investigation also revealed
Lieutenant Greene’s investigation was reviewed by Lieutenant Vingom who SUSTAINED the following
Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, re. IA 2023-003
Nevada County MOU General Employees Unit 39, Subsection (B)(6) - Causes for Discipline
Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, re. IA 2023-003
Nevada County Sheriff’s Office Policy Manual Lexipol Policy 319.4 – General Standards
Members shall conduct themselves, whether on- or off-duty, in accordance with the United States
and California constitutions and all applicable laws, ordinances, and rules enacted or established
pursuant to legal authority. Members shall familiarize themselves with policies and procedures
and are responsible for compliance with each. Members should seek clarification and guidance
from supervisors in the event of any perceived ambiguity or uncertainty.  Discipline may be
initiated for any good cause. It is not mandatory that a specific policy or rule violation be cited to
sustain discipline. This policy is not intended to cover every possible type of misconduct.
Any on-or-off duty conduct which any member knows or reasonably should know is unbecoming
a member of this office, is contrary to good order, efficiency, or morale, or tends to reflect
unfavorably upon this office or its members.
After reviewing Lt Greene’s investigation, I concur with Lt Vingom’s sustained finding as outlined above.
Additionally, after reviewing the investigation, I also find that you are in violation of:
Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, re. IA 2023-003
On July 4th, 2023, you were involved in a mutual domestic battery.  This incident was investigated by the
Grass Valley Police Dept. At that time it was determined that you were
told officers that the two of you were engaged and were living
together. During that investigation you lied to GVPD Officer Fish about how you sustained your visible
injuries.  You also lied to officers about your participation in the incident when you told them it was only a
verbal argument. You told GVPD Officers your visible injuries were from tripping and falling. It was also
noted that you initially identified yourself as an employee of the Sheriff’s Office, and you admitted you
were under the influence of alcohol. It was also noted that you were heard talking on your phone during the
detention, and were recorded telling someone about the incident, and you commented that you were “so
fired”. Your statements were recorded on multiple Grass Valley Police Officers body worn cameras
During the Grass Valley Police investigation of the July 4th incident, they learned that a citizen had recorded
your altercation on a cell phone, and they obtained a copy of the video recording.  In the recording you can
been seen walking after your boyfriend on a public sidewalk. As he is walking away from you, he stops and
then two of you start arguing again. While he is standing in front of you, you abruptly hit him across his
face. He then subsequently grabs you and throws you onto the ground.  In watching the video, it was clear
the statements you made to the officers regarding how you sustained the injuries to your hands and knees
was a lie.  It was also very clear that when you told Officer Fish it was only a verbal argument, that too was
a lie.  In watching the video recording, it was clear that at that moment you were the dominant aggressor.
Your recorded comment that evening about being “fired” and your knowledge about what you had done
during the argument provides sufficient motivation for you to lie.
On July 4th you had the option of telling the truth, remaining silent, or simply telling the responding officers
you did not want to provide a statement. Instead, you chose to knowingly provide false information. As a
person who had been a Correctional Officer for over two years, and also having earned a degree in
Administration of Justice, you should have known that providing false information is absolutely
On July 22nd, 2023, (18 days later) a disturbance at your residence was reported to the Sheriff’s Office.  You
were contacted at your residence and were found inside with an injury to your head and other parts of your
body.  On the evening of this event, and when questioned later by investigators, you told them that you did
not know how you sustained your injuries.  You also claimed you didn’t not know who caused your injuries.
It was later learned that while you were seeking treatment for your injuries, you had sent messages to a
as the person that was responsible for your injuries.
Again, instead of telling the truth, remaining silent, or telling law enforcement officers you did not wish to
make a statement, you defaulted to providing a false statement. It is also noted that you were under the
influence of alcohol during this incident.
Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, re. IA 2023-003
false information on multiple occasions, is a violation of state law, Sheriff’s Office Policy, Nevada
County Policies, and the Local 39 MOU.
Sheriff’s Office employees have always, and will always, be held to a greater standard. This is further
evidenced by the strict Sheriff’s Office hiring standards and a pre-employment background process, which
is not required by other positions located outside the Sheriff’s Office.  If you had these types of sustained
violations in your background, prior to your employment with the Sheriff’s Office, you would not have
been selected to be a Correctional Officer. Additionally, had you been convicted in a criminal court of
domestic violence, you would not be allowed to be in possession of firearms, which is an essential part of
your jobs function. I recognize that Sheriff’s Office employees do not have to be perfect, but they must
A Correctional Officer’s job is a position of respect and trust. All Sheriff’s Office employees are held to
the highest standards of behavior.  Honesty and credibility are crucial to proper performance of your
duties. Dishonesty in matters of public trust is intolerable. Your documented and lengthy pattern of
deliberate deception, toward coworkers, supervisors, investigators, and outside law enforcement is
irrefutable. Dishonesty is not an isolated act
column2: it is more a continuing trait of character. False statements,

column1: misrepresentations and omissions regarding official matters are likely to result in harm to public service,
the public’s trust in law enforcement and irreparable harm to the reputation of the Sheriff’s Office and its
Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, re. IA 2023-003
As a result of the investigation and above sustained charges, I am recommending the following discipline
to the Sheriff, which I find to be worthy based on all the facts and findings.
The materials upon which this proposed disciplinary action is based include the following documents:
The entire contents of your personnel file
Nevada County Sheriff’s Office Corrections Policy
Nevada County Sheriff’s Office Policy Manual
